We tried to put an end to guilt by association when Joe McCarthy was denounced,'' McCain said in a statement. ``McCarthyism has no place in the deliberations of the ethics committee or how members of the Senate are judged.'' Glenn said he had not read the brief but added: ``Common Cause, like every citizen, has the right to put forward its views. I have no way of knowing what, if any, influence this opinion will have with the ethics committee.'' The Washington Times, meanwhile, citing ``sources close to the Senate Ethics Committee,'' reported in today's editions that the committee's special counsel will recommend dropping further inquires of Glenn and McCain. Spokesmen for Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle said they would have no immediate comment on Common Cause's brief. The ethics code says a public servant should never discriminate by performing special favors, said Cox, a former U.S. solicitor general and special prosecutor during the Watergate investigation. All the senators except Riegle met with Edwin Gray, then-chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, on April 2, 1987. They discussed the board's investigation of Lincoln S&L, although details of the conversation are in dispute. Riegle joined the four senators a week later at a meeting with four bank board officials who were investigating Lincoln. He had received $78,250 from Keating and associates but later returned the money. The board eventually seized control of the insolvent thrift last year. Bailing out Lincoln is expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion, making it the most expensive bailout in the savings and loan crisis. Citing news reports, Common Cause said the senators pressed regulators to treat Lincoln fairly and expedite the investigation. But even if the senators did not request favorable treatment for Lincoln, the regulators ``could not fail to be impressed with the amount of senatorial influence supporting Lincoln Savings and Loan,'' Cox said. Intervention by senators raises ``highly delicate ethical questions,'' Cox said. The Keating case, he said, ``involves such extraordinary use of the office of senator as to violate the portion of the Code of Ethics which mandates that a public servant should never discriminate unfairly by the dispensing of special favors or privileges to anyone, whether for remuneration or not.''

DOC.HEAD: Cultures Clash at Prairie Dog Shoot
DOC.TEXT: A festival atmosphere is building for the first Top Dog World Championship Prairie Dog Shoot this weekend. The sheriff is just hoping the combination of cowboys and animal-rights activists doesn't get someone killed. In this isolated southwestern Colorado town, ravaged by drought and the closing of most of the uranium mines that were the economy's backbone, residents hope to have some fun and make a little money off the competition. Stores are selling T-shirts, hats, pins, bandannas and whatever else they can get a prairie dog logo on. All 52 rooms in the area's only two motels, in tiny Naturita five miles away, have been booked for the first time in two years. The event has drawn 106 shooters from as far away as Texas and California. Some 50 protesters, many of whom plan to make a nine-hour drive from Denver, are also expected to show up for the two-day hunt starting Saturday. ``Those people over there carry guns, but if they don't like our attitude, tough. We have a First Amendment right to protest,'' said Robin Duxbury of the Rocky Mountain Humane Society. ``There's no good reason to shoot prairie dogs.'' It's shaping up as a clash of cultures _ urban, liberal animal-rights advocates coming into a rural, conservative valley where many residents moved to avoid city hassles. The combined population of Nucla and Naturita is about 1,500. Gov. Roy Romer has refused protesters' demand that he protect them with the National Guard, and local authorities are concerned about the possibility for violence. Sheriff Tom Gilmore said he will have at least 25 officers on hand, some from the state and the U.S. Bureau of Land Management. ``If we can just keep the protesters away from the locals and the locals away from the protesters, we'll be OK,'' he said. Animal-rights activists are demanding that Romer issue an executive order to stop the hunt. At a rally last week, cartoonist Berke Breathed and author Cleveland Amory called the prairie dog a ``lovable, innocent, defenseless animal.'' Many rural Westerners, however, regard prairie dogs as disease-ridden rats, dangerous to livestock and children. Teen-agers routinely spend summer mornings shooting the critters. ``The problem is, they're called prairie dogs, not rats or mice,'' said rancher Bob Dyer. ``I got hassled in the Denver airport last week, but they quieted right down when I told them I'd ship as many prairie dogs to 'em as they wanted. For $50 a pair, I'll even put them through sheep dip and get the fleas off.'' Mike Mahew, the shoot's organizer, said the hunters competing for more than $7,000 in prizes will have to follow strict rules. They'll shoot from 7 a.m. to 1 p.m., with rangemasters along to supervise scoring. No spectators or booze will be allowed. ``We'll wait and see,'' Mahew said. ``That's all anybody can do.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,575.32, up 281.14 points, or 0.87 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: US to Seek Support for Chamorro
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration plans an ambitious diplomatic campaign to rally support for Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro in her effort to overcome widespread strikes by pro-Sandinista workers, U.S. officials say. The campaign will be focused on Western Europe and Latin America and will include personal letters from President Bush to some foreign leaders, said the officials, who asked not to be identified. Several officials scoffed at the notion that the United States may be planning to intervene militarily on Mrs. Chamorro's behalf. The State Department said Wednesday that Mrs. Chamorro has not asked for U.S. assistance nor, has the United States offered any. Strike leaders say 90,000 workers have walked off their jobs since the unrest began almost two weeks ago, but Nicaraguan officials say that figure is highly exaggerated. Mrs. Chamorro and the State Department have both said the strikes are a politically motivated effort by the leftist Sandinistas to undercut the government's economic program. Five weeks ago, delegates from more than 20 countries assembled in Rome to pledge financial backing for the Nicaraguan government, based on Mrs. Chamorro's economic recovery program. The plan includes some painful adjustment measures, including an end to government subsidies on some food items as part of bid to bring down the country's high inflation rate. The message being sent by Bush and U.S. diplomats is that Mrs. Chamorro deserves support at a time when she is under fire for implementing a program which has won broad international backing, the officials said. The pledges at the Rome conference came to about $300 million, the officials added, roughly the same as the U.S. bilateral aid program. ``She (Mrs. Chamorro) needs the kind of international support that will encourage the Sandinistas to cease and desist,'' one official said. Underscoring the apparent U.S. determination to limit American involvement in the conflict, the State Department expressed full confidence in Mrs. Chamorro's ability to manage the situation. At least four people have been killed and 84 injured in the disturbances, but strike leaders issued a statement Wednesday indicating interest in a negotiated settlement. The State Department, meanwhile, expressed support for Mrs. Chamorro's call for a swift and peaceful resolution of the conflict. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said mismanagement by the Sandinista government that Mrs. Chamorro succeeded this year left the Nicaraguan economy in ``disastrous straits.'' Now, he said, for political gain, ``they are seeking to blame the government for taking reform measures necessary to clean up the mess.'' The department said Wednesday night it is urging U.S. citizens not to travel to Nicaragua at present because of the unrest. Americans in Nicaragua were urged to stay inside their hotels and homes.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Says Other Summit Spouses Raved Over Houston
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush says President Bush ``spoke for all the family'' when he made a spirited defense of son Neil Bush's integrity in a savings and loan bankruptcy case. The first lady, gently resisting further questioning about the case, told reporters, ``You don't want to see a grown woman cry, do you?'' She spoke on Air Force One on the way home Wednesday night from the economic summit in Houston. Mrs. Bush attended the post-summit news conference where the president confided the probe has been hard on the family. The president said he has had said he had to calm down other sons who want to ``go to the barricades'' against what they regard as unfair criticism of their brother's role as an outside director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver, which went under at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. ``The president spoke for all the family today,'' the first lady said. ``I loved what he said.'' Mrs. Bush, confessing to ``a little bit of chauvinism'' for her hometown, says she heard nothing but raves from the other leaders' wives for the job Houston did. Asked whether she was exhausted, the first lady made a tired face and said, ``I ain't going to lie to you.'' She joked that ``what's-his-name feels fabulous.'' Actually, the president plans to ``get a good rest at Camp David'' this weekend, she said. Mrs. Bush, sporting a silver star and Lone Star earrings given to all the leaders' wives received as mementos, said even the heat was not ``as bad as I expected.'' She said ``the real truth'' is that ``it was hotter every single day in Washington, D.C. than it was in Houston, Texas.'' She expressed amazement that 5,000 volunteers turned out beforehand to clean up Houston's streets. ``They didn't just clean the streets we saw. They cleaned ... all the neighborhoods. They were wonderful,'' she said. ``The wives raved _ truthfully _ over everything. They raved over the attitude of the people,'' she said. ``I heard one wife say to another one, 'If you went home to your country, do you think you could find 5,000 volunteers to put on a program like this?' And she said, `No way. We don't even understand the concept of volunteers,''' related Mrs. Bush, who refused to identify her. She said ``I love'' Denis Thatcher, husband of Britain's prime minister and denied he felt out of place as the only male spouse at the summit. ``Oh, no. We had men at the party for him,'' she said, referring to Monday's dinner for spouses. ``But I told him he could no longer kiss my hand because I am not going to be teased back into kissing his,'' said Mrs. Bush, who did just that in London last year.

DOC.HEAD: President Holds Back on Endorsing Houston for 1992 Convention
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is brimming with pride over his hometown's job in hosting the Houston summit, but he's not ready to endorse it as his choice for the 1992 Republican National Convention. ``I'm not sure how much say I want to have on that,'' Bush told reporters on Air Force One Wednesday night on his way back from Texas. ``It's like judging a beauty contest. One contestant is happy and the others are mad. ``But they did a great job on this,'' he added.

Wilson Scaling, chief of the Soil Conservation Service for five years, has resigned his Agriculture Department job. Assistant Secretary James R. Mosely, who oversees USDA natural resources and environment programs, said Wednesday he has named Roy M. ``Mack'' Gray as acting chief of the agency. Gray, a career employee, has been an assistant to Scaling. Spokeswoman Jane Ade Stevens said Scaling, a political appointee, had been head of the agency for five years and that Mosely felt it was time for a change. However, she said, Scaling resigned as was not fired. Scaling was named chief of conservation agency in 1985 by then Agriculture Secretary John R. Block. He is from Henrietta, Texas, and was general manager of his family's farming operations before taking the USDA job.
DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group Urges Heart-Valve Maker Warn Patients of Defects
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group wants federal authorities to force a heart-valve manufacturer to warn 56,000 people of defects in the value. Public Citizen petitioned the government Wednesday to make the Irvine, Calif.-based Shiley Inc., a subsidiary of Pfizer Inc., to notify all those who have had the device implanted about the symptoms and consequences of a failed valve. The group also wants the company to advise patients of the risks and benefits of having the valve removed. The company has reported to the FDA more than 250 deaths that have resulted from fractures of the valve. Public Citizen asked the FDA to order the company to send a notice to each person who has had a Shiley valve implanted describing the signs and symptoms of imminent valve failure. The notice also would list each hospital in the United States where open heart surgery is performed so patients would know where to go for emergency valve replacement surgery. Public Citizen filed suit against the company in March to force the company to notify patients directly, but the suit was dismissed in Los Angeles County Superior Court. Public Citizen has filed an appeal. Robert J. Fauteux, a spokesman for Shiley, said the company has followed the FDA's policy on the matter, which recommends that companies communicate with patients through their physicians. Shiley has kept physicians of patients with Shiley valves updated on the device's problems on a regular basis since 1980, he said. The FDA is reviewing its recommendation on how to get information to patients, and ``if the FDA were to reconsider its policy, Shiley would reassess our policy,'' Fauteux said. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said agency officials would review Public Citizen's petition.
DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Moves to End Trade Status for China
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell is taking steps to end favored trade treatment for China, saying the administration's hopes for improved human rights have proved futile. President Bush notified Congress on May 24 that he was renewing most-favored-nation trading status and its preferential tariff treatment for Chinese goods. The status took effect July 3 _ exactly 13 months after the government's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in and around Beijing's Tiananmen Square. Mitchell, with 16 other Democratic and Republican senators, introduced a bill that would roll back the preferred trading status until the president certifies that political prisoners in China have been freed, free emigration is granted, surveillance of Chinese students abroad is halted and religious persecution is stopped. The certification also would have to assert that press freedom has been restored, pro-democracy leaders aren't being persecuted and internationally recognized human rights are being honored. Mitchell, D-Maine, said he was introducing the bill ``to give tangible expression'' to what he called Americans' overwhelming support for the dormant Chinese pro-democracy forces.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up In Tokyo, Stocks Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed against the Japanese yen in Tokyo Thursday, and share prices closed higher on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar closed at 148.90 yen, up 0.80 yen from Wednesday's close of 148.10 yen. It opened at 148.78 yen and ranged between 148.40 yen and 149.25 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 281.14 points, or 0.87 percent, to 32,575.32. The index had risen 141.18 points Wednesday. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar was higher after the economic summit in Houston failed to fulfill market expectations of a call for a stronger yen. They also said the dollar firmed after Bank of Japan officials denied Wednesday renewed speculation over an increase in Japan's official discount rate. A dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank said the dollar's rebound also was attributable to ``those who sold the currency too excessively yesterday were buying back today.'' On Wednesday, the dollar plunged to a 4{-month low against the yen in Tokyo. Dealers on the stock market said share prices were higher aided by a steep overnight rebound on Wall Street and the absence of heavy selling. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds stood at 86.90 points, unchanged from Wednesday's close. The yield was 7.215 percent, unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: New Drug Shows Promise in Treating Osteoporosis
DOC.TEXT: A prescription drug already on the market can reverse the slow loss of spinal bone that causes the crushed vertebrae and stooped posture of old age, a study published today shows. Women who took the medicine in a two-year experiment conducted at seven U.S. medical centers cut their risk of broken vertebrae in half. ``We think it's extremely encouraging news,'' said Sandra Raymond, executive director of the National Osteoporosis Foundation. ``Our arsenal is very small. Hopefully now, based on these studies, we may have another option.'' The medicine, called etidronate, joins two other prescription medicines available to treat osteoporosis, the brittle-bones disease that afflicts an estimated 15 million to 20 million Americans. Because of its apparent advantages, it could become the medicine of choice for many elderly victims. ``This is really exciting,'' said Dr. Nelson B. Watts of Emory University, principal author of the study. ``We can wait until somebody is already in bad shape and make them better. They won't stand straight or play basketball. But the deterioration will be halted.'' Crushed vertebrae are the most common consequence of osteoporosis, a disorder that largely affects women after menopause. There is no evidence so far that etidronate will prevent hip fractures, which are a less common but more serious hazard of the disease. The study was published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. In May, the journal carried a smaller study by European researchers that reached similar conclusions. Both studies were financed by Procter & Gamble's Norwich Eaton Pharmaceuticals, which makes etidronate. In the latest work, 429 women with osteoporosis were randomly assigned to take etidronate or dummy placebos for two years. When it was over, the spinal bone density of those getting etidronate had increased 5 percent, and they suffered half as many vertebral fractures as the other women. During their younger years, people lose old bone and make new bone at about the same rate. Later on, however, many lose bone faster than they replace it. Etidronate works by slowing the body's resorption of old bone. This allows the slow production of new bone to outpace the loss. The medicine resulted in a two-thirds drop in fractures in women with the weakest bones, the study showed. ``The impact of etidronate was greatest in individuals with the lowest bone mass,'' noted Dr. William Peck of Washington University in St. Louis. ``That means we are talking about reducing fractures in people who are at the greatest risk. That's an exciting possibility.'' During the study, the women took the medicine for two weeks out of every three months. The drug is already on the market for treatment of Paget's disease, another bone ailment. However, it has not been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for osteoporosis. Currently, the only prescription drugs approved for treatment of osteoporosis are estrogen and calcitonin. Etidronate carries no known side effects, costs $200 to $300 per year and is taken in pill form. Doctors say these are important advantages. Calcitonin requires three injections a week and costs 10 times more. While estrogen is a highly effective treatment for protecting bones during the first years after menopause, doctors are unsure whether it helps older women. Estrogen, which is a sex hormone, cannot be taken by women at high risk of breast cancer. It also can cause resumption of menstrual bleeding.

DOC.HEAD: Police Stake Out Killer They Suspect Could Strike Today
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Undercover police guided by the stars staked out various points in the city in their quest for the Zodiac killer, whose 21-day pattern of shootings led investigators to suspect he would strike again today. Police consulted astrological charts, occult books, FBI psychological profiles and letters scrawled by the gunman in selecting their positions. The gunman has vowed in his letters to shoot 12 people, one for each sign of the zodiac. He has struck four times in four months. One victim died. Police, including a task force of 50, refused to divulge the locations staked out. To match Zodiac's pattern of preying on easy targets, they dressed as homeless or elderly people or others who are vulnerable. The Guardian Angels, a red-bereted citizen crime-fighting force, patrolled sections of the Brooklyn-Queens boundary, where three of the attacks took place, and inside Central Park, where the fourth occurred. The shootings have followed a 21-day pattern. The first occurred March 8, the others on March 29, May 31 and June 21. The time between the second and third shootings was 63 days, a multiple of 21. Each shooting occurred early on a Thursday. The Zodiac's victims, all men, have been a Scorpio, a Gemini, a Taurus and a Cancer. In letters he sent to police and news organizations, he scrawled the symbols for his victims' astrological signs. One survivor said a stranger asked him his birth date two days before he was shot. Police said the gunman may have obtained other victims' birth dates where applications are filled out, such as banks or government offices. Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli acknowledged on Wednesday the best leads could come after the killer claims another victim. ``The more times an incident occurs, the better the chance of finding the individual,'' he said. In his letters, the gunman has tried to convince police he is the Zodiac who terrorized San Francisco during the late 1960s and early 1970s. The original Zodiac is believed to have killed as many as 40 people. Police doubt the New York killer is the same person but think he may be getting his ideas from a 1986 book about the San Francisco attacks. While police searched and waited, some wary New Yorkers stayed inside. Madeline Sanchez, 17, of Queens, said the Zodiac has affected her social life. ``My mother's making me come home by 11. She doesn't want me to be going out when Zodiac is around. But I told her he shoots old men, not young girls,'' she said. In tracking the gunman, detectives studied a turn-of-the-century book called ``The Law is For All,'' which contains a series of revelations from a deity named Aiwass, news reports said. The 21st revelation in the Aleister Crowley book reads, ``Nature's way is to weed out the weak. This is the most merciful way.'' Two of Zodiac's victims walked with canes. Another was shot while drunk. The fourth was wounded while sleeping on a park bench.

DOC.HEAD: Disagreement On Repatriation Forces Meeting Postponement
DOC.TEXT: An international conference to discuss the future of Vietnamese boat people has been postponed in a continued disagreement over repatriation of non-refugees. Raymond Hall, spokesman for the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said Wednesday that no new date has been set for the conference, which had been scheduled for July 16-17. Hall called the delay ``very dangerous'' and said risks were growing that countries near Vietnam would refuse to allow boat people to land on their shores. He said about 112,000 boat people are in Southeast Asian refugee camps. He said the delay could threaten the U.N. principle of first asylum, under which refuge-seekers are granted temporary asylum until they are resettled in other nations or repatriated to their homeland. A U.N. meeting last year agreed on an international plan to cope with the flood of Vietnamese boat people, including the introduction of screening procedures to separate genuine refugees _ those escaping political persecution _ from migrants in search of a better life. It also set up a program to repatriate people wishing to go back to Vietnam. So far 3,400 have returned voluntarily, Hall said. However, disagreement continues over the fate of non-refugees who are unwilling to be sent back. The Bush administration remains opposed to the forcible repatriation of economic migrants. Diplomats in Geneva say U.S. officials, privately, are showing some flexibility. Hanoi, also, is reluctant to accept involuntary returns. Britain, under pressure from its overcrowded Hong Kong colony, and Southeast Asian nations have demanded the United States agree to mandatory repatriation or set up its own camps to accommodate non-refugees. At a meeting in Manila in May, Southeast Asian countries issued an ultimatum that they would stop granting asylum if no settlement was reached. Hall said the High Commissioner had agreed to postpone next week's meeting because of lack of common ground among participants _ the United States and other resettlement countries, first-asylum countries and Vietnam. He said intense negotiations were taking place, but a further meeting was unlikely to take place before August. Hall said by the end of May there were 112,000 boat people in camps in the region, up from 83,000 in May 1989. About 55,000 are in in Hong Kong.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf of 3rd item, `Actually, Madonna ...' CORRECT spelling of Kahlo's first name, Frida sted Frieda, and CLARIFY that she is dead
DOC.TEXT: If Madonna could trade places with someone, living or dead, who would it be? Marilyn Monroe? Nah. ``She'd probably have an exercise video,'' the sultry singer-actress said. John F. Kennedy Jr.? Nope. But she'd like to be stranded with him if they were the only two people left on the planet. Forget it. You'll never guess. Try Malcolm X. Actually, Madonna first chose Frida Kahlo to trade places with, but remembered the painter, who died in 1954, spent much of her life in pain after being crippled in a streetcar accident. So the assassinated black Muslim leader was her next choice. Madonna answered these and other questions submitted by readers of the teen magazine YM. Her answers are in the August issue, which hit newsstands Wednesday. Other gems: The best present she ever received was ``a handful of sweaty diamonds and emeralds.'' She didn't say from whom. If she had only two days to live she'd spend them ``eating potato chips, watching `The Little Rascals.''' And if Madonna could change herself in any way, what would she change? ``Just my hairdresser,'' she says.

DOC.HEAD: October Earthquake Producing Tiny Temblors, a Hospital Says
DOC.TEXT: Tiny aftershocks of the Bay Area earthquake are being delivered this month, nine months after the earth moved, says a hospital projecting up to a two-thirds increase in births. But other hospitals are not sure the fault for any baby boom lies with the Oct. 17 quake that caused blackouts and trapped people at home for days. Seton Medical Center in Daly City just south of San Francisco projects the higher birth rate for July. ``We're calling them quake babies,'' Kathy Kohrman, Seton's director of marketing, said Wednesday. ``We had a blackout situation, but not a lot of devastation from the quake in our area. And people had a lot of time on their hands,'' she said. Lisa Gonzales, a nurse at Seton, was due July 15 but delivered 7-pound Alejandro prematurely this week. ``The telephones were down, the TV wasn't working,'' Mrs. Gonzales said of the situation at her house. ``It was a very emotional time. ``We didn't know whether we were going to see each other again and so, you know.'' Mrs. Gonzales was at home and her husband, Dr. Gilberto Gonzales, was working when the quake struck. It measured 7.1 on the Richter scale and killed 67 people. ``He took several days off work after that when he finally got home,'' Mrs. Gonzales said. ``I was afraid to be home alone for a while. We weren't really planning a baby, but we had been thinking about it.'' Seton expects to deliver 100 babies this month, compared with 60 to 80 during an average July. Newborns will get special ``quake baby'' certificates and mothers and fathers will win a ``parent survival kit'' if their infant weighs in at 7 pounds, 1 ounce, the hospital said. The kit includes diapers and toys. Other San Francisco area hospitals say the wave of births hasn't registered on any scale yet. ``We did have a fairly high rate of birth over the norm during June, but I can't say it was quake-related,'' said Barbara Shingai, spokeswoman for the community hospital in Watsonville, nearest the epicenter of the temblor. ``It's really too early to tell if we'll see a continued peak in July.'' She said 136 babies were born at the Watsonville hospital in June compared to an average 129 a month. Kaiser hospitals in Northern California and San Francisco General Hospital also report no shakeups in their delivery statistics this summer. ``There's a two-year trend in California and the U.S. of rising birth rates, but I don't think you can speculate that the earthquake is causing any of it,'' said Jennifer Cross of Kaiser. ``It's hard to tell what's behind birth rates.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain Dampens Midwest, South
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across the Midwest and South today, but the early morning hours offered little relief from the sweltering heat in the Southwest. Showers dampened parts of Louisiana and Indiana early today. Rain fell over Ohio and Tennessee. Today's forecast called for thunderstorms to develop from Arkansas to northern Virginia and over New Mexico, central Texas and southern Nebraska. Rain was forecast from southern Missouri to the Eastern Seaboard. Temperatures remained above 90 in parts of the Southwest early today. It was 97 in Phoenix and 92 in Las Vegas at midnight Wednesday. Temperatures soared above 100 degrees earlier Wednesday as far north as Washington state. Pendleton, Ore., reported a record high for the date of 105 degrees. Temperatures also rose above 100 in southern Oklahoma, northern Texas, South Carolina and Georgia. Augusta, Ga., had a record high of 103. The high for the nation on Wednesday was 123 degrees at Death Valley, Calif. Also Wednesday, thunderstorms developed over Colorado, Arizona, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Kansas, the Dakotas, Iowa, Minnesota and western Wisconsin. A thunderstorm pelted metropolitan Denver with golf ball-sized hail and heavy rain, injuring about 25 passengers on an amusement park sky ride, and damaging hundreds of windows and parked cars. One stranded passenger said the hail pounded the ride's machinery so hard that it made his ears ring. The injuries were confined to cuts and bruises. Thunderstorms also rumbled over Virginia, Georgia and the Carolinas.
