DOC.HEAD: Report: East Germany Allowed Libyan Attack On Discotheque
DOC.TEXT: Ousted East German leader Erich Honecker and his secret police chief allowed Libyan terrorists to carry out the 1986 discotheque bombing that killed two American soldiers, a leading newspaper reported today. The West Berlin bombing, which also killed a Turkish woman, prompted the U.S. Air Force raid on the Libyan capital of Tripoli 10 days later. The report in the West Germany paper Die Welt was the latest in a string of disclosures on relations between international terrorists and Honecker's Communist regime. According to the report, secret police chief Erich Mielke knew on March 20, 1986, that Libyan terrorists were about to attack a U.S. target in West Berlin, but did nothing to stop it. Sixteen days later, a bomb at the La Belle discotheque killed the soldiers and Turkish woman and injured more than 200 other people. ``On March 24, the Ministry for State Security (secret police) drafted a written report for Honecker. The response was not to do anything but rather to let the Libyans do as they pleased,'' Die Welt said. A colonel in the secret police, or Stasi, who tried to stop the April 5 bombing was fired on the spot, the paper said. The terrorist incident provoked the April 15 U.S. bombing raid on the Libyan cities of Benghazi and Tripoli, including an attack on the heavily guarded compound of Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi. Die Welt said Stasi archives gave a detailed account of preparations for the La Belle bombing. The paper supplied gave the following account: On March 25, 1986, a man claiming to be a diplomatic courier for the Libyan's People's Bureau, or embassy, in East Berlin, drove into West Berlin in an embassy car carrying seven grenades, three automatic pistols and two semi-automatic rifles. The driver, identified as Musbah al-Albani, carried a note with the addresses of three discotheques, including La Belle. Stasi records even contain the car's license number, CD 68-20. However, the attack was postponed because of inadequate planning. The driver traveled to West Berlin once more on March 30 but returned on April 4, the eve of the La Belle bombing. On April 5, the Stasi monitored a telephone call to the home of Yussef Salam, a Palestinian it knew under the code name of ``Nuri.'' Immediately after the call, in which Salam was told ``It hasn't worked out yet,'' he met with a Libyan embassy official and drove to West Berlin. The La Belle bomb went off around 5 a.m. that morning. Die Welt identified several other Palestinians and Libyans who allegedly played a role in the attack. Salam, who also uses the name of Yasser Chraidi, is believed to be living in Algeria, it said. Authorities of the non-Communist government that came to power in East Germany after free elections in March also say the Communist regime harbored West German terrorists of the Red Army Faction, which launched fatal attacks in West Germany. Some suspects have been captured. East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel has been quoted as saying the Stasi sheltered the international terrorist known as Carlos as well as the man believed responsible for the 1972 massacre of 17 Israeli athletes at the Olympic Games in Munich. The secret police force maintained at least informal contacts with the Basque separatist group ETA and the Irish Republican Army, which seeks to overthrow British rule in Northern Ireland, Diestel has said.

DOC.HEAD: City Hall Celebrates Choice of Democratic Convention Site
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: A band played ``Happy Days Are Here Again'' and City Hall was adorned with flags from every state as officials celebrated the news that the Big Apple will host the 1992 Democratic convention. Democratic National Chairman Ron Brown, Mayor David Dinkins and Gov. Mario Cuomo used a desk Wednesday in City Hall that belonged to George Washington to sign a contract making New York City the convention site. ``We won't let you down,'' Dinkins told Brown, an old friend and native New Yorker. ``New York is a great convention town.'' The convention at Madison Square Garden is expected to pump $100 million into the New York economy and bring 35,000 delegates, guests and journalists to town. ``Democrats will nominate the next president of the United States two years from now this week in America's most dynamic city and in one of the world's greatest cities _ New York, the Big Apple,'' Dinkins said. The race for the Democratic presidential nominee is wide open. New York was chosen over New Orleans as the convention site. Brown said New Orleans' chances were hurt by the Louisiana Legislature's passage of strong anti-abortion legislation, but that was not the deciding factor. New York's early pledge to come up with the more than $20 million for the convention and a pledge by prominent Democratic fund-raisers in the city to fill the party's coffers helped persuade Brown. New York had the convention in 1976, when Jimmy Carter was nominated and won the presidency, and in 1980, when Carter was renominated and lost.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Gov. Uses Prison Inmate Shift for Political Damage Control
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez has moved to shore up his law-and-order image in a tough re-election campaign after an apparent murder by an escaped convict stirred memories of the Willie Horton affair. Earlier this week, Martinez, a Republican, ordered thousands of prison inmates removed from work-release programs similar to one that cost Democrat Michael Dukakis dearly in his failed 1988 presidential bid. Among the inmates affected by Martinez' order was 80-year-old Roswell Gilbert, who is serving a life sentence for shooting his wife in a widely publicized mercy-killing case. In the 1988 presidential race, then-candidate George Bush painted Dukakis, the Massachusetts governor, as a liberal weak on crime. GOP television ads featured Horton, a Massachusetts inmate who raped a Maryland woman while on a furlough program. Public-opinion surveys indicate Martinez can ill afford to lose ground on law enforcement, an issue that helped propel him to victory in 1986. But the June 24 slaying of a woman at a shopping mall, allegedly by a convicted killer who walked away from a prison work detail, gave Democratic challengers an opening against the vulnerable first-term governor. The front-runner in the Democratic race for governor, popular former U.S. Sen. Lawton Chiles, immediately seized on the slaying of 44-year-old Faye Lamb Vann as evidence that Martinez's tough talk on crime was just that: talk. ``It's proof that there is no system, there is no strategy about how we're going to fight crime in this state,'' said Chiles, who served three terms in the Senate. ``I think it's obvious that this has not been something the governor and his people have been paying attention to.'' Mrs. Vann's alleged killer, escapee Donald David Dillbeck, was convicted of killing a sheriff's deputy in 1979. Dillbeck was eligible for minimum-security work details despite his crime. Martinez denied he was trying to put out a political fire by removing inmates from work-release programs. ``I don't think we can guarantee forever that someone can't get away from one of our prison systems. We can guarantee there's less likelihood now. The great regret is that the life can't be brought back,'' Martinez said. The governor said the state's inmate review system wasn't working and was antiquated when he ordered 3,400 inmates in work-release programs to more secure prisons. Before the new controversy, Martinez had often touted the 28,000 new prison beds authorized during his administration. He made a television ad boasting of the number of death warrants he has signed that featured the smiling face of serial killer Ted Bundy, put to death in January 1989. But recent polls have indicated Chiles would defeat both Martinez and the other Democrat running in the Sept. 4 primary, U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson. The surveys also show Nelson beating Martinez. Nelson has stayed out of the Dillbeck case. He was burned earlier in the campaign by attempting to attack Martinez over the early prison release of a black man, Charles Street, who is currently on trial in Miami for the subsequent slayings of two Miami police officers. Nelson brought up the spectre of Horton, who is also black, then was forced to apologize when civil rights activists labeled his charges racist. Chiles hasn't mentioned Horton, but contends Mrs. Vann might be alive if Martinez had been properly managing the prison system. ``If you can do it today, then obviously there was room to do it all along,'' he said. ``He just elected not to do it or failed to do it.''

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Buys Houses to Prevent Move to Peoria, Ill.
DOC.TEXT: A historical society won't be allowed to cart off three French colonial houses from Missouri in its efforts to celebrate this western Illinois city's tricentennial next year. Missouri decided late last month to buy the houses in Ste. Genevieve, Mo., to keep them there, Jane Beetem of the Missouri Department of Natural Resources said Tuesday. The purchase price was not disclosed. She said the state will try to resell the houses with stipulations they remain in Ste. Genevieve, a town of 5,000 that was once part of France's Louisiana Territory. ``We certainly would have hated to see them moved,'' Ms. Beetem said Tuesday. `They are a very unique type of property.'' The state of Missouri became interested in the houses after a group called Peoria 1691 Foundation said it wanted to buy and move them to Peoria in time for the Illinois River city's tricentennial in September 1991. One proposal called for reconstructing on the banks of the Illinois River a French colony like the settlement three centuries ago that evolved into Peoria. The original village, located in what is now downtown Peoria, was destroyed by fire in 1812, forcing civic leaders to look elsewhere for authentic French colonial houses to restore. The prospect of Peoria buying and moving historic houses outraged local residents of Ste. Genevieve who demanded Missouri officials step in to prevent the transaction. The three houses targeted by Peoria included the Bequette-Ribault House _ a restored log ``post-and-ground house'' built sometime between 1790 and 1808. It's considered valuable because there are only four known structures of its kind in the United States and three of those are in Ste. Genevieve, a town of 5,000 located 75 miles south of St. Louis on the Mississippi River. The other historic structures are: the Durant House built in 1810; and the Rozier Cabin, built in 1841 and currently disassembled and in storage. A fourth home had been considered but the society expressed concern about moving it because it is built of stone.

DOC.HEAD: Sharp Words Over Publication of Private Royal Chitchat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with comment from Wilson, SUB two grafs for 19th, `Wilson, who ...' Picks up 20th pvs, `Commenting in ...' ^By MARCUS ELIASON
DOC.TEXT: The code that governs British treatment of royalty is largely unwritten but always strict, and novelist A.N. Wilson has violated one of the sternest rules of all. His sin has been to report a dinner-table chat with Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother. That her remarks to Wilson were fairly innocuous, and that the conversation took place nearly a decade ago, matters little. The affair has provoked some sharp language from London society. ``Scoundrel!'' thundered Lord Wyatt of Weeford. ``An intolerable betrayal!'' echoed Nicholas Soames, member of Parliament and scion of the Churchill family. Wilson, 39, is a gifted novelist and acute social commentator who clearly knew he was courting trouble when he published ``The Queen Mother's table-talk'' in the weekly Spectator magazine two weeks ago. ``It is probably the grossest impropriety to embarrass her, or her host, by repeating our conversation,'' he wrote. ``I do so, however, without very much compunction, since she never gives `interviews,' and I can think of no better person than Queen Elizabeth with whom to start off an occasional series of conversations with men and women who have lived through most of the years of this century ... and whose memories stretch back far.'' In the conversation, reproduced in dialogue form, the mother of Queen Elizabeth II and widow of King George VI was said to have revealed a fondness for detective stories, and a problem with her cash flow: ``Had such an awful afternoon today with my bank manager, scolding me about my overdraft.'' After a few remarks about politics came this gem of an account of a poetry evening at Windsor Castle during World War II, at which T.S. Eliot recited ``The Waste Land.'' Elizabeth: ``We had this rather lugubrious man in a suit, and he read a poem. ... I think it was called `The Desert.' And first the girls got the giggles, and then I did and then even the King.'' Wilson: ```The Desert,' ma'am? Are you sure it wasn't called `The Waste Land?''' Elizabeth: ``That's it. I'm afraid we all giggled. Such a gloomy man, looked as though he worked in a bank, and we didn't understand a word.'' Wilson: ``I believe he DID once work in a bank.'' The article, published in the midst of national celebrations of the queen mother's 90th birthday, was thoughtful and affectionate. But Lord Wyatt, himself a former journalist, was scandalized, especially since it was he who was host of the dinner. ``Wilson is boastfully shameless in being a scoundrel,'' he wrote in a letter to the Spectator published a week later. It was, he charged, a ``deceitfully obtained and stolen `interview.''' Soames, in a letter to the magazine, called it ``an appalling want of chivalry'' and ``an absolutely fundamental breach of trust.'' Buckingham Palace, which speaks for the queen mother, declined to comment. But Wilson, who prefers initials to his first name, Andrew, reacted in this week's Spectator to what he called an ``absurd taboo.'' ``Why all the fuss?'' he asked. ``The Queen Mother is about to be 90 years old. The newspapers are full of 16-page, full-color supplements all, roughly speaking, conveying the message, `Gawd bless yer, Ma'am.' None of the articles I have read have conveyed what it is like to meet her, or what she says.'' Commenting in The Independent on Sunday, columnist Francis Wheen said Wyatt was cutting ``a comical figure.'' He noted that the lord's own autobiography contained gossipy tidbits from his private conversations with famous people. Wyatt warned that the affair would strengthen those who want to impose stricter privacy laws on the media. Wheen wrote that Wyatt himself is a columnist, for the tabloid News of the World, ``and although that newspaper has many qualities, respect for privacy is not, I think, one of them.'' Hugh Montgomery-Massingberd argued in The Daily Telegraph that writers were always scribbling down conversations with the high and mighty, hoping to publish them one day. ``This may be an ungentlemanly instinct,'' he wrote. But ``you have to decide whether to be a gent or a scribbler and I, for one, am prepared to defend A. N. Wilson for choosing the latter course.''

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Covenant House Selects Nun as New President
DOC.TEXT: The troubled Covenant House for young runaways has turned to a nun to restore cash and credibility that were diminished in a scandal that forced the resignation of its founder. Covenant House said Wednesday it selected Sister Mary Rose McGeady as president. She replaces the Rev. Bruce Ritter, a Franciscan priest who resigned in February. Sister McGeady, 62, is an associate executive director of Catholic Charities in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn. She oversees 80 social service programs, a $40 million budget and a staff of more than 800 people. The Covenant House Board of Directors named Sister McGeady on Tuesday. She takes office Sept. 1. In a statement, Sister McGeady said she looks forward to the challenge of ensuring Covenant House ``continues to shine as a beacon for the thousands of kids who are still out there without a family or home.'' Covenant House shelters 25,000 youths annually in 17 dormitories in the United States, Canada and Latin America. Ritter, who resigned Feb. 27, had been accused of having sexual relations with shelter residents and lending Covenant House funds to two former board members. He has denied wrongdoing. Covenant House officials have expressed concern that the institution may have difficulty surviving without Ritter, whose fund-raising appeals attracted hundreds of millions of dollars in donations. Donations, which almost solely sustain Covenant House, have fluctuated wildly since his departure. Anticipating serious losses, the organization's board has laid off 111 of its 420 employees and cut its budget from $86 million to $72 million in the new fiscal year, which started July 1. ``We're hoping the donations will come back up,'' Sister McGeady said in a telephone interview. ``If they don't it might be necessary for us to do some more cutting.''

DOC.HEAD: Animal-Rights Activist Challenges Pigeon Shoot Organizer to Fight
With PM-Prairie Dog Hunt, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An animal-rights activist has challenged an organizer of a pigeon shoot to a no-rules fistfight to end the fund-raising event that leaves thousands of birds dead each year. Steve Hindi, among 300 animal-rights activists who protested the Labor Day shoot last year, challenged organizer Bob Tobash in a letter. ``Shooting a pigeon down is punk sport,'' Hindi said in an interview. ``We'll throw out the rules. We'll give them the pure blood sport that they've become accustomed to. One man against one man.'' Tobash said he did not know Hindi and the challenge appeared to be a publicity stunt. ``There's 200 people involved in this,'' Tobash said. ``Even if I would have the duel with him, it doesn't mean the other people would call off the shoot. He's attacking me and I take offense to that.'' The pigeon shoot has been a tradition for 57 years in Hegins Township, a community of nearly 4,000 residents about 50 miles northwest of Allentown. Between 5,000 and 8,000 pigeons are shot during the daylong event, which is held to raise money for a 30-acre park in Hegins. Pigeons that survive the shoot are killed later when their necks are snapped by youngsters recruited to do the task. ``They think it's sportsmanlike,'' said Hindi, from Plano, Ill. ``It's barbaric.'' In his letter, which Tobash received Tuesday, Hindi proposed that they each put up $10,000 and ``meet in a public place in the Hegins area for a physical confrontation which would be without time limit, rules, officiating or any protective gear whatsoever.'' If Tobash were victorious, Hindi said his $10,000 would go toward maintaining the Hegins Community Park. Should Hindi prevail, he proposes that the shoot be canceled and Tobash's $10,000 be forfeited to the park. The confrontation would end when either man submits or is unable to continue, Hindi proposed. Animal-rights advocates have lobbied state legislators annually to ban the pigeon shoot, but Schuylkill County lawmakers have killed such efforts. Tobash said the shoot is the ``most effective'' way for the town to raise money to maintain the park. ``We would like to have these groups leave us alone. It's a sporting event,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Govt Says Tamil Rebels Resorting to Scorched Earth Policy
DOC.TEXT: The government said today that Tamil rebels fleeing army troops are resorting to a scorched earth policy, blowing up bridges and buildings and destroying a state-owned television station. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told reporters that government forces were in full control of the east, a month after new fighting broke out with the separatist Tamils. ``We are on top of the situation and have destroyed some of their key strongholds in the east,'' Wijeratne said, though adding that fighting in the north continues. In their retreat, the rebels are leaving little behind, he said: ``They are on the run and are resorting to a scorched earth policy, destroying bridges, buildings, food stores.'' Wijeratne said they had destroyed the TV station in Kokkavil in the north and blew up a key bridge linking the Sri Lankan mainland to Mannar island in the northwest. In other developments, the government denied charges that army troops killed 50 Tamil civilians Tuesday in eastern Sri Lanka. The Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization on Wednesday accused the army of killing 50 Tamil civilians in Kalmunai, an east coast town where about 115 policemen were slain by Tamil rebels a month ago. ``I am categorically denying a report that troops had lined up and shot 50 Tamil civilians in Kalmunai,'' said Gen. Cyril Ranatunge, the defense secretary. ``We don't do that kind of thing.'' Wijeratne described the fighting in the rebel-dominated northern Jaffna peninsula as a see-saw battle between the rebels and the army: ``They throw a few rockets at us, and we throw a few at them.'' Jaffna has been cut off from the rest of the country since the ethnic war resumed June 11. The peninsula has been the scene of some of the worst fighting. The rebels control most of the area except for an army camp in Jaffna town, a naval base and a military airfield. The Tamil rebels broke a 13-month-old cease-fire last month, renewing a 7-year-old war for independence for the predominantly Tamil north and east from Sinhalese-dominated Sri Lanka. Tamils make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people and have long accused the Sinhalese majority of discrimination. The Sinhalese, who account for about 74 percent of the people, control the government and the military. The Tamil ethnic war has claimed more than 13,000 lives.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs Perth-dated fourth item to add 2 grafs of comment. Karin is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Former tennis great Margaret Court says Martina Navratilova is a poor role model for young players because she is a lesbian. Court, who won 25 Grand Slam events, said Wednesday in newspaper and radio interviews that Navratilova's homosexuality is a bad example. ``She is a great player, but I'd like to see somebody at the top to whom the younger players can look up to,'' said Court, 47, a born-again Christian who lives in Perth. ``It is very sad for children to be exposed to it.'' Peter Johnson, a spokesman for Navratilova, said she had no comment. Navratilova won her first Wimbledon singles title in 1978 and a record ninth when she defeated Zina Garrison on Saturday. ``Winning Wimbledon a record nine times qualifies you as a role model,'' said Karin Schwartz of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation in New York. She called Court's comments ``totally ridiculous.'' `Underlying her statements is a complete ignorance of homosexuality,'' Schwartz said. ``You don't catch it.''

DOC.HEAD: The Tentative Search for Common Ground on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: The executive director of the abortion clinic that lost a landmark U.S. Supreme Court decision last year has been holding talks quietly with the lawyer who wrote the law that restricted access to abortion. B.J. Isaacson-Jones of Reproductive Health Services and Andrew Puzder, a longtime leader in Missouri's anti-abortion movement, have discussed over the past eight months letting an anti-abortion counselor work at the clinic. They met Wednesday with leaders from both sides of the abortion debate to get reaction to the idea and determine what to do next. The meeting sought to explore and answer questions about the counselor idea, such as who would pay the counselor, which patients would be counseled and what kind of counseling would be provided. The two agreed to examine the need for better foster care and for better help for handicapped and hard-to-place children, as well as the idea of putting an anti-abortion counselor in the Reproductive Health clinic. But they said the fact that they found some common ground shouldn't be viewed as a victory for either side, Puzder said. ``If anything, our talks are a victory for women and children,'' he said. News of the meetings about the counselor idea was disclosed this week. Before then, it was difficult to imagine the two talking to one another. Puzder, a St. Louis lawyer, represented people who sat-in at abortion clinics in the 1970s and '80s. He drafted the restrictive abortion law at the center of last year's landmark Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services Supreme Court decision, which gave states more power to restrict a woman's right to abortion. Isaacson-Jones has long defended a woman's right to have an abortion. Her clinic performs nearly half the 18,000 abortions each year in Missouri and sees women from 10 states. ``This could be a very good idea or it could die tomorrow,'' Puzder said. ``What B.J. and I are doing can be killed very easily. We are dealing with very delicate politics.'' Both said it was surprisingly easy to get together and talk. ``I was very nervous when I called him, but after we talked I was encouraged and excited,'' said Isaacson-Jones, who contacted Puzder after a newspaper column he wrote about the need to help women and children. Puzder said he was glad she called. ``The first thing we did was say, `I know that I'm not going to convince you to become pro-life, and you know that you can't convince me to become pro-choice,''' he said. ``We got that out of the way and were able to talk.''

DOC.HEAD: Poisonous Insects Kill 30 in Bangladesh
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious, diamond-shaped insect whose bite can kill within four hours has claimed the lives of at least 30 people and attacked hundreds of others in the past month, doctors and newspapers said today. Panick-stricken villagers are destroying the bushy, fast-growing plants that harbor the insects, which have 30 tiny stingers. This could create more problems because the ipomoea crassicarlis plant's roots help check soil erosion in frequently flooded Bangladesh. The plant usually grows up to 10 feet but has no food value. A government-owned newspaper, Dainik Bangla, said the insect that feeds on the plant's leaves has killed at least 30 people across the country. Many of the victims were children who played in the bushes. Dozens of the bugs swarm into each plant. Doctors at Dhaka Medical College Hospital said they treated more than two dozen people who said they had been bitten by the insect. ``A victim may die within four hours of the attack if not properly treated,'' Dr. Mostafa Jalal Mohiuddin said. Survivors have responded to injections of oradixon, followed by three days of antihistamine tablets, doctors at the hospital said. Scientists in the government's Agriculture Department are trying to determine the insects' species and origin. Newspapers have suggested it arrived from Africa via India. The Health Ministry has urged the people not to panic and report to hospitals if they are bitten. The warnings are being broadcast by state-owned radio and television.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Grandmaster Leads Tournament in Manila
DOC.TEXT: Soviet grandmaster Vassily Ivanchuk defeated compatriot Alexander Khalifman today and took over sole leadership of the Manila Interzonal chess tournament. Ivanchuk forced Khalifman to resign after 44 moves of a Pirc Defense, giving him 8{ points and the lead after the 12th round. The 13th and last round of the tourney will be played Saturday after a rest day Friday. Boris Gelfand, the top favorite, agreed to a draw with fellow Soviet Leonid Yudasin. He was tied with Indian chess sensation Anand Viswanathan for second place with eight points. Viswanathan forced Soviet grandmaster Mikhail Gurevich to resign in 38 moves of a French Defense game. Viswanathan, playing the black pieces, managed to overcome Gurevich's slight lead playing with the white by an early exchange of queens. Gurevich, an 11th round co-leader with Ivanchuk and Gelfand, quit after Anand threatened to promote a pawn to a queen in two moves.

DOC.HEAD: Foe of Kenya Government Leaves U.S. Embassy for London
DOC.TEXT: A major critic of President Daniel arap Moi who took refuge in the U.S. Embassy during four days of violent anti-government protests has left Kenya for London, the U.S. ambassador said. Gibson Kamau Kuria, an Oxford-educated human rights lawyer, was allowed to leave the country Wednesday night, U.S. Ambassador Smith Hempston said. The sheltering of Kuria in the U.S. Embassy heightened tensions between Washington and Nariobi, already bristling over U.S. suggestions that the one-party state allow competing political parties. Kenya has long been considered one of Africa's most stable and successful nations. But since early this year, Moi has come under increasing pressure to allow a multiparty system. Kenya, an East African nation of 23 million, was calm on Wednesday. But four days of violent clashes between stone-throwing mobs and heavily armed riot police left 28 people dead, according to the English-language Daily Nation newspaper. The government says 20 died in the rioting, which began Saturday when the government tried to stop a pro-democracy rally. Dozens of people were injured by gunfire and beatings and 1,040 were charged in courts with looting and rioting, the paper said. The U.S. State Department on Tuesday advised Americans against all but essential travel to Kenya because of the unrest. It was not immediately clear what sort of negotiations took place to secure the release of Kuria, who sought refuge at the embassy on Saturday after a wave of government arrests in which about 11 top opposition figures were detained. ``Kuria left the U.S. Embassy and Kenya at 7:45 p.m. Wednesday night aboard a regularly scheduled airline. His immediate destination was London. I am personally grateful to the government of Kenya for permitting his departure and to the government of the United Kingdom for admitting him to Britain. Any further information regarding his departure will have to come from (the government of) Kenya,'' Hempstone said. Kuria, 43, won the Robert F. Kennedy human rights award in 1988. The award citation praised him as ``one of the few lawyers in Kenya who defends political prisoners.'' It says those who do ``fear government harassment, or worse.'' Kenya condemned the U.S. decision to give Kuria asylum. Kenya also accused Washington of fueling the pro-democracy movement. The Bush administration protested the charge in a meeting between Herman Cohen, assistant secretary for African affairs, and Kenya's ambassador in Washington, Denis Afande. Clashes between riot police and angry crowds began Saturday, following the arrests of opposition leaders and police used tear gas and guns to disperse demonstrators in Kenya's capital. By Monday, rioting spread to outlying cities and rural areas. Moi blamed the violence on ``hooligans and drug addicts.''

DOC.HEAD: Richard Bernstein, Prize-Winning Chemist, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Richard B. Bernstein, a professor of chemistry at UCLA whose work in molecular chemistry earned him a National Medical of Science award, has died. He was 66. Bernstein died in Helsinki, Finland, on Sunday after suffering a heart attack. He was attending a conference of Soviet and American scientists. Bernstein joined the faculty of the University of California, Los Angeles, in 1983 and pioneered research of interactions between molecules. His work in molecular beam scattering earned him the National Medal of Science in 1989, and he received the prestigious Robert A. Welch Award in Chemistry in 1988. With Ahmed H. Zewail of the California Institute of Technology, Bernstein developed ``femto'' chemistry, which employs lasers to observe the birth of molecules almost as they happen. A member of the National Academy of Sciences, Bernstein initiated the academy's first study of the impact of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, on the Earth's ozone layer. Prior to joining UCLA, Bernstein was chairman of the chemistry department at Columbia University in New York. As an undergraduate at Columbia, he became a member of the Manhattan Project, the United States' secret effort to develop the atomic bomb during World War II. He received his doctorate at Columbia in 1948. Bernstein also taught at the University of Texas, the University of Wisconsin and the University of Michigan, and served as a senior vice president of Occidental Research Corp. in Irvine. Bernstein is survived by his wife, Norma; a son, three daughters, a brother and four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Peace Talks Resume
DOC.TEXT: Delegations representing the Liberian rebels and the government of President Samuel Doe sat down with mediators today to discuss a possible peace agreement in the country's civil war. But before the talks began, rebel delegate Thomas Woewiyu held out little hope there was anything to negotiate. ``We have not come to discuss a cease-fire,'' he said after disembarking from the trawler Treesie, which had made the 30-hour voyage from the rebel-held port of Buchanan in neighboring Liberia. Woewiyu said the Economic Community of West African States, which was mediating the peace talks, was ``a very powerful institution and we have an obligation to come and hear what they have to say and then we shall react.'' The mediation group, which includes the region's military giant, Nigeria, reportedly has proposed introducing a peacekeeping force in Liberia, pending new elections. The rebels, who believe they are close to capturing the Liberian capital of Monrovia, have criticized the proposal. ``What we have in Monrovia is a man holding on to a city as hostage and we are not here to negotiate for hostage holding,'' Woewiyu said. ``As long as Doe is in Monrovia, there can be no talk about cease-fire.'' Doe's delegation to the talks was led by Tambakai Dangaba, who has been waiting in Freetown for Woewiyu to return since earlier peace talks collapsed last month. Dangaba refused to talk to reporters. Gambia, Nigeria, Ghana, Togo, Guinea and Sierra Leone also were represented at the talks. The rebels, led by Charles Taylor, have been advancing on the capital, Monrovia, since December. The insurgents accuse his government of corruption, tribalism and suppression of opposition. Taylor supports capitalism, but Washington and other governments have questioned his commitment to democracy. On Wednesday, two captured coast guard vessels flying the scarlet rebel flag fired on Monrovia's port before being driven off by rocket and machine-gun fire. A cannon installed at Doe's fortified cliff-top executive mansion about a mile from the port fired two rounds at the rebels and missed. Doe's army has been flying men and equipment up to Grand Gedeh County, his native region. Liberians close to Doe, speaking on condition of anonymity, say if forced to leave Monrovia, Doe may prefer to go there than leave the country. Heavy firing broke out in northern and eastern suburbs of Monrovia Tuesday afternoon and evening, rattling house windows in the center of town. The army fired about 10 rockets from a Soviet-designed BM-21 multiple rocket launcher at a large rebel force in the eastern suburb of Paynesville on Tuesday, witnesses said. The atmosphere in the Liberian capital remained tense. Residents are weary of food, water and electricity shortages, the curfew, and the nightly gunfire. Of Liberia's 2 million people, about 400,000 live in the capital. Monrovians also were frightened by tribal reprisal killings by the army. Decomposing bodies of victims were seen around Monrovia. Another corpse washed up overnight on the beach below the Italian Embassy. The rebels also reportedly have slain civilians in tribal revenge killings. Doe took power in a 1980 coup that ousted elitist descendants of American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Denies George Hamilton's Bid To Keep Marcos Testimony Sealed
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Supreme Court justice has denied actor George Hamilton's bid to keep his sworn testimony sealed in the government's case against Imelda Marcos and her late husband, Ferdinand. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who handles emergency appeals to the high court from California, denied the request Wednesday. Her action upheld a ruling Tuesday by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco. The appellate court ruled in favor of the Los Angeles Times, which sought access to papers concerning Hamilton in U.S. District Court in Los Angeles. The 2-1 appellate ruling says: ``The risk that harm or injury will befall Mr. Hamilton as a result of the release of these documents is no greater than the risk that all public figures are subject to daily by virtue of the fact that their activities may become the subject of favorable or unfavorable mention in the news media. ``That is a risk that Mr. Hamilton, as a sometime motion picture and television actor as well as a noted man about town, is in any event subject to at all times.'' The ruling was written by Judges Dorothy W. Nelson and Stephen Reinhardt, said federal Deputy Clerk Ernie Cruz in San Francisco. Hamilton was out of the country and unavailable for comment, said a secretary for his publicist, Jeffrey Lane, who also was out of his office. A message left with Hamilton's attorney after hours was not returned. Hamilton was among 61 unindicted co-conspirators named in a federal case bought against the Marcoses in New York. On July 2, Imelda Marcos was acquitted of the fraud and racketeering charges, which alleged she helped loot her country of $168 million. Ferdinand Marcos, who was indicted with his wife in 1988, died in exile in Hawaii last fall. An unindicted co-conspirator may have done something to advance an alleged criminal conspiracy without necessarily knowing he or she was doing it. In 1981, Hamilton bought a Beverly Hills estate once owned by Charlie Chaplin for $1.2 million. He obtained a five year loan, based on the property's increased value, in late 1983 from Calno Holdings N.V. in the Netherlands Antilles, which reportedly was tied to the Marcoses. Mrs. Marcos met Hamilton at a Manila festival in 1982. He entertained her at his Beverly Hills home, shopped with the Philippines first lady and escorted her to parties. In 1986, after the Marcoses fled Manila, Hamilton said Mrs. Marcos had no financial interest in his home.

DOC.HEAD: Government Orders Extradition of Soviet Hijacker
DOC.TEXT: Sweden today ordered the extradition of a 17-year-old Soviet who hijacked a domestic flight from the Soviet Union by threatening the pilot with what turned out to be a fake hand grenade. Dimitry Semionov is believed to the first person ordered extradited from Sweden to the Soviet Union since the end of World War II. ``It's a signal to would-be hijackers,'' said acting Prime Minister Lena Hjelm-Wallen. ``The government considered the boy's age and possible extenuating circumstances. But since the crime is very serious we decided that we can make no exceptions,'' she said. Semionov hijacked the aircraft on June 9 with 114 passengers and seven crew aboard, saying he wanted to leave his home in Byelorussia after a quarrel with his father. Semionov was the first of five Soviet youths to hijack Soviet domestic airliners to Sweden or Finland since June 9. All of the hijackers falsely claimed to be carrying explosives and all surrendered peacefully. Swedish airline pilots and police have urged the quick approval of Soviet requests for extraditions, saying delays would encourage more hijackings. Semionov told Swedish news media Wednesday he would commit suicide if he were sent home to face hijacking charges. He said he faces five years in jail and 10 years of banishment from major cities in the Soviet Union if convicted. Prisons official Lisbet Lindberg said extra guards were placed on Semionov, who was being held in Kronoberg jail. Government spokesman Lars Danielsson said the youth would be extradited as soon as Soviet authorities are prepared. Also today, Helsinki's flight control center said a hijacked Soviet airliner approached Finnish air space but turned back to Leningrad, apparently after a hijacking attempt was foiled. No further details were available about the plane, which had been on a domestic flight from Leningrad to the northern city of Murmansk. On Tuesday, the flight control center said a hijacked Soviet plane headed toward Finland but changed course and returned to Leningrad.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Coal Miners End One-Day Strike
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of coal miners returned to work today following a one-day strike to press demands that the Communist Party to get out of their lives and the Soviet government resign. According to strike organizers, workers were back on the job in the Ukraine's Don River coal basin, the Kuznets Basin of Western Siberia and Vorkuta in the Far North. ``All of the miners are working,'' said Nikolai Volynko, a strike organizer in Donetsk, the center of the Ukrainian mining region. Miners' spokesmen in the other regions, contacted by telephone, said that mining operations were back to normal. Miners staged the 24-hour walkout despite appeals from the Soviet government and party. In Donetsk, a rally passed a resolution Wednesday demanding that the government of Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov resign, that party cells be removed from mines, economic enterprises, the KGB, army and police, and that party property be nationalized. ``We should kick the party not only out of the Ukraine, but everywhere,'' declared mine construction worker Viktor Kitenko, speaking at the rally. No figures were available on the number of miners who actually walked off their jobs. But judging from the number of mines on strike in the Donetsk region, it appeared that about 100,000 miners stayed away. Strike organizers claimed that about 300,000 miners took part in western Siberia. Ryzhkov today told the Communist Party's 28th Congress meeting in Moscow that 276 enterprises and 655 branches took part in the strike. He said workers at 230 mines stayed off the job all day, and elsewhere, the walkout lasted from two to 12 hours. ``In light of what happened yesterday, we must quickly work out conclusions,'' he said. The job action was a repetition of a long and bitter strike coal miners conducted last summer to press the Soviet government for better supplies of basic consumer goods, better pay and working conditions. The government acceded to their demands, but has been unable to fulfill its promises. Mikhail Shchadov, minister of the coal mining industry, said in a newspaper interview Wednesday that the government was trying to give mines more independence, improve housing, vacations and construction of schools. But he acknowledged shortages in the Soviet economy, and said that a lack of timber to properly construct mine shafts had led to some deaths underground.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Claims Cambodian Defense Minister Arrested in Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Khmer Rouge guerrilla radio said today that Cambodia's defense minister has been arrested and is under guard in a Vietnamese hospital. The report, which was monitored in Bangkok, could not be independently confirmed. Khmer Rouge radio reports cannot always be considered reliable sources of information. Roland Eng, spokesman for the guerrilla faction loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, said Defense Minister Tie Banh had been arrested, but details were sketchy. Sihanouk leads the three-faction rebel coalition. Last month Asia Watch, a U.S. human rights group, said Cambodian authorities in May arrested at least six senior government officials and army officers for trying to form a rival political party. Tie Banh's name was not mentioned in those reports. Cambodia's one-party Communist administration was installed after a Vietnamese invasion of the country in late 1978. It continues to fight the three guerrilla groups backed by China and other countries. The Khmer Rouge radio report said Tie Banh had not been seen in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, for a month and reportedly was flown to Vietnam under armed guard on the pretext he had a heart disorder. Tie Banh was not arrested in Phnom Penh because it might undermine Premier Hun Sen's government, the radio said. Instead, he was flown to Vietnam from central Kompong Thom after he was ordered there in mid-June. ``Tie Banh is being hospitalized in Ho Chi Minh City under the heavy guard of Vietnamese soldiers,'' the radio said. The radio said the reason for the arrest was personal. It mentioned family corruption and conflict between Tie Banh and the Vietnamese over how to conduct the war in Cambodia. Commanders loyal to Sihanouk in Kompong Thom province said last week they had intelligence reports of Tie Banh's arrest. Government forces have recently been involved in heavy fighting with the three guerrilla factions and by many accounts have suffered major setbacks.

DOC.HEAD: Hail and Rains Rip Path Across Denver
DOC.TEXT: A hailstorm pelted the Denver area, shattering windows, stripping leaves from trees and bruising about four dozen amusement park patrons stranded on rides by a power failure. Aaron and Sarah Creer were riding a Ferris wheel at Elitch's Gardens amusement park in northwest Denver when the hailstorm hit Wednesday. ``I was just praying,'' said Aaron, 15. He said he wrapped his arms around his sister, 9, to protect her head and her glasses from the pounding ice. Patrons at the amusement park received mostly bumps, bruises, welts and cuts. Forty-seven of those injured were taken to hospitals but most were treated and released, said Tom Cribley, Denver paramedic supervisor. The hail splintered auto and building windows and dented vehicles. The hailstorms also flattened gardens and stripped trees of leaves, turning residential streets into paths of green. The University of Denver reported about 750 windows broken, mostly on the north sides of buildings, the direction from which the storm came. The storm developed north of Denver, near Estes Park, and moved south. In Arvada, where the strongest effects of the storm were felt, police Sgt. Merle Westling said the hail even stripped the bark off trees. It fell ``in solid sheets,'' Westling said. ``You couldn't see a thing.'' A 26-year-old woman was killed near Golden in a traffic accident that was blamed on a wet, slippery road. Golden police spokesman Dave Farley said the woman was a passenger in a car that spun out of control and hit a tree.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Guts Part of Abortion Clinic
DOC.TEXT: Fire inspectors today were investigating the cause of a blaze that destroyed part of an abortion clinic. The fire erupted late Wednesday at the Feminist Women's Health Center and gutted one end of the clinic building before it was brought under control. Neighbors reported seeing someone near the clinic shortly before the fire broke out, said police Sgt. Dave Mundy. No one was injured in the blaze. Authorities could not immediately estimate the damages but said the medical offices where abortions are performed were destroyed. The administrative offices received smoke damage. A fire also damaged the clinic in September. Investigators found no evidence of arson. Meanwhile, the trial of 19 Operation Rescue anti-abortion activists opened Monday in a packed courtroom but was delayed when the prosecutor became ill. The activists face charges of trespassing at the clinic during an anti-abortion blockade three months ago. The case is the second such prosecution involving protests at the clinic in rugged Shasta County about 260 miles northeast of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater's Leadership Missing as GOP Holds Midyear Session
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf, It was, to fix wording to `fabled' sted `failed'.
DOC.TEXT: From the surprise visitor at Republican Party headquarters came a not-so-surprising message. Republicans ``always do better when we're on the offensive,'' party Chairman Lee Atwater told his audience. ``Get back on the offensive.'' It was simple but welcome advice from a man whose trusted political instincts have been sorely missed by the party, which convenes for its midyear meeting today in Chicago. Infighting over taxes has exposed cracks in the GOP's fabled unity and Democrats have gotten more aggressive about taking on the Republicans. For the past four months, however, Atwater has been missing from the party's day-to-day operation, battling a life-threatening brain tmor. Aides say his condition has improved, but Atwater was readmitted to George Washington University Hospital on Wednesday for testing. Atwater was hospitalized overnight for routine testing, according to his press secretary, Leslie Goodman. ``This is nothing out of the ordinary. Everything is great,'' she said. ``There is a consensus among his doctors that the tumor is not growing.'' When Atwater was elected GOP chairman 18 months ago, Bush said, ``He will be my political eyes and ears.'' With that, the president effectively moved the White House political operation across town to the Republican National Committee. Atwater stays in daily touch with his office and the White House, and keeps tabs on major campaigns by tapping his extensive network of GOP contacts across the country. He spent much of Monday participating in conference calls with RNC members preparing for the Chicago meeting. ``He's in the loop on all the big decisions and strategy sessions but he's just not able to work full time,'' said GOP consultant Charles Black, who has been helping top Atwater deputy Mary Matalin run the RNC in Atwater's absence. But Atwater, 39, has been to the White House just once and to his office only once since he collapsed at a political breakfast in March. Known for his energy and zeal, Atwater now tires easily because of his exhausting medical treatment. He gets most of his information over the phone, from meetings at his house or during drives with aides and GOP political operatives. It was during a drive two weeks ago with Ed Rogers, a top White House political aide, that Atwater decided to make a surprise visit to his office. He whisked his wheelchair in for a 45-minute strategy session with Matalin, Rogers and others. Frustrated with White House handling of Bush's decision to back away from his ``no new taxes'' pledge and with Democratic attacks on GOP involvement in the savings and loan crisis, Atwater told those at the meeting that Republicans needed to be more aggressive. ``Get back on the offensive,'' one participant quoted Atwater as saying. That also was the theme recently of one of his frequent memos to White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. Few believe Atwater could have convinced Bush to hold firm on taxes, but many within the party think he would have handled the sensitive switch more deftly than did the White House. Bush was kept away from reporters for two days after the tax announcement took most Republicans by surprise and undermined GOP candidates running on ``no new taxes'' planks. ``Lee would not have sent the president into a bunker for two days,'' said an Atwater loyalist who asked not to be identified. ``It gave the impression they were trying to hide from the decision.'' Black said Atwater had put a 1990 plan in place that has allowed others to run the party in his absence with little disruption. Where Atwater is most missed, Black and others said, is in the party's relations with the press and on the fund-raising circuit. ``Everyone had come to learn to look to Lee; he was the voice of the party,'' said Matalin. Should his recovery allow it, the decision on whether to return to work full time will be Atwater's, according to party officials. His doctors believe they have stopped the tumor's growth but it could be months before they know whether aggressive radiation treatment has killed the tumor. Atwater will have to decide by the party's January meeting whether to seek a second two-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Agreements, Like Wine, Await Their Time
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS pvs 8th graf bgng, French President, to CORRECT, reading Gallic instead Gaelic. ^By RUTH SINAI
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the world's seven richest democracies struck agreements to help the Soviet Union, reduce farm supports, and stem the pollution which causes global warming. Or did they? Wednesday's final declaration of the three-day economic summit contains all these promises, and more. But, as usual, the document was heavy on the manana tactic long invoked by allies who have sharp differences but want harmony in their parting anthems. Consider this: With three of the seven nations _ the United States, Britain and Japan _ vehemently opposed to direct financial aid for the Soviets, the leaders decided to send a team of experts to study the Kremlin's economic needs and report by the end of the year. And what then? Asked whether the United States would help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev if the study recommends giving him cash, Bush replied, ``Not necessarily. But ... maybe this will lead to support.'' In deference to Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the summit set conditions for any coordinated direct aid program _ reductions in military spending and support for client states like Cuba. French President Francois Mitterrand, chafing along with Italy and West Germany about the refusal to provide direct aid, said with typical Gallic fatalism that the six-month deadline was ``the best we could hope for.'' He also dismissed the pre-conditions as ``negligible.'' Mitterrand also said the study was a good idea because it was better to fully understand Soviet needs before the West does extend cash assistance. That may be, but it hasn't stopped West Germany or Canada, which have already promised the Soviets loans and credits worth more than $5 million. Another agreement trumpeted by the leaders was compromise language designed to resolve a fight between the United State and the Europeans over farm subsidies. Bush had sought their elimination. The Europeans balked, willing only to reduce some of the supports and warning that cutting off the supports could cost up to 3 million farmers their livelihood. Each side got a little of what it wanted, but no one was fooled into thinking the problem was solved. And the real test will only begin when negotiators meet in Geneva at the end of the month to try to translate the communique language into action before the Dec. 31 deadline for completion of a global trade agreement. ``I'm not under any illusions that we'll be dealing with a new era by Christmas or even by next spring,'' was the assessment by Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. The summit communique was particularly non-committal on the question of how to deal with global warming. The leaders agreed it was a pressing problem and that the emissions believed responsible for the problem should be limited. But they declined to set limits _ basically because the Bush administration opposed the Europeans' demand _ and deferred all significant action until after a convention on climate change is reached in 1992. Reporters' suggestions of procrastination on Soviet aid, farm subsidies and the environment, drew irate reaction from the leaders at their windup news conferences. ``It's not an effort to delay anything,'' said Bush in response to a question about the study of Soviet economic needs. Margaret Thatcher suggested another interpretation. ``The greatest achievement of the summit has been to make it easier for all of us to reject short-term soft options in favor of longer-term solutions,'' she said. And what looks like procrastination to some, has some distinct advantages for Bush. By leaving wiggle room on questions like aid to the Soviet Union and China, Bush has space to maneuver with Congress _ and likely a better chance to fulfill his own foreign policy objectives. Lawmakers have made clear they wouldn't support money for Gorbachev, both for ideological reasons and because of a gaping budget deficit. They have also lashed out at any hint that Bush is trying to ease sanctions against China, imposed last year as punishment for its repression of pro-democracy reforms. But Bush has said he doesn't want China isolated, and is probably privately pleased with the policy evolving out of Japan where Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has decided to resume a $5.2 billion lending program to Beijing. Bush and the others said they wouldn't stand in the way. And West Germany, whose pockets are full and constituents are eager, is well positioned to help Gorbachev where Bush can't.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Ruth Sinai covers foreign affairs for The Associated Press in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Apes Make Courtroom Appearance in Entertainer's Defamation Trial
DOC.TEXT: Monkey business was the order of the day, much to the dismay of defense attorneys in a state judge's courtroom. Four orangutans used by entertainer Bobby Berosini in his Stardust Hotel act were bought into the courtroom Wednesday and shown to jurors as Berosini's lawsuit against People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals opened in District Court. Berosini claims PETA defamed him by secretly filming him allegedly beating the orangutans backstage at his show last year, then releasing the tape to the media. Jurors smiled and others in the crowded courtroom laughed as Berosini ran his charges through their motions, calling each orangutan to a podium to lift their arms and display themselves to the panel. But attorneys for the defendants were not as happy, claiming the appearance biased jurors by portraying the orangutans and Berosini as one big happy family. ``It was a complete zoo,'' defense attorney Daniel Foley protested to Judge Myron Leavitt. ``This was nothing but a big show for the jury.'' ``It does show that they are powerful animals but I think the jury has a right to see that too,'' Leavitt said. ``The jury has a right to see what kind of animals they are.'' A trio of defense attorneys took turns asking first for a mistrial, then for Leavitt to disqualify himself as the two sides opened what is expected to be a two-week trial. PETA attorney Phil Hirschkop claimed Leavitt was biased against the organization and should disqualify himself because he is a close friend of the operator of the Stardust Hotel, which is not a plaintiff, and took a $25,000 campaign contribution from the resort. ``I know we can't get a fair trial,'' Hirschkop said. ``We have no chance of winning in this courtroom.'' Leavitt refused to disqualify himself. ``I have no personal bias or prejudice for or against any parties in this case,'' the judge said. The appearance by the orangutans came after jurors were taken backstage at the Stardust to view the area where the secret videotape was made last summer. The videotape shows Berosini apparently striking some of the orangutans with what PETA officials claimed was a metal rod. Berosini denied abusing the animals and claims PETA ruined his career by releasing the videotape. He later was cleared by federal officials of any wrongdoing involving the orangutans. Stardust officials later said they would close the show next year after a more than three decade run, but denied it was because of the controversy.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Boat Lift Under Way
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with ships leaving; Edits to trim; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two ships were cruising toward Albania today to pick up thousands of asylum-seekers who took refuge in foreign embassies there. In order to prevent a mass exodus from the Communist nation, officials gave few details about the operation. An Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman said Wednesday that the Albanian authorities ``reserved for themselves the right to decide at the last minute'' when they will allow the ships into port. Early release of details on the boatlift could cause other Albanians to rush to get on board, and ``it would be a thing of biblical proportions,'' the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. An Italian-chartered ferry left Wednesday for Albania to carry away many of the estimated 4,000 people who clambered over embassy fences in the capital of Tirana to escape Europe's last hard-line Communist nation. The Orient Star, a Maltese boat chartered by France, set sail early today from the Greek port of Patras for Durres, Greek port authority spokesman Frangiscos Vomviras said. A third ship was also expected to sail today from southern Italy. People began seeking refuge in the embassies June 28, some braving police gunfire. Albania agreed to let them leave after conditions worsened at the compounds. Supplies of food and medicine are strained and hygienic conditions poor. The first group of 51 people to leave the country flew to Czechoslovakia on Monday. Albania has resisted the democratic reforms that swept the rest of Eastern Europe last year. Despite limited restructuring this year by Communist leader Ramiz Alia, Albania remains Europe's most backward and isolated nation. Trying to stem popular discontent, the government in the past week has replaced high-ranking officials, including several hard-liners associated with the late Communist ruler Enver Hoxha. On Wednesday, more reform was announced. The state news agency ATA said the government would allow some privatization of handicrafts and small trade. But entrepreneurs could not employ non-family members and had to register with the authorities. As part of the boatlift, the Italian-chartered ship Appia left Venice on Wednesday, carrying nine nurses and three doctors from the Red Cross, said Lino De Rosa, a director of the company that owns the ships. The French-chartered ship was carrying 44 French officials, doctors and 3{ tons of medical supplies and food, said Vomviras. It was to arrive off Durres later today then return with the refugees to the French port of Marseille. Another vessel, the Espresso Grecia, was to leave from the southern Italian city of Brindisi later today, De Rosa said. The ships were to wait in Durres harbor until the Albanians decide to let them dock, late today or early Friday, Foreign Ministry officials said. New arrivals at the embassies have dropped off dramatically since police placed a cordon around the embassy quarter this week, diplomats said. Many of the asylum-seekers in Tirana have said they eventually want to emigrate to the United States, which does not have diplomatic relations with Albania. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States has no specific quota for Albanian refugees but has a ceiling of 6,500 on refugees from Eastern Europe. So far this year, 52 Albanian refugees have resettled in the United States, Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party's New No. 2 Leader A Gorbachev Protege
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Ivashko news conference. Changes byline, dateline. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party's new No. 2 leader pledged today to push society rapidly forward, but acknowledged that some hasty moves in the past have hurt the party and the people. In his first meeting with reporters after being elected deputy to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Vladimir A. Ivashko showed himself to be a loyal and emphatic supporter of the Soviet leader's policies. Endorsed by Gorbachev, the 58-year-old Ivashko soundly defeated party traditionalist Yegor K. Ligachev on Wednesday for the newly created post of deputy secretary general. He said he only learned Tuesday he was Gorbachev's choice for deputy and has not yet had a chance to map out his exact responsibilities with the Soviet leader. The deputy secretary general is responsible for the day-to-day affairs of the party. ``I am for moving forward fast,'' Ivashko said at his first news conference. ``I see no other option. There is no way back.'' He said he would try to avoid a split in the party ranks by trying to find room for people with widely varying points of view. But Ivashko also said the party had to avoid repeating the many mistakes it made in the first years of Gorbachev's rule. ``I am against ill-conceived leaps _ forward, backwards, sideways,'' he said. ``Perestroika proves that we have made many erroneous decisions, quickly designed to solve all problems.'' Perestroika is Gorbachev's policy of economic and social restructuring. He said the 1985 drive against alcoholism, Gorbachev's first large-scale reform effort, caused ``huge moral and financial damage, and damage to the health of the people.'' The national treasury lost billions in alcohol sales and the campaign encouraged moonshiners whose low-quality brew killed and injured many people. Ivashko, an economist and engineer, also said the Soviet government should not have agreed to the demands of striking coal miners last year that it knew it could not fulfill. The miners' anger has since become more political, and on Wednesday hundreds of thousands of miners struck for one day to demand the resignation of the government, the nationalization of Communist Party property, and the removal of party organizations from mines, offices, the KGB, the army and the police. In the Donetsk coal fields of the eastern Ukraine, striking miners cheered Wednesday when they heard that Ivashko might be heading to Moscow. ``Ligachev and Ivashko are from the same regime. There's no way we can support him,'' Yuri Makarov, a Donetsk strike organizer, told a news conference. On Wednesday, before his election to the party post, Ivashko submitted his resignation as the Ukraine's president in a dispute with the republic's parliament. Miners in the Ukraine's Donetsk Basin, the Soviet Union's biggest coal-producing region, admit they don't know Ivashko well because he had only been in the Ukrainian leadership since last fall. Nevertheleass, they consider him part of the Communist Party and government apparatus that has failed to improve their living and working conditions. ``Have you been around to the stores?'' 34-year-old Anatoly Berezhnikov, who has spent 13 years in the mines, asked a reporter who sought his view of Ivashko. Without awaiting an answer, he offered: ``They're empty.'' A native of Poltava, Ivashko graduated from the Kharkov Mining Institute and joined the Communist Party in 1960. He became a candidate member of the party's Central Committee in 1986, shortly after Gorbachev came to power. Ivashko was promoted to full, voting membership in April 1989, when 110 mostly elderly conservatives were retired. Earlier that year, top Communists picked Ivashko for one of the party's 100 guaranteed seats in the new Congress of People's Deputies. In December, Ivashko became a member of the Soviet Communist Party's Politburo. He resigned the party leadership of the Ukraine this spring after he was elected president of the republic.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Attorney General Pleads Innocent to Theft Charge
DOC.TEXT: The Arkansas attorney general has been charged with billing more than $8,000 in personal entertainment expenses to the state. Attorney General Steve Clark pleaded innocent to a charge of theft by deception filed Wednesday. He withdrew as a Democratic gubernatorial candidate in February after he was told his expense reports were being investigated. ``My only statement is, I am innocent of the charge against me and I do not to intend to resign,'' Clark said after a brief court appearance. Clark, 43, was released on $2,500 bond. He is not seeking re-election to the office he has held since 1979. Little Rock Municipal Judge Marion Humphrey ruled there was probable cause to charge Clark. The ruling was based on a 55-page affidavit submitted by Pulaski County Prosecutor Chris Piazza on Tuesday. It included state police interviews with dozens of people listed by Clark on his expense forms. Those people told police either they didn't eat with Clark or didn't discuss state business. The charge against Clark carries a maximum penalty of five to 20 years in jail and a $15,000 fine. The affidavit listed 56 instances when Clark reportedly charged the state for private meals. The state was billed at least $8,448.27 for 86 inappropriate claims, according to the affidavit. Clark said in January the errors were made when he tried to itemize his expenses months later. He blamed the discrepancies on sloppy bookkeeping. The attorney general is not required by state law to itemize his expense claims; Clark said he wanted to be more accountable.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed in Nagorno-Karabakh Gunbattle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lede to specify that soldiers were Soviet.
DOC.TEXT: Armenian militants attacked a convoy of vehicles in a disputed region of Azerbaijan, and three people were killed in a gunfight between the militants and Soviet soldiers, the Tass news agency reported today. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, informed of the attack while presiding over the 28th Communist Party Congress in Moscow, told delegates that ethnic bloodshed in the region must come to an end. Tass said the convoy of 16 trucks and a bus carrying Azerbaijani passengers was attacked near the village of Charektar in Nagorno-Karabakh, the mostly Christian Armenian enclave that is located in and administered by Azerbaijan. It said heavily armed Armenian militants stopped the convoy, guarded by five busloads of Interior Ministry troops, and fired point-blank at the trucks and bus. The soldiers returned the fire, Tass said. The news agency said two people died in the exchange of fire and a woman passenger on the bus later died in a hospital of gunshot wounds. The report did not say if the two people who died immediatedly were militants or soldiers. The attackers fled, leaving behind six hand grenades, three radio transmitters and explosives, Tass said. Gorbachev read out the report on the shootoout, then said that Azerbaijani delegates to the congress were justified in their demand that the Soviet leadership ``put a stop to the outrage of unlawfulness and bloodshed.'' He expressed condolences to the victims' families and called on the leadership of Azerbaijan, which is mostly Moslem, and Armenia to ``vigorously participate in the effort to normalize the situation in the region.'' However, Gorbachev rejected an Azerbaijani request to put the issue of Nagorno-Karabakh up for debate by the Congress. ``There is no need to debate it now,'' he said. At least 200 people have died in ethnic violence that has wracked the two Caucasus Mountain republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan for the past two years. The dispute is centered on control of Nagorno-Karabakh.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Official Says Germany Aims To Take Over Europe; His Ouster Demanded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Mrs. Thatcher speaking to Commons. Pickup 7th, `Ridley was...'
DOC.TEXT: A senior member of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet said today he regretted calling West Germany's government ``uppity'' and saying its economic policy was intended to ``take over the whole of Europe.'' In a magazine interview that provoked widespread demands for his resignation, Trade and Industry Secretary Nicholas Ridley also compared the European Community to Adolf Hitler. Mrs. Thatcher, speaking at a rowdy session in the House of Commons this afternoon, said Ridley's remarks did not reflect government policy nor her own views, but she rebuffed demands for his dismissal. ``On reflection, I very much regret the remarks reported in The Spectator and unreservedly withdraw them,'' Ridley said in a one-sentence statement issued by his department in London. In Bonn, West Germany, Lutz Stavenhagen, a high-ranking aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said the attacks were ``scandalous.'' By accusing Germany of seeking to dominate Europe, Lutz said, Ridley ``discredits the entire European Community.'' Ridley was in Budapest today with a British trade mission. In the interview, Ridley condemned what he called the ``breath-taking arrogance'' of the European Community. ``I'm not against giving up sovereignty in principle, but not to this lot. You might just as well give it to Adolf Hitler, frankly,'' he told the Spectator magazine in an interview published today. ``This rushed takeover by the Germans on the worst possible basis, with the French behaving like poodles to the Germans, is absolutely intolerable,'' Ridley was quoted as saying. The magazine's cover carried a cartoon of Ridley painting a Hitler mustache on a portrait of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Several members of the British and European parliaments demanded this morning that Mrs. Thatcher remove Ridley from the Cabinet. ``I think the prime minister has no choice to but ask him to resign,'' said Hugh Dykes, a Conservative Party member in the House of Commons. ``Unless Mrs. Thatcher gets rid of him today, one can only take it that she secretly endorses his attitude,'' said Gerald Kaufman, the opposition Labor Party's spokesman on foreign affairs. In Strasbourg, France, leaders of the European Parliament's 180-strong Socialist group, the largest in the 518-seat body, sent a letter to Thatcher demanding Ridley's resignation. In the interview, Ridley said the West German government's support for European monetary union ``is all a German racket designed to take over the whole of Europe. It has to be thwarted. Mrs. Thatcher and fellow Conservatives like Ridley have been reluctant to go along with European Community moves toward full political and economic integration, fearing a loss of control over domestic policy. Following Ridley's remark about Hitler, Spectator editor Dominic Lawson suggested Kohl was much less threatening. ``He's not going to bomb us, after all,'' Lawson said. Ridley reportedly replied: ``I'm not sure I wouldn't rather have ... er ... the shelters and the chance to fight back, than simply being taken over by ... economics. He'll soon be coming here and trying to say that this is what we should do on the banking front and this is what our taxes should be. I mean, he'll soon be trying to take over everything.'' Ridley was asked if his views were colored by the fact that, at age 61, he could remember World War II. ``Jolly good thing too,'' Ridley was quoted as replying. ``About time somebody said that. It was pretty nasty. Only two months ago I was in Auschwitz, Poland. Next week I'm in Czechoslovakia. You ask them what they think about the Second World War. It's useful to remember.'' Britain's historic role had been to play the balance of power in Europe, Ridley said, ``and never has it been more necessary than now, with Germany so uppity.'' In his remarks Ridley criticized the 17 members of the European Commission, which governs the European Community. ``Seventeen unelected reject politicians with no accountability to anybody, who are not responsible for raising taxes, just spending money, who are pandered to by a supine parliament which also is not responsible for raising taxes, already behaving with an arrogance I find breathtaking _ the idea that one says `OK, we'll give this lot our sovereignty,' is unacceptable to me.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Salvadoran Death Squad Member-Turned-Informer Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Immigration officials have arrested a man seeking political asylum as an informer on the death squads linked to the murders of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador. Cesar Vielman Joya Martinez was arrested by Immigration and Naturalization Service agents on a felony warrant for failing to appear in court on an immigration charge, INS spokesman Ron Rogers said Wednesday. Joya, 28, is a former member of the Salvadoran First Infantry Brigade's intelligence unit and a self-described ex-member of the unit's death squad. Joya said a member of the intelligence unit was one of nine soldiers charged with murdering six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter in San Salvador in November, the London Observer reported last month. The slayings occurred during an offensive in the capital by leftist guerrillas fighting the U.S.-supported government. Joya was deported after illegally entering the United States in 1983, said his lawyer, David Carliner, in Washington, D.C. Joya returned to the United States in July 1989. He has applied for political asylum and has briefed members of Congress and human rights activists on the Salvadoran brigade's alleged assassinations, Carliner said. ``He said he was in danger of being killed by members of his own death squad because he bungled a job that came to public attention,'' the attorney said. Joya was arrested on Tuesday by INS agents and city police, Rogers said. He was indicted last month on a felony charge of illegally re-entering the country. The warrant for his arrest was issued after he failed to heed an order to appear in court, Rogers said. Carliner said that Joya never received the summons. Joya could face a jail term if convicted but cannot be deported until his application for political asylum is resolved, Carliner said. A decision is expected by July 20, and an appeal could allow Joya to stay in the country for up to three years, the attorney said. More than 70,000 people, most of them civilians, have been killed in the 10-year Salvadoran civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Messenger Charged in Mysterious `Dartman' Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with details from news conference, name of suspect, charges, police giving new number of attacks.
DOC.TEXT: A messenger with a criminal record and psychiatric problems was charged today with three of 55 dart-blowing attacks that have unnerved women in midtown Manhattan, police said. Jerome Wright, 33, of the Bronx was arrested after being identified in a lineup by three women on Wednesday night, police said. He was charged with three counts each of reckless endangerment, criminal possession of a weapon and harassment. Chief Joseph DiMartino said Wright was suspected in the other attacks, but was charged only in the cases in which women identified him. Two plainclothes officers stopped Wright on a street corner Tuesday because he fit the description of the man who has been blowing homemade needle darts at the backsides of well-dressed women. DiMartino, head of Manhattan detectives, said the officers took Wright's name and address and passed it on to detectives who persuaded Wright to come in for questioning Wednesday. DiMartino said Wright admitted to the three attacks he was charged with, but didn't have a clear motive. ``Mr. Wright has made numerous statements to us, none of which has given us real insight into why he is doing this,'' DiMartino said at a news conference. The chief said Wright ``indicated to us he has been under observation for psychiatric problems.'' He did not elaborate. Wright, who is on probation until 1992 for a drug conviction, ``works in the area as a messenger and mail room clerk, which puts him on the streets during the day,'' DiMartino said. At least 55 women have reported feeling the sting of the so-called Dartman's needle darts since June 26. A majority of the attacks took place in the Penn Station and Times Square area, many at lunchtime. Eighteen darts were recovered and tests showed none was tainted. None of the women suffered serious physical injury but the odd attacks had women looking over their shoulders for several weeks.
