DOC.HEAD: Witness Says Mayor Refused Medical Testing
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry refused routine medical testing when he was rushed to a hospital for shortness of breath after using cocaine at a 1987 Super Bowl party, an advertising executive who has been a friend of the mayor testified today. Jeffrey Mitchell, who said he loves Barry ``like a brother,'' also detailed seven instances in which he said he and Barry used cocaine together. He also described other instances of drug use with the mayor. At the Super Bowl party, Barry and Mitchell drank cognac and champagne and smoked marijuana together before Barry and a female visitor disappeared into a bedroom of the private home they were staying in, Mitchell said. ``I next saw him in the living room, sitting in a chair with his head back ... he was clearing his nose, sniffing,'' said Mitchell. ``I asked him if he was okay, because he had his head back and he looked uncomfortable. ...He said he was having trouble breathing.'' Mitchell said he led Barry outside for some fresh air, but the mayor's breathing troubles continued and he was taken to a hospital. ``He said he felt like he was going to faint,'' Mitchell said. At the hospital, Barry felt better after being given oxygen in the emergency room, Mitchell said. ``He didn't want any tests,'' Mitchell said. ``He felt better and wanted to leave.'' Mitchell then testified that he called Lloyd Moore, another Barry friend, and told him what had happened. ``I kind of suggested that he (Barry) might have gotten ahold of some bad stuff,'' Mitchell said he told Moore. Moore, who testified Wednesday, said he and Mitchell had worked frantically to cover up Barry's cocaine use in Los Angeles. ``Jeff basically had taken charge,'' Moore said of the telephone call he had with Mitchell. ``He told me how he got the mayor to the hospital, what tests he allowed them to take. He would not let them take a blood test.'' Back in Washington, Barry's office said the mayor had received treatment for the flareup of a hiatal hernia. Moore, who testified that he supplied cocaine to Barry on several occasions, said Mitchell told him that Barry was afraid he became ill after using cocaine ``laced with something.'' Barry had been ``very sick. ... They thought he was going to die,'' Moore said Mitchell reported to him. Mitchell, who heads his own BMY Inc. advertising agency, is the subject of an FBI investigation into allegations that he bribed Bahamian officials in 1987 with money from Barry and other witnesses in the trial, The Washington Post and The Washington Times reported today. The Post, quoting law enforcement sources, said authorities were trying to determine whether Mitchell paid $40,000 to secure a contract to manage advertising space at Nassau International Airport. The Times, quoting Norman Beebe, a partner in Mitchell's advertising company, said the bribe was paid to close friends of Bahamian Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling. Beebe also told the Times that Mitchell told him Barry contributed $5,000 of the alleged bribe. One of the 14 charges against Barry accuses him of conspiring to conceal his cocaine use. Moore testified that he and Barry used cocaine together at Moore's home about a half-dozen times from May 1986 to March 1987 and that the mayor used cocaine by himself at Moore's home on three or so other occasions. He said he gave Barry cocaine ``a couple of times,'' each time in an amount worth about $50. ``Thirteen times you saw the defendant use or possess cocaine in your home?'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts asked. ``That is correct,'' Moore replied. Moore, who practices law in Washington, was appointed by Barry to the District of Columbia Boxing Commission and Commission on the Arts and Humanities.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Kills One, Forces Hundreds to Evacuate Tourist Riviera
DOC.TEXT: A forest fire whipped by overnight wind Thursday killed one person and forced hundreds of people to flee their homes and tourist camps in a region near this Adriatic summer resort. The fire broke out Wednesday near a campsite for vacationers in Kupari, about six miles south of Dubrovnik. It quickly spread toward this exclusive tourist resort, eyewitnesses said. Special firefighting aircraft and and hundreds of rescuers rushed to the area on the southern Adriatic coast, where at least 300 people, mostly tourists, were forced to evacuate homes, camps and hotels, radio reports said. The Tanjug news agency said the unidentified victim of the blaze took part in the firefighting operation. The cause of the fire was being investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Plant Back On Line After Valve Leak
DOC.TEXT: A nuclear plant went back on line Thursday, four days after it was ordered closed due to a valve leak that filled the containment building with radioactive steam. Vandellos II, one of the newest of Spain's nine operating nuclear plants, was connected to the national electrical grid at 4:13 a.m. after an eight-hour warm start, according to a spokesman for the plant's owner. The Nuclear Security Commission authorized the start-up Wednesday evening after completing a technical study of the accident, which did not release any radiation into the air. A commission spokeswoman said the leak was caused by a faulty joint in a flow-meter on a line where the temperature of steam in one of the plant's main refrigeration units is measured.

DOC.HEAD: Hitler, Goering To Be Stripped Of Honorary Citizenship
With AM-Britain-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Adolf Hitler and Hermann Goering will lose their honorary citizenship of Potsdam if a City Hall proposal is approved next month, the East German news agency ADN reported Thursday. The Nazi dictator and his air force chief were awarded the honor in 1933, but it was never revoked because of a 57-year administrative mess and the ousted Communist leadership's fear of causing a public scandal, ADN said. Records showed officials assumed shortly after World War II that the issue had been settled under decrees issued by the Soviet military administrators of what is now East Germany. However, those Red Army decrees on ``de-Nazification'' made no specific mention of the honorary citizenships, the agency said. ``When the problem finally came to light in the city council in 1988, the matter was quietly relegated to the archives,'' ADN said. Hitler committed suicide during the April 1945 Red Army siege of Berlin. Goering killed himself in 1946, shortly before his scheduled execution in Nuremberg for war crimes. Erwin Motzkus, mayor of this city on Berlin's southwestern outskirts, recommended that Potsdam councilors revoke the honorary citizenships during their next session on Aug. 15, ADN said. Last week, the East German city of Rostock revoked the honorary citizen title it had bestowed on Hitler, ADN reported. The action came after the new city council, elected in Rostock's first democratic elections in May, appointed a committee to investigate the city's list of honorary citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Worker Fired For Communist Party T-shirt
DOC.TEXT: A factory worker was fired for wearing a Communist Party T-shirt to work, a news agency reported Thursday. Henry Beerwinkel, 19, said he had been fired from a Cape Town plastics factory for wearing a T-shirt bearing the slogan ``Freedom, Socialism, Peace'' and a picture of South African Communist Party leader Joe Slovo. Beerwinkel, a general worker at Fabricated Plastics, was warned after he had worn the T-shirt to work several times, the independent South African Press Association said. Factory manager Louis Avenant said the company ruled in February that no clothes representing any political party should be worn at work. ``We like to call the company neutral. We are here to work,'' Avenant said. President F.W. de Klerk legalized the South African Communist Party, the African National Congress and other organizations on Feb. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill Two Leftist Radicals, Capture Two Others
DOC.TEXT: Police today shot and killed two armed leftist radicals who barricaded themselves inside a house in a residential district of Istanbul, officials said. Two other radicals were captured by police during the raid. A police statement said security officials discovered three handguns, one hand grenade and material for making bombs in the house. Officials said the four people belonged to an outlawed Marxist-Leninist organization _ the ``Revolutionary Communist Party-Armed People's Units'' _ a little known group believed to be about a year old. Members of the group have been sought since March for their suspected role in an Istanbul shootout that left one policeman dead and two wounded. The semi-official Anatolia news agency said police acting on a tip surrounded the house and ordered those inside to surrender. Police opened fire after they were fired upon. The news agency identified the dead as Alper Ersoy, a man, and Gulay Arici, a woman. Two others, Ali Cinar and Veyis Deprem, both men, were captured. A wave of terrorism in late 1970s claimed 5,000 lives in Turkey and triggered a military takeover in 1980 that lasted three years.

DOC.HEAD: Kollek Gets Retroactive Permit To Take Art Works Out Of France
DOC.TEXT: Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek retroactively won permission to take 103 works by painter Marc Chagall out of France, the mayor's spokeswoman said Thursday. Kollek had carried the drawings, gouaches and an oil painting out of France in four suitcases in April without getting the necessary exit permits. When French authorities complained to Kollek, he returned the works to the French Consulate in Jerusalem, Kollek spokeswoman Bonnie Boxer said. ``The procedures that should have taken place before the works left France took place in Jerusalem on French soil,'' Ms. Boxer said. ``Once the legal proceedings were completed, the works were returned to us.'' She said Kollek had been unaware that he needed an exit permit for the art works, which were a bequest to the Israel Museum by Chagall's daughter Ida, a Paris resident. Chagall, who was born in Russia in 1887, settled in France in 1923 and died in 1985. Much of his work dealt with Jewish subjects. The drawings bequeathed to the Israel Museum include a sketch for one of his wall tapestries, which hangs in Israel's Parliament, and an image of King David playing the harp.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Ends Strike in Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 12th graf, `A public...' with 2 grafs to ADD figures for average salary, inflation. Pickup 13th graf, `The latest...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA1
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for the government and striking unions agreed early today to end a strike that tore up city streets, brought commerce to a halt and left at least six people dead. The accord was signed by negotiators for President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and the Sandinista-led National Workers' Front, ending the biggest challenge so far to Mrs. Chamorro's 10-week-old government. The strike took hold July 2 and spread through most government ministries and many state businesses. Strike leaders claimed 90,000 took part. The Sandinistas, who left office April 25 after a February defeat at the polls, remain the largest single political force in Nicaragua. In its settlement, the government agreed to suspend a decree permitting the return of confiscated lands to previous owners. It also agreed to a 43 percent salary raise in July and another increase of undetermined size for August. Under the pact, public sector workers fired since Mrs. Chamorro took office April 25 will be paid and there will be no retribution against the strikers. The Sandinistas had opposed the layoffs ordered by the U.S.-backed government, which is trying to cut the budget deficit and nurse back to health an economy ravaged by a decade of war and U.S. trade sanctions. Opposition was also strong in the country of 3.7 million people to government plans to sell many of the properties the Sandinistas confiscated and nationalized after coming to power in a 1979 popular revolution. The strike closed the international airport, cut electricity and water service, limited telephone and mail delivery, reduced gasoline supplies and shut down factories and businesses. It was the second major strike, and the most violent, in Mrs. Chamorro's administration. At least six people were reported killed and 100 injured in fighting between strikers and government supporters since Friday. On Wednesday, barricade-building and gun-fighting in the streets of Managua that had occurred in recent days appeared to have subsided. There were no large crowds out at night as earlier in the week. A public sector strike in May resulted in 100 percent raises and other important concessions. The raises helped offset high inflation in Nicaragua, where the average worker's salary is only about $100 a month. The minimum salary is about $20 a month, and inflation was officially listed at 124.7 percent for the month of June. The latest strike was initially called to protest the firings of government workers and to demand a voice in government economic policy, which they say favors the wealthy under the new government. Those demands were met in part through the indemnification and the land redistribution issue. The government had proclaimed the strike illegal, claiming it was politically motivated. Workers were returning to their jobs today. The streets of many neighborhoods remained torn up where Sandinista backers had used the paving stones for barricades. The unions that called the strikes, the army and police are all loyal to the leftist Sandinistas, who ruled the country for a decade until their February loss at the polls. The U.S. economic embargo that helped create shortages even in basic foodstuffs, contributed to their defeat. Mrs. Chamorro won with the backing of a 14-party coalition that ranged from far right to Communist, and had little more in common than a distaste for the Sandinistas. The U.S. trade sanctions and a nine-war against the U.S.-supported Contra rebels devastated the economy before Mrs. Chamorro took office, and her reconstruction efforts have stirred resentment and opposition. Talks got under way Wednesday night with Antonio Lacayo, a son-in-law and close aide of Mrs. Chamorro, representing the government and Sandinista Labor Center leader Lucio Jimenez heading the union team.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BOISE
Nation's Last Known Crank Telephone System Gives Way to Technology
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with switch made, quotes. Picks up 6th graf, `The fate...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto IDA1
DOC.TEXT: The nation's last known hand-crank party line was disconnected today when residents of central Idaho's rugged Salmon River canyon received private-line, touch-tone service. ``It's sure nice,'' country store owner Garry Pedrow said in answering the first incoming call. ``I'm not screaming anymore.'' Public Utilities Commission President Joe Miller made the first call out from Pedrow's store to Gary C. Byrne, administrator of the Rural Electrification Administration, which financed the switch. The depression-era system had grown familiar, and residents greeted the change with mixed emotions. ``I hate to see the historical value of it leave, but as far as being in business it's hard to communicate on this line!'' Pedrow yelled into the mouthpiece Wednesday. Pedrow's Shoup Country Store is near North Fork, about 200 miles northeast of Boise. He and 17 year-round neighbors depended on the magneto-operated system and switchboard operator Steve Freestone to talk to each other and the outside world. At first, they resisted efforts to do away with the phones. But eventually they agreed the convenience of modern private-line, touch-tone service was more important. The new system, which required 40 miles of underground cable laid over several months, made an immediate difference. ``It sounds great,'' said Joyce Rinehart at the Ramshead motel and restaurant. ``Now that I know it's working, I'm going to call my mother back in Iowa.'' ``Everybody's got a list a mile long of people they want to call,'' said David Hobson, a technician who worked on the modernization project. The fate of the old system was cast a year ago when AT&T announced that computerization would force elimination of the switchboard operator. Freestone operates the switchboard from his Motel Deluxe in Salmon, about 20 miles from the canyon. The residents along 34 miles of the canyon used the system like an intercom to talk among themselves without help, but Freestone was their link beyond the wilderness. He placed outgoing calls and fielded incoming ones, directing calls to the right customers through a system of coded rings. Pedrow's store, for instance, was three longs. ``They're sad to see the last crank phone system being taken out, but they're glad to get better service,'' Freestone said. ``That line's been so bad. It's a raggedy old thing. They've got it nailed to trees and mountains. Most of the time you have to yell pretty loud to talk to people down river.'' The system originally was set up by the U.S. Forest Service in 1931 and was sold to a cooperative for $1 in 1952. In their heyday, such wall-mounted phones _ consisting of a black metal mouthpiece on an arm and a receiver hung on a two-prong hook _ represented the communications heart of as many as 1.2 million American farms and ranches. A crank on the right side rang bells along the line. An operator could be reached with persistent cranking. Each customer was to answer just his own coded ring while ignoring the rest. But party line chatter, with two or three people talking and several more secretly listening, was a popular rural recreation, long before electricity, television and even radio. A ``line call'' of continuous ringing was often used to alert families of emergencies like approaching storms, tornadoes or forest fires. The crank phones fit in well with the lifestyle in the isolated canyon, where residents need generators for electricity and have only seasonal running water. ``In the beginning some of the people said they didn't want to lose the crank system,'' said Mike Martell of Rural Telephone Co., who coordinated cable-laying for the new system. ``There were a few ideas and they weren't even feasible. ... But the people are real happy now. They're ready to get off the old system.'' Pedrow's wife, Peggy, agreed. ``Once it's gone, it's gone forever,'' she said. ``But at this point right now, I guess I'm ready because I can't hear anything on it.''

DOC.HEAD: Indians Dig In After Police Raid At Disputed Site
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with police adding reinforcements, Mohawk reservations sending aid, ADDS name of slain police officer. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Mohawk warriors dug trenches and reinforced barricades with crushed police cars today, one day after fighting a gun battle with police over a golf course addition the Indians say encroaches on tribal land. A police officer was shot and killed Wednesday morning when the 4-month-old dispute between Mohawks and officials from this town near Montreal escalated into a shootout. Both sides accused each other of opening fire first. About 100 police moved to dismantle a barricade of cement blocks and barbed wire the Indians had built on an access road to the disputed land. However, the police were driven back during an exchange of gunfire with 200 armed Mohawks wearing war paint. Officials were unsure whether the slain police officer, Cpl. Marcel Lemay, 31, was shot by a Mohawk or a fellow policeman. After the fight, the Indians dug defensive trenches with a commandeered earth mover and brought in reinforcements from other reservations. They patrolled the edge of the golf course in stolen golf carts, preparing for another attack. Down the hill, dozens of police wearing flack jackets and carrying shotguns patrolled their new sandbagged positions reinforced with concrete blocks. During the night, police brought in hundreds of additional officers. The Mohawks claim title to a small pine forest the leaders of Oka, a picturesque town 18 miles west of Montreal, want to cut down so the golf course can add nine holes. The police had intervened at the request of Oka's mayor. The Mohawks said late Wednesday that Quebec Security Minister Sam Elkas had promised them police would not attack during the night or this morning unless they were fired on first. Several Mohawks confirmed late Wednesday that Mohawk warriors from the Kahnawake reserve, south of Montreal, and the Akwesasne reserve south of Cornwall, Ontario, had arrived as reinforcements. No figures were immediately available. ``I know that if they (police) come in we'll be ready for them,'' said Harvey, a Mohawk who declined to give his last name. The Indians took advantage of the police retreat to seize four police cars and two vans, then used the commandeered earth mover to crush the vehicles, forming a barricade on a hill across the main highway through the region. Their position overlooked a police roadblock at the bottom of the hill.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Condition Improves; He Receives Visitors
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, who arrived with a slight case of pneumonia, was reported in better condition and even received visitors Thursday, ANC and government officials said. ``He is up and about and has received several guests today,'' said a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He declined to name the visitors or say how many Mandela received, saying only: ``Believe me. He is much better.'' In other developments, the wives of seven prominent Kenyans, four of whose husbands recently were detained without charge for criticizing the government, pleaded with Mandela to intervene on their behalf and urge President Daniel arap Moi to free the men. ``What is even more painful than the imprisonment of the black man by the white man is the unjustified imprisonment of the black man by the black man,'' the wives said in a one-page letter to Mandela. Mandela, who is a guest at Moi's official residence, arrived Wednesday following four days of violence in which at least 28 people were killed. The fighting was sparked by a weekend pro-democracy rally dispersed by security forces with guns and tear gas after demonstrators attacked a police officer. Mandela was scheduled to leave Saturday for Mozambique, the last leg of a grueling six-week tour through North America, Europe and Africa. He plans to return to South Africa in time for his 72nd birthday July 18. Njuguna Mahugu, the foreign ministry's chief of protocol, refused to comment on reports that Mandela had sought hospital treatment Wednesday. Mandela, 71, arrived in Kenya from Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, one day earlier than planned, and ANC officials in South Africa said the change was prompted by a slight case of pneumonia. ``All medical reports we have received indicate that comrade Mandela is comfortable and is expected to be able to resume his duties within a few days,'' said the ANC statement released in Johannesburg. Concerns about Mandela's health have arisen previously, and he has had to postpone or cancel several events due to fatigue. He underwent surgery in June to have a benign cyst removed from his bladder and doctors have expressed concern about his heart. Mandela was jailed for 27 years for opposing South Africa's white-led government. In 1988, he was hospitalized for tuberculosis.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Host Bans Blacks From Calling Talk Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with host suspension, station apology; picks up 5th graf pvs, ``The Rev. Abraham.''
DOC.TEXT: A radio station today suspended a talk-show host who banned black listeners from speaking on his show because a station employee's car was broken into and her purse stolen, allegedly by a black man. Berkley Fraser, manager of WERC-AM, went on the air with his apology and said Tim Lennox was being suspended indefinitely after this afternoon's show to give the station time to review the situation. ``We encourage free expression with live programming, and unfortunately mistakes do occur,'' said Fraser. Callers to ``The Tim Lennox Show'' Wednesday were asked their race before being allowed to talk on the air, Lennox said. He said he took the action after he described the theft to listeners and reported that a black man was a suspect. Callers talked about their experiences as victims of crime and how to avoid becoming a victim, but nearly half were critical of Lennox for banning blacks, the Birmingham Post-Herald reported. The Rev. Abraham Woods, president of the Birmingham chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said he would demand an apology from Lennox. ``That was uncalled-for action on his part,'' Woods said. ``It really bordered on stupidity in this day and time.'' Lennox said he could not explain his action. ``On the spur of the moment, I said, `Let's not take calls from any blacks,''' he said. ``It was interesting, the reaction to it,'' said Lennox, who has worked in radio for 15 years. ``I had my boss sticking his head in the door. ... If nothing else, it says something about the racial sensitivity.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Prime Minister Arrives in Atlanta
LaserPhoto AX1
DOC.TEXT: Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu visited the tomb of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and met briefly today with the slain civil rights leader's widow. Kaifu and his wife, Sachiyo, stood together after he placed a wreath of pink and red carnations, purple daisies and burgundy chrysanthemums on King's grave. He made no public comments during the ceremony and reporters were not allowed at a short meeting later between Kaifu and Coretta Scott King. American civil rights advocates were outraged four years ago when then-Prime Minister Nasuhiro Nakasone said blacks and Hispanics lowered U.S. intelligence standards. Steve Klein, research associate at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change, said civil rights leaders appreciated Kaifu's gesture. ``He's a new prime minister,'' Klein said. ``We can't hold him responsible for what others have said.'' Kaifu was to deliver a speech Thursday night outlining a broad cultural exchange project and encouraging cooperation between Japan and the United States, said Stephen Allen, public relations officer for the Japanese Consulate in Atlanta. Kaifu has made few public remarks since he arrived in Georgia Wednesday night but told The Atlanta Journal-Constitution in a written statement that ``the American Southeast has long had good relations with Japan, and this region is today home to about 600 Japanese companies ... (that) contribute to the region's economic development. ``I am hoping to have the chance to meet with some of these corporate leaders, and I will take the opportunity to encourage them to fit in with their local communities as good corporate citizens,'' he said. Kaifu planned brief meetings today with local Japanese business leaders as well as a private meeting with Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris and Govs. James Martin of North Carolina and Bill Clinton of Arkansas. He began his 37-hour visit to Georgia after attending the economic summit in Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Cold War's End, French Keep Ambitious Military Goals
DOC.TEXT: Unswayed by visions of a ``peace dividend,'' France has declared its intent to field Western Europe's strongest army and retain an independent nuclear arsenal based on the deterrence strategy of the Cold War. Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement, a Socialist admired by conservatives, has rejected demands for spending cuts and says France should never again retreat into the defensive, passive strategies that led to its defeat in World War II. On Saturday, the pride of the French army _ 7,000 soldiers from elite units, 340 armored vehicles and scores of warplanes and combat helicopters _ are scheduled to march, roll and fly over the Champs-Elysees in celebration of Bastille Day. There are no plans for counter-demonstrations _ France never experienced the anti-nuclear protests that mushroomed throughout Western Europe in the mid-1980s _ but there are signs of some cracks in the longstanding consensus on military policy. The Finance Ministry and the governing Socialists' left wing are asking for substantial military spending cuts to reflect the collapse of Soviet-backed regimes in Eastern Europe and the reduced threat from Moscow. Chevenement has also become a prime target for some elements of the press. Le Canarde Enchaine, a satirical weekly, carried a front-page cartoon this week showing French and Soviet generals each shouting: ``We don't want to disarm.'' The cartoon also featured Chevenement devising a solution _ a ``Disneyland with real bullets'' in which the two armies can blast away at each other to their hearts' content. Francois Heisbourg, a Frenchman who is director of the London-based International Institute of Strategic Studies, said France, unlike its allies, ``has a basic unwillingness to consider major choices in restructuring its forces.'' France waged the wrong kind of war in 1940, Heisbourg said in a telephone interview, ``and we may now being fighting the wrong kind of peace.'' An example, he said, was France's decision to press ahead with the development of the short-range Hades nuclear missile even though its range extends no farther than Germany. Chevenement has refused to join optimistic assessments that the world is becoming a safer place. He foresees a dangerous strategic vacuum developing in Europe over the next five years, with the specter of instability, cross-border ethnic violence, and potentially virulent nationalism. France, he said last weekend, ``must maintain all its capabilities.'' Foremost in the French military arsenal is the independent nuclear force that has been preserved and improved by all French leaders since the 1960s. France has insisted on maintaining total sovereignty over its nuclear strategy and has refused to endorse the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's recent declaration that it would use nuclear weapons only as a last resort. Despite the crumbling of the Warsaw Pact, France is sticking by its Cold War policy of nuclear deterrence. According to military headquarters, this requires the ability to ``inflict damage on the aggressor's population and industrial capacity damage at least equal to that suffered by France.'' The nuclear arsenal is tested and upgraded regularly, and consumes an estimated one-third of all money spent on defense equipment. The French army maintains a force of about 470,000 soldiers, sailors and airmen. France produces most of its own armaments and is the world's No. 3 weapons exporter. France also aspires to a global military role. It guards territories in the Caribbean, the Indian Ocean and the South Pacific, deploys more than 6,000 soldiers in Africa under bilateral treaties, has sent warships on relief missions to Lebanon, and recently established a joint France-German brigade in West Germany. Although a strong advocate of European unity, President Francois Mitterrand, president since 1981, has rejected suggestions that France return to the integrated military structure of NATO. Chevenement has not been totally inflexible. Last weekend he said 35,000 soldiers would be trimmed from the military by 1995 and offered to consider reducing mandatory military service from 12 months to 10. But he balked at reconsidering major weapons programs or making major cuts in the proposed 1991 defense budget of $36 billion _ 3.5 percent of the gross domestic product and about 16 percent of the total national budget. Such an expense, Chevenement said, ``is a small price to pay for freedom.''

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Patient's Trees Destroyed
DOC.TEXT: A 42-year-old man with AIDS wanted to leave something behind when he died, so in April he planted 15 trees in a city park. He recently discovered 11 were destroyed. Philip Risko said he found that city workers five weeks ago had leveled or bent the 4- to-6-foot saplings while mowing to cut grass and weeds. ``It was heartbreaking,'' he said. He said city workers told him they saw the trees but did not have instructions to take the extra time to mow around them. He complained to the city but was told he needed a permit to plant anything in a city park. William Darnell, supervisor of forestry and landscape for the Parks and Recreation Department, said it was likely the workers would knock over the trees because they were not supposed to be planted. ``All we can say is there's nothing we can say,'' Darnell said. ``Thank you, but that wasn't the way to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Train Hits Van Loaded With Children, Three Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Three adults...', with outing to an amusement park sted at; INSERTS one graf after 6th, `A witness...', to UPDATE with driver surviving, victims related. Picks up 7th graf, `Eight passengers...'.
DOC.TEXT: A van loaded with children was crushed when it drove into the path of a train, authorities said. Two children and a 25-year-old woman were killed. Three adults and five children remained hospitalized today in serious or critical condition. They were on a family outing to an amusement park. The engineer of the 65-car Southern Pacific train tried to warn the driver as she approached the crossing Wednesday evening, said railroad company spokesman Jim Johnson. ``According to the engineer, he was blowing his horn and ringing his bell when he saw the van approach...,'' Johnson said. ``She never stopped.'' The engineer threw on his emergency brakes, but the train hit the van broadside, crushing it and flipping it, Johnson and rescue workers said. ``A witness reported the van was eastbound on Stagecoach Road and drove into the path of the northbound freight train,'' said Sgt. Mike Middleton. Caddo Parish sheriff's deputies said the driver survived but they have not been able to interview her because of her injuries. Investigators said the victims were related. Eight passengers were thrown from the van, and three were pinned in the wreckage, said Thurman Speaks, chief of Fire District 6. Killed were Sandra Stultz and her 18-month-old daughter, Hannah, of Texarkana, Ark., and 8-year-old Amy Gray of Taylor, Ark. The railroad crossing south of this northwest Louisiana city was equipped with a crossing warning sign and a stop sign.

DOC.HEAD: Baby's Birth Time: 12:34:56 7-8-90
DOC.TEXT: Michelle McKenna's new baby boy has great timing _ John Patrick McKenna was born 12:34:56 7-8-90. Michelle and Brian McKenna's newborn son was delivered at 12:34 and 56 seconds on Sunday morning, July 8, '90 _ giving him the perfect string of consecutive numbers. The McKennas of Marlboro aren't numerologists. But while Mrs. McKenna was preparing for the delivery at Leonard Morse Hospital on Saturday afternoon, her husband watched a television news program that carried a piece on the unusual digital occasion. He told his wife and suggested she concentrate on 12:34:56 as a goal. ``That's great; that'll be a great focal point,'' Mrs. McKenna recalled. Mrs. McKenna said she lost track time around 11 p.m., because ``I was in too much discomfort really to be thinking about it.'' But her husband, the delivering doctor, Frank Wilson, and nurse Karen Johnson didn't forget. The trio reminded Mrs. McKenna of the goal around midnight. It became easy to concentrate on the time because ``it just so happened that a clock was staring me dead in the face.'' Mrs. McKenna was urged to hold off her delivery until the perfect moment. ``No, don't push yet, hold off a second,'' she recalled the nurse saying. Wilson declared the boy officially born at exactly 56 seconds past 12:34, when his feet appeared. The occurence is not officially recorded. Massachusetts birth certificates only have space for the hour and minute.

DOC.HEAD: State Appeals Court Upholds Cuomo's Shoreham Deal
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court today unanimously upheld Gov. Mario Cuomo's agreement to have the state buy the Shoreham nuclear power plant for $1 and dismantle it. The 5-0 decision from the Appellate Division of state Supreme Court upheld two lower court rulings in Cuomo's favor. The Shoreham plant, built at a cost of more than $5.5 billion, has never operated at anything above low-level test power. The plant, located in Suffolk County on Long Island, was built by the Long Island Lighting Company and brought the company to the brink of bankruptcy. Cuomo argued that Shoreham was unsafe to operate because its location on a heavily populated island made an emergency evacuation impractical. Cuomo reached the agreement with LILCO to scrap the plant in 1989. ``Our decision is not meant to be a judgment on any party's position regarding nuclear-generated power generally or Shoreham specifically,'' said the appeals court in an unsigned opinion. ``It is simply an assessment of the authority granted by the Legislature and how that authority has been exercised.'' Martin Kaufman, a lawyer for the Atlantic Legal Foundation, said he wasn't yet certain whether his group would attempt to appeal the ruling to New York's highest court, the Court of Appeals. The foundation, a conservative-oriented organization, had been joined in the lawsuit by the U.S. Justice Department and other supporters of not abandoning Shoreham. ``Obviously, this loss is not helpful,'' said Kaufman.

DOC.HEAD: Sacramento Union Names New Editor
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Farah, former executive news editor of Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, has been named editor of The Sacramento Union, the newspaper announced Thursday. Farah, 37, who became executive editor of the Glendale News-Press after leaving the Los Angeles newspaper, replaces James Vesely, 49, who resigned. Publisher James Smith said replacements for editorial page editor Peter Hayes and City Editor Jerry Eagan, who also resigned in recent weeks, will be named after Farah assumes his post on July 22.

DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
Infants Were Most At Risk for High Radiation Doses Near Hanford
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with scientists' news conference. Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: Some infants living near the Hanford nuclear reservation in the 1940s may have received more radiation than people living near Nevada nuclear weapons testing sites, a scientist said today. John Till, chairman of a panel trying to estimate doses of radiation to people living near the federal weapons production reservation, said some infants may have received 2,900 rads of radioactive iodine over three years. A rad is a measure of radiation exposure to human tissue and is roughly equal to the radiation in 12 chest X-rays. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission requires that facilities it licenses limit yearly radiation exposure from airborne emissions to 15 thousandths of a rad. Release of the study came one day after the Department of Energy acknowledged for the first time that Hanford leaked radiation at levels that endangered the health of nearby residents. ``Now that they've admitted what they've done, I think they should make restitution and they should provide medical help for the rest of our lives for anything the radiation has caused,'' said Betty Perkes, whose family farms near Pasco, Wash. ``I feel like they used us for guinea pigs, and I don't feel like they cared one iota what happened to us either, or our families.'' However, it would be very difficult to prove a long-term illness was caused by exposure more than 40 years ago and the law prohibits lawsuits against the government, said Jim Thomas of the Spokane, Wash.-based Hanford Education Action League. The study was not intended to identify health risks from radiation exposure. But Till said the numbers were high enough to strongly justify a study of thyroid diseases among so-called ``downwinders'' who lived near Hanford during periods when it was spewing radioactive particles into the atmosphere in large quantities. The study of 270,000 people living in 10 counties of Washington and Oregon near the reservation in south-central Washington indicated that 13,500 people received cumulative doses greater than 33 rad in the years 1944-47. ``These numbers are significant because that is a lot of folks,'' Till said at a news conference before the actual release of the study. ``That dose level is significant enough to strongly justify a thyroid dose study.'' Radioactive iodine was released when spent reactor fuel rods were chemically dissolved to separate weapons-grade plutonium and uranium. When it concentrates in the thyroid gland, iodine-131 can cause cancer and other diseases. Till said that by comparison, doses downwind from the Nevada nuclear weapons testing site ranged from a few rad to 500 rad. The Hanford Environmental Dose Reconstruction Project uses computer models to estimate how much radiation escaped when plutonium was produced for nuclear weapons. ``I know of no other releases of this magnitude from any other U.S. facility,'' Till said of the 1944-47 period, noting that modern releases are extremely small. A small number of infants may have received as much as 2,900 rad during that time, Till said. Infants were particularly vulnerable to radioactive iodine because their thyroids were not as developed as an adult's, and they likely drank more milk produced by cows that grazed on grass contaminated by radioactive iodine. Of the 270,000 people studied, half received doses of less than 1.7 rad over the three years, and half received doses greater than that. Of the upper half, 13,500 got doses greater than 33 rad, Till said. Because of prevailing west-to-east winds, the affected area lies roughly east of Hanford, with larger radiation doses affecting those who lived closest to the reservation, Till said. The 10 counties covered in the study were Yakima, Kittitas, Grant, Adams, Benton, Franklin, Walla Walla and Klickitat in Washington state, and Morrow and Umatilla in Oregon. Some of the counties are included entirely, others only partly. The panel also studied radiation doses to 70,000 people exposed through water in the Columbia River, which borders part of the reservation, and found that the average dose to the gastrointestinal tract was 1.7 rad during a three-year period from 1964-66. The study is the first part of a five-year, $15 million project that is the first major research into accidental and intentional release of large amounts of radioactive materials that drifted from Hanford.

DOC.HEAD: Panel OKs Bill Putting China `On Notice'
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee approved a bill Thursday that would allow China to keep favored-trade status this year but require significant progress in human rights if the designation is to be renewed. Rep. Donald Pease, D-Ohio, called his legislation an attempt to ``put China on notice that next year will be different if human rights practices don't improve.'' The action by the Ways and Means trade subcommittee, on a voice vote, fell far short of the revocation of most-favored-nation trade status called for by the most strident congressional opponents of President Bush's China policy. Those opponents believe a stronger response is needed in light of last year's crushing of China's pro-democracy movement. But even the relatively mild move drew opposition from the administration, which said it would harm U.S. competitiveness and do more harm than good. The United States and China have about $18 billion annually in bilateral trade. ``With increasing signs of moderate, pragmatic thinking in Beijing, we fear explicit public linkage of (most-favored-nation trade status) to human rights may harden China's posture and make it more difficult to address our concerns,'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger said in a letter to the subcommittee. Kent Wiedemann, director of the department's China desk, noted Beijing's reported release of 881 political prisoners since the beginning of the year. An estimated 435 political prisoners are still detained, he said. The subcommittee, on a 5-3 vote, rejected an effort by Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., to toughen the measure by requiring that the president certify that all human rights conditions set out in the bill have been fully met, rather than simply certifying ``significant progress'' toward those goals. On Wednesday, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine introduced a bill that would revoke China's favored-trade status _ and the lower tariffs it provides _ within 90 days. None of the moves is expected to win enough support on Capitol Hill to overcome an almost certain presidential veto.

DOC.HEAD: Flamboyant Thrift Figure Faces 17 Federal Charges
With PM-S&L Fraud, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to UPDATE with McBirney appearance in court. Picks up 5th graf, `He was...' A longer version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: A flamboyant former president of a failed Texas thrift has been charged with bank fraud in a $700 million real estate deal. Edwin T. McBirney III, who presided over tremendous growth of Sunbelt Savings Association before its $2 billion failure, was to surrender today to authorities. McBirney's attorney, Paul Coggins, said the indictment returned Wednesday ``is a typical case of government overkill.'' He said his client acted in Sunbelt's best interest. McBirney, 37, appeared before U.S. District Judge Barefoot Sanders today to hear the charges against him and was released on his own recognizance. Coggins said McBirney would plead innocent at a July 19 arraignment. McBirney would make no comment to reporters at the courthouse. He was indicted on 17 counts, including bank fraud, misapplication of funds, false entries and making false statements to regulators. He faces up to 85 years in prison and a $4.2 million fine if convicted. The indictment accuses McBirney of hiding from regulators agreements with Western Savings Association over partial financing of $700 million worth of property in Southern California. FBI agent Pat Dorsey said the deal contributed to the collapse of Sunbelt in 1988. Sunbelt Savings was taken over by federal thrift regulators and merged with other insolvent thrifts. The indictment was returned by one of three grand juries in Dallas investigating bank and thrift fraud. Thirteen other Sunbelt officials, borrowers and accountants have been convicted as a result of a 2{-year investigation. McBirney acquired the Dallas-based thrift in 1982 with five associates. The thrift engaged in high-risk loans that were either unsecured or inadequately secured by commercial real estate and land, according to government documents. McBirney was known in the thrift industry for flying friends to Hawaii for fishing and Las Vegas for gambling. He dressed as a king for a 1984 Halloween party where guests dined on pheasant, antelope and lion. U.S. Attorney Marvin Collins of Dallas has said complex bank fraud cases are difficult to prove ``unless we are able to put some money, a lot of money, in somebody's pocket.'' The charges against McBirney do not show who might have profited from the transactions. He is accused of ensuring Western Savings a $6 million profit on the sale of a property in return for Western providing $30 million in financing on California property being bought by Sun Cal, a Sunbelt subsidiary. The indictment ``marks another milestone in our crackdown on fraud in the thrift industry,'' Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: New England Journal Editor Announces Retirement
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Arnold Relman said Thursday he will retire in June after 14 years as editor of the New England Journal of Medicine, the world's leading chronicle of medical research. Relman, 67, said he plans to write, teach and lecture after he retires as editor in chief. ``I've been thinking about it for some time and finally decided,'' Relman said. ``It's better to leave a little too soon than a little too late.'' During Relman's tenure, the journal's circulation grew by one-third, and the weekly magazine established itself as a forum for exploring social and economic issues in medicine as well as being the leading showcase of research findings. Relman was frequently criticized for using the journal to question, among other things, the growing role of business in medical care. ``Relman has provided the strongest voice for professionalism and against business taking over medicine,'' said Dr. George Lundberg, editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association. ``He has sought controversy in a responsible way,'' he said. ``He was very early in those areas and did engender great controversy and a lot of personal attacks. He stood his ground and should have. We are all in his debt for doing so.'' The New England Journal, founded in 1812, was already one of the world's leading medical publications when Relman took over from Dr. Franz Ingelfinger in 1977. Relman has continued to publish a large share of the world's hottest medical research. ``If you look worldwide, the New England Journal is clearly the leading journal of clinical medicine and has been for some time,'' said David Pendlebury, editor of Science Watch published by the Institute for Scientific Information in Philadelphia. Many agree that Relman's chief accomplishment has been taking the journal into the contentious area of medical finance and ethics. The journal has explored and editorialized about such areas as the growth of profit-making medicine and physicians' financial conflict of interest. Relman said he plans to concentrate on these and related matters after he leaves the journal. ``I want to spend the next few years as a more active participant in what I think will be a growing national discussion of health care,'' he said. ``I think the medical profession can make a major contribution toward solving the health care problems of this country if it will rouse itself. I want to help in that process.'' Dr. Barry M. Manuel, president of the Massachusetts Medical Society, which owns the journal, said a search committee will be established soon to name a new top editor. While Relman has been editor, the journal's circulation has grown from 165,000 to 225,000, and it claims the largest paid circulation of any medical journal in the world. Before joining the New England Journal, Relman taught at Boston University and the University of Pennsylvania and edited the Journal of Clinical Investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia Asks to Join International Monetary Fund
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia has asked to join the International Monetary Fund, the IMF announced Thursday. The central Asian country, officially the Mongolian People's Republic, was formerly known as Outer Mongolia. Switzerland, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Namibia also have asked to become IMF members in recent months. When all applicants are accepted, the IMF will have 156 member nations _ nearly all of the countries of the world except the Soviet Union. The United States, the fund's most influential member, has opposed letting the Soviets join. IMF membership is followed by membership in the World Bank, the biggest source of aid to the Third World. Leaders of the seven wealthiest IMF members _ the United States, Great Britain, Canada, Japan, France, West Germany and Italy _ met this week at an economic summit in Houston. The countries asked the IMF to head a survey of what changes the Soviets need to make to get more foreign aid.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Officials Say Oil-eating Microbes Worked in Mega Borg Tests
DOC.TEXT: Texas officials said today that oil-eating microbes dumped on part of an oil slick from the wrecked supertanker Mega Borg appeared successful in eating the oil while not harming the environment. ``If you believe your eyes, it was a great success,'' Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro said at a news conference today. ``Test results from the small application show no evidence that the microbes produced any toxic byproducts, and no evidence of change in the nutrient balance of the natural marine environment. ``Best of all, the tests show that the microbes ate the oil,'' Mauro said, adding that the surface oil in some samples was ``reduced to 30 percent of the original volume.'' The process, called bioremediation, involves the use of microorganisms that are dumped on oil. The naturally occurring bacteria reduce the oil to an emulsion of fatty acids. This emulsion sinks and is consumed by marine life, while the microbes die after the oil is gone. The microbes were dropped on part of the slick from the Mega Borg, which was left crippled in the Gulf of Mexico after an explosion June 8. An estimated 3.9 million gallons of Angolan crude leaked from the vessel, although much of that was consumed by fire. The bioremediation tests on the spill cost the state $26,000. Mauro and B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne, chairman of the Texas Water Commission, said they were pleased with the results and were ready to push forward to have bioremediation included in companies' oil spill contingency plans.

DOC.HEAD: Oral Cancer Kills 10,000 a Year, And Survival Rates Not Improving
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Mouth cancer kills nearly 10,000 people a year in the United States, and unlike other cancers, survival rates aren't getting better, federal health officials said Thursday. The Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control said oral and pharynx cancers killed 9,742 Americans in 1987, the latest year for which statistics are available. That works out to 3.6 deaths per 100,000 people _ the same rate it was back in 1973, said CDC dental health specialist Linda Crossett. And the survival rate hasn't changed in 16 years, the CDC said. Only 52 percent of oral cancer patients survive five years or more. That's in contrast to the survival rates for breast, colorectal and prostate cancer, which are improving. Federal health officials have set a national goal of cutting oral cancer deaths in middle-age Americans by 15 percent to 30 percent by the year 2000. ``We're not making a lot of progress,'' Crossett said. ``Looking at new cases now, about 30,000 Americans are diagnosed with oral cancers each year.'' The survival rates are lower for blacks _ and getting worse. Just 31 percent of black patients survived oral cancer, in 1981-86 statistics, compared with 35 percent in 1974-76. For whites, the survival rates have remained more constant: 53 percent in 1981-86, 55 percent in 1974-76. Major risk factors for oral cancer include tobacco use _ either smoked or smokeless _ and drinking. And ``the combined risks from tobacco and alcohol use appear to be substantially greater than those from tobacco or alcohol alone,'' the CDC said in its weekly report. ``The increased use of tobacco among women, adolescents and children'' _ as compared to a decline in smoking overall _ ``is likely to elevate death rates for these cancers in the next several decades,'' the report said. In addition to continued use of tobacco, the other major reason for oral cancer deaths ``is the fact that there has not been any improvement in early detection,'' Crossett said. ``Most are only detected ... after they've grown pretty large, so advanced that it's obvious.'' Traditionally, a dentist has been most likely to perform a thorough oral exam on a patient. But the CDC noted a 1986 survey showing that people at highest risk for oral cancer sought the services of a standard physician four times more often than they went to the dentist. ``And many people going to their physician may not get a thorough oral, head and neck exam,'' Crossett said. ``That's the big key _ early detection.''

DOC.HEAD: East German Lawmakers Back Liberal Abortion Law
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's major political factions said Thursday they will fight to retain East Germany's liberal abortion law when the nation unites with West Germany. Also Thursday, the head of the West German central bank said East German factories must make radical changes to survive the increased competition that will come with reunification. During an intense debate, most of the political factions that control East Germany's Parliament spoke out in favor of retaining the abortion law in the territory of what is now East Germany. The German states are negotiating a final treaty that would result in the creation of a single Germany by year's end and the disparity in abortion laws is among the differences officials in each nation will be negotiating in the coming weeks. Some East German lawmakers expressed fear that their nation would become a lure for ``abortion tourists'' from West Germany who head to the east for the operation. The arch-conservative German Social Union was the only party of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's broad governing coalition that objected to retaining the law. ``An abortion is always murder,'' said lawmaker Sabine Landgraf of the German Social Union. Family Minister Christa Schmidt told lawmakers the ministry has received more than 100,000 letters from citizens asking that the abortion law be retained, and 25,317 demanding that it be revoked. East German allows a female over age 14 to receive an abortion on demand during the first three months of pregnancy. West Germany allows abortions in the first three months only in cases of rape or incest, if the mother's life is in danger, if the fetus is expected to be severely handicapped, or if the woman's financial situation would make it impossible for her to raise a child. There were 75,297 abortions performed in West Germany last year, a nation of 60 million people, and 73,000 abortions in East Germany, which has 16 million people. Also Thursday, Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl told reporters following a Central Bank Council meeting that was held in the former headquarters of the Communist Party Central Committee that West German taxpayers are unlikely to support unprofitable East German factories for long. Following the July 1 economic merger the bank began controlling the money supply of both German states. ``East German companies have to earn their marks,'' he said after the bank's board held its first meeting in East Berlin. East German factories have recently cut payrolls and forming joint ventures with Western firms in an effort to survive. But an East German official said many of the nation's factories are firing foreign workers first as they slash employee payrolls to compete with Western busineses. ``I am ashamed of that,'' said Horst Kinitz, head of the state employment agency. He called such layoffs illegal because they are discriminatory. An estimated 80,000 Mozambicans, Cubans and Vietnamese are working in East German enterprises under contracts with those countries made by the former Communist government. The government is trying to blunt the effects of unemployment by encouraging enterprises to reduce worker hours to keep more people on payrolls. About 222,000 employees in the nation of 8 million workers are on such shortened hours now and another 240,000 will be added soon, Kinitz said. An estimated 162,000 East Germans are unemployed. Poehl said East Germans have been frugal with their marks and have withdrawn about half of the 25 billion marks made available to them. ``There is no reason to fear that (monetary union) will lead to unacceptably high inflation levels,'' Poehl said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Hands Reputed Terrorists to West Germany
DOC.TEXT: Two reputed Red Army Faction terrorists were handed over to West German authorities Thursday, prosecutors said, after years of sanctuary that may have been provided by East Germany's now-disbanded secret police. Inge Viett and Werner Lotze arrived in the West German city of Karlsruhe, where they will appear before an investigating magistrate, according to Rolf Hannich, a spokesman for the West German prosecutor's office. They were among nine alleged Red Army Faction members arrested in East Germany in a series of raids last month. One alleged terrorist was released because the arrest warrant against her had expired. The arrests caused an uproar in both Germanys after one of those seized said she had been given sanctuary and a new identity by the old East German secret police force, known as the Stasi. News reports in West Germany have also alleged that deposed Communist Party chief Erich Honecker and Stasi boss Erich Mielke were personally responsible for hiding the purported terrorists. In East Berlin, prosecution spokesman Dieter Plath said Ms. Viett had been extradited ``against her will'' and in defiance of an article in the East German Constitution that bans the extradition of criminal suspects to a ``foreign power.'' Plath said prosecutors had acted on the ``assumption'' that the article no longer applied to West Germany after the two Germanys unified in effect with the July 1 merger of their economies and social welfare systems. An East Berlin court confirmed that reading of the law, Plath added. Ms. Viett is suspected of the attempted murder of a Paris policeman who stopped her during a routine check in 1981. Lotze has said he wanted to cooperate with West German prosecutors in order to possibly qualify for a program that offers lenient punishment for former terrorists willing to testify against their organization. Lotze, who has said he made a ``deliberate decision'' to quit the Red Army Faction and move to East Germany in 1979, is suspected of involvement in the 1977 kidnapping and shooting death of Hans-Martin Schleyer, chairman of West Germany's biggest employers' group. West Germany has warrants out for the arrest of both suspects for their alleged Red Army Faction membership. They are the second and third terrorist suspects to arrive in West Germany. On July 5, Susanne Albrecht, another Red Army Faction suspect, was handed to West German authorities after saying she wanted to testify for the prosecution. Plath would not confirm recent reports that another of the suspects, Silke Maier-Witt, had also asked to be sent to West Germany. West German authorities have said they weren't planning to seek formal extradition in any of the cases because West German law will come into force in East Germany after the two nations formally unite, most likely in December. The Red Army Faction waged a terrorist campaign against West German capitalism and NATO in the 1970s and 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Suffer Nausea and Dizziness Aboard TWA Flight
DOC.TEXT: Five passengers and three flight attendants aboard a TWA flight from Columbus, Ohio, were taken to hospitals Thursday after becoming ill, officials said. The eight were released after treatment. ``The first flight attendant started feeling a little nauseous about 30 minutes outside of Columbus,'' spokesman Jim Faulkner said from TWA's St. Louis headquarters. By the time the plane landed at La Guardia Airport, two other attendants and five passengers on Flight 112 complained about nausea and dizziness, said Emergency Medical Service spokesman Charles DeGaetano. TWA officials do not know what caused the illness, Faulkner said. ``There were no fumes on the plane,'' he said. ``There was no indication in the cockpit of anything being wrong, all systems were running normally.''

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Fear Democrats Will Be Winners-Take-All
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with state Senate delaying action on the bill. SUBS final graf to conform with 2nd reference to Taft.
DOC.TEXT: North Carolina could become the second state to scrap the winner-take-all method of allocating electoral votes in presidential elections. A bill that would divide the state's 13 electoral votes by congressional districts was up for a state Senate vote today after passage by the House last year. But the vote was delayed until Friday or next week because a cost analysis hadn't been completed, said Sen. Tom Taft, chairman of the Senate Election Laws Committee. The Democrat-controlled state Legislature is expected to redraw congressional district lines in 1992. Republicans fear the new system would leave Democrats with control of all 13 electoral votes. Currently, whichever candidate garners a majority in a state wins all the state's electoral votes. Maine adopted the alternative method in 1969, but it has made no difference in the way the state's electoral vote has been allocated. A similar proposal passed the Connecticut House this session but died in the Senate after the governor hinted he would veto it. In North Carolina, where Republican Gov. Jim Martin has no veto power, the Senate was on its way to approving the bill Wednesday when Republican Lt. Gov. Jim Gardner ruled the measure must be accompanied by a fiscal note showing how much its passage might cost the state. Republicans acknowledged the move was a delay tactic. Under the bill, candidates would receive one electoral vote for each of the 11 congressional districts they win. North Carolina's two remaining electoral votes would go to the candidate who carried the state. Jack Hawke, state GOP chairman, told reporters Republicans would lose if the bill becomes law. ``Frankly, I believe we should be more interested in a fair system than in one that can be rigged in favor of a particular party that happens to control the redistricting process,'' Hawke said. Taft denied partisan motivation behind the bill, calling it ``good government.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Redd Foxx's jewelry, including a diamond and gold watch given to him by Elvis Presley, will be auctioned by the Internal Revenue Service later this month. The comedian, who starred as a junk man in the 1970s TV series ``Sanford and Son,'' owes the government $2.9 million in taxes and penalties, according to the IRS. Seventy-six pieces of jewelry will be sold at the auction, scheduled for July 23 at IRS headquarters in Las Vegas, said auctioneer Robert Deiro. Included in Foxx's collection is the watch Foxx says was a gift from the late Presley. Deiro and IRS officials displayed the jewelry several months ago, but the auction was delayed while attorneys for the comedian argued that the bankruptcy court should have jurisdiction over the items. The IRS auctioned eight of Foxx's cars in May, raising $49,555. The cars and jewelry were seized in an IRS raid last November, along with Foxx's Las Vegas home. Attorneys later worked out a payment plan with the agency that allowed Foxx to keep his home. Foxx has been performing at the Hacienda Hotel on the Las Vegas Strip.

Former pop singer Cat Stevens, now known as Yusuf Islam, said Thursday that Israeli authorities expelled him without explanation after holding him and his son at the airport and searching his belongings. Islam said in a statement he endured a ``three-hour ordeal'' while his luggage was ``ripped apart and everything from my sandals to my pocket copy of the Holy Koran was X-rayed and searched.'' He said he arrived at Ben-Gurion Airport on July 1 with his 5-year-old son, Muhammad, to attend a Moslem folk festival. ``I was getting highly irritated with the endless stream of uniformed officials all sneaking into the area and gawking side-eyed at me and my son, whispering, `It's him ... it's Cat Stevens,''' Islam said. He said he was finally ordered out with no explanation. The Israeli Embassy said its immigration authorities were not required to explain their actions. The popular 1970s British pop singer changed his name and abandoned pop music when he became a Moslem.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corp., is being sued for $700 million by the heir to the estate of his wife, claiming at least a half interest in Hammer's art collection. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in state court, alleges fraud, legal malpractice and financial misconduct. It contends Hammer and a law firm representing the industrialist repeatedly deceived Frances Hammer about her ownership rights to Hammer's assets. The lawsuit was filed by Robert Weiss of Los Angeles, husband of Joan Weiss. Mrs. Weiss, a niece of Frances Hammer, is the sole heir to Mrs. Hammer's estate. Mrs. Hammer died in December after 33 years of marriage to Armand Hammer and named Robert Weiss executor of her will. The 92-year-old Hammer maintains that his wife signed documents waiving her interest in his art collection, which has been estimated to be worth $450 million. Richard C. Cleary, a lawyer for the Weisses, said those were part of the pattern of fraud and deceit. The suit also says Mrs. Hammer was fraudulently deprived an interest in thousands of shares of Occidental stock and millions of dollars in cash paid to Armand Hammer in salary and fringe benefits. Howard Collins, a spokesman for Hammer and Occidental, declined to comment. Hammer began collecting art during the 1920s in the Soviet Union. His collection, including Impressionist and Old Master paintings and drawings by Leonardo da Vinci, had been promised to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. But he got into a dispute with that museum over how the art was to be displayed, and decided to build his own museum.

Singer-writer Mel Torme might be nearing age 65 but that doesn't mean he has any plans of bowing out of show business. In fact, ``1990 is the single biggest year in my life,'' Torme says. ``I'd be crazy to even think about retiring.'' Torme's date at the Flathead Festival on July 18 is sandwiched between performances with the Los Angeles Philharmonic at the Hollywood Bowl and the London Symphony in England. In between concerts, he keeps busy writing, Torme said by telephone from his California home Wednesday. ``My main visibility is that of a singer, and I love to sing,'' said Torme, whose birthday is in September. ``But my greatest joy is in writing, the creative activity.'' Probably his single best-known writing achievement is ``The Christmas Song'' (``Chestnuts roasting on an open fire...''), which Torme composed in 1946. It has been recorded 500 times, most notably by the late Nat King Cole. Torme is working on an entire album of Christmas music, to be recorded with the BBC Symphony, and scheduled for release near Christmas 1991, he said.

Tony award-winning actor and dancer Ben Vereen has been released from a hospital after undergoing minor knee surgery. ``It's a relatively minor surgical procedure with a high success rate,'' said Cedars-Sinai Medical Center spokesman Ron Wise on Wednesday. ``He had some minor knee glitch.'' Vereen, 43, was admitted to the hospital Tuesday, Wise said. The entertainer appeared in the musicals ``Hair'' and ``Jesus Christ Superstar,'' and won a Tony Award for his performance in ``Pippin.'' Vereen starred in the TV miniseries ``Roots,'' based on Alex Haley's novel, and played con man E.L. ``Tenspeed'' Turner in the NBC-TV adventure series, ``J.J. Starbuck.'' He also appeared regularly in the ABC-TV comedy series, ``Webster.''

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Minister's Blast at Germany Reflects British Unease
LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.TEXT: A senior government minister has accused an ``uppity'' West Germany of trying to dominate Europe, the Common Market of being worse than Hitler's Germany and the French of ``behaving like poodles to the Germans.'' Nicholas Ridley withdrew the remarks hours after they were published Thursday in The Spectator magazine. But political observers say the trade and industry secretary articulated a deep sense of unease felt by many British about the new face of Europe. ``I think a lot of people (in the Conservative Party) will agree with him privately, including a number of those who wouldn't have the guts to say so publicly,'' said John Burrow, deputy chairman of Ridley's constituency association in Cirencester and Tewkesbury. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the House of Commons on Thursday that Ridley's remarks did not reflect government policy, or her own views, but she rejected demands for his dismissal. Opposition Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock said Mrs. Thatcher should recognize the interview ``is not just deeply offensive to our allies and partners, but deeply damaging to our country's interests, and he must go.'' But Channel 4 News reported that a straw poll of 52 of the 372 Conservatives in the House of Commons found that 22 shared Ridley's fears of German domination of Europe. Conservative lawmaker James Hill said it was timely to warn West Germany ``that we cannot stand by ... and aid them to take over central Europe.'' Ridley, 61, the chain-smoking younger son of Viscount Ridley, has survived many previous controversies because of his close relationship with Mrs. Thatcher. ``I'm a great Nick Ridley fan,'' the prime minister said last year. In the Spectator interview, Ridley said the West German government's support for European monetary union ``is all a German racket designed to take over the whole of Europe. It has to be thwarted. ``This rushed take-over by the Germans on the worst possible basis, with the French behaving like poodles to the Germans, is absolutely intolerable,'' Ridley said. He also condemned the ``breath-taking arrogance'' of the 12-nation European Community, which he said was run by ``17 unelected reject politicians.'' ``I'm not against giving up sovereignty in principle, but not to this lot. You might just as well give it to Adolf Hitler, frankly,'' he said. Spectator editor Dominic Lawson, who conducted the interview, suggested that West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl was ``not going to bomb us, after all.'' Ridley replied: ``I'm not sure I wouldn't rather have ... er ... the shelters and the chance to fight back, than simply being taken over by ... economics.'' Britain must play its historic role as the balance of power in Europe, Ridley said. ``Never has it been more necessary than now, with Germany so uppity.'' The Spectator's cover had a cartoon of Ridley painting a Hitler mustache on Kohl's portrait. Mrs. Thatcher, who returned Thursday from a summit meeting with Kohl and other leaders of major industrial nations, told the House of Commons that Ridley's apology should be the end of the matter. In Bonn, Kohl's aide Lutz Stavenhagen condemned Ridley's attack as ``scandalous.'' Otto Graf Lambsdorff, chairman of the Free Democrats, Kohl's coalition partners said: ``Either he was drunk ... or he had not yet gotten over the soccer loss of the English team against the Germans'' in the World Cup semifinals. Tim Helm, a member of the European Movement which promotes continental harmony, said Ridley's remarks reflected ``a section of opinion which is present across Europe, not just in this country.'' Helm, who is of German-English parentage, said it was fitting that the issue erupted while Ridley was on a visit to Hungary, ``because clearly a number of Eastern European countries are frightened of what they see as a Fortress Europe with an overpowerful Germany. But all those fears are based on lack of knowledge.'' Lawson said he thought Ridley ``was expressing the views of many ordinary people in the way that politicians don't.''

DOC.HEAD: Meese Awarded Legal Fees
DOC.TEXT: Former Attorney General Edwin Meese III was awarded $460,509 Thursday for legal expenses he incurred during a special prosecutor's criminal investigation. Independent counsel James McKay declined to prosecute Meese at the conclusion of the investigation, which was expanded several times to include a variety of conflict-of-interest allegations against the attorney general. The independent counsel division of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the government should pay $460,509 of the $575,598 in legal fees and costs claimed by Meese's defense lawyers, Nathan Lewin and James Rocap. Among the $115,000 worth of expenses the court disallowed was a claim of $16,652 by Meese's lawyers for time spent talking to reporters about the case. Under the independent counsel law, Meese is entitled to government reimbursement for reasonable legal fees because he was not indicted as a result of the 14-month investigation. Among other things, Meese was investigated for possible ethics law violations for intervening to help Wedtech Corp. obtain a lucrative defense contract at a time when his longtime friend E. Bob Wallach was a consultant for the company. Wallach has been convicted of racketeering in connection with his Wedtech dealings. McKay found that Meese, who was counselor to President Reagan when Wedtech won the contract, did not personally benefit from the deal and therefore did not violate conflict-of-interest laws. The independent counsel also investigated Meese's failure to divest himself of $14,000 worth of stock in regional Bell System operating companies when he was formulating Justice Department policy about the breakup of American Telephone & Telegraph. McKay's investigation found probable violations of conflict-of-interest and tax laws but declined to prosecute, saying there was no evidence Meese was motivated by personal gain or self-interest. Meese left office about a month after McKay issued his July 5, 1988, report. The court also refused to reimburse Meese for $6,335 for legal bills after the filing of a response to McKay's report of the investigation and for $5,170 he was billed to prepare to testify at the trial of former White House aide Lyn Nofziger. A federal appellate court last year overturned Nofziger's ethics-law conviction for lobbying former Reagan administration colleagues, including Meese, on behalf of Wedtech, a labor union and another defense contractor. The court also disallowed $11,311 worth of staff overtime, $10,000 for photocopying it found excessive and $51,167 for costs it said were not adequately documented by the lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Rebels Overrun Sri Lankan Army Camp, Killing 58
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels overran a Sri Lankan army camp and killed 58 soldiers, military officials said Thursday. It was the first major victory for the insurgents since fighting resumed last month. Only two soldiers were known to have survived the assault Wednesday night on the Kokkavil army camp, 165 miles north of Colombo, military officials said on condition of anonymity. It was the first reversal for the army since Tamil rebels ended a 13-month cease-fire on June 11 by taking over several police stations and attacking army camps. Rebel mortar fire ignited gasoline tanks at the Kokkavil camp. The rebels then launched a ground attack shielded by armor-plated bulldozers, the officers said. They also blew up the north's main television relay station. The rebels began the attack on the Kokkavil television center Tuesday, but were initially pushed back. At least 21 guerrillas and three soldiers died in the earlier fighting, the officials said. Wednesday's deaths raise to 2,300 the number of combatants killed in the monthlong fighting. Many civilians also have been killed. The government, however, denied the latest Tamil allegations that soliders massacred townspeople in eastern Kalmunai on Tuesday. ``I am categorically denying a report that troops lined up and shot 50 civilians in Kalmunai,'' Defense Secretary Gen. Cyril Ranatunge said. ``We don't go in for that sort of thing.'' The Tamil Tiger rebels killed 115 policemen in Kalmunai last month as they renewed hostilities in their seven-year war for an independent Tamil homeland. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne accused the Tigers of destroying public property before retreating from army attacks. ``They are on the run and are resorting to a scorched-earth policy, destroying bridges, buildings, food stores and now a television station,'' he said. Since 1983, the war has claimed at least 13,200 lives. Tamil militants say their community, which comprises 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, is discriminated against in jobs, education and language by the majority Sinhalese. The Sinhalese, who dominate the army and government, comprise 75 percent of the population.
