DOC.HEAD: Genes Uncovered for Variety of Diseases
With AM-Elephant Man Disease, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The discovery of a gene causing ``Elephant Man's Disease'' is the latest in a series of such findings for various illnesses. Scientists pursue these genes in the hopes of improving treatment and, in some cases, aiding detection of people who can unknowingly pass the faulty genes to their offspring. Last August, scientists from the United States and Canada announced they had found the gene that causes cystic fibrosis, a devastating killer of young people that affects some 30,000 Americans. In 1986, scientists found the gene that causes the most common and serious kind of muscular dystrophy, the Duchenne form. In follow-up analysis announced the following year, researchers identified the protein produced by the normal version of the gene. That revealed that Duchenne is caused by the lack of this protein, giving clues for developing a treatment. Other recent studies have found that cancers of the breast, lung and colon can appear if particular cancer-suppressing genes are absent or malfunctioning.

DOC.HEAD: Two New Books by Salman Rushdie to be Published
DOC.TEXT: Two new books by Salman Rushdie will soon be published, the first since his ``The Satanic Verses'' brought death threats from Iran's late leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Rushdie's publisher announced Thursday. Granta Books, in association with Penguin Books, said it had acquired world English-language rights to Rushdie's novel ``Haroun and the Sea of Stories'' and ``Imaginary Homelands,'' a collection of essays. ``Haroun and the Sea of Stories,'' written for Rushdie's adolescent son, ``is the story of a story-teller who loses the gift of the gab until the gift is restored by his son,'' said Bill Buford of Granta books. The novel is ``as full of stories as `The Arabian Nights,' from which the principal character Haroun takes his name,'' he said. It will be published in Britain on Sept. 27 and in the United States next year. ``Imaginary Homelands,'' with 72 essays on subjects ranging from nationalism to Britain's general election and the American short story, will be published in Britain next spring, Buford said. Rushdie, a British citizen born into a Moslem family in India, has been in hiding under police protection since Feb. 14, 1989, when Khomeini said he deserved to die for what he called blaspheming Islam in ``The Satanic Verses.'' Death threats against Rushdie have hampered a restoration of diplomatic ties between Tehran and London which were effectively severed in June 1987 after a series of expulsions of diplomats. Rushdie has published poetry and several essays and reviews since the threats against him were first made. Granta magazine, one of the best-selling literary magazines in English, was started in 1979. On its 10th anniversary it launched Granta Books, a joint venture with Penguin, the publisher of ``The Satanic Verses.''

DOC.HEAD: FCC Reiterates Desire for Round-the-Clock Indecency Ban
DOC.TEXT: Children are in the radio and TV audience 24 hours a day, the Federal Communications Commission said Thursday in reiterating that it wants a total ban on ``indecent'' broadcast programming to protect youngsters under 18. The commission voted 5-0 to report its conclusions to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, which is considering a 24-hour ban the FCC imposed under orders from Congress in 1988. The court last year told the commission not to enforce the 24-hour ban pending further review but said the commission could develop evidence supporting its position. The FCC report could play a major role in how the appeals court _ and, inevitably, the Supreme Court _ decides the issue. In essence, the FCC is now enforcing the regulations that were in effect before Congress told the commission two years ago to ban indecent programming round-the-clock. The current regulations ban obscene material at all times and indecent material from about 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. local time. The FCC defines ``indecent'' as language or material ``that depicts or describes, in terms patently offensive as measured by contemporary community standards for the broadcast medium, sexual or excretory activities or organs.'' Neither the current regulation nor a 24-hour ban would affect cable television programming. The FCC, in its report, said a 24-hour indecency ban would promote a ``compelling'' government interest and would be ``narrowly tailored'' to serve that interest without infringing on broadcasters' First Amendment rights. The FCC said it was guided in its conclusion by a 1989 Supreme Court ruling that used the ``compelling interest-narrowly tailored'' argument in deciding that the government had the right to regulate indecent telephone transmissions. Broadcasters and free-speech advocates, who had asked the appeals court to prevent the FCC from implementing the round-the-clock ban, attacked the commission's new report. ``It's clear that Congress doesn't want broadcasters to be able to operate within limits guaranteed by the First Amendment, and, sadly, the FCC is enthusiastically cooperating,'' said Andrew J. Schwartzman, an attorney for People for the American Way, one of the groups challenging the 24-hour ban. ``What adults should be able to hear or see should not be determined by what children's needs are,'' Schwartzman added. ``I think it's preposterous,'' said Peggy Charren of the Boston-based Action for Children's Television, the main plaintiff in the court challenge. ``Protecting children from indecency should not be the role of the FCC. That should be the role of parents.'' Edward O. Fritts, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said the NAB was ``disappointed'' with the FCC's action. ``The courts have made it clear that a 24-hour ban on constitutionally protected speech is contrary to the First Amendment,'' Fritts said. Under new chairman Alfred Sikes, the FCC has put the nation's radio stations on notice over the last year that it will not tolerate the broadcast of indecent programs before 8 p.m. The commission has fined several stations already for broadcasting sexually explicit material. FCC officials Thursday said the commission had received 88,000 letters complaining of indecent programming, mostly on radio. ``We've received a huge amount of mail ... and it seems the public strongly supports the action we're taking today,'' Sikes said. At Thursday's meeting, commissioner Ervin S. Duggan read from a letter from a mother who said it would take a ``superhuman'' effort for parents to monitor what their children hear on see on radio and TV at all times. FCC officials repeatedly refused to speculate on what types of TV programs could be considered indecent.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Advocate Snyder Faced IRS Demand for $90,000
DOC.TEXT: Homeless advocate Mitch Snyder faced IRS demands for about $90,000 at the time of his apparent suicide last week but was looking forward to turning the issue into a forum on national priorities, friends said Thursday. ``We had just gotten the bill a few weeks ago,'' Carol Fennelly, Snyder's longtime companion said. ``They have been investigating us for two years and we had been waiting for a decision.'' The Internal Revenue Service sent the 46-year-old Snyder a preliminary notice, dated June 17, demanding $50,000 in back taxes plus $40,000 in penalties to cover $150,000 he received in 1985 and 1986 from television producers for the rights to his story, Fennelly said. ``We refused to respond to their silliness,'' Fennelly said. ``Obviously he did not have that kind of money, and if he did he wouldn't give it to them.'' ``He saw it as an opportunity to have a forum to address national priorities,'' Fennelly said. ``Mitch used everything as a forum.'' Snyder was found hanged last Thursday at a homeless shelter he helped found in northwest Washington. Police said he apparently committed suicide. Attorney Jerry Kafka, who was handling the case for Snyder, described the IRS action as a ``run-of-the-mill audit'' in its beginning stages. IRS officials have declined to comment. Fennelly said the federal inquiry came after she provided financial documents relating to the management of the Community for Creative Non-Violence, which runs Snyder's shelter. Snyder had maintained he contributed all his earnings to the group, which operated on a budget of $570,000 last year. Fennelly said Snyder never handled checks for the organization. ``Mitch didn't even sign the check,'' Fennelly said. ``Someone always signed them for him. It has always been a joke around here _ `Will the real Mitch Snyder signature please stand up.''' Fennelly said Snyder ``relished the thought'' of going to trial against the IRS. Kafka said, ``If Mitch has any taxable estate, they (the IRS) could pursue that (but) my understanding is that he has none.''

DOC.HEAD: House Panel OKs Health Spending Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House Appropriations Committee on Thursday approved a $170 billion spending bill for federal health, labor and education programs next year _ $4 billion more than President Bush requested. The appropriations bill continues provisions from past years prohibiting spending federal Medicaid money for abortions for poor women except in cases where the life of the mother is in danger. Abortion-rights supporters succeeded in adding language to a similar bill last year that expanded that exception to include Medicaid abortions for victims of rape and incest. But Bush vetoed the bill because of the broadened abortion provisions, and the House failed to override his veto. Because of parliamentary roadblocks, abortion rights lawmakers said they probably would not attempt to add abortion provisions when the spending bill goes to the House floor, probably next Thursday. However, they said they expected the Senate to add a similar amendment when it debates the spending bill, triggering a repeat of the 1989 fights when the bill returns to the House for concurrence. The bill provides $7.6 billion for the Department of Labor in fiscal 1991. It authorizes $135.7 billion for the Department of Health and Human Services, $26 billion for the Department of Education, and $1 billion for related agencies. The total represents a $17.3 billion increase over 1990 spending and a $4.2 billion increase over the amount requested by Bush in his proposed 1991 budget. Rep. William Natcher, D-Ky., chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that wrote the bill, said it included money set aside for major child care and AIDS prevention bills that are nearing passage. Nearly three-quarters of the bill's money goes to mandatory entitlement programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, welfare and other programs, in which spending is required by previously passed law. It includes $43.9 billion in discretionary programs, an increase of $5.6 billion over comparable amounts in 1990 spending and $3.2 billion more than requested by Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Government Survives Strike Crisis By Making Major Concessions
DOC.TEXT: A violent Sandinista strike that threatened to topple President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro ended early Thursday with her government agreeing to more major concessions as a price of survival. The strike accord dilutes Mrs. Chamorro's power to trim a bloated public payroll and to reverse what her economic advisers see as a crippling legacy of more than a decade of leftist Sandinista rule. Public employees won an immediate 43 percent raise with another unspecified raise to come next month. It was the second major wage concession for Nicaragua's 65,000 government employees, who got a 100 percent raise after a May walkout. In addition to government workers, thousands of employees of state-run industries also stayed off the job inthe latest strike. In addition, the government agreed not to carry out its threat to fire those taking part in what it had declared an illegal walkout and to pay compensation to 800 people fired since Mrs. Chamorro's April 25 inauguration. The strikers also forced the conservative government to back down on a key part of its plan to return Nicaragua to a free-market economy: the return of lands confiscated in the 1979 revolution. But the price of survival was high, and the support the army and police gave Mrs. Chamorro appeared limited. Both were party organs under the Sandinistas. Mrs. Chamorro said late Wednesday she wouldn't negotiate until the strikers met certain conditions. But secret talks began within hours and the accord with the Sandinista-led National Workers Front was announced early Thursday. The president had said a dialogue could begin only after the streets were clear of the barricades that had paralyzed the capital since Sunday, strikers vacated occupied government installations and basic public services were restored. Although the violence that claimed at least six lives had ended, the capital was still a maze of paving stone barricades or their debris when talks began and many buildings were still in the hands of strikers. Managua began returning to normal Thursday, although its pocked and scarred streets were still a motorist's nightmare. Taxis were circulating, businesses were reopening, and the union had told strikers to go back to work, the only concession the strikers made. Both sides were declaring victory in a confrontation the United States and President Chamorro had called an attempt to destablize her government. Despite her concessions, Mrs. Chamorro portrayed her government as a winner. It had not fallen, and she and her advisers called the army's decision not to back the strikers a triumph. Army and police bulldozers had removed barricades, but most blockades were rebuilt without interference, and there were no arrests. In addition to putting the brakes on returning confiscated land to pre-revolutionary owners, the agreement opens the door to power-sharing with workers in key industries such as textiles, construction and transportation. The Sandinistas had vowed to ``govern from below'' after Mrs. Chamorro and her coalition won the Feb. 25 general elections. The Sandinista party newspaper, Barricada, said Thursday the Sandinistas were making good on that promise. ``Victory for the Strikers,'' a banner headline proclaimed over news of Mrs. Chamorro's promise to negotiate a nationwide ``social accord'' with workers and businessmen on economic reforms. Other concessions include a promise to establish a new national minimum wage in September, payable in a new currency that will trade on a par with the dollar. The Nicaraguan cordoba has been devalued more than 20 times since Mrs. Chamorro inherited a bankrupt government and now goes for about 450,000 to the dollar on the black market. Francisco Mayorga, the head of the Central Bank and the architect of the government's economic program, said he hoped the strike had reaffirmed the possibility of cooperation. ``We could have arrived at the same outcome without a strike, without a confrontation, without a crisis,'' he said on Radio Catolica.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Candice Hughes is based in Mexico and has covered Central America for The Associated Press for the past two years.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Says Air Force Spent $73 Million for Outmoded Battle Fax
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a Senate panel said Thursday the Air Force had spent $73 million on 173 facsimile machines that are made to withstand a nuclear blast but are technologically outdated. Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., questioned that spending as well as the service's decision to buy nearly $40 million worth of spare parts for the machines, added equipment that should last 20 years. ``The Air Force fax machines are a textbook example of how the system should not work,'' Levin, who chairs the Senate Governmental Affairs subcommittee on oversight of government management, said in a speech on the Senate floor. The Air Force had no immediate comment on his allegations. The Senate committee found that the Air Force developed specifications for the fax machines in 1982 but, due to design and production problems, did not make a final production decision until April 1989, Levin said. ``By that time, commercial fax technology had evolved so much that the original specification _ which may have been at the cutting edge of technology in the early 1980s _ was outdated even before the machines were built,'' the senator said. The Navy has decided to buy an off-the-shelf machine with a higher resolution that the Air Force's fax and at a significantly lower cost of about $50,000 each. The Army has purchased a commercial machine modified to meet its specifications without Defense Department funds. The Army machine costs about $16,000 each, Levin said. The Navy and Army originally had been involved with the Air Force in the plan to buy special fax machines. Criticism of the Air Force fax machines arose in November 1989 after a published report said the equipment cost the service $421,000 apiece, a figure derived by dividing the $73 million cost by 173. An Air Force spokesman, Maj. Lou Figueroa, disputed the total, saying the service was paying $76,000 for each unit. He said that the machines were being purchased from Litton Industries under a contract for $33 million and that an additional contract for some $40 million covers ``a very extensive list'' of diagnostic equipment, laser assemblies and paper _ which costs $100 a roll. The machines are designed to withstand the rigors of the battlefield and to be used under a variety of conditions that might be encountered in wartime, Figueroa said. The machines must withstand a nuclear explosion, be able to operate after being immersed in three feet of water and function in temperatures ranging from -25 to 125 degrees Fahrenheit, Levin said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says IGs Had Successful Investigations
DOC.TEXT: Federal inspectors general initiated 5,639 successful prosecutions and recovered $726.9 million as a result of investigations of fraud and abuse during fiscal year 1989, a presidential panel said Thursday. The President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency, which coordinates activities of the watchdogs assigned to government agencies, said the prosecutions resulted from investigations of contractors, program participants and government employees. Some of the investigations were conducted by the inspectors general independently and some in cooperation with other federal and non-federal agencies. The largest number of prosecutions, 1,444, involved the Defense Department. The Department of Health and Human Services was next, with 1,278. In the nine years since the council was established, there have been 32,902 successful prosecutions, the report said. The report said the money was in the form of recoveries made during an investigation, legally ordered fines and penalties, restitutions and out-of-court settlements. The Defense Department accounted for $472.9 million of the total. In addition, the report said that 2,851 disbarments, exclusions and suspensions were taken during the fiscal year as a result of fraudulent or abusive practices by individuals and companies doing business with the federal government. It said 2,514 personnel actions ranging from firings to reprimands and demotions were taken against federal employees. Administrative penalties for fraudulent claims or statements totaled $115.6 million, the council said. It also estimated that recommendations by inspectors general resulted in $48.7 million in savings and avoidance of unnecessary expenditures.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin, Once Again a Ringleader, Challenges Gorbachev
LaserPhoto MOSB12
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin once persuaded his entire fifth-grade class to jump out the window. On Thursday, 50 years later, he threw down a similar challenge to 18 million Soviet Communists. ``I have to obey the will of the people...'' Yeltsin told nearly 4,700 Communists at a Kremlin congress as he began what could become an exodus of radical reformers and angry workers from the ruling party. In quitting, Yeltsin cited his duties as the newly elected president of the Russian Federation, the largest Soviet republic, which he has pledged to free of the ``diktat'' of central Communist and government rule. The mostly hard-line delegates, who sat in stoney silence as Yeltsin approached the podium to deliver his suprise announcement, shouted ``Shame!'' and whistled in derision as he strode out of the Kremlin Palace of Congresses. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who holds the top jobs in the central government and party, watched impassively as Yeltsin rose to challenge him for control of the reform movement. Leaving the party does not mean leaving the Kremlin for Yeltsin, who in May was elected chairman or president of the Russian Supreme Soviet, the legislature that meets regularly in the Great Kremlin Palace. Last month, Yeltsin persuaded the Russian legislature to pass a resolution on sovereignty, declaring its intention to remain within the Soviet Union but take over much of the decision-making power of central authorities. Yeltsin gambled and lost before, at a closed Communist Party meeting in late 1987, when he criticized the slow pace of reforms. As a result, he lost his job as party leader in Moscow and was bounced from his non-voting membership in the Communist Party Politburo. The 59-year-old Siberian with a shock of silver hair and a booming voice fought his way back to the top, winning election to the national parliament last year, then gaining the newly created Russian presidency six weeks ago. Yeltsin's spectacular departure from the party seemed likely to transform the defections from the party from a trickle into a river. Coal miners throughout the nation staged a one-day strike on Wednesday, urging workers to quit the party. And members of the radical reformist Democratic Platform also announced their intent to leave. It was not clear how many of the Communist Party's 18 million members would exit, but a sizeable movement seemded likely to rally around Yeltsin, who has described himself as a lifelong maverick. ``I was the ringleader, always devising some mischief,'' he wrote in his recent autobiography, ``Against the Grain.'' His aspirations to leadership are based on a long history of persuading others to join in sometimes mischievous adventures. As a schoolboy in the Ural Mountains, where European Russia turns into Siberia, Yeltsin persuaded his entire fifth-grade class to jump out the window when their unpopular teacher left the room. The room was on the first floor, Yeltsin persuaded the headmaster to forgive the class, and all ended well. But Yeltsin's mischievous side has provided his opponents with ample material to embarrass him, and deepened the conviction among some Soviets that Yeltsin is not always in control of himself _ a potentially dangerous quality in a national leader. Last year Pravda, a publication of the Soviet Communist Party, ran a report accusing him of drinking heavily during a trip to the United States, especially before a speech in Baltimore. Yeltsin claimed he was under the influence of jet lag, not bourbon, but the mud stuck. In another widely publicized incident, he insinuated that government agents pushed him off a bridge into a river near Moscow. Yeltsin acknowledges that he has undergone a transformation, from an old-style party boss into a firebrand populist, a change he says reflects the changes sweeping the country as a whole. Before Gorbachev rose to power in March 1985, Yeltsin was the party leader in Sverdlovsk in the Urals, a virtual dictator over one of the most important centers of the Soviet defense industry. In a speech Friday at the 28th Communist Party congress, Yeltsin warned delegates that if they did not change their attitude, they could go the way of dictators swept from power last fall in other socialist countries. ``If you think there is a different possibility, look at the fate of the Communist Parties of Eastern Europe,'' Yeltsin said. Those parties, he said, ``separated themselves from the people, didn't understand their role, and were left on the side of the road.'' Gorbachev had sought to avoid the split in the party by accelerating the reforms. Under his guidance, the party last winter relinquished its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power. So far, no nationwide political organization has emerged to challenge the party, but that could change quickly. Leading members of the radical reformist Democratic Platform, who balked at fulfilling their pledge to quit the party, announced shortly after Yeltsin that they, too, were quitting the party. Yeltsin has said he will use his government post to divest the Communists of their wealth. ``It is an illusion to think that after all dissenters, all who do not wish to be drive belts and cogs of the apparatus, quit the party, it will retain all the property of the Soviet Communist Party and the associated authority,'' he said Friday. As president of Russia, he is in a strong position to strip the party of much of that wealth.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Zodiac-Dartman, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here's a list of shootings that occurred overnight while police assigned to Operation Watchdog waited for the Zodiac killer to strike: _7:41 p.m.: A gunman steps out of a car and fires an Uzi machine gun into a crowd standing on a corner in the Fordham section of the Bronx. Five men are wounded in the possible drug-related attack. _8:10 p.m.: 45-year-old man is shot twice in the stomach during a robbery by an unidentified man in front of a Bronx apartment house. The suspect flees. Wounded man is in stable condition. _8:40 p.m.: 21-year-old man is shot in the back and killed in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn by two unidentified men who flee. _9:10 p.m.: 30-year-old man is shot five times and killed and four bystanders suffer minor gun wounds when a man opens fire in a drug-related shooting near the Apollo Theater in Harlem. _10:41 p.m.: 17-year-old boy is shot in the head and killed inside a Brownsville apartment by an unknown suspect. _11:15 p.m.: 19-year-old is shot in the head and killed during a dispute over drugs with another man in front of a building in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan. No arrest is made. _1 a.m.: A gas station attendant is shot in the leg during an attempted robbery in the Gerritsen Beach section of Brooklyn. Suspects flee empty-handed. _1:35 a.m.: 50-year-old man is shot in the back during a possibly drug-related burglary at his Prospect Park home in Brooklyn. Four suspects flee. _2:30 a.m.: A truck driver is found shot to death in the cab of a parked tractor-trailer in Harlem. _3:03 a.m.: 28-year-old man is shot in the chest in the Prospect Park section of Brooklyn during a reported money or drug dispute with an unidentified man.

DOC.HEAD: ACLU Wants U.S. to Drop Request for Information
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with 2 grafs to UDATE with Justice Department comment
DOC.TEXT: The American Civil Liberties Union said Thursday that it wants the Justice Department to drop a request for information from a group lobbying to suspend military aid to El Salvador. The Justice Department last month asked the National Agenda for Peace in El Salvador to describe the nature of its ``activities for or in the interests of'' the rebel FMLN and whether its activities were financed or directed by a foreign organization. The federal law requiring registration of foreign agents does not give the department the right to ask those questions, ACLU official Morton Halperin said at a news conference. National Agenda was formed at the 1988 Democratic National Convention by a group of delegates seeking to bring visibility to the issue of U.S. military aid to El Salvador. Geoffrey Thale, head of the three-person National Agenda staff based here, said the group did not receive money from anyone in El Salvador. ``Our view clearly is that we're not foreign agents,'' Thale said. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, known as the FMLN after its initials in Spanish, is the principal opponent of the El Salvador government in the decade-old civil war. The Justice Department said a May newspaper advertisement by the group ``indicates that you are engaged in publicity activities on behalf of'' the FMLN. The ad called on Congress to withdraw military aid to El Salvador as a way to force a political solution to the war and to force action against those responsible for the murders of six Jesuit priests and their housekeeper and her daughter last year. Reps. Robert W. Kastenmeier, D-Wis., and Don Edwards, D-Calif., said in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh that there were nothing in the ad ``to indicate that the group is engaged in activities on behalf of any foreign principal.'' The letter from Kastenmeier and Edwards, released by the ACLU, asked Thornburgh for information about the inquiry. Doug Tillett, a spokesman for the Justice Department, described the request as ``fairly routine'' and said he didn't believe the department would withdraw it. ``It sounds to me like an over-reaction on their part,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Scraps Tests for Chemical Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has canceled plans to test chemical weapons as a result of the recent U.S.-Soviet agreement to destroy the deadly armaments in the future, a Pentagon spokesman said Thursday. ``All of these decisions are in keeping with our intent to get ready for the bilateral destruction agreement with the Soviet Union,'' spokesman Pete Williams said. The agreement, signed June 1 by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, must still be ratified by the legislatures of the two countries, expected next year. But Cheney is making decisions in preparation for the agreement, Williams said. The defense chief has made cuts in the 1991 budget being debated in Congress. Specifically, Williams said Cheney has: _Eliminated money for production of the Bigeye bomb and canceled testing for the Navy's technically troubled program that has been scheduled for this fall. _Decided not to ask for production money for the Army's 155-millimeter artillery shell. _Opted to end testing of the Army's multiple launch rocket system after technical aspects are checked out. ``Once we get a good set of data on how that works, we will stop the program, and there will be no production funds requested for that _ simply research and development funds to finish that analysis and testing program,'' said Williams. While plans are under way to scrap chemical weapons, Williams said some will remain in the arsenal ``simply to maintain a small part of our deterrent capability because we believe that is a prudent thing to do insofar as chemical weapons are concerned,'' he said. In money terms, Cheney is eliminating $66.7 million from the Bigeye bomber; $74.3 million from the artillery shell program and $27.8 million from the MLRS program. But Williams said money will be needed after when the chemical weapons programs are killed because ``it takes some money to cancel a contract. ... You can't just call up a contractor and say, `I'm sorry, never mind.''' Williams said the Defense Department will continue to buy a chemicals used in the binary weapons _ weapons that use two harmless chemicals that are dangerous only when combined _ in order to finish testing at a plant in Pine Bluff, Ark. Officials want to make sure they can produce binary weapons in case the United States ``should need it, should something go wrong with the treaty.'' On a related matter, Williams said U.S. officials have temporarily stopped verification tests at the Johnston Atoll chemical agent disposal system, about 700 miles southwest of Hawaii. ``They want to take stock of what has happened so far,'' Williams said, adding there were ``some positive monitor'' readings after a chemical weapons test. Officials want to make sure the monitors are working properly, he said. Tests are expected to resume at the end of the week.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Experiments With Interactive TV on Late-Night Newscast
DOC.TEXT: Viewers who grumble that the only news on TV is bad news soon will be able to choose some of the stories they want to see on Cable News Network. CNN announced Thursday the first experiment in ``interactive news'' by a national network _ a program similar to ones by smaller stations where viewers vote on whether to see ``Godzilla'' or ``Planet of the Apes'' as the late-night movie. The experiment begins July 23 on CNN's ``Newsnight,'' an hour-long newscast at midnight. The choices will involve secondary news or features. Viewers will see a summary of headlines at the beginning of the show and, as anchors read the day's top news, dial a 900 telephone number to vote on which of the stories they'd like to see. The stories that get the most votes, which cost 95 cents per call, will be shown. CNN officials emphasize that viewers won't be dictating news value but will tell the network what areas, outside of breaking news, most interest them. ``We're not going to let viewers decide the editorial policy of CNN,'' said spokesman John Bianchi. ``A lot of stuff does not make it on the air that we do in fact cover. This is a way to get more of the stuff on the air that we might not have made the decision on initially.'' Bianchi said CNN, which had trouble filling all its newscasts when it was started by media mogul Ted Turner in 1980, just doesn't have enough time now to air all the stories it would like to. So viewers _ in 54 million U.S. households and 90 countries _ are being asked to let producers know their preferences. ``We can tell by the volume and quality of viewer phone calls and letters we receive each day that CNN has very informed viewers,'' said CNN Senior Executive Bob Furnad. ``This new interactive segment will allow those viewers to tell us in a relatively direct fashion the kinds of information they most want.'' At least one of CNN's network competitors reacted with surprise to the announcement. Asked if the concept would spread to the Big Three networks, CBS spokesman Tom Goodman said, ``It doesn't sound like something we'd get involved in.'' The public relations departments at NBC and ABC offered no immediate response. Interactive television, a concept of two-way communication between viewers and programmers with TV remote controls, emerged in the early 1980s. CNN's concept ``is not exactly the promise of interactivity where you can really customize your TV viewing on what you want to see,'' said media analyst Betsy Frank with Saatchi & Saatchi in New York. ``But using 900-line technology to a certain degree and having people feel they have a decision-making posture in what gets aired _ it's an interesting idea.'' Ms. Frank said the phone-in concept is not new _ networks like Fox have used it for viewers to vote on movie lineups. ``The trend of the last decade is viewers assuming more control and taking it away from the three networks,'' she said, adding that CNN could raise its ratings with the experiment. ``The more involved the viewer, the more likely he is to hang around.'' Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. developed the first interactive technology, called ``Qube,'' in Ohio in 1981. In one experiment, cable subscribers electronically registered their reactions to a speech by then-President Carter by responding to questions on remote, book-sized consoles hooked to their televisions. ACTV Domestic Corp. then developed technology, tested in a eight-week experiment on Continental Cablevision in Massachusetts, in which viewers of a golf tournament chose which player they wanted to see. The camera followed that player through the course.

DOC.HEAD: Technology Gives Way to History as Nation's Last Crank Phone System Dies
LaserPhoto IDA1
DOC.TEXT: A bit of Americana slipped into history Thursday when the nation's last known operating hand-cranked, party-line telephone system was disconnected _ replaced by private-line, touch-tone technology. ``Now that I know it's working, I'm going to call my mother back in Iowa,'' said Joyce Rinehart at the Ramshead motel and restaurant. ``This is the first time I've talked on a phone like this in a long time where I could hear and not have to shout.'' ``I'm not screaming anymore,'' said Garry Pedrow as he answered the first incoming call on the new system at his Shoup Country Store near North Fork in central Idaho's rugged Salmon River canyon. ``It's sure nice.'' The depression-era, single-line, ring-down system, a fixture of rural America in decades past, had been the link to the rest of the world for the 18 year-round canyon residents. Parties on the line could crank the magneto to ring others along the line or the central office for a connection to town numbers and long-distance. Each customer had a coded ring and supposedly answered just that ring while ignoring the rest. Operator Steve Freestone handled the last outgoing call from the old system at the switchboard of his Motel Deluxe in Salmon 20 miles away and then announced the old line was dead. A half hour later, state Public Utilities Commission President Joe Miller placed the first call on the new system to Gary Byrne, head of the Rural Electrification Administration, which underwrote the $350,000 modernization. ``We're moving into our second century,'' said Miller, referring to Idaho's centennial on July 3. ``It's time for as much of our state as possible to be connected to the rest of the world in a meaningful way.'' The demise of the battery and magneto system was set a year ago when AT&T said computerization would require the elimination of the local operator. Freestone and the operators preceding him connected calls from canyon customers to the proper numbers outside and routed incoming calls to the right phone, using a series of coded rings. The Shoup Country Store was three longs. AT&T, US WEST and Century Telephone Co. in Salmon agreed to keep the operator in place until installation of the new system. Residents along the wilderness river had mixed feelings about losing a system they felt fit in well with a lifestyle that includes only seasonal running water and requires private generators for electricity. ``It's historic, ... but when you're in business you need a town phone system,'' said Rinehart at the Ramshead motel and restaurant about 30 miles down the canyon. The crank system was originally set up by the U.S. Forest Service in 1931. It was bought by the resident cooperative called the North Fork Telephone Corp. for a dollar in 1952 when the government switched to radio communications. The years had taken their toll. ``It's a raggedy old thing,'' Freestone said. ``They've got it nailed to trees and mountains. Most of the time you have to yell pretty loud to talk to people down river.'' In their heyday, the wall-mounted units with a black metal mouthpiece on an arm and a receiver hung on a two-prong hook on the left side were the communications heart of as many as 1.25 million American farms and ranches. Party line chatter, with two or three parties talking and several more secretly listening, was a popular rural recreation, long before electricity, television and even radio. Pedrow said the canyon residents are keeping a few of the hand crank phones hooked together for the historic value, an idea whole-heartedly endorsed by Rinehart. ``I'd just like to keep them around to show the younger generation what we had to use,'' she said. ``On this old system I've talked to the Marshall Islands. I've talked to Canada. I've talked to Hawaii. So that old line did reach out.''

DOC.HEAD: President Appoints Sullivan Chief Military Appeals Judge
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday named Eugene R. Sullivan to be chief judge of the U.S. Court of Military Appeals, the White House announced. The appointment takes effect Oct. 1. Sullivan, a member of the military appeals court since 1986, succeeds Robinson O. Everett. The White House also announced John S. McGraw will remain as assayer of the U.S. Mint in Philadelphia, a post he has held since 1983. The president also announced several board appointments: To the Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board he named: Porfirio C. Diaz Jr., an assistant director of the California Department of Rehabilitation in Sacramento; Scott Moore Duncan, a fund-raiser for Duncan and Associates in Houston, and Robert T. Kelly Jr., a Southern Bell official in Miami. To the arts advisory committee of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts he named: Susan Goldwater Keenan, a member of the board of directors of Pace Industries, Inc., of Aiken, S.C., and Chesley Pruet, president of Chesley Pruet Drilling Co. of El Dorado, Ark. And he named Vartan Gregorian, president of Brown University, and Margarita B. Tonkinson, a University of Miami administrator in Coral Gables, Fla., to the Fulbright Scholarship Board.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Says Consumers Paying Too Much For International Calls
DOC.TEXT: U.S. consumers are paying as much as $1 billion too much annually for international telephone calls, the Federal Communications Commission said Thursday in proposing to make it easier for U.S. carriers to negotiate lower rates with overseas phone companies. The commission said U.S. phone companies in 1988 paid $2 billion more to foreign _ usually government-operated _ phone companies than they collected from foreign carriers for international calls. About half that amount represented an overpayment by U.S. consumers to foreign carriers, the FCC said. Intense competition among U.S. phone companies since the 1984 breakup of the Bell system has pushed prices down for international calls, but has resulted in foreign companies gaining a larger share of the charges for such calls, FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes said before the commission's 5-0 vote. ``Competition and technological progress in telecommunications has revealed a cartel-like pricing and profit-sharing arrangement,'' Sikes said. ``U.S. subscribers and those in a handful of other countries are both the winners and losers.'' Companies such as AT&T negotiate ``accounting rates'' that determine how AT&T and a foreign company will divide the charges consumers pay for international calls. Under present formulas, about 75 cents of every dollar collected by U.S. carriers for international calls goes to foreign carriers. AT&T contends foreign governments are charging far above the actual cost of service, and that because more calls flow from the United States to other countries than in the reverse direction, having accounting rates that exceed costs results in a significant outflow of U.S. dollars to other nations. Some overseas phone carriers use the funds to finance local service and say it is vital to their economies. AT&T argues that what foreign entities will lose in lower accounting rates, they will more than make up in the increased volume of calling resulting from lower prices. The FCC proposed to allow U.S. companies to negotiate lower accounting rates more quickly. The commission also proposed to lower the accounting rates itself, if it finds that costs are too high. AT&T welcomed the commission's proposal. Company spokesman Herb Linnen said the proposal ``sets up the possibility of lowering accounting rates for all of the U.S. carriers, and that can translate into savings for consumers.''

DOC.HEAD: Text of Nicaraguan Strike Settlement
DOC.TEXT:
Here is the text of the Nicaraguan strike settlement as translated from Spanish by The Associated Press: 1. Considering the need to reestablish social tranquility and a climate of confidence that is needed to foster reactivation of the economy, the government of Nicaragua, represented by the Employment and Salary Commission, met with a delegation of the National Workers' Front (FNT) July 11, 1990. After a presentation to the government by the labor leaders, the government of Nicaragua communicates the following: First: It has made the following decisions to be effective immediately: _ It will apply in the present month of July a general adjustment of 43 percent to budgeted salaries. This adjustment will be paid July 25. At the same time it is established that in the month of August a salary increase for the budgeted sector will be established according to the economic capacity of the government. This emphasizes the need to help the majority of the lowest-paid workers. _ An environment of confidence and labor stability will be strengthened for public servants of the central government, autonomous organizations and state-run businesses. All workers who return normally to their jobs will have the right to continue in them. _ Meanwhile, the Civil Service Law is changed so that public sector workers fired after April 26, 1990, will get an indemnity equal to a month's salary for each year worked up to three months. Cases in which special agreements or arrangements have been reached are excepted. _ Transportation tokens to all workers and students who now get them are guaranteed. _ (The government) will pay the debts the Transportation and Construction Ministry owes to businesses. _ With relation to Law 90-10, the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock has reviewed all rental requests, which were made public in separate lists and ended the application of said law. As the rental contracts contemplate, (businesses) will push for stability and more rights for workers on rented productive lands. _ Reclassification of job categories by the state to take effect in September of this year will proceed. Second: The following points will be studied and analyzed: _ In problems existing in some branches of industry, especially in textiles, construction, metals, public transport and other branches of the economy (mining, timber, fishing, etc.) a program will be put in practice requiring industrial reactivation and rehabilitation, the immediate objective of which will be to maintain jobs for the workers in these areas. To bring this about a mixed commission will be organized among government representatives and those of the FTN, which will be installed Monday, July 16, giving priority to the textile industry. _ Within the framework of tripartism, a commission will be formed made up of employers, unions and the government to prepare a proposal for a minimum wage law that will be presented to the National Assembly in September at the latest. The minimum wage will be expressed in gold cordobas. Third: The government ratifies entirely its extension of an agreement reached with the FNT May 16, 1990, which includes: _ The application of national agreements with their respective additions and rules signed with the Education Ministry, the National Association of Nicaraguan Educators and the Health Ministry, the Federation of Health Workers and will not change them. _ The commitment on regulations for the Civil Service Law. Any modification of this agreement will be discussed in advance and approved by the parties. Fourth: Representatives of the FNT who sign the present communique express: _ Taking into consideration resolutions that the government of Nicaragua makes public in this communique, pledge that the workers and employees will return normally to their work July 12 of this year. They also pledge to respect the normality and public order in the entire country. _ Their willingness to promote the resumption of productive work in the agriculture and livestock sector and to reestablish the climate of tranquility and labor stability that is required to fulfill production goals. _ Their satisfaction over the government's statements that it will take no reprisals against workers and employees who return to their jobs normally beginning July 12. In concluding the conversations, which were held in a climate of understanding, both parties pledge to maintain a fluid and permanent communication on the economic problems for the purpose of contributing to reactivation of production and national reconstruction. In the city of Managua, the 11th day of the month of July of 1990. Signed: (for the government) Antonio Lacayo, minister of the presidency Francisco Rosales, minister of labor Silvio De Franco, minister of the economy Emilio Pereira, minister of finances Francisco Mayorga, minister-director of the Central Bank of Nicaragua
(for the FNT) Lucio Jimenez Edgardo Garcia Gustavo Porras Guillermo Martinez Jose Angel Bermudez Freddy Cruz Lilly Soto

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Says Wheat Farmers Harvesting Bumper Crop
DOC.TEXT: Wheat farmers are harvesting a bumper crop estimated at 2.7 billion bushels, up 33 percent from last year and the biggest output in six years, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. ``This would be the largest crop since 1982 and the third largest on record,'' the department said in a report. And it will be a near-record production at that. Records show the biggest U.S. wheat crops were back-to-back in 1981 with 2.79 billion bushels and 1982 with 2.77 billion. New production estimates for the first time this season included durum and other spring-planted wheat, in addition to winter wheat planted last fall. The department's Agricultural Statistics Board said the average yield, based on indications as of July 1, was estimated at 38.6 bushels per acre, compared with 32.8 bushels last year. Farmers are expected to harvest about 70 million acres of wheat this year, also the most since 1982. The 1989 crop was from 62.1 million harvested acres. The department's first official estimate of 1990 corn, soybeans and some other major spring-planted crops will be issued Aug. 9, along with an updated estimate of wheat production. Winter wheat production was estimated at 2.04 billion bushels, down 3 percent from the June forecast but up 40 percent from the 1989 harvest. Winter wheat makes up about three-fourths of the U.S. total. Yields in many of the winter wheat states are down from the June forecast, especially in Illinois and Missouri, the report said. The huge Kansas crop, at 460.2 million bushels, was unchanged from last month. Durum wheat production was estimated at 114 million bushels, up 24 percent from last year, and other spring wheat was indicated at 549 million bushels, up 12 percent from 1989. North Dakota, the biggest durum producer, was estimated at 97.6 million bushels, compared with 66 million bushels last year. The state's production of ``other'' spring wheat, also the largest, was estimated at 254.4 million bushels, up from 174 million in 1989. Government crop watchers said earlier this week that the nation's wheat harvest was 71 percent completed by July 8, slightly ahead of the five-year average for this time. The July report also estimated barley production at 414 million bushels, up 3 percent from last year. Yields were indicated at 53.4 bushels per acre, up 4.9 bushels from 1989. Oats production was estimated at 375 million bushels, virtually the same as last year, with average yields at 60.2 bushels per acre, compared with last season's 54.4 bushels. Flue-cured tobacco production was forecast at 856 million pounds, up 6 percent from last year, reflecting a larger acreage. In a related supply-and-demand report, ``highly tentative'' projections of 1990 production of corn showed the fall harvest might total 7.85 billion bushels. That would be down from the 8.1 billion bushels projected in June, but still larger than the 1989 harvest of 7.53 billion bushels. ``Among many contributing factors are late plantings in parts of the Corn Belt, an extended period of hot, dry weather in the South and slightly less planted area than indicated (by a survey) in March,'' the report said. Soybean production also was projected down _ 1.86 billion bushels against 1.93 billion projected in June. Last year's output was about 1.93 billion bushels, about what had been projected in June for 1990. The analysis showed wheat prices at the farm in 1990-91 may average in the range of $2.80 to $3.20 per bushel, down 10 cents from the June forecast. Last season, wheat prices averaged $3.72 per bushel. Corn prices, reflecting tighter supplies, were projected to average $2.50 to $2.90 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year, up 15 cents from June. They are expected to be in the range of $2.35 to $2.40 in 1989-90. Soybean prices were projected at $5.50 to $6.75 per bushel, a 50-cent increase from the range last month. The 1989-90 price was estimated at $5.70 per bushel. Cotton production was projected at 15 million bales, down 1 million bales from the June outlook, primarily because of ``extremely hot, dry conditions which have reduced prospective harvested acreage and trimmed potential yields in Texas,'' the report said. No price information was projected for 1990-91 cotton.

DOC.HEAD: Sand Sculptors Miss Record by 2 Inches
DOC.TEXT: The shifting sands of this beach resort foiled an attempt to build the world's largest sand sculpture. When officials from the Guinness Book of World Records arrived to measure the mammoth castle, they found the top had crumbled slightly _ leaving it 2 inches short of the record of 56 feet, 2 inches. ``We built the mound up to 60 feet high, but we made it too steep at the top,'' said Adam Showell, project coordinator for Sandcastle Fest 90. ``You can't make sand stand straight up.'' As a result, some sand fell during carving. Guinness only allowed one chance last Friday, so the builders could not add 2 inches and have it remeasured, he said. Gerry Kirk and a team from San Diego-based Sand Sculptors International, which also built the world record sand sculpture in Kaseda, Japan, oversaw the Ocean City project. ``We were short of the world record, but it is still the tallest sand sculpture ever built in the United States,'' Showell said. Thousands attended the sand castle festival, which will be held again next year.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Quits Party, Leads Reformers' Exodus
LaserPhoto MOSB6
DOC.TEXT: Populist Boris N. Yeltsin quit the Communist Party on Thursday in a move that could start the exodus of liberals that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has warned could destroy his reform movement. Yeltsin's dramatic announcement to the 28th Communist Party congress capped a day in which his orthodox Marxist foe, Yegor K. Ligachev, was vanquished in a bid for the party's No. 2 job. For more than two years, Gorbachev has balanced the party between liberals, led by Yeltsin, and hard-liners led by Ligachev. The departure of Gorbachev's two antagonists marked a triumph for Gorbachev's centrist politics. But it could prove a hollow victory. Yeltsin took with him some of the most reform-minded party members. Leaders of the Democratic Platform reform movement announced they would follow Yeltsin out of the party and form a rival group. Other delegates who favor Yeltsin's demands for faster and more radical economic reforms were thought likely to follow. It would be the first split in the Communist Party since 1921. Yeltsin, elected president of the Russian republic in May on the strength of his populist program, became the first non-Communist leader of that huge territory in 72 years of Soviet power. The burly, white-haired reformer strode down the center aisle to the podium in the Kremlin Palace of Congresses and read without emotion from a sheet of paper to a silent audience. He said that as newly elected president of Russia he could no longer obey only the policies of the Communist Party. ``In connection with my election as the chairman (president) of the Supreme Soviet of Russia and my great responsibility before the people of Russia, taking into account the transition of society to a multiparty system, I cannot fulfill only the decisions of the Communist Party,'' he said. ``I have to obey the will of the people and their all-powerful representatives,'' he said. ``Therefore in connection with my obligations, I declare my exit from the party.'' Yeltsin's announcement was greeted with some applause, whistles of derision, and shouts of ``Shame!'' He left the podium and walked out of the congress hall without further comment. Yeltsin said he had planned to make the announcement after the congress, but was forced to do it earlier because he was nominated for the party's Central Committee, which will be elected before the congress adjourns. Gorbachev brought Yeltsin to Moscow in 1985 from the Ural Mountain industrial center of Sverdlovsk, but fired him as Moscow party boss two years later for criticizing the slow pace of reform. Yeltsin rebounded by launching a populist campaign against Gorbachev, and tops the Soviet leader in popularity in some polls. Gorbachev said Yeltsin's resignation would not be discussed at the congress, but otherwise showed no reaction. Outside the hall, however, one prominent military official called Yeltsin's actions disgraceful. Marshal Nikolai Ogarkov said Yeltsin made a ``shameful speech.'' The Communist Party helped Yeltsin ``and suddenly he throws it up and leaves it,'' Ogarkov said. Yeltsin's resignation led the Soviet evening television news program ``Vremya.'' The announcer declared the resignation a ``sensation.'' Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, a leader of Democratic Platform, took the floor and said he and other reform-minded delegates, including Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak, Yuri Boldyrev of Leningrad and Vladimir Lysenko of Moscow were leaving the party. He did not say exactly how many leaving the party, but said they would form their own independent organization. Delegates began applauding in the middle of his statement in an effort to cut him off. ``I am empowered to declare a division in the Communist Party, and our intention to form an independent, democratic, parliamentary party,'' Shostakovsky said. He urged delegates not to turn in their party cards, but to register with the Democratic Platform, apparently in order to later lay claim to Communist Party property. Vladimir Filin, a spokesman for Democratic Platform, estimated that only about 15 percent of Democratic Platform members would remain in the Communist Party. According to the organization's polls, about 40 percent of the party's 18 million members support the Democratic Platform. Gorbachev said as he opened the congress that unity was essential among reformers. ``If perestroika fails, it will be because someone succeeds in splitting the pro-perestroika forces,'' he said. He and his advisers have preached unity throughout the congress' 10 days, and until Thursday it seemed to be working. The congress was scheduled to continue Friday. Ligachev pledged to stand by the Communist Party, despite his drubbing by Gorbachev's choice, Vladimir A. Ivashko, for the party's new No. 2 job. Asked to comment on the speech by Yeltsin, his long-time foe, Ligachev hinted that the party would be better off without him. ``There are people who, in leaving the party, could strengthen it,'' he said. ``For me for example, if I left the party, it would be political death.'' Ligachev admitted he had no chance of remaining on the party's ruling Politburo, where he has been Gorbachev's leading critic among the hard-liners. ``There's no need for it,'' he said. His name also did not appear on the list of 311 party members nominated by the 15 republics for the policy-making Central Committee. However, it was not clear whether he was among 85 others nominated by Gorbachev and the central leadership.

DOC.HEAD: `The Get to Know Me' Man Leaves NBC's `Saturday Night Live'
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Jon Lovitz, the saturnine ``Saturday Night Live'' cast member who potrayed a pathological liar with the catch phrase ``That's the ticket,'' is leaving the show. Lovitz joined the show in 1985 and had a five-year contract as a member of the ``SNL'' company, NBC announced late Wednesday. His other, recurring comedic bits included an impression of playwright Harvey Fierstein as an affection-starved talk show host, and as himself, jovially urging viewers to ``Get to know me!'' In May, when fellow cast member Nora Dunn boycotted the show hosted by raunch comedian Andrew Dice Clay, Lovitz played Satan in a parody of ``It's a Wonderful Life,'' showing that Dunn's boycott saved her from a tragic death. ``He has an enormous gift, and his talent contributed greatly to the success of the show,'' the program's executive producer, Lorne Michaels, said. ``He was always punctual and worked well with others. I would recommend him to any other producer without hesitation. ``I am sad to see him move on, and I wish him all the best in his work in the future. He will always be welcome here.'' NBC said Lovitz could be reached only through his Los Angeles-based manager, Brad Gray, who did not return phone calls from The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Thursday's Session of the Party Congress
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights of Thursday's session of the 28th Communist Party congress, its 10th day. The congress is scheduled to continue Friday.

YELTSIN QUITS PARTY: Boris N. Yeltsin, the populist president of the Russian republic, stunned the congress by announcing he was quitting the party. Although some delegates shouted ``Shame!'' and whistled derisively, Mikhail S. Gorbachev had no reaction, other than to say the congress would not discuss the resignation. Leaders of the Democratic Platform reform movement also said they were leaving the party.

LIGACHEV NOT BITTER: Traditionalist Yegor K. Ligachev, defeated in his bid to become deputy party leader and left off a list for the new Central Committee, nevertheless said he had no intention of leaving the political scene: ``I have sound health and the energies _ both intellectual and physical _ for this. Don't forget, I am a Siberian. I plan to write a book about my life and generally, I'll tell you honestly, I am in a good mood.''

KEY QUOTE: ``I have to obey the will of the people and their all-powerful representatives. Therefore, in connection with my obligations, I declare my exit from the party.'' _ Boris Yeltsin, announcing his resignation from the Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Oil-Eating Microbes Worked in Mega Borg Tests
DOC.TEXT: Oil-eating microbes dumped on a slick from a leaking tanker in the Gulf of Mexico apparently did their job: gobbling up oil without hurting the environment, officials said Thursday. State Land Commissioner Garry Mauro and Texas Water Commission Chairman B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne said that while more testing is needed, there is enough evidence to push for expanded use of the process called bioremediation. ``We have strong evidence that bioremediation works,'' Mauro told a news conference. ``The results show that we are close to having a tool that actually cleans up oil spills.'' The microbes were tested after the Norwegian tanker Mega Borg exploded June 8 and burned 57 miles off Galveston. An estimated 3.9 million gallons of light crude leaked into the Gulf. Much of the oil burned, but some created a slick that appeared headed toward the Texas coast. Skimmers and booms were deployed, but Mauro and Wynne pushed to test the microbes. The test, done first on about 40 acres of the spill and again on a smaller patch, was not a major part of the cleanup. Mauro and Wynne said Thursday there is no evidence the microbes caused any environmental damage. Both said the microbes should be used again on the next significant oil spill, and should be tested on smaller spills near the Texas coast. The test on the Mega Borg spill marked the first time the microbes were used in open waters. Bioremediation had been used before to clean up hazardous waste sites, extract oil from tight geologic formations, and clean some rocks on shore after the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska last year. The naturally occurring bacteria reduce the oil to an emulsion of fatty acids, which sinks and is eaten by fish. When the oil is gone, the microbes die. ``We found surface oil was reduced after the application, and we found no similar reduction in the control slick,'' Mauro said. The surface oil in some samples was ``reduced to 30 percent of the original volume,'' he said. Wynne and Mauro conceded that weather and currents may have helped disperse the oil, but were confident the microbes did their duty. ``The best that anything else in our oil spill response arsenal can do is mitigate disaster,'' Mauro said. The next step, he said, is persuading companies to include bioremediation in their oil spill contingency plans.

DOC.HEAD: California Board Adopts Rules to Protect Owls, Reduce Timber Harvesting
DOC.TEXT: Loggers can't harvest parts of privately owned forests where threatened spotted owls live, under rules adopted by a state panel. The decision could make California the first state to officially protect the species. Timber industry leaders immediately blasted Wednesday's decision by the state Board of Forestry that could cut logging in Northern California in half and could cost up to 1,900 jobs. ``I'm here representing the 25,000 people who are going to be out of work because of your decision today,'' said Gil Murray, of the Timber Association of California. Environmentalists supported the decision because it protects old growth Redwood trees where spotted owls have been found, but they said a harvesting moratorium is needed. ``We've got to become the first state to shut the door on this destruction to preserve jobs, forests and a healthy planet,'' said Mark Heitchue, a Santa Cruz member of the environmental group Earth First! The regulations would take effect July 23 if they are approved by the state's office of administrative law. The rules would be in effect during the next three months until a more comprehensive protection plan is approved. In June, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service put the spotted owl on the threatened species list, setting up the battle between the timber industry and environmentalists. The regulations, which apply to all counties north of Marin, don't ban logging entirely within areas where the owl lives. But landowners won't be allowed to cut timber within 1.5 miles of where a spotted owl has been seen. Ross Johnson, chief of forest practice regulations for the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, estimated timber yields will decrease from 35 percent to 50 percent under the temporary rules. It could cost between 968 and 1,901 jobs in lumber and related industries, depending on how the rules are enforced, he said. Biologists estimate that about 5,000 pairs of spotted owls have survived recent years of clear-cutting of old growth forests in Washington, Oregon and California.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Allege Some U.S. Subsidiaries Are Dodging Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Democrats and Republicans took turns Thursday decrying alleged tax dodging by U.S. subsidiaries of foreign corporations, but the Treasury Department would not concede there is wholesale cheating. ``I propose we're talking about billions _ in the range of $30 billion'' a year in tax avoidance, said Rep. J.J. Pickle, D-Texas, chairman of the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee. Other members of the panel, which has been investigating the problem for nine months, put the figure at $50 billion. ``We really do not have a way of estimating'' the tax loss, said Kenneth Gideon, assistant secretary of the Treasury for tax policy. ``I would find $50 billion very hard to accept'' because the U.S. take from all corporations is only about twice that figure. Rep. Ronnie Flippo, D-Ala., asked if foreign-controlled corporations were paying their share. ``That's a question I can't answer,'' Gideon replied. ``In many cases what we have is criminal conduct,'' said Rep. Clay Shaw, R-Fla. ``The way these companies are operating ... I find incredible.'' ``These companies are paying less than the average citizen, the average taxpayers of the United States,'' said Rep. Richard Schulze, R-Pa. ``That's abominable.'' Noting a movement to raise taxes to reduce the budget deficit, Schulze shouted: ``I'll be damned if I'll do it while billions of dollars are floating overseas.'' That sentiment was echoed by lawmakers as diverse as House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. The Internal Revenue Service told the subcommittee earlier this week that foreign subsidiaries operating in the United States had revenues of $686 billion in 1987 and paid federal income tax of $4.56 billion. That rate of 0.66 percent of revenues compares with 1.04 percent paid that same year by U.S.-owned corporations. Subcommittee investigators examined 36 giant companies that distribute foreign-made automobiles, motorcycles and consumer electronic goods in this country and found that more than half paid little or no tax over a 10-year period. The chief means of avoiding U.S. tax was through a practice known as transfer pricing. A foreign company could charge its U.S. subsidiary an artificially high price for television sets, for example, thus lowering the amount of income subject to U.S. tax. Such price manipulation also can worsen the U.S. trade deficit and make it more difficult for American companies to compete abroad, witnesses told the subcommittee. Michael E. Granfield, vice chancellor of the University of California, Los Angeles, who assisted the IRS in an earlier case against Japanese automobile companies, said there is a serious compliance problem. Granfield said the IRS is hampered by a lack of resources and the inability to pay salaries high enough to retain personnel who can match expertise with industry economists and lawyers. But the agency has other problems of its own creation, including a penchant for seeking settlements that are so high as to be counterproductive, he said. ``It is transparent that the IRS is not doing an adequate job in this area,'' Granfield said. Pickle expressed hope that the subcommittee's investigation not be viewed as aimed solely as Japanese corporations. Although government officials are barred by law from disclosing the names of taxpayers being investigated by the IRS, most of the criticism of subcommittee members has been aimed at Japanese companies _ though not by name. Rep. Duncan Hunter of California, chairman of the House Republican Research Committee, released a list of Japanese companies that he said have been identified in public reports as being under IRS investigation. The list included many of the Japanese companies best known to Americans, including Hitachi, Toshiba, Sony, Nissan, Toyota, Yamaha and Matsushita Electric (Panasonic).

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Warns Against Reducing Deposit Insurance Coverage
With AM-Fed-Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: Congress would be better off forcing bank owners to invest more capital in their institutions than scaling back the $100,000 limit on deposit insurance, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said Thursday. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee he did not flatly oppose an insurance reduction, but he warned that lowering the limit would involve ``significant transition costs.'' He acknowledged the need for change in the wake of the savings and loan crisis, but said deposit insurance has lent stability to the financial system. Deposit insurance allowed thrift owners to gamble on investments, knowing they may reap the profits if they succeeded but taxpayers would pick up most of the loss if they failed. However, it also has ``been the major reason why the United States has not suffered a financial panic or systemic bank run in the last half-century,'' the chairman said. ``Reform is required. So is caution,'' he added. The most promising approach would be to force bank and S&L owners to risk more of their own capital, he said. That should be coupled with improved supervision to make sure banks use sound practices, are reined in when they weaken and closed promptly if they fail. More capital is needed particularly if, as the board advocates, banks are allowed to engage in activities traditionally forbidden to them, such as securities underwriting, he said. Thursday's Banking Committee hearing was 10th in a series of 13 intended to lay the groundwork for next year's debate on an overhaul of the financial and banking system. Greenspan's views generally carry great weight with members of Congress. The Bush administration is expected to make its own recommendations in a report late this year. The 1980 decision by Congress and the Carter administration to boost deposit insurance from $40,000 per account to $100,000 is often cited as one of the root causes of the savings and loan crisis. Advocates of cutting the limit include conservatives who oppose government intervention in the economy and populists who believe the $100,000 deposit insurance limit protects rich people at the expense of average taxpayers. ``If we were starting from scratch, the board believes it would be difficult to make the case that deposit insurance coverage should be as high as the current $100,000 level,'' Greenspan said. ``However,'' he said, ``it is one thing initially to offer and then maintain a smaller degree of insurance coverage, and quite another to reimpose on the existing system a lower level of insurance, with its associated readjustment and unwinding costs.'' The central bank chairman also said Congress should exercise care in increasing risks to uninsured deposits over the $100,000 limit. ``Runs of uninsured deposits from banks under stress have become commonplace. So far, the pressure transmitted from such episodes to other banks whose strength may be in doubt has been minimal,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Says Barry Used Drugs, Drank Heavily Before Collapse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with late testimony, inserting 6 grafs after 13th graf, After Barry
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry used drugs and drank heavily before collapsing at a 1987 Super Bowl party, a friend testified Thursday at the mayor's cocaine and perjury trial. Jeffrey Mitchell said Barry was rushed to a hospital and given oxygen but then ``said he didn't want any tests'' and walked out. The two men used cocaine on at least 10 occasions from 1985 to 1987, testified Mitchell, an advertising executive who has worked on Barry's mayoral campaigns. In major areas, his testimony supported that of another Barry friend who told the jury on Wednesday of a conversation with Mitchell about the Super Bowl episode. But the two witnesses disagreed on several points, including whose idea it was to steer clear of tests at the hospital. Lawyer Lloyd Moore had testified that Mitchell told him he had refused to allow blood tests on Barry. Mitchell testified Thursday that he did not intervene. At a 1987 Super Bowl party in Los Angeles, Mitchell testified, he found the mayor slumped in a chair with his head back and pinching his nose. Earlier, they had smoked a marijuana cigarette and Barry drank champagne, a fifth of cognac and wine, said Mitchell. Barry was sniffing heavily, trying to clear an air passage and ``he looked uncomfortable,'' Mitchell testified. ``He said he was having trouble breathing.'' Had there been other times when Barry made those sounds? asked assistant U.S. attorney Judith Retchin. ``Yes ... often after we had done cocaine,'' said Mitchell. Mitchell said he helped Barry out of the chair and told him to take deep breaths, but it didn't help. ``He felt like he was going to faint,'' Mitchell said of Barry. After Barry was taken to an emergency room in an ambulance, he was given oxygen and ``seemed to feel a little stronger. He wanted to leave. ... He said he didn't want any tests,'' said Mitchell. Barry did leave the hospital, the witness said. The official explanation given at the time for Barry's collapse was that he had suffered a hiatal hernia. Another witness Thursday, Darrell Sabbs, said that he and the mayor snorted cocaine together on four occasions between 1986 and last September. Sabbs traveled to Washington on Jan. 19 for Barry's planned announcement that he was running for re-election, but Barry was arrested the night of Jan. 18 in an FBI sting operation and charged with cocaine possession. By the time Sabbs got in town, ``there had been this entrap, sting or whatever,'' testified Sabbs, who was a reluctant prosecution witness. The day after Barry's arrest, Sabbs spoke to the mayor by telephone and ``told him that I loved him and to take care of himself.'' Barry's defense in the sting operation is that the FBI trapped him into smoking crack cocaine. The mayor has announced he won't seek re-election. Mitchell said he and Barry snorted cocaine on two fishing trips on the Chesapeake Bay, at a Memorial Day cookout, on a trip to the Bahamas and on a number of other occasions, usually at Mitchell's home. They even used cocaine by blowing it into each other's mouths off a card, he said. He said it was Barry who introduced him to cocaine, putting it up Mitchell's nose with a matchbook cover or a business card during a fishing trip. The ad executive said he and the mayor were close friends and he tried to slow Barry's cocaine use by sometimes lying when asked if he had any. ``If I knew that he was going somewhere ... in an official capacity, I just said I didn't have'' the drug, said Mitchell. ``I love Marion Barry,'' he said. Mitchell disputed other portions of Moore's testimony about the Super Bowl trip. Moore and Mitchell had a conversation about Barry's collapse shortly after it occurred, and Moore testified about that Wednesday. Moore said Mitchell indicated the mayor had been smoking ``cocaine laced with something.'' Mitchell said it was Moore who ``suggested'' that Barry ``might have gotten hold of some bad stuff, speed.'' Moore testified that the conversation with Mitchell occurred in a telephone call. Mitchell testified the two talked face-to-face in Washington. Moore was ``strictly speculating'' that cocaine caused the collapse? Barry's lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, asked on cross-examination. ``Yes,'' replied Mitchell.

DOC.HEAD: Court Asked to Push Government for Federal Property for Homeless
DOC.TEXT: An advocacy group said in federal court Thursday that the Bush administration is dragging its feet on a judge's order that surplus government property be made available for the homeless. The group filed a motion seeking to enforce a 1988 permanent injunction requiring the federal government to correct violations and speed up implementation of the surplus property program. The action was filed by the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty in U.S. District Court in Washington. The center said only 28 surplus federal properties have been made available to house the homeless despite a 1987 federal law and the 1988 court injunction issued by U.S. District Judge Oliver Gasch. ``Almost two years later, the federal agencies are still doing everything possible to subvert this program,'' said Maria Foscarinis, director of the center, a non-profit advocacy group. ``The federal government has barely lifted a finger to use its enormous existing resources to help those most in need.'' The center contends in documents filed with the court that the Department of Housing and Urban Development has failed to adequately review federal properties that may be suitable for the homeless. They also charged the application process is too burdensome and has discouraged non-profit organizations from applying for surplus property to house homeless people. The surplus property program was begun as part of a 1987 Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act, which was named for its sponsor, the late Republican congressman from Connecticut.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Host Suspended, Apologizes after Banning Blacks From Calling
DOC.TEXT: A radio talk show host was suspended Thursday for barring black listeners from calling his show. He and the station apologized. Tim Lennox said he was upset because a black man had broken into a station employee's car and stolen her purse.
