He told his listeners about the theft during hi two-hour show Wednesday, then stopped blacks from calling. ``I made an emotional spur of the moment decision to accept only calls from white listeners,'' Lennox said at the start of his Thursday program. ``I want to sincerely apologize to anyone who was offended by my actions. Anybody who has listened to my show for 14 years is aware of my liberal outlook,'' said the 40-year-old Lennox, who is white. Berkley Fraser, WERC-AM general manager, said he decided to let Lennox go on the air Thursday ``because he said he wanted to apologize to the Birmingham community. We let him have that opportunity.'' Fraser earlier apologized on behalf of the station and announced that Lennox had been suspended indefinitely. The station, Fraser said, encourages free expression with its live programming and ``unfortunately, mistakes do occur.'' Fraser said three station employees in the parking lot saw the thief knock out a window, grab the purse and run. Lennox said he had not planned to continue the ban throughout Wednesday's two-hour show but did so even though some callers disapproved. ``I've never had a show this intense before,'' he said. ``Even my white callers had something to say about what I was doing, so I decided to play it out.'' Callers talked about their experiences as crime victims and how to prevent becoming a victim, but nearly half were critical of Lennox for banning blacks. Don Palmer, a black man, said he tried to call during the two hours but was not allowed on the air. ``I think that as a citizen of Birmingham, I've got the same right to express my opinions,'' Palmer said. ``In my opinion, the whole show was biased and unfair.'' During Thursday's show, Lennox said he was proud to have been part of the first integrated talk show in Birmingham some years back. ``None of that excuses yesterday's show,'' he said, ``but it might provide some perspective for what happened.'' President Abraham Woods of the Birmingham chapter of the Southern Chistian Leadership Conference said he was surprised at the decision by Lennox, especially in light of a controversy over blacks not being accepted as members at the Shoal Creek Country Club, the site of next month's Professional Golfers' Association championship. ``That was uncalled-for action on his part,'' Woods said. ``It really bordered on stupidity in this day and time.'' Woods could not be reached for reaction to the apologies and suspension.

DOC.HEAD: African Presidents Discuss Peacekeeping Force in Liberia
With AM-Liberia
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of Nigeria and the Ivory Coast met Thursday to consider proposals to end the civil war in Liberia, including the introduction of an African peacekeeping force. Nigeria's Ibrahim Babangida said there had been talks on the peacekeeping proposal, ``and I do hope as time goes by a lot of things will come out of the discussions we had.'' Ivorian President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, listening to Babangida's remarks following three hours of talks, nodded in agreement. Babangida said the two presidents were awaiting further word from diplomats in Freetown, Sierra Leone, who were meeting with rebel representatives Thursday. The two presidents have become key figures in regional efforts to negotiate an end to the conflict, which has degenerated into a tribal war that has claimed several thousand lives since it began in late December. Houphouet-Boigny's government has been sympathetic to rebel leader Charles Taylor, while Babangida reportedly has sent arms to Liberian President Samuel Doe. If the two leaders back a proposal to send a peacekeeping force to Liberia it would increase pressure on Taylor's rebels to accept it. Taylor has bitterly opposed the plan, which the rebels see as an effort to stop them from toppling Doe's government just as they are at the gates of the capital. It seemed unlikely the rebels would want to offend Houphouet-Boigny, from whose country they launched their invasion of Liberia, or Babangida because Nigeria is West Africa's military powerhouse. Said Babangida, ``Both of us are concerned about Liberia. There has to be a solution. My visit will give us time to review possible solutions.'' Houphouet-Boigny, a Roman Catholic, also took Babangida on a tour of the colossal basilica he built here, at a cost of more than $150 million. Pope John Paul II will visit the church, which rivals St. Peter's in size, for its official consecration Sept. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Stars Turner, Kline Oppose Restricting Federal Arts Grants
DOC.TEXT: Movie stars Kathleen Turner and Kevin Kline met with members of Congress Thursday and urged rejection of proposals to place restrictions on federal grants for the arts. Kline, who starred in the movie ``The Big Chill,'' said the controversy over the National Endowment for the Arts is ``a kind of hysteria'' that is making artists become ``suddenly suspicious characters.'' ``The NEA is a wonderful program _ it should be protected and perpetuated,'' Kline told reporters. ``We're heading toward, if we're not careful, a sort of cultural illiteracy.'' Turner, who starred in ``Body Heat,'' said the issue amounts to ``whether one has the right to tell another person, even supposedly for their own good ... how they should do their job.'' The two attended a private lunch with members of the congressional arts caucus, a group of members interested in the arts, and later spoke briefly with reporters. Bills to continue the NEA are pending in both the House and Senate, and a fight is expected over several proposals to apply provisions restricting federal subsidies from going to art that is deemed obscene, sacrilegious or otherwise offensive.

DOC.HEAD: More Stormy Weather In Eastern Half Of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Wet, stormy weather was scattered across the eastern half of the nation Thursday, with heavy rain causing street flooding in Iowa, and the West Coast sizzled in hot air. Showers and thunderstorms developing along and ahead of a slowly moving cold front were scattered from south-central Texas to the southern and middle Atlantic Coast states. The storms were most numerous from southeastern Texas through the Gulf Coast states to the southern Ohio Valley. Showers poured heavy rain in much of Iowa, with up to 3 inches of rain in central Iowa and unofficial reports as high as 5 inches. Some streets were closed in Des Moines and 35 miles to the northeast in Nevada, Iowa, where police said basements also were flooded. No injuries were reported. Showers prevailed from the upper Ohio Valley and the lower Great Lakes region across southern and central New England, and in southwestern Texas. Strong northerly wind ushered unseasonably cool air into the central Plains and the middle Mississippi Valley, and afternoon highs were only in the 60s in parts of the Northeast. But temperatures in the West soared into the upper 90s as far north as Washington state and Idaho at midday, when readings were already above 100 degrees at some locations in the desert Southwest and in the valleys of northern California. Because of the heat and lightning, federal and state firefighters were working on more than 100 new fires Thursday in Oregon, said Doug Decker, a spokesman for the Oregon Forestry Department. Monitoring equipment recorded more than 2,500 lightning strikes between noon and midnight Wednesday in a strip through central Oregon. Lightning also started a fire in Georgia's Okefenokee Swamp which had burned 3,900 acres as of Thursday. Overnight temperatures cooled only into the 70s and 80s in the Southwest deserts with a morning low of 89 at Yuma, Ariz. Afternoon temperatures also were generally in the upper 80s and 90s from southern Texas to the southern half of the Atlantic Coast. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 40 at Estes Park, Colo. Severe weather was widespread Wednesday, the National Weather Service said. Thunderstorms spawned two tornadoes in Florida and one in Georgia, and there were more than 40 reports of large hail and damaging wind from Ohio and Virginia southward to the Gulf Coast region. In Virginia, 5 to 10 inches of rain fell around Virginia Beach, the weather service said. Hail as big as golf balls was reported near Warrenton, Ga., and thunderstorm wind gusted to 65 mph at Columbia, S.C., 66 mph at Newport News, Va. Thunderstorms also produced severe weather late Wednesday in eastern Colorado, including two tornadoes and hail as big as softballs in the Denver area, the weather service said. The hail caused millions of dollars in damage to windows, vehicles, lights and gardens, and one traffic death was blamed on slippery roads. Forty-seven visitors to the Elitch Gardens amusement park were treated for cuts and bruises after the storm cut power to the area, stranding many on rides with little or no shelter from the hail, said Connie Schafer, the park's marketing director. Tornadoes also were reported Wednesday in northern Iowa and southern Minnesota, the weather service said. Showers and thunderstorms over northern Texas late Wednesday produced 2.26 inches of rain across southern Wichita Falls.

DOC.HEAD: House Chairman Urges End to Apache Copter Purchases
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a House panel on Thursday urged Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to halt any more purchases of Apache helicopters because of problems with the all-weather aircraft. ``I understand the contracts could be signed within the next few days _ this should be stopped,'' Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee, said in a letter to Cheney. The General Accounting Office recommended to the committee in April that the Army not buy the final 132 aircraft at a cost of $1.49 billion. The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, found that six of the best Apaches the Army handpicked for the invasion of Panama last December were plagued by problems. One helicopter never took off because of a hydraulic failure. The fuel cell failed in another and still another was forced to return to the base when its target detection system didn't work, the GAO said. Complicating matters were the helicopters' sensitive electronic components that failed to work when rain and humidity caused moisture to build up. Army officials were forced to dry the parts in kitchen ovens, the GAO said. Army Secretary Michael P.W. Stone said the service did not dispute the GAO findings, but is making progress in rectifying the problems. The Apache is ``the finest attack helicopter in the world, an aircraft that has given the United States a capability that is the envy of the world,'' Stone told the subcommittee on oversight and investigations. The Army plans to buy 807 Apaches from McDonnell Douglas at a cost of $12 billion. It's committed to 675 and the last 132 would cost $1.49 billion, which has already been appropriated for the current fiscal year. Dingell, in his letter, said the current plan is ``not my idea of rational decision-making. Apart from the illogic of a decision to buy more Apaches, such a decision would limit your budgeting options at a time when you most need them.''

DOC.HEAD: GOP Delivers Counterpunch in Rhetorical War Over S&L Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs, If money, to update with Democratic response from Brown.
DOC.TEXT: The Republican Party opened its mid-year meeting Thursday with an aggressive counterattack against Democrats seeking to blame the savings and loan crisis on President Bush and the GOP. Edward Rollins, co-chairman of the GOP's congressional committee, led the effort by accusing congressional Democrats of causing the S&L debacle and delivering a caustic assault on Democratic values and priorities. ``They've become corrupt, complacent and cocky,'' Rollins said in a speech to the Republican National Committee. ``Now it's time for a comeuppance.'' Democrats, including several potential 1992 presidential contenders, have tried to gain a political edge by blaming the $300 billion-plus S&L bailout on the Reagan and Bush administrations. But Rollins said blame for the crisis rested with the majority Democrats in Congress. He singled out three fallen Democrats _ former House Speaker Jim Wright, former House Whip Tony Coelho and former House Banking Committee Chairman Fernand St Germain. Wright and Coelho resigned last year amid ethics questions, and St Germain was defeated in 1988. They and other Democrats, Rollins said, took millions of dollars from the S&L industry in the 1980s and refused to act when significant evidence of a looming crisis first surfaced. ``If money is the mother's milk of politics, the Democratic fund-raisers who were getting rich by looting S&Ls were the milkmen,'' Rollins said. ``For a few million dollars in campaign contributions, the Democrats sold out the taxpayers. For the sake of their own re-elections they left us a bailout legacy that could reach the cost of thousands for every taxpayer for generations.'' Democratic party Chairman Ronald Brown returned Rollins' fire and predicted that GOP efforts to claim the high ground on S&Ls would fail. ``We're not surprised that `casino economy' Republicans who gambled us into this whole mess are whining and scapegoating every step of the way,'' Brown said in a statement. ``None of it is going to work.'' When the Democrats latched on to the S&L bailout as a partisan issue, Republican officials said they did not think the pitch would resonate with voters. But some GOP leaders give the Democrats credit for trying to exploit the bailout as a political issue because of growing taxpayer anger over the its cost. ``For once, a party without leadership has agreed on one thing,'' said Mary Matalin, the RNC executive director. ``We're not going to sit there and let them define the debate.'' The effort by Rollins and other senior Republicans to blunt the attack was a clear indication the GOP is concerned about the Democratic salvos. ``We're fighting back,'' said GOP consultant Charles Black, who has been helping run the RNC while party Chairman Lee Atwater battles a brain tumor. ``Democrats not only aren't clean on this issue but a lot of their leaders are the people who caused the problem.'' RNC member Haley Barbour of Mississippi, a party strategist in the South, said ``Democrats are going to get their fingers burned on this as often as they are going to have success.'' It appears the GOP would be happy with a political draw on the S&L issue. Republicans, too, accepted millions from S&L interests. And with Bush's son, Neil, involved in a highly publicized S&L case, the Democrats have ample fodder for attacks on the GOP. Atwater, who was hospitalized in Washington for what aides said were routine tests related to treatment of his tumor, has urged Rollins and other party operatives to be more aggressive in answering the Democratic attacks. Rollins' speech was rich with rhetoric sure to be repeated this fall in the congressional races around the country. Although GOP prospects for cutting into the Democratic majority appear bleak this year, Rollins is betting heavily on making inroads in 1992. Rollins delivered personal attacks on a handful of Democratic lawmakers and offered a sarcastic assessment of the party overall, labeling it soft on crime, eager to raise taxes and reliant on a divisive platform of class warfare for support. Answering the concerns of many Republican leaders gathered for the two-day meeting, Rollins said Bush abandoned his ``no new taxes'' pledge because it was the only way to get Democrats to agree to spending cuts. He warned that Democrats may try to blame the Republicans should cuts in Social Security and other entitlement programs emerge from ongoing budget talks between Congress and the White House. Privately, many of the RNC members have expressed worries that Bush's reversal on taxes will hurt GOP candidates this fall. But there was no public effort to question the president, and party officials made it clear the White House likely would oppose any efforts to raise personal income taxes as part of a tax package. ``A good economy is good politics,'' Bush pollster Bob Teeter told the RNC, saying Bush needed to give up his tax pledge to spur a deficit-reduction package. ``There is no worse politics than a recession.''

DOC.HEAD: Married Bishops Recommended for Greek Orthodox Church
With AM-Bush-Dimitrios
DOC.TEXT: Married men could become bishops of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Western Hemisphere under a recommendation approved Thursday by the church's 30th Biennial Clergy-Laity Congress. Although the Congress is recognized as the supreme legislative body of the church in the Western Hemisphere, members said it did not have the right to make a new rule on the subject. By a voice vote, it recommended ``that the matter of inclusion of married priests as candidates for elevation to the Episcopacy be respectfully referred to the Holy Synod for consideration.'' The synod consists of Archbishop Iakovos and the Episcopacy, that is, the bishops under him. Orthodox churches permit married men to become priests, unlike the Roman Catholic church, which has been separated from the Orthodox churches for more than 900 years. Orthodox priests may not marry after they are ordained, however, and married priests may not become bishops. More than two million members adhere to the Greek Orthodox church in the Western Hemisphere.

DOC.HEAD: Hamilton Beach Recalls Coffee Makers
DOC.TEXT: Hamilton Beach Inc. is recalling 42,500 drip coffee makers because of a potential fire hazard. Hamilton Beach Inc. said this week that it was recalling the under-the-cabinet coffee makers because ``a defect in the analog clock may cause the appliance to catch fire during use,'' the Consumer Product Safety Commission said. The North Carolina-based company has received 25 reports of the coffee makers catching fire, with consumers being burned in two instances. The recall is limited to models 816-2 and 816-3 manufactured between November 1987 and November 1988 and sold nationwide. Consumers may contact Hamilton Beach at 1-800-334-2785. North Carolina residents should call 1-800-672-5872.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Says Prospects Still Good for Soviet Bumper Crop
DOC.TEXT: Prospects are still good for a bumper grain harvest in the Soviet Union this year, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Total grain production continues to be estimated at 215 million metric tons, up from 211.1 million tons in 1989, the department said in a report. That would be the largest since a record 237.4 million tons were harvested in 1978. Soviet grain imports for the 1990-91 year that began July 1 also were unchanged from the previous forecast, 36 million tons compared with 38 million tons in 1989-90. But officials said the Soviet Union would probably boost its wheat imports to 17 million tons, up 1 million tons from the previous forecast, and reduce imports of coarse grains by the same amount. Analysts said the shift was due mostly to widening price spreads between lower-quality wheat used for livestock feed and corn.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Seaport Prepares for Arrival of Albanian Refugees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with offshore rendezvous, report Albania won't let ships dock, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BRI1
DOC.TEXT: Ships from three nations sailed on Thursday to a rendezvous off Albania in a sea lift of more than 4,500 Albanians seeking to escape their homeland, Europe's last haven for hard-line Communists. Five ships were engaged by France, Italy and West Germany to ferry the refugees 85 miles across the Adriatic from Durres, Albania, to the southern Italian port of Brindisi, a voyage of five to seven hours. The exodus was expected to ease a 2-week-old crisis created by Albanians storming foreign embassies in Tirana seeking asylum. Some braved police gunfire. Others crashed through embassy compound walls in trucks, or scrambled over walls. The embassies have been struggling to feed and shelter the Albanians, many of them young people. ``They will all arrive tomorrow (Friday),'' said Franco LoParco, president of the Italian Red Cross in Brindisi. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the ships would meet up off Durres but further details would be withheld at the request of the Albanian government. The Italian news agency ANSA, without citing its sources, said Albania doesn't want the ships to dock and that the asylum-seekers will be transferred from shore to the foreign vessels by Albanian boats. Two Greek-owned ferries, chartered by the West German government, arrived at Durres Thursday afternoon, a spokesman for the shipowner said. Together the two vessels can carry 1,900 passengers. Two Italian ships were bound for Albania from Venice and Brindisi and a French-chartered ship set sail for Albania from Greece. The first ship is due shortly after dawn. Most of the arrivals will be given coffee and croissants and then put on three trains headed for West Germany. West German diplomats in Brindisi said 3,200 Albanians who took refuge in their embassy in Tirana, Albania's capital, would make the sea crossing. Earlier, Italian officials put that figure at 2,200. Figures on the total number of Albanian asylum-seekers also varied. An earlier version put it at more than 5,000. Among those expected to arrive was a baby born Wednesday at the West German Embassy, diplomats in Tirana said. The Germany-bound refugees will be given medical examinations and a chance to shower in Brindisi before boarding trains for a 30-hour journey. Giuseppe Mazzitello, Brindisi's administrative chief, said the port would be closed to tourist traffic Friday. Brindisi is in the heel of Italy, about 330 miles southeast of Rome. Only 51 of the refugees had left Albania to now. The small group in the Czechoslovak Embassy was flown to Prague early Monday. Albania agreed to let the refugees leave the embassy compounds after supplies of food and medicine ran low and hygienic conditions deteriorated. The approximately 800 Albanians who took refuge in the Italian Embassy will be given temporary shelter in a military camp near Brindisi. About 540 from the French Embassy will continue to France by ship after stopping in Brindisi, authorities said. A final destination will be determined in the refugees' host country. Many say they hope to go to the United States. Soldiers wearing yellow rubber gloves used wire-cutters to remove coils of barbed wire from concrete walls around the perimeter of the camp Thursday. ``We are taking down the barbed wire so it doesn't seem like a concentration camp,'' said Lt. Col. Michele Dodde. LoParco said the Red Cross expected to treat about a dozen wounded, including three or four people with fractures and several with kidney problems. Hungary's state news agency MTI said Hungary will fly the 40 Albanians in its embassy to Budapest Friday night. The assault on the embassies presented the biggest challenge in decades to the Albanian government. It was reminiscent of the rush on foreign embassies in East Germany last year that contributed to the collapse of the country's Communist government. Albanian leader Ramiz Alia introduced limited reforms this year, including some religious freedoms and travel abroad. The crisis caused a shakeup in the leadership, but the government said it will maintain its hard line. Some Albanians who arrived this week in Prague speculated that Communist rule in their country may last only a year or two more. ``I give Communism in my country one or two years,'' said Kola, 36-year-old Albanian construction worker. Kola, who gave only his first name, is housed with other refugees in a barracks outside Prague. ``It was intolerable. We all dreaded the isolation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Truckers Doubt Seat-Belt Regulation Can Be Enforced
DOC.TEXT: At I-70 Truck City on Thursday, resting drivers expressed indignation and doubt about a government proposal to make them buckle up while working. ``A lot of people might be for it, but I'm against it. They can tell me how fast to drive, but I don't think they should be able to say, `Get in and strap yourself in this thing,''' said Ed England, a trucker from Hopkinsville, Ky. The regulation the U.S. Labor Department proposed Wednesday would cover 5.4 million businesses with 35 million workers, like Jerry Aiello, a 48-year-old truck driver from Upland, Calif., also taking a break at the truck stop. Aiello wears his seat belt when the road gets bumpy but doesn't like the way it cuts into his belly on long hauls. And he doesn't think the government can force him to buckle up. ``I don't see how they're going to enforce it. They can't even enforce the drug laws,'' said Aiello, who was hauling lumber on Interstate 70 in western Maryland. Under the proposed Occupational, Safety and Health Administration rule, workers who drive or ride on the job would have to wear seat belts. Self-employed people and businesses with 10 or fewer employees would be exempt. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said the new rules could save up to 685 lives a year. She said automobile accidents were the single largest cause of occupational fatalities, causing about 2,100 job-related deaths a year. ``It could cost lives, too,'' said England, 36, who was headed to Georgia with a load of syrup used to flavor cigars. England said he was glad he wasn't wearing a seat belt when his truck crashed into the rear of another last year. ``The whole front end of the cab came through the windshield,'' England said. ``The cop said if I had been seat belted-in, I wouldn't have been there to talk about it.'' Bill Thomas, 42, a trucker from Terre Haute, Ind., said he was willing to risk a ticket in the more than 30 states that have mandatory seat belt laws. ``I don't wear a seat belt _ not in a truck,'' said Thomas, who was fined for not wearing a seat belt in Illinois. ``At the time I was hauling gasoline. ``I'm afraid of fire. I've seen too many people burn up. If you're upside down and your arms are trapped, what are you going to do?'' Thomas, who was taking a load of appliances from Baltimore to Columbus, Ohio, said he did not see how the government could enforce the regulation. ``I think the government is overstepping its bounds,'' Thomas said. ``To me, it should be a choice, except for small kids in a car or something.'' Dole admitted enforcement would be difficult. Federal inspectors would make checks of seat-belt use part of their routine. Businesses guilty of violations could be fined up to $10,000, she said. Vince Carter, 27, who was delivering packages in downtown Frederick, said his employer, United Parcel Service, requires drivers to wear seat belts. ``Our company says it's mandatory from stop to stop,'' said Carter. ``It seems reasonable. It might even be able to help insurance costs a little.'' But Curt King, 36, a driver for City Cab Co. in Frederick, said seat belt laws infringe on his freedom. ``If you want to get splattered on the highway it's your right,'' said King, who does not buckle up. ``It's just a nuisance. I just personally feel that it isn't anybody's business.''

DOC.HEAD: Education Department Mails Anti-Drug Use Curriculum
DOC.TEXT: The Education Department began mailing public and private schools advice Thursday on how to teach children the dangers of drug abuse and warning against using recovering alcoholics and drug addicts in classrooms. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos released the drug education model, which is being sent to about 122,000 schools, and described it as a blueprint for effective techniques and suggestions for classroom activities. Recovering alcoholics and drug addicts should not be used in classroom presentations that try to discourage youngsters from experimenting with illegal drugs, the department said. ``One of the dangers of using recovering addicts in prevention programs is that we might be giving a mixed message _ `I tried it. I've recovered and I'm driving away in my BMW,''' said Dick Hayes, head of the agency's drug abuse prevention program. ``Where recovering addicts seem to have a role is particularly in intervention and treatment. This is the consensus in the field,'' he said. Cavazos said the program was divided into four academic levels: kindergarten through grade three, grades four through six, seven through eight and nine through 12. ``Education is our best hope for a drug-free America,'' Cavazos said. Each element contains suggestions for teachers on how they can work effectively with parents and with agencies in the community. A lesson plan defines the specific learning objective, with suggested activities and resources required. Drug prevention lessons are included throughout core academic subjects including mathematics, science, language arts, social studies, health or physical education classes, art or music classes. The model won immediate praise from Rep. Lawrence Coughlin, R-Pa. and the National School Boards Association, which is urging all of its members to ``give careful review'' to the document. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., who has complained the administration isn't doing enough to promote drug prevention, praised the curriculum but questioned whether there is incentive to ensure schools will use it. ``As promising as this curriculum appears to be, and knowing the secretary's good intentions, it would be a shame, and a waste of resources, if this were not put into action far and wide,'' said Rangel. Cavazos said the model contains ``clear, unequivocal messages that illegal drug use is wrong and harmful and that any drug use involves risk.'' By using loose-leaf binders, he said educators can incorporate material developed by local school districts. The model is being sent to about school principals and superintendents, as well as to the 1,500 largest private schools and members of the Chief State School Officers.

DOC.HEAD: Crew, Passengers of Soviet Jet Foil Hijack Bid
DOC.TEXT: Passengers and crew on a Soviet jetliner Thursday thwarted a hijacking by a 17-year-old who claimed he had a bomb and demanded the plane fly to Sweden, state-run television reported. It was the 11th attempt this summer to hijack an Aeroflot jetliner, according to the news program ``Vremya.'' Six of the jets have landed in foreign airports _ mainly Nordic countries. Five have landed at Soviet airports. All the hijackers have been arrested. Thursday's attempt began when a Leningrad youth, identified only as Lebedev, announced he had a bomb and demanded the jet be flown to Stockholm, ``Vremya'' reported. It was on a flight from Leningrad to Murmansk. The pilot landed instead at Leningrad's Pulkovo Airport, where the youth was subdued, the television program reported. The suspect was then seized by special police agents. The program gave no details of how the suspect was subdued. It did not say if the teen-ager actually had a bomb.

DOC.HEAD: AFT Calls on Government to Foster Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Government agencies must help Eastern European teachers and union officials reform their education system, the American Federation of Teachers said Thursday. AFT President Albert Shanker said the ideas and principles of democracy will take root only if they are taught effectively to the next generation. The AFT, to encourage democracy in education in Eastern Europe, developed a seven-point agenda detailing steps that can be taken by governmental agencies, Shanker said. A key emphasis of the program, part of the AFT's Education for Democracy-International and estimated to cost $100 million, is to get more assistance from Congress and the federal government to help Central and Eastern Europe overcome a lack of educational resources, he said. But Shanker stressed that private foundations, state education departments, colleges and universities all must play a role in promoting the teaching of the history, principles and practices of democracy. The Education for Democracy-International project began early this year as an extension of a program launched in 1987 to advocate strengthening the teaching of democratic values in the United States. ``Teachers in Eastern Europe are for the first time in 45 years able to teach non-propagandistic history, literature, economics, and politics,'' he said. ``But there are no textbooks for these subjects, except those produced by the communist governments to indoctrinate students about the accomplishments of communism.'' Zoltan Pokorni, national spokesman for the Democratic Teachers Union in Hungary, said the U.S. Information Agency told him it would expand its Fulbright exchange program for teachers, and other education programs. The American Council on Education also agreed to develop teacher and student exchange programs, he said. The AFT said there are more than 50,000 Russian-language teachers in the five Eastern European countries but fewer than 5,000 teachers of Western languages. Pokorni said about 10,000 Hungarian and 18,000 Polish Russian teachers are expected to lose their jobs. The exchange programs could help many of them find new classroom jobs, such as teaching English. The AFT plan also calls for providing tax incentives and other assistance to public and private American universities willing to open branches in various Eastern European countries, and establishing special English-language training schools and teacher training colleges in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Cymbals, Dolls Recalled
DOC.TEXT: The cymbals on about 9,200 Sesame Street Rhythm Band sets will be replaced because a New York toy company says the parts pose a choking hazard for small children. LEWCO Corp. said this week it would offer to replace the Oscar the Grouch cymbals for its model 3553 band sets because ``the heads detached from the cymbals'' and fail the Consumer Product Safety Commission's small-parts test. The sets consist of a drum, drum sticks, maracas, slide whistle, tambourines and the cymbals. Only the cymbals are subject to the replacement program, the company said. There have been no injuries reported involving the sets but consumers should discard the original cymbals and contact LEWCO Corp., 1107 Broadway-Suite 905, New York, N.Y., 10010 for replacements. In a similar action, another toy manufacturer recalled 2,364 dolls because various body parts detach easily and present a choking hazard to young children. Allen-Lewis Manufacturing Co. of Denver, Colo., said its ``Cutie Kid'' dolls were sold or distributed as free premiums since 1989 to tourists in small towns throughout the nation. The 6-inch dolls came with pacifiers and are dressed in a pink or blue two-piece pajama outfit. The cardboard headers on the clear plastic bags packaging are labeled ``Cutie Kid Made in China.'' Consumers should take the dolls away from young children and contact Frank Garlett at 1-800-525-6658.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Finds Americans Unwilling to Radically Change Health Care System
DOC.TEXT: Americans want change in the nation's health care system but they are far from agreement on how to do it, according to a poll released Thursday. The survey by the Gallup Organization Inc. found more contradictions than consistencies in Americans' views on health care, said officials of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, which commissioned the poll. It found that 68 percent believe government spending on health care should be increased, but 52 percent said the amount the nation now spends on health care is either ``too much'' or ``about right.'' ``Americans are torn between the social value they place on equal access to care, and the economic reality of paying for that care,'' said Bernard Tresnowski, president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association. ``Americans want change, but their answers show they're not ready for a radical dismantling of our health care system,'' he said. Among the findings: _Americans don't single out health care costs and quality as a major problem in the country. Drug abuse is named the biggest problem facing the nation, with 45 percent. Health care was named by 2 percent. _When asked about health care, 57 percent say they are ``very concerned'' about costs and 44 percent say they are ``very concerned'' about their quality of the care. _70 percent believe that rising costs are leading to a health care crisis. _86 percent agreed that the federal government should assure that everyone gets needed health services. _60 percent said all health care services should be funded through a government insurance program. _But nearly half said the federal government is not well-suited to run health programs, 63 percent said government-run programs are inefficient and wasteful and two-thirds agreed that ``dealing with the government is often not worth the trouble.'' Gallup interviewed 2,000 randomly selected American adults by telephone Jan. 5-30. The margin of sampling error for the survey was plus or minus 2 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Police Increase Bounty on Escobar, Cocaine Kingpin
DOC.TEXT: Authorities say cocaine kingpin Pablo Escobar is hiding out in northeastern Colombia and a three-day manhunt has failed to nab the fugitive billionaire. The government raised the reward for information leading to the capture of Escobar from $400,000 to $600,000, a police spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Escobar, Colombia's most wanted man, is the reputed leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel. Police Tuesday launched a massive drug raid in northeastern Colombia. Eleven employees of the Medellin cartel were arrested, but the drug baron fled near Puerto Triunfo, 75 miles southeast of Bogota. Security forces in the area, known as Magdalena Medio, arrested seven more employees of the Medellin cartel on Wednesday. They included Escobar's personal physician and brother-in-law, Hernan Dario Quintero, police said. Gen. Octavio Vargas, a national police director, said another of those arrested was a man believed to have handed out money to keep local residents quiet about Escobar's hideout. Vargas said 2,000 soldiers and police were sweeping the region with helicopters and land patrols Thursday. ``The presence of family and men close to Pablo Escobar ... and information we have received from peasant farmers indicates he is still in the region,'' Vargas said. In the Wednesday raid, security forces also found 900 pounds of dynamite in a truck near Puerto Triunfo, where Escobar is believed to own extensive property. Since Tuesday, authorities have seized more than 8,500 pounds of dynamite, assault rifles, sophisticated radio equipment, and documents belonging to the drug cartel, the world's largest. The police spokesman said the anti-drug operation would continue indefinitely. According to several accounts, Escobar, 42, went from being a petty car thief to one of the world's 20 richest men, with an estimated worth of over $3 billion. The raids Tuesday and Wednesday were the latest attacks in the government's 11-month-old war on traffickers that began last August, when drug barons allegedly assassinated leading presidential candidate, Sen. Luis Carlos Galan. Since then, the traffickers have retaliated with a terror campaign of car bombings, massacres and police assassinations, and hundreds of people have been killed. Meanwhile, in Medellin, Colombia's second-largest city, two policemen were slain Wednesday, bringing to 133 the number of law officers assassinated in Medellin so far this year, according to police. The cartel has reportedly offered to pay $4,300 for each police officer killed. Since August, President Virgilio Barco has extradited 15 drug suspects to face charges in the United States and confiscated hundreds of properties belonging to the cocaine barons.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Prime Minister Visits Grave of Martin Luther King Jr.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Last 6 grafs EMBARGOED until 8 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu urged his countrymen to be ``good corporate citizens'' in the United States and proposed a broad cultural exchange between the two countries. Kaifu, the first Japanese prime minister to tour the Southeast, also placed a flower wreath at the tomb of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and met Thursday with the slain civil rights leader's widow. ``He greatly admired Dr. King. It's only natural he would come here,'' said Stephen Allen, public relations officer for the Japanese Consulate in Atlanta. ``Japan is committed to human rights around the world.'' Coretta Scott King King took Kaifu on a brief tour of the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change and gave him several mementos, said Steve Klein, the center's research associate. U.S. civil rights advocates were outraged four years ago when then-Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said blacks and Hispanics lowered the U.S. intelligence standard. ``He's a new prime minister. We can't hold him responsible for what others have said,'' Klein said. ``The American Southeast has long had good relations with Japan, and this region is today home to about 600 Japanese companies ... (that) contribute to the region's economic development,'' Kaifu said. ``I am hoping to have the chance to meet with some of these corporate leaders, and I will take the opportunity to encourage them to fit in with their local communities as good corporate citizens.'' In a speech Thursday night, Kaifu intended to outline a broad cultural exchange project and encourage cooperation between Japan and the United States, Allen said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Following grafs embargoed until 8 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: In comments prepared for delivery at a dinner of the Japan-America Society of Georgia, Kaifu said the United States and Japan should focus on their similarities. ``All human beings are increasingly tied to one another as the world becomes more integrated into one community,'' he said. ``Talks between our two countries should not be used as a forum for one partner to criticize the other,'' Kaifu said. ``Rather we should seize these opportunities to promote our joint endeavors.'' He proposed a cultural exchange, called the Communication Improvement Initiative, to promote understanding between the two countries. Although he offered no specifics, Kaifu said the public, as well as politicians, should participate in the exchange. Kaifu arrived in Georgia Wednesday night after attending the economic summit in Houston.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-funded Anti-missile Missile Reportedly Ready for Test
DOC.TEXT: Israel will soon launch its first test of a missile-killing missile developed with U.S. ``Star Wars'' funds, a newspaper reported Thursday. The Arrow missile, designed to combat short-range ballistic missiles, was created with funds from the U.S. Strategic Defense Initiative, better known as the Star Wars program. In its report Thursday, the Jerusalem Post said a date for the first test of the Arrow missile was ``imminent.'' Officials at Israel Aircraft Industries, which is developing the Arrow along with Lockheed Corp. of Calabasas, Calif., declined comment Thursday. Moshe Keret, the head of Israel Aircraft, last month told reporters the Arrow will not be ready for operational use until at least 1992. Defense Minister Moshe Arens on Thursday discussed the Arrow with Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the U.S. joint chiefs of staff. Powell is on a five-nation Middle East tour. ``I mentioned the Arrow project to Gen. Powell since he is familiar with it. I understood that he greatly appreciates Israel's technological achievements in this field, which in many respects are indeed unprecedented,'' Arens said on Israel radio. ``I think we've apparently found an answer to ground-to-ground missiles,'' Arens added. ``We expect the U.S. administration to continue funding this project so that we t.'' Washington provided 80 percent of the $158 million for the first phase of the Arrow project. Israel's Defense Ministry supplied the rest. Israel wants about $200 million from Washington for the second phase. Arens said the Arrow was discussed in the context of Iraqi threats to use missile-carried chemical weapons against Israel in retaliation for any attack. The Arrow is designed to defend against ballistic missiles with a range of 600 miles or less. The Star Wars program is mainly conducting research into the feasibility of space-based defenses against ballistic missile attacks. The Bush administration spent $1 billion on the program the past fiscal year. But its $4.5 billion request for the next year is expected to come under severe attack in the U.S. Congress. The program's critics contend the system is too expensive and unnecessary in this time of lessened East-West tensions. However, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has touted the program's possibilities to counter the growing threat of Third World ballistic missiles. Cheney has also argued the Soviet's spaced-based defense research is continuing.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's No. 2 Lays Out Middle Road
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB4
DOC.TEXT: The man just picked to run the daily affairs of the Soviet Communist Party charted a middle ground Thursday, backing quick reform and tolerance for many views but warning of ``ill-conceived leaps.'' Vladimir A. Ivashko, the personal choice of Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, trounced party traditionalist Yegor K. Ligachev in an election to choose the party's No. 2 leader at the 28th Communist Party Congress. In his first meeting with reporters after his victory, Ivashko on Thursday proclaimed himself a staunch supporter of Gorbachev's policies who nevertheless was very surprised to find himself the Soviet leader's new deputy. ``I will make every effort to consolidate the party, to accommodate different points of view in the party,'' he told a news conference. He urged party members contemplating defection from the party to remain, because the party under Gorbachev ``is able to solve all the tasks put forward by perestroika,'' he said. Perestroika is President Gorbachev's program of social and economic reforms. However, only hours later, radical reformer Boris N. Yeltsin announced to the congress he was quitting the party. Leading members of the Democratic Platform, a reform group, said they would follow suit. In his comments Thursday, Ivashko showed the influence of his many years as a teacher. The 58-year-old spoke forcefully, using examples and hand gestures to buttress his arguments. Ivashko was picked last fall to replace longtime Ukrainian Communist Party chief Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, who retired. The deputy party leader's position is new. Gorbachev needs a deputy to run much of the party's business because he spends much time on government business as Soviet president. The new deputy said he only learned Tuesday he would be Gorbachev's choice. ``When I came here to the congress, I never, never thought that my life would change so drastically,'' he said. He said he had not had a chance to discuss his exact duties with Gorbachev. He spoke out emphatically for speedy reform but said the party and Soviet government also had to avoid costly mistakes. Gorbachev's reform effort, begun in 1985, was 20 years too late in coming, he declared. Now, he said: ``I am for moving forward fast. I see no other option. There is no way back.'' But he said the leadership had to avoid the kinds of mistakes it made in the first years of Gorbachev's reforms. ``I am against ill-conceived leaps _ forward, backwards, sideways,'' he said. ``Perestroika proves that we have made many erroneous decisions, quickly designed to solve all problems.'' Although backing transition to a market economy, he stuck to Gorbachev's line that the moves cannot be made hastily. He said a 1985 drive against alcoholism, the first large-scale reform effort tried under Gorbachev, caused ``huge moral and financial damage, and damage to the health of the people.'' The campaign took billions of rubles from alcohol sales out of the national treasury. It also encouraged moonshiners whose low-quality brew killed and injured many people. Ivashko also said the Soviet government was foolhardy to agree to demands it knew it could not fulfull in response to a strike last year by Soviet miners. On Wednesday, hundreds of thousands of miners struck for one day to demand the resignation of the government, the nationalization of Communist Party property and removal of party groups from the workplace and security forces.

DOC.HEAD: Pebble Beach Resort Warns Pro Photographers About Famed Tree
LaserPhoto MTY1
DOC.TEXT: Photographers say a famous lone cypress tree on the coast near Carmel is a natural monument and that anyone can take a picture of it for any reason. But the company that owns its rocky perch warns commercial photographers away, insisting the tree _ not just the logo it inspired _ is a trademark. ``The Pebble Beach Co. does not mind anyone photographing the tree for private purposes. What it does object to is the commercial exploitation of its own property by others without its consent,'' said Kerry Smith, a San Francisco lawyer for the resort company. The tree, which stands alone on a windswept finger of rock that juts into the Pacific, is a popular tourist stop on the 17-mile drive just north of Carmel, about 85 miles south of San Francisco. Although the tree has been recorded on film for a century, including by renowned photographers Ansel Adams and Edward Weston, the scenic golf resort recently told two professional photographers not to use pictures of the tree without its consent. The action and trademark claim have evoked bewilderment, amusement, skepticism and outrage. ``This just knocked me over. ... I thought the tree was made by God,'' said Los Angeles photographer Craig Aurness, who got a warning letter from the company after his picture of the tree was used in an MCI brochure last fall. Pebble Beach Co. also denied photographer Ed Young of Carmel permission to take pictures of the cypress if he planned to use them for commercial purposes. ``I'm sure Ansel Adams and Edward Weston didn't have to get anything in writing,'' Young said in a letter of protest to the company. The Pebble Beach Co. warns visitors in a brochure that unauthorized commercial photography is not allowed. And it has registered several depictions of the tree as a trademark and uses them on company letterhead, golf clubs, balls, caps and other items at the resort, Smith said. The trademark includes the tree itself as well as abstract and realistic depictions of it, he said. ``The lone cypress itself has been the symbol and trademark of the Pebble Beach Co. and its predecessors since 1916,'' he said. But photographers, people who sell their work and experts in ``intellectual property'' law disagree with the trademark claim or say the issue is unclear. ``What is trademarkable is your logo or illustration,'' said Nancy Wolff, partner in the New York law firm of Cavallo and Wolff, representing Aurness. ``That doesn't mean the tree is trademarkable. ... They're trying to get a monopoly over a natural object because they have this drawing.'' Critics of the Pebble Beach Co. also argue that the cypress is in the public domain, pointing out that people were taking pictures of it long before the area became a resort. ``The tree is, in my opinion, a world-renowned symbol,'' said Allison Worthern, graphics manager of a Carmel gallery. ``It's part of us here. ... We already put a price on so many things in this world ... that belong to God and nature.''

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Transit Officials Foiled In Coon Hunt On Train Tracks
DOC.TEXT: Transit Authority workers said Thursday they're determined to catch a wily ``non-paying invader'' _ a raccoon that's taken residence at a downtown train stop. ``Rocky the Raccoon has been able to give us the slip somehow,'' Peter Poholik, director of the city's Commission on Animal Care Control, conceded on Thursday. ``We've been out there the last three days trying to get close enough to grab him.'' Transit officials say if the raccoon is cornered, it may be a threat to riders. ``We want to get this non-paying invader off of our system,'' spokesman Don Yabush said. Poholik, a veterinarian, and the Transit Authority's security officers rose early Thursday in the latest attempt to capture the elusive raccoon. Armed with a tranquilizer gun and bait, they were hoisted on a small platform into the rafters beneath the tracks as trains roared by above. But the raccoon _ spotted on the preceding two mornings on a particular rafter above the street _ was having nothing of it. ``Never saw him,'' Poholik said glumly. A trap set in the rafters, which would catch the raccoon alive, had malfunctioned, closing as the vibrations of the trains shook it. Poholik on Thursday added more fragrant peanut butter bait to the trap and tightened its springs and latches. Because of the hoopla, Poholik said that if the raccoon is captured, it would probably avoid the fate of other wild animals the city captures: extermination. ``What we will do, because of all the attention, is ... find some zoological society to take him off our hands.'' But he's hoping it's all a moot point. ``There's a very good possibility that he got sidetracked'' during a nocturnal stroll and won't be coming back, Poholik said.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Force New Evacuations in Already Ravaged Ohio Towns
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rain flooded creeks and broke a dam Thursday, forcing renewed evacuations in part of eastern Ohio that was heavily damaged by deadly flooding last month. About 600 people in Dillonvale and 200 people in Dunglen were urged to evacuate their homes, said Francis Sebring, director of an emergency services command post. Residents also were evacuated from their homes in Adena, some by boat. Dillonvale and Adena suffered extensive damage during flash floods that struck eastern Ohio on June 14 and killed 26 people near Shadyside, about 20 miles south of Dillonvale. ``We got hit again,'' Sebring said. ``It's pouring down rain.'' Evacuations also were reported in central Ohio because of flooding. Ohio had been hit with thunderstorms much of the week. The National Weather Service said rain was expected to continue into the weekend. National Guard units in Cambridge and Steubenville were being sent to the eastern Ohio flood areas to help relief efforts, said Ohio Emergency Management Agency spokeswoman Stacy Gilg. Emergency shelters for the evacuees were set up in churches and fire departments. Sebring said a dam at a strip-mine operation broke. He said water from the dam would enter Short Creek, which runs through the Dillonvale and Newtown before emptying into the Ohio River. In the Adena area, boaters took people to higher ground. ``It's been raining constantly, hard rain, all day,'' said firefighter Greg Arnett. He said there was about two feet of water around the firehouse. ``Here in Adena I know people are evacuating some houses,'' said church secretary Mary Martha Carter. ``They're telling people to leave houses and go where they can go.'' Flooding also was reported in Licking County in central Ohio and Athens County in southeast Ohio. Ms. Gilg said there were no requests for state aid from those areas. Dozens of people were evacuated from low-lying areas of Licking County, one county west of Columbus, after steady rainfall caused the south fork of the Licking River to spill over its banks. No injuries were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Announces End of Budget Deficit
DOC.TEXT: The government announced Thursday it has erased its chronic budget deficit with a new fiscal plan that heralds lower inflation and renewed foreign debt payments. In the latest of a series of labor troubles, however, workers at the country's second-largest steel factory began a sit-down strike. They are demanding higher wages to counter inflation in this nation of 150 million residents. President Fernando Collor de Mello is trying to combat Brazil's economic woes. The country, the largest debtor in the Third World, owes about $6 billion after withholding interest payments to private creditors for more than a year. Brazil's inflation last year soared to 5,000 percent. A key to balancing the 1990 budget was the president's controversial ``administrative reform'' plan, said Economy Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello. It includes selling government cars and mansions, closing or selling dozens of state-owned companies and firing about 360,000 federal workers. Despite a wave of labor strikes to protest the planned firings, Cardoso de Mello said, ``the price was worth paying.'' De Mello said Brazil's new budget calls for a surplus equivalent to 1.65 percent of the country's gross national product, which the Economy Ministry put at $500 billion. Earlier estimates had projected a deficit of 7.82 percent of the GNP, the annual total of goods and services produced. ``We have liquidated a chronic situation of fiscal imbalance, which was one of the main causes of inflation,'' Cardoso de Mello said in a live television interview. To obtain the surplus, the government raised tax revenue 16 percent, cut planned investments 39 percent and reduced costs 18 percent, the minister said. She denied the spending cuts would bring recession to Brazil. ``We are working with the hypothesis of zero growth this year,'' she said. ``Even so, we can't talk of recession, but rather of an accomodation of some sectors.'' Collor, who took office March 15, originally promised a 2 percent budget surplus. But the minister said the 1.65 percent surplus was still a success, ``because it shows the political desire to combat inflation.'' Inflation was 10 percent in June. It is expected to rise to 12 or 15 percent this month. The striking steel workers were demanding a pay increase of 188 percent to cover losses caused by the record inflation, union leaders said. Bartolomu Cideli, financial director of the Steel Workers Union, said all 22,000 workers at the National Steel Company's plant in Volta Redonda were taking part in the strike. He said production had been completely halted. Cideli spoke by phone from Volta Redonda, 80 miles west of Rio de Janeiro. He said the strike was also to meant to protest the layoff of almost 1,400 workers the past two months and the government's plan to privatize the company. ``There is no way of telling how long the strike will last as the company is not prepared to negotiate,'' he said. ``But we won't go back to work until our basic demands are met.'' In her comments, the economy minister said Brazil will send a mission to Washington next week with a new budget to present to the International Monetary Fund. An endorsement from the fund is considered essential for a new agreement with creditor banks. Private banks hold nearly 70 percent of Brazil's $114 billion foreign debt.

DOC.HEAD: Bargainers Agree to Phase In Double Hull Requirement for Oil Tankers
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators agreed late Thursday that most single-hulled oil tankers should be phased out over the next 20 years and all new tankers should be built with double hulls. The agreement removed a major obstacle to oil spill protection legislation Congress has been debating since the devastating spill from the Exxon Valdez tanker off the Alaska coast in March 1989. Members working out differences between the House and Senate bills hope to complete action on the legislation before the upcoming August recess. Negotiators, by voice vote, agreed on a compromise timetable for removing so-called single-hulled tankers to phase out the oldest and largest ships beginning in 1995. A small number of tankers would be allowed to operate until 2015, but most would be gone by 2010. Environmental groups in a letter to the conferees earlier this week called a requirement for double-hull tankers ``the single most important step Congress can take to prevent oil spills.'' The petroleum industry has opposed a requirement for double hulls. There are more than 1,300 tankers of various sizes that transport oil in and out of the United States and between U.S. ports, according to congressional estimates. Double hulls provide added protection if a tanker runs aground or collides with another ship. There have been conflicting studies on whether the Alaska spill would have been significantly reduced if the Exxon Valdez had a double hull. The bill approved by the Senate called for only a study of issue and the original House version would have phased out single-hull tankers by 2005. Environmental groups had called for the faster phase-out. Clifton Curtis of Friends of the Earth called the compromise ``a kiss on the cheek _ followed by a slap in the face.'' The tanker hull issue was one of the thorniest in a package that also calls for a $1 billion emergency response fund to deal with oil spill cleanup and sets liability levels for spills. The emergency response fund will comes from a 50-cent-a-barrel levy on petroleum that began being collected last January. Senate and House sources said with the double-hull issue resolved, the legislation, the subject of intense negotiations between the House and Senate for months, may be approved before Congress begins its summer recess Aug. 3. Under the compromise, new tankers must be constructed with double hulls and existing single-hull tankers must begin to be phased out of operation in 1995, with the largest and oldest tankers to be taken out of service or retrofitted first. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, said that under the timetable, 43 percent of tankers would likely have double hulls by the end of the decade and 80 percent by the year 2005. Tankers that unload oil 60 miles outside U.S. waters and tankers that already have double bottom or sides have until 2015 to comply.

DOC.HEAD: Panic in Monrovia as Liberian Peace Talks Resume
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with second Freetown session held, two presidents meet in Ivory Coast, Sen. Pell asks Doe to leave. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following includes material from a pool report by foreign correspondents, including Associated Press correspondent Michelle Faul.

Hundreds of Monrovians fled in panic Thursday after soldiers searched houses in the port city and fired at a fishing boat suspected of carrying rebels. The latest disturbances came as peace talks began in Freetown, the capital of neighboring Sierra Leone, between delegations representing the Liberian rebels and the embattled government of President Samuel K. Doe. Presidents Ibrahim Babangida of Nigeria and Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast also met on Thursday in Yamoussoukro, Ivory Coast, to consider proposals to end the 6-month-old Liberian conflict, including introduction of an African peacekeeping force. In Monrovia, troops fired into the Nigerian Embassy early Thursday, where 150 Nigerians had sought refuge. Two bullets grazed a guard's face. More than 6,000 Liberians and foreigners have sought refuge in churches and embassy compounds in the rebel-besieged capital of 400,000 inhabitants. It was the army's second violation of a diplomatic mission'ck and cash. Current shareholders would get warrants to buy about 5.8 million shares of the stock, or about 10 percent of the reorganized company, Romanoff said. Bank creditors would get cash of about $55 million, plus about 47 percent of the reorganized firm's stock. Other creditors would get about 43 percent of the company. The company and its advisers value the plan at about $687 million. Romanoff declined to speculate about how soon the company could emerge from bankruptcy, but he said finalization would take at least several weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Makes Fall Schedule Changes Early
DOC.TEXT: Fox Broadcasting Co. announced Thursday that it will start its fall season early with two programming moves designed to snatch viewers from the three major networks. ``Babes,'' a half-hour comedy about three overweight sisters, will make its debut Aug. 23 at 8:30 p.m. The hefty trio will be preceded on Thursday nights by repeats of ``The Simpsons,'' as the animated family moves sooner than planned into its new time slot against NBC's top-rated ``The Cosby Show.'' Original episodes of ``The Simpsons'' will begin in late October. Fox's highly publicized decision to do battle with Bill Cosby is the most daring aspect of the alternative network's fall schedule. The announcement that ``Babes'' will start in six weeks came just two days after Fox executives said the pilot was being redone because some of its jokes were too raunchy. The 4-year-old Fox network hopes to gain viewers while ABC, CBS and NBC are still broadcasting reruns.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Welcomes Orthodox Patriarch to White House
DOC.NOTE: For Release 7:25 p.m. EDT
Eds: SUBS 6th graf to correct number in Orthodox Christian following
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday welcomed Patriarch Dimitrios, the spiritual leader of Orthodox Christians, to the White House and thanked him for helping sustain the faith of people in Eastern Europe. ``The world rejoices that the new freedoms of the past year mean that your Orthodox followers in so many lands are now once again able to follow freely and openly the road of holy light,'' Bush later told Dimitrios in remarks at a banquet of the Greek Orthodox Biennial Clergy-Laity Congress. ``We celebrate the dawn of hope for these people, particularly those for whom you speak in Eastern Europe,'' Bush said in reference to the democratic reforms in Eastern Europe over the last year. He praised Dimitrios for ``unflinching devotion to the passing on of clear moral values and your emphasis on the importance of a good eduction.'' Bush also praised the Orthodox community for ``deeply rooted spiritual beliefs as well as the richness of your cultural life.'' Dimitrios' domain includes the Greek and Russian Orthodox denominations and a following of 250 million people, many in Eastern Europe. His is the first U.S. visit by the Orthodox patriarch. Bush told Dimitrios at a Rose Garden photo session: ``As I survey the changes that are taking place in Eastern Europe and around the world, our thoughts go to the faith of individuals in so many countries, the faith that is sustained and strengthened by the church and by the leadership of His Holiness.'' ``Faith of people is a driving force for change,'' Bush added. The 75-year-old religious leader thanked Bush during their meeting for his support and initiatives that have helped bring about changes in Eastern Europe, according to his interpreter, the Rev. Leonidas Contos.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Want Deeper Cuts in Aid to Salvador
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats on Thursday rejected as too small a Bush administration offer to cut military aid to El Salvador, but they held out hope for eventual agreement on a bipartisan policy toward the Central American country. ``The cuts just aren't deep enough,'' said Rep. Joseph Moakley, D-Mass., the leader of a Democratic task force on El Salvador appointed by House Speaker Thomas Foley. ``The initial offer was outrageously low,'' added Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., after a two-hour meeting with Bernard Aronson, assistant secretary of state for the Western Hemisphere. According to documents made available to \te Associated Press, the administration proposed to cut by 15 percent El Salvador's expected 1991 allotment of $85 million in military aid. The withheld money would be made available to the Salvadoran government only if several conditions were met, including adherence by the government to a cease fire, participation in negotiations aimed at a peaceful settlement of the 10-year civil war and reforms of the military and judicial systems. There also would have to be ``significant progress'' toward bringing to trial those responsible for the murder of eight people, including six Jesuit priests, in San Salvador last November. To encourage the country's leftist rebels to also work toward peace, the package would provide another 15 percent could be cut if the rebels comply with the cease fire, negotiate in good faith and forsake shipments of weapons from outside the country and terrorism. Although Democrats rejected the plan on Thursday, another meeting was set for next week and both sides said they hoped a compromise could be reached. Bonior said he wanted assurances that deeper cuts would be made at the beginning of the fiscal year and that tighter requirements on the Salvadoran government be written into the plan. The administration proposal, like one House Democrats wrote into an emerging 1991 foreign aid bill, is designed to give both the Salvadoran government and the rebels incentives to resolve their conflict peacefully. The congressional proposal calls for an immediate 50 percent cut in military aid. The remaining 50 percent could be cut if the government abandons the peace talks or seeks to crush the FMLN rebels militarily; the full amount could be restored if the rebels mount a major offensive or walk away from the negotiating table. In talks in El Salvador earlier this week, Aronson pressed authorities on the Jesuit murder case. A report by Moakley's task force in April said the investigation had come to a virtual standstill and that the Salvadoran government had showed no interest in determining whether senior military officers were responsible. El Salvador's decade-long civil war has cost more than 70,000 lives and has continued despite some $5 billion in U.S. economic and military aid. Officials have been optimistic about peace prospects in recent months, in part because they believe diminished international support for the rebels will make them more flexible in negotiations. The government and the guerrillas have had several rounds of discussions this year. The next meeting is set for July 20 in Costa Rica.

DOC.HEAD: Charter Plane Hits Power Line, Blacks Out Hundreds, Kills Crew Member
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Company name _ Great Western Aviation Inc., Ogden Air Service _ is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A charter airplane that may have had engine trouble hit a power line Thursday and crashed into a river, blacking out hundreds of utility customers and killing a co-pilot. The break in a 46,000-volt power line left about 1,400 customers without power from the mouth of Ogden Canyon eastward to Huntsville, Eden, Liberty and Snowbasin and Powder Mountain ski resorts, said Dave Mead of Utah Power & Light Co. Most customers regained service in a few hours, he said. The single-engine, six-seat Cessna 210 left Ogden Airport en route to eastern Utah's Dutch John, near Flaming Gorge, to pick up a couple of fishermen, said Weber County Sheriff George Fisher. ``It appears they had engine trouble and were coming back down the canyon,'' he said. ``Someone did a beautiful job of bringing it down ... if they hadn't hit the power lines, they could have landed on the road,'' he said. Floyd Leonard ``Buddy'' Hatley, 60, died and Floyd Henry Duncan Jr., 52, believed to have been in control of the plane, was critically injured when they crashed on the Ogden River, he said. The plane was owned by the men's employer, Great Western Aviation Inc., Ogden Air Service.

DOC.HEAD: British Spy Case of 1960s Reaches High Court
DOC.TEXT: A panel of British judges Thursday began hearing requests to stop the trial of two men accused of helping a Soviet double agent escape from prison _ a charge they admitted in a book last year. Patrick Pottle and Michael Randle, known as peace activists in the 1960s, admitted helping Soviet spy George Blake flee in their book titled ``The Blake Escape: How We Freed George Blake and Why.'' Legal authorities opened the case against them only after they published their work. They are accused of helping Blake escape from London's Wormwood Scrubs prison in 1966. At Thursday's hearing, their lawyers asked the High Court to overturn a lower court ruling in April to let the trial go forward. They are challenging the court's jurisdiction to hear the case. Blake, 67, was a double agent who confessed to spying for the Soviets while employed by British intelligence. He was jailed in 1961 for 42 years, the longest spy sentence ever imposed by a British court. Pottle and Randle said in their book that they helped Blake because of the ``cruel and inhuman sentence.'' They said authorities knew of their involvement by 1970 but decided not to prosecute. They now face charges of aiding Blake's escape and conspiracy. The escape charge carries a maximum sentence of five years, while the conspiracy charge has a maximum sentence of two years or an unlimited fine. Pottle, 52, works as an antiques dealer, and 56-year-old Randle is a researcher.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Attack Peruvian Army Post, Kill 20
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas attacked an army post in the eastern jungle and killed 20 soldiers in the latest flareup of this country's political violence, police said Thursday. The same day, guerrillas shot to death two policemen and a civilian bystander as the officers ate breakfast at an outdoor counter in Lima. Two other civilians were wounded. Police blamed the Lima attack on the Maoist group Shining Path. The same group was blamed for an attack Wednesday night at Urpay by 80 rebels. The town of Urpay is 10 miles east of the highland city of Ayacucho. The guerrillas killed eight members of a community civil defense group. Police in Pucallpa, a major jungle town 300 miles northeast of Lima, said about 300 rebels of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement surrounded and attacked the nearby army base Wednesday afternoon. Police said many people were wounded in the three-hour battle, but they did not have a figure. They said an unknown number of rebels were killed in addition to the 20 soldiers. Local military officials would not comment on the attack. Wednesday's attack came three days after 48 rebels from the same group, including reputed leader Victor Polay, staged a spectacular prison break from a maximum security prison in Lima. The rebels fled before dawn Monday through a 660-foot tunnel they had dug. The government declared a state of emergency following the breakout. Police have arrested thousands in sweeps through Lima's streets and shantytowns looking for the escapees. The escape was a great embarrassment for the outgoing government of President Alan Garcia. Many opposition leaders have called for the resignations of his ministers of justice and interior. The Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement is a pro-Cuban group that started its insurgency in 1984. It takes its name from an 18th century mestizo revolutionary who led a peasant revolt against Spanish colonial rule. Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima in the Andean highlands, is the birthplace of the Shining Path. That group took up arms against Peru's elected governments in 1980. The government says more than 18,500 people have been killed in the 10 years of political violence.

DOC.HEAD: House Speaker Chides Common Cause on Campaign Finance Ads
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley on Thursday accused Common Cause, the biggest public advocacy group behind legislation to reform election spending, of conducting a ``scurrilous campaign'' against Democrats. Foley, D-Wash., called the group's ads in the hometown newspapers of 13 House Democrats ``the lowest point in the public presentation of issues by Common Cause in its history.'' ``This is not the organization that I think carries forward the spirt of John Gardner,'' Common Cause's founder and one-time secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Foley said. In the past month, the 280,000-member organization chaired by former Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox has mailed out editorials and other material calling the leading House Democratic campaign finance proposal a ``sham.'' With several campaign finance bills now stalled in both the House and Senate, Common Cause escalated its grass-roots pitch last week with the ads linking millions of dollars politicians received from political action committees to the savings and loan crisis. Under a headline reading ``S&L interests gave members of Congress millions, taxpayers were ripped off for billions ... and Congress has done nothing,'' the group targeted the 13 House Democrats, two Senate Democrats and seven Senate Republicans. Each of the senators was accused at the bottom of the ads of helping kill a campaign finance reform bill two years ago. The ads targeting House members focused on how much money they received from ``PACs representing special interests'' during recent past elections. All were urged to vote for major cuts in allowable PAC gifts and told, ``Don't vote for the House Democrats' fake campaign reform bill.'' For example, a July 3 ad in The (Hackensack) Record targeted Rep. Robert Torricelli, D-N.J., as receiving $579,000 in PAC money the past three elections. ``The ad is dishonest, it is untruthful,'' Torricelli said, citing another public interest group's determination that he had a ``nearly perfect record on S&L votes in the public interest.'' ``... They should be placing the blame where it is, not saying that environmental organizations, labor unions, students, senior citizen organizations who represent these PAC contributions are somehow part of the problem,'' he said. Foley accused the group of using ``tactics of innuendo and inference that are typical of the worst elements of campaign advertising.'' Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer called the ad campaign ``fair and appropriate.'' ``The bottom line is we have a rotten campaign finance system in Congress and that system is one of the reasons we wound up with an S&L scandal that will cost every taxpayer $2,500,'' Wertheimer said.

DOC.HEAD: `Ford Fairlane' Opens to Strong Business
DOC.TEXT: Raunchy comedian Andrew Dice Clay may not impress many movie critics, but his new film ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane'' has opened to strong business. According to figures released Thursday by 20th Century Fox, the movie grossed $2.1 million in its debut Wednesday night, playing on 1,201 screens in North America. ``It's working everywhere, right across the board. It exceeded my expectations. ... I don't think the reviews have had any impact,'' said Tom Sherak, head of Fox's domestic distribution and marketing. Fox was concerned that Clay, who stars in the film as a detective, was not a box-office draw outside big cities. But Fox's research found that he is attracting a young male audience in most markets. Meanwhile, the studio's ``Die Hard 2'' has grossed more money in its first week of release than any of this summer's other releases. According to Exhibitor Relations Co. Inc., ``Die Hard 2'' made $37.2 million after seven days. After their first weeks, ``Total Recall'' made $36.1 million and ``Dick Tracy'' netted $34.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: Messenger Charged in Three Dart Attacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4,6,10,11 and 14 to CORRECT spelling of DeMartino, sted DiMartino.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Zodiac-Dartman, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A messenger and mail room clerk with a history of psychiatric problems and a drug conviction was charged Thursday in connection with the ``Dartman'' attacks on women in midtown Manhattan. Jerome Wright, 33, of the Bronx, was arrested after being identified in a lineup by three of the 55 women who have reported feeling the sting of makeshift darts aimed at their backsides during the past three weeks. With Wright's arrest, police predicted the attacks would end. ``We believe he is our darter,'' Chief Joseph DeMartino, who heads the Manhattan detective division, said at a news conference announcing Wright's arrest. The chief said Wright admitted to the three attacks. He also ``indicated to us he has been under observation for psychiatric problems.'' DeMartino was less positive about the suspect's motive. ``Mr. Wright has made numerous statements to us, none of which has given us real insight into why he is doing this,'' he said. Wright was charged with three counts each of reckless endangerment, criminal possession of a weapon and harassment.
