Police said it was unlikely he would be charged in any other attacks since most of the women did not see their assailant. The oddball attacks began June 26 when women started complaining of being stung in the buttocks, legs and arms. In addition to the Manhattan attacks, one woman reported being stung in Queens. The Dartman targeted women in dresses or skirts, and used homemade darts fashioned out of pins and sewing needles attached to paper guides. Most of the incidents occurred in the Penn Station and Times Square areas during lunchtime. Wright, who is on probation until 1992 for a drug conviction, works in the area as a messenger and mail room clerk, which puts him on the streets during the day, DeMartino said. DeMartino said Wright was stopped by two police officers Tuesday because he fit the description of the Dartman. The officers took Wright's name and address and gave it to detectives investigating the attacks, the chief said. The detectives called Wright the next day and asked him to come in for questioning. Wright voluntarily went to a precinct house where he was questioned for more than eight hours. The lineups were conducted late Wednesday and Wright was arrested early Thursday. DeMartino said Wright is unmarried and lives with an aunt.

DOC.HEAD: A Night Stalking the Zodiac Case; Dartman Suspect Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `We believe ...' to CORRECT spelling of DeMartino, sted DiMartino.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Zodiac-Blotter
LaserPhoto NY08; NY20
DOC.TEXT: The police radio would squawk, a dispatcher would rasp ``Confirmed shooting ...'', and we, the Zodiac watchers, would tense. So it went throughout the night, as police and journalists waited for another strike from the man who had shot four people. Elsewhere in the city, police had better luck against the Dartman, arresting a suspect in three of 55 dart-blowing attacks on women. The ``Night of the Zodiac'' did not see a fifth shooting by the astrologically obsessed gunman. But the police at least half expected one; it had been 21 days since the last shooting, and two of the other attacks came after the same interval. On Wednesday night, that fact brought out legions of police and press, the latter to see if Zodiac turned up, the former to capture him if he did. In the Dartman case, authorities said Jerome Wright, 33, a messenger with a criminal record and admitted psychiatric problems, was charged Thursday after several hours of interrogation in connection with the firing of darts at more than 50 well-dressed women, most in midtown Manhattan. Wright was identified in a lineup by three women on Wednesday night and was charged with three counts each of reckless endangerment, criminal possession of a weapon and harassment. ``We believe he is our darter,'' said Manhattan Chief of Detectives Joseph DeMartino. But the search for Zodiac went on. My assignment was to team up with a photographer and stay up all night, driving around. Listen to police scanners. Chase shooting reports. Get there first. The cycle of shootings started March 8, with other shootings on March 29, May 31 and June 21. The time between the second and third shootings was 63 days, a multiple of 21. Each shooting had occurred early on a Thursday. Of the four shooting victims, one was dead. The police had gleaned possible shooting locations from astrological charts, occult books, FBI psychological profiles and notes the bizarre gunman has sent to police and the media, vowing to shoot one person from each Zodiac sign. So the photographer and I left the office at 8 p.m. and drove to the area along the Brooklyn-Queens line where the first three shootings occurred. Here is what we saw and heard: _ 8:45, East New York: At the Grecian III diner, which the gunman referred to in his first letter to police, employees say they recognize the Zodiac sketch as that of a former customer. But he ``hasn't been here in three or four weeks,'' the manager says. _ 9:00, Nichols and Jamaica avenues, site of Zodiac's second shooting: Tom Thompson, 37, believes he has it figured out. ``He won't be in this neighborhood tonight,'' he says. ``Too many cops here. This neighborhood is hot as a firecracker.'' _ 10:07: ``Units take note,'' a dispatcher on a citywide police radio frequency announces, ``Operation Watchdog is in effect.'' ``Operation Watchdog'' took in 50 officers, many of them decoy police, who fanned out through the city to the suspected locations. When the radio crackled with reports of other shootings that did not fit the Zodiac pattern, the officers were to stay put. Or, as the dispatcher said at midnight, ``Designated officers will not respond to any incident unless confirmed incident announced.'' _ 1:15, Central Park, near the scene of the last shooting: Not a soul in sight, except for the occasional four-door sedan with two front-seat occupants _ undercover police. Suddenly, the radio announces a shooting in Brooklyn. When we arrive, we find it was an attempted gas station robbery. An attendant was shot in the leg. _ 3:25: Shooting in Brooklyn. We speed to the site, but a plainclothes officer says Zodiac is not involved. ``Your standard 70th precinct drug- or money-related dispute involving a gun,'' he says. _ 4:00: Driving through Brooklyn's Prospect Park, we spot a red lump in the grass. We find a man in a brand new sleeping bag who is not asleep. ``My wife threw me out,'' he says. Isn't he worried about the Zodiac? ``I don't care, I'm a Virgo,'' he replies. We return to the car, discuss his appearance and his admission of his birth sign, and decide he's a decoy cop. _ 5:20, Bedford-Stuyvesant: We hear a suspect is at the 79th Precinct station house, but it turns out the police brought in a Zodiac-sketch lookalike, questioned him for 10 minutes, and let him go. _ 5:45: ``Blue Angel units, White Angel units, your EOT is 0600 hours,'' squawks the police radio. EOT means end of tour, and dozens of units confirm. _ 6 a.m.: We call it a night. Apparently Zodiac stayed home.

DOC.HEAD: Hanford Downwinders `Finally Getting Truth' About Nuclear Radiation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 3rd, `An independent ...,' to include comment from state Health Dept., radiological oncology expert; picks up 4th graf pvs: `The preliminary ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SE3; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: People who live downwind from the Hanford nuclear reservation reacted with anger and relief Thursday about the government's disclosure that enough radiation spewed from the base to cause cancer. ``I feel like they used us for guinea pigs, and I don't feel like they cared one iota what happened to us either, or our families,'' said Betty Perkes, a farmer in Pasco, which is next to the 560-square-mile reservation. An independent panel of scientists released preliminary data Thursday that showed some residents in the early years of atomic-bomb building in the 1940s could have been exposed to large doses of radioactive iodine. For a few infants, the doses were as high as 2,900 rad over three years. One rad is the amount of radiation a body organ would absorb from about a dozen chest X-rays. Terry Frazee of the state Health Department said radiation standards allow a maximum of five rads a year for industrial workers, although individual organs can handle greater amounts. Dr. George Laramore, professor of radiological oncology at the University of Washington School of Medicine, recommended that people who were infants in the Hanford area during the period be checked for thyroid conditions. But he added that thyroid tumors would likely have appeared five to 15 years after exposure. Survivors of the U.S. atomic bombings of Japan at the end of World War II received thyroid doses estimated at 130 rad, Laramore said, adding that some nuclear medicine treatments use doses as high as 800 rads. The preliminary study results came a day after Energy Secretary James Watkins admitted past Hanford emissions may have caused health problems. John Till, a South Carolina consultant who chaired the 18-member panel of scientists and experts, cautioned that the figures were not meant as health risk estimates. But, Till added, ``These numbers are significant because that is a lot of folks. That dose level is significant enough to strongly justify a thyroid dose study.'' A parallel study by the federal Centers for Disease Control will use the exposure estimates to try to document cases of thyroid disease among Hanford-area residents. The Hanford Environmental Dose Reconstruction Project concluded that most people living near the Hanford site from 1944 to 1947 were exposed to low doses of radiation. The study covered 270,000 people living in 10 Washington and Oregon counties. But up to 13,500 people may have received doses of more than 33 rad of radioactive iodine from the milk they drank. About 1,400 infants and children living in the area received 15 to 650 rad, Till said, including a small number of infants who may have received doses of 2,900 rad or more. The radioactive iodine was produced when spent reactor fuel rods were chemically dissolved to produce weapons-grade plutonium and uranium. When it concentrates in the thyroid gland, iodine-131 can cause cancer and other diseases. Till said that by comparison, doses downwind from the Nevada nuclear weapons testing site ranged from a few rad to 500 rad. ``I know of no other releases of this magnitude from any other U.S. facility,'' Till said of the 1944-47 period, noting that modern releases are extremely small. ``Downwinders,'' people living directly east of the installation during the years of heaviest releases of radioactive iodine, called a news conference after the report was released to express confidence in the Technical Steering Panel's work and anger at the government's long record of secrecy. ``We really believe we're getting the truth now,'' said Tom Bailie, a Mesa farmer whose family's history of cancers and other medical problems have been extensively chronicled in news reports about the downwinders. Although the government cannot be sued under the doctrine of sovereign immunity, Bailie said compensation could be sought through Congress, similar to that recently given to uranium miners for radiation-related illnesses. ``The federal government owes something if folks have been harmed by these early releases of radiation,'' Rep. Sid Morrison, R-Wash., whose district includes the reservation, said in Washington, D.C. ``While these estimates are preliminary and they will change, the potential for harmful side effects is with us to stay.'' At the downwinder news conference, residents gave a litany of family health problems, including thyroid dysfunctions and cancers, that they attributed to the radiation releases. ``For a lot of years, I have been hunting every scrap of newspaper I could find to see why this is happening,'' said Mary Pengelly, who lives in Kirkland and was raised near Pendleton, Ore. ``It makes me feel that maybe ... we're going to see some answers.'' The Technical Steering Panel was appointed in 1988 after health concerns were raised by the release in February 1986 of 19,000 pages of previously classified Hanford environmental documents. The phased, five-year, $15 million study is intended to create computer models of possible radiation doses to nearby residents. The first phase studied airborne radioactive iodine emissions during from 1944-47 and radioactive cooling water poured into the Columbia River from 1964-67. Because of prevailing west-to-east winds, the affected area lies roughly east of Hanford, with larger radiation doses affecting those who lived closest to the reservation, Till said. Most at risk were infants near Hanford's eastern border who drank a lot of milk from family owned cows, Till said. On Wednesday, Watkins told reports in Washington, D.C., that the implications of the report were serious. It was the government's first admission that the leaks were at levels sufficient to cause cancer and other illnesses in people living near Hanford. ``I don't want you to think we do this today,'' Watkins said. ``But we do have to go back and look at what happened to people.'' The inch-thick preliminary report contains hundreds of pages of tables listing dose ``pathways'' in each U.S. Census area among the 10 counties. The counties are: Benton, Franklin, Walla Walla, Adams, Grant, Kittitas, Yakima and Klickitat in Washington and Oregon's Morrow and Umatilla.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Seeks Extradition of Two From Jamaica
DOC.TEXT: Two Jamaicans wanted on drug-trafficking, racketeering and murder charges in the United States were arrested in Jamaica, the U.S. Marshals Service said on Thursday. Both were arrested this week by Jamaican police near Kingston, the Caribbean nation's capital. ``This is the first time the Jamaican government has begun extradition procedures against Jamaican citizens,'' in cooperation with the U.S. government, said Joyce McDonald, spokeswoman for the Marshal Service. Officials said the pair are believed to be leaders of a Jamaican organized crime group known as the ``Shower Posse'' based in Florida. One of the men, Richard Orville Morrison, 35, is among the service's ``15 Most Wanted'' fugitives and has been sought on federal drug charges since October 1988. Lester Coke, 42, has been wanted since September 1988 on narcotics and racketeering charges, including nine murders. Morrison also was named along with Coke in a November 1984 killing in Miami. They are being held pending extradition to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Police Suspect Dismembered Girl Was Victim of Satanic Ritual
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `A 22-year-old ...' to DELETE incorrect reference to arrested man's age; SUBS 12th graf, `Police Commissioner ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with quote from neighbor. Pick up 13th graf, `We'll try ...'
DOC.TEXT: The head of a teen-age girl was found in a freezer, and she probably was killed and dismembered as part of a satanic ritual, according to police, who arrested two people in the case. A Saginaw man and a juvenile were arrested Wednesday after two women found the head in a freezer of a house in this town 15 miles north of Detroit and took it to police, said Deputy Police Chief Carl Muschong. The head had been cleaned of skin and hair, he said. Jaime Rodriguez Jr., 21, was arraigned Thursday on charges of first-degree murder, conspiracy to commit first-degree murder and mutilation of a human body, said Warren police Sgt. Robert Ahrens. A hearing was adjourned Thursday for a 15-year-old Saginaw boy who was apparently staying at the Warren home where the body was found, Ahrens said. He was being held at a youth home until a hearing set for Tuesday, he said. Police said he was expected to be charged with similar offenses. Murder and conspiracy are both punishable by life in prison and mutilation is a 10-year-felony. Saginaw police said Rodriguez also was wanted on robbery, kidnapping, extortion, auto theft and weapons charges. Police found body parts wrapped in garbage bags buried in the house's back yard and hidden in a black car in the garage, Muschong said. The car had been reported stolen earlier in Saginaw, he said. Several books and cassettes about witchcraft were found in the basement, leading police to believe that the girl was the victim of an occult ritual, Muschong said. Neighbors said there had been trouble at the house for more than two years. Some said fighting in the streets and parties that lasted through the night were common and police were called often. ``It really is a creepy feeling,'' said Berta LaPointe, who lives three doors away from the house and watched the police carry bags of body parts out of the back yard. Police Commissioner Paul Pash said no illegal activity was uncovered at the house during previous calls. ``We'll try to interview anybody that has had contact with that house, and we'll check missing persons from that area,'' Muschong said. ``We'll have a description when we get it all to the medical examiner and he can put it all together.'' Police believe the victim is a 15-year-old reported missing June 26, Ahrens said. He said a positive identification had yet to be made using dental records, but ``we're pretty confident that it's her.'' An autopsy determined the girl died recently.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Makes Allegations on Bush Partner; Democrats Seek Prosecutor
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf pvs, ``The case, with two grafs to UPDATE with additional signature and ADD one graf of explanation; picks up 8th graf pvs, The letter
DOC.TEXT: A House Democrat suggested Thursday that a $10,000 donation to the Republicans by a business partner of President Bush's son could have been aimed at blocking an investigation concerning a Colorado savings and loan association. The partner dismissed the allegation as ``total unadulterated nonsense,'' and the No. 2 House Republican said a separate Democratic move _ toward requesting a special prosecutor for the S&L's collapse _ had ``the stench of corruption and hypocrisy.'' In a day of charges and countercharges concerning the institution where Neil Bush was a director, Rep. Frank Annunzio of Illinois suggested developer Kenneth M. Good's $10,000 contribution to the Republican National Committee on Nov. 2, 1988, could have been ``a donation of hush money.'' Annunzio, who has accused the Bush administration of not prosecuting savings and loan fraud vigorously, didn't provide specific evidence to back up his allegations. Meanwhile, action as well as talk was escalating in Congress on the explosive S&L issue and Neil Bush's role in the collapse of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. Bush, 34, was a director of the Denver thrift, which failed at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee are moving to ask Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to appoint an independent counsel to investigate Silverado's collapse, Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said Thursday. ``The case has criminal implications that should be aggressively investigated,'' said a letter that had been signed by 11 of the committee's Democrats by Thursday night. The law requires the signature of at least 12 Democrats, a majority of the 21 on the committee, to make the request. The letter sparked an outraged reaction from No. 2 House Republican Newt Gingrich, D-Ga., who criticized congressional Democrats for seeking to investigate the president's son while trying to block past probes of Democrats accused of wrongdoing. Republicans have said Democrats are trying to use the Neil Bush case as a way of attacking his father. The Democrats' letter to Thornburgh said that because Neil Bush and several other people with political connections were associated with the bank, it would be a conflict of interest for the Justice Department itself to conduct the investigation of Silverado. Thornburgh, in a news conference Wednesday, said, ``I am not a great fan of independent counsels, as you know, but we know our obligations under the law and will execute them.'' A spokesman said that if legislators formally requested a special prosecutor he would review the request and respond within 30 days. Good, in a statement issued by his attorney, said, ``My contribution to the Republican Party in 1988 was two years after my relationship with Silverado was terminated through a negotiated settlement.'' ``With no evidence whatsoever, Mr. Annunzio has accused a private citizen of criminal activity. He is spreading vicious, false accusations in the public arena without any basis. ... No government agency at any level has accused me of any wrongdoing,'' Good said. Good donated more than $90,000 to Republican candidates in the 1987-88 period, including $5,750 for George Bush's presidential bid, the Federal Election Commission said. Some $85,000 _ to candidates other than Bush _ was given in November 1988 just before the elections. The developer, who also invested over $3 million in Neil Bush's oil exploration company, was the fifth-largest individual political contributor in Colorado in 1988, according to a study by the Center for Responsive Politics. His contributions included $750 in August 1986 and $5,000 in October 1987 for the Bush presidential campaign, said Scott Moxley, a spokesman for the Federal Election Commission. The developer also contributed to the campaigns of several Democrats, including Sen. Robert Kerrey of Nebraska ($500), Sen. Timothy E. Wirth of Colorado ($2,000) and Sen. George J. Mitchell of Maine ($500), according to the Federal Election Commission. During Neil Bush's tenure on its board, Silverado loaned Good around $30 million that was never repaid. Federal regulators have ordered the president's son to answer allegations of conflict of interest in his role as a director of the thrift. Among accusations, the regulators allege that he failed to adequately disclose his ties to Good. Bush has denied any wrongdoing, and the president has defended the ``honor and integrity'' of his son at news conferences. Annunzio said Good's donation to the Republicans, made shortly before the election that brought George Bush to the White House, could have been aimed at blocking a Justice Department investigation of Good as a Silverado borrower. Annunzio said officials of the Office of Thrift Supervision made five criminal referrals concerning Silverado to the Justice Department, but the thrift office has refused to give him the names or dates of those referrals. He speculated that one of the referrals could have involved Good, and that the information is not being made public because the referrals could have been made at around the same time Good contributed the $10,000. Annunzio sent a letter Thursday to Thornburgh requesting copies of the five Silverado referrals. Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said Thursday the names of any people who might be involved wouldn't be made public since they would be part of a pending investigation. He wouldn't confirm whether Silverado referrals had been made to the department. Neil Bush's attorney, James Nesland, said his client would have no comment. Good recently told a House Banking Committee hearing on Silverado that his net worth has plummeted from $100 million to less than zero. Campaign finance records show that Good donated $42,500 to Republican candidates in Colorado and an equal amount to Republicans in California, both in early November of 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Last F-117A Stealth Fighter Delivered to Air Force
LaserPhoto LA7
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. delivered the 59th and last F-117A stealth fighter to the Air Force on Thursday in a well-publicized ceremony that contrasted sharply with the secrecy that veiled the jet for a decade. Delivery from Lockheed's famed supersecret Skunk Works division comes as the defense firm girds for heated competition with Northrop Corp. to build the Advanced Tactical Fighter for the Air Force of the next century. The ATF contract for hundreds of warplanes is the last big ticket item on the Pentagon shopping list for the end of the 20th century and represents the major spoils of what is left in the rapidly shrinking U.S. defense budget. Gen. Michael J. Dugan, the new Air Force chief of staff, described the F-117A as an example of a ``small is beautiful'' philosophy promoted by Skunk Works founder Kelly Johnson and noted that the program finished within budget and ahead of schedule. ``We are going to be a smaller Air Force,'' Dugan said. ``We are going to be a little smaller and little smarter. ... Small can be beautiful.'' Still, at a cost of $42.6 million a plane, the F-117A remains one of the most expensive fighter aircraft ever built. Part of the cost resides in program secrecy imposed in 1981. The project was accomplished with the strictest security measures known since the Manhattan Project to build the atom bomb during World War II, former Defense Secretary Frank Carlucci has said. What the Air Force got for its money is a force of a little more than 50 planes. The black, sharply angled jet is actually a ground attack aircraft able to sneak past radar while dropping bombs with pinpoint accuracy. The last delivery was announced in big newspaper advertisements which have become common in the aerospace industry since the defense budget began shrinking and firms and the services have become eager to show off advanced, operational hardware that once was secret. About 500 people attended the ceremony at Lockheed's Palmdale plant. A Northrop-led team has already rolled out its ATF prototype but Lockheed's prototype is not expected until late summer. Both Northrop and Lockheed are laying off many workers in Southern California. For Lockheed's part, the company hopes its breakthrough in stealth technology will help in the winner-take-all contract to build the ATF. The stealth fighter was built at the top-secret Skunk Works that developed such other high-technology aircraft as the U-2 and the Mach 3 SR-71 Blackbird spyplanes. ``Let the nation know we are ready to do it again,'' said Skunk Works chief Ben Rich. If Lockheed gets the ATF contract, the Calabasas, Calif.-based contractor said it would build the fighters for the $63 billion program in Georgia. Northrop would build ATF planes in California at Palmdale.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Civil Rights Law for Disabled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS six grafs at bottom with names of those voting against and not voting; DELETES extraneous matter after 6th graf pvs, ``It is
DOC.TEXT: The House passed landmark legislation on Thursday guaranteeing rights to millions of disabled Americans, including access to public transportation, businesses and jobs. Approval of the Americans with Disabilities Act, by a 377-28 vote, came after House and Senate negotiators agreed on a way to protect the jobs of AIDS-infected workers who handle food. Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif., and others tried unsuccessfully to restore an amendment that would have let employers keep AIDS-infected workers away from food-handling duties. The Senate will vote on the bill Friday morning, said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. President Bush has urged passage of the bill, one of the most significant pieces of domestic legislation of his term. The bill has been hailed as the most significant civil rights legislation since the 1964 act prohibiting racial discrimination. ``It is indeed a bill which will open up America to 43 million Americans who have been shut out, sometimes consciously, but too often subconsciously,'' said the chief House sponsor, Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md. Among the measure's key provisions: _Restaurants, stores, professional offices and all other businesses must make their services available to people with disabilities, provided the cost of doing so is not excessive. The requirement takes effect 18 months after enactment, except for small businesses, which would have longer. _Businesses with 15 or more employees must disregard handicaps in hiring decisions and make special accommodations, at the employer's cost, for those disabilities. The accommodation is limited by the financial hardship it will cause for the company. The requirement will be phased in over four years. _Amtrak, commuter rail systems and local and intercity bus systems will have to provide areas for disabled passengers, including those in wheelchairs. _All telephone companies will have to provide special services for people with speech and hearing impairments. Opponents of the bill , such as Rep. Dan Burton, R-Ind., complain the bill is vaguely worded and will ``create a firestorm'' of lawsuits at the expense of the economy. The bill caps two years of efforts, including negotiations last summer with the White House. The Senate passed the bill last September by a 76-8 vote. The House passed its version of the bill in May by a 403-20 vote. The House, however, added an amendment to let employers reassign workers with AIDS so they couldn't come into contact with food. An attempt to resurrect that amendment failed Thursday night by a 224-180 vote. Under a compromise approved earlier Thursday by House and Senate negotiators, the Department of Health and Human Services would be required each year to study all communicable diseases and how they are transmitted. The House vote on the bill approves that compromise, which originated Wednesday in the Senate. Under the compromise, employers in the food industry would be able to reassign workers whose diseases may be spread to customers through contact with food. The compromise effectively negates the earlier House amendment. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan and other leading health officials have repeatedly stated the disease cannot be spread through such casual contact. Proponents of the House amendment included Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., who unsuccessfully sought to have the Senate adopt it. Helms and others said public fears about AIDS could drive restaurants out of business despite scientific evidence. Those voting against the bill were: Reps. Bill Archer, R-Texas; Richard K. Armey, R-Texas; Joe Barton, R-Texas; Herbert H. Bateman, R-Va.; Dan Burton, R-Ind.; Jim Chapman, D-Texas; Jim Cooper, D-Tenn.; Philip M. Crane, R-Ill.; William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; Tom DeLay, R-Texas; Bill Edwards, R-Mo.; Melton D. Hancock, R-Mo.; J. Dennis Hastert, R-Ill. Wally Herger, R-Calif.; Clyde C. Holloway, R-La.; Jerry Lewis, R-Calif.; Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa; Ron Marlenee, R-Mont.; Bob McEwen, R-Ohio; Clarence E. Miller, R-Ohio; Howard C. Nielson, R-Utah; Jim Olin, D-Va.; Ron Packard, R-Calif.; Mike Parker, D-Miss.; Norman D. Shumway, R-Calif.; Bud Shuster, R-Pa.; Charles W. Stenholm, D-Texas; and Bob Stump, R-Ariz. Not voting were: Reps. Rod Chandler, R-Wash.; George W. Crockett Jr., D-Mich.; Floyd H. Flake, D-N.Y.; Harold E. Ford, D-Tenn.; William D. Ford, D-Mich.; William F. Goodling, D-Pa.; William H. Gray III, D-Pa.; Frank J. Guarini, D-N.J.; Ralph M. Hall, D-Texas; Charles Hatcher, D-Ga.; Jerry Huckaby, D-La.; Ed Jenkins, D-Ga.; Ben Jones, D-Ga. Donald E. ``Buz'' Lukens, R-Ohio; Matthew G. Martinez, D-Calif.; Joseph M. McDade, R-Pa.; Bruce A. Morrison, D-Conn.; Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; Carl D. Pursell, R-Mich.; Tommy F. Robinson, D-Ark.; James H. Scheuer, D-N.Y.; Bill Schuette, R-Mich.; Charles E. Schumer, D-N.Y.; Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn.; Lamar S. Smith, R-Texas; Robert G. Torricelli, D-N.J.; and Bob Traxler, D-Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Supreme Court Says Impeached Governor Can Run Again
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Evan Mecham can run for office again despite his 1988 impeachment and ouster from office, the Arizona Supreme Court ruled Thursday. ``Impeachment, essentially a political process, is not subject to judicial review,'' the state's highest court said in a unanimous decision. ``Any appeal from the impeachment conviction lies in the electoral process.'' A former highway patrolman, Dennis Ingram, challenged Mecham's re-election bid, saying the Arizona Constitution automatically barred him from running again. The justices decided, 5-0, that the state constitution was unclear on that point and that ``election, the ultimate weapon of democracy, is favored where any doubt exists.'' Mecham was convicted of misuse of about $80,000 given him by supporters and obstruction of justice in a cover-up of an alleged death threat made by an aide. ``As expected, the court made the only decision that we could see that they could make,'' Mecham said at a campaign stop in Yuma. ``We appreciate that and now let's get on with the election and let the people do the choosing of who their next governor's going to be and get on with solving the critical problems of the state.'' Mecham filed as a gubernatorial candidate last month for the Sept. 11 Republican primary. He faces four primary opponents. With incumbent Gov. Rose Mofford stepping down, the gubernatorial race is wide open. Former Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard is considered the Democratic front-runner. Ingram contended Mecham's impeachment and conviction automatically barred Mecham from ever again seeking office. ``I'm disappointed, obviously,'' said Michael Meehan, Ingram's lawyer. Mecham argued the state constitution does not automatically ban him from seeking public office and the state Senate rejected such a ban. The Senate convicted Mecham by a two-thirds vote but came up three votes short of a two-thirds majority when it considered a ``Dracula clause,'' which would have banned him from holding public office. Mecham and Arizona Attorney General Bob Corbin said disqualification from holding office is discretionary and the only thing the constitution required was removal from office. Ingram has declined to discuss his motivation for filing the challenge to Mecham's comeback attempt. Mecham has said he believes one of his political opponents was behind Ingram's challenge, but Meehan denied that.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bahamas Officials: 39 Haitians Drown
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-nine Haitians drowned when their sailboat capsized in choppy seas in the Bahamas while being towed by a military patrol boat, according to a government statement Thursday. Sixty-seven others aboard the unnamed 45-foot sailing sloop were rescued after it sank Tuesday afternoon, the Bahamian government said. The government did not explain what caused the sloop to sink while under tow. The Bahamian Defence Force vessel HMBS Yellow Elder, under the command of Lt. Cmdr. Godfrey Rolle, spotted the Haitian vessel at 11:30 a.m. Tuesday off Staniel Cay, about 200 miles southeast of the southern tip of Florida near Great Exuma island. The sloop tried to enter shallow waters and the patrol boat pursued, catching up to the vessel and taking it under tow, according to the statement. During the tow back to Staniel Cay, the sloop capsized. One Haitian radio station reported that the tow line broke, while another said that panicked Haitians ran to one side of the vessel when Bahamian soldiers boarded the vessel. The bodies of the 30 men and nine women were buried Wednesday at Bitter Guana Cay in the Exumas, about 80 miles from Nassau, the statement said. Defence Forces officials Thursday night did not return calls from The Associated Press. A fishing guide, Walter Robinson, said the bodies of the Haitians were placed on a raft, covered with a canvas and brought into Black Point on the Great Guana Cay. He said he helped a police boat tow the raft with his skiff, navigating between shallow flats and rocky heads. Robinson said he arrived at 2 a.m. Wednesday after being called to the scene to help move the bodies. ``There was nobody to take charge of the bodies. I put the raft into the beach, took a grapple overboard and pulled it up on the island and tied it to the beach and left them there,'' Robinson said. The surviving Haitians were brought to Nassau on Wednesday. Defense Force divers were searching the sunken vessel Thursday for more bodies.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Elated as Government, Union Agreement Ends Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Ortega claims victory, quotes from business association, government. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA4
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Sandinista workers jumped for joy and began returning to their jobs Thursday after the U.S.-backed government gave in to strike demands in order to settle a destructive work stoppage. Former President Daniel Ortega called the settlement a victory for the Sandinistas that preserved a basic ``conquest of the revolution'' _ land reform. A Sandinista strike in May ended with a 100 percent pay raise. Businesses opened Thursday in Managua and workers began to replace street paving stones torn up to build barricades. Six people were killed and 100 wounded in clashes between strikers and government supporters during the 10-day strike that tested the stability of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and her government, which replaced Ortega's government on April 25. The government met many Sandinista demands: salary increases, compensation for fired government workers, suspension of a decree to return Sandinista-confiscated land to its original owners, and restoration of free public transportation for students. Unions also appeared to have made headway in their demand for a role in running the economy in this country of 3.7 million residents. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the administration was pleased the strikes had ended. But he assailed Sandinista authorities, saying they have been unwilling to grant the government the breathing spell it needs to get desperately needed economic reconstruction under way. Ortega denied the strike was a Sandinista attempt to undermine the government and said senior party leaders played a pivotal role in settling it. He praised the Sandinista armed forces, which his brother heads, and the Sandinista police for avoiding confrontation. The Superior Council of Private Enterprise, the major business group here, said the strike amounted to blackmail and accused the government of caving in under pressure. Council President Gilberto Cuadra said the accord crippled the government program to return Nicaragua to a free market economy. The strike hit at planting time and involved thousands of agricultural workers. Cuadra said it will cost Nicaragua from $35 million to $50 million. Presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo defended the settlement on state radio. He said it prevented more bloodshed and assured stability. Employees at the Industry and Commerce Ministry jumped up and down and hugged each other in celebration when the end of the strike was announced. The strike began July 2 and grew into the biggest challenge to Mrs. Chamorro since the Sandinistas were voted out of office 10 weeks ago after nine years in power. The Sandinistas had said since losing elections to her United National Opposition coalition that they would ``rule from below.'' Unions claimed 90,000 government and state industry employees joined the walkout. It was the second time the Sandinistas brought public services to a halt to force pay raises and modifications in Mrs. Chamorro's plans to cut public spending, sell off state-owned enterprises and turn into a capitalist economy the socialist-oriented economy built by the Sandinistas. Traffic stareted returning to normal Thursday, but cars and trucks had to creep around potholes, dislodged paving stones and rubble left behind from the barricades and fires that filled the streets during three days of disturbances. The unions called off street disruptions Wednesday to persuade the government to negotiate, but intense gunfire could be heard in the city through the night. No casualties were reported. Army and city cleanup crews used heavy equipment to shovel away remaining barricades. Others fit paving stones back into place. The government had declared the strike ``illegal, illegitimate and non-existent'' and threatened to fire those who took part. Most government employees received their positions during Sandinista rule. The agreement with the pro-Sandinista National Workers' Front grants a 43 percent raise this month and another increase in August. The amount of the second raise is to be later determined. The agreement specifies that 800 employees fired after April 26 will receive compensation, state jobs will be reclassified in September and a new minimum wage law will be established. The strikers forced the conservative government to back down on a key part of its plan to return Nicaragua, debilitated by the Reagan administration's economic embargo, to a free-market economy: the return of lands confiscated in the 1979 revolution. Workers and students are to once again ride public transportation for free, a privilege granted by the Sandinistas and recently suspended by the new government to save money. The government agreed to create a commission of government and National Workers' Front representatives to discuss government investment in state-owned texile, metalworking and construction companies. The talks are to begin Monday. Creation of the commission appeared to be a response to the Front's demand for a role in making economic policy.

DOC.HEAD: Artists Rejected by National Endowment Plan Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Four performance artists denied grants by the National Endowment for the Arts plan to appeal. ``I refuse to accept the overturning of my grant and those of the three other artists,'' Holly Hughes said Wednesday at a news conference called by the National Campaign for Freedom of Expression. The NEA vetoed funds June 29 for Hughes and fellow artists Karen Finley, Tim Miller and John Fleck, despite a recommendation by an endownment peer panel that they be given money. Grants totaling $104,000 were awarded to 14 other artists. The endowment has come under attack from right-wing critics and some religious groups who contend public money should not be given to art that might be considered obscene. The work of all four artists, three of whom are openly homosexual, contains explicit sexual references and, in some cases, nudity. ``Our work is not, as the religious right charges, pornographic,'' Hughes said. ``If any of these artists were doing pornographic work, we wouldn't bother applying to the NEA. We would be making plenty of money already.'' The process of appealing the NEA decision has not yet been worked out, but the idea has received strong support from the Solo Performance Fellowship Panel which initially recommended that the grants be given to the four artists. ``We believe that each of these individual artists, based on the criteria that was before us, is deserving of the fellowship as recommended,'' said Philip Arnoult, panel chairman and director of the Theater Project in Baltimore. In an emotional statement, Finley said: ``I am being punished because I am a morally concerned artist. ... This is a sad regressive time in our national history. As the wall in Eastern Europe is coming down, it seems that a new wall in our own country is going up.'' But she cautioned against abolishing the NEA and relying solely on private business to underwrite the arts. ``Corporations use the NEA as a guideline in knowing who to give money to, by knowing who has gone through the distinguished process of the endowment's granting procedures,'' she said. ``Most private funds and foundations do the same.'' Richard Elovich, a performance artist whose grant was approved this year by the endowment, called on artists and organizations given government funds to use a part of that money ``to support artists and arts organizations blacklisted by the NEA.'' In Denver Wednesday, a group of artists attending the Composer-to-Composer International Telluride Institute conference, including Pulitzer Prize winner Roger Reynolds, denounced the NEA's rejection of the four, saying it was part of a disturbing trend toward censorship. ``We really believe these artists have a right to express themselves,'' said Laurie Anderson, a performance artist. ``These artists, in my opinion, were sacrificed to the so-called greater good.'' The National Campaign for Freedom of Expression, based in Washington, was created earlier this year by arts activists. It has called for the five-year reauthorization of the National Endownment for the Arts without restrictions or restructuring.

DOC.HEAD: `thirtysomething,' `Wonder Years' Writers Honored
DOC.TEXT: Episodes of the ABC hits ``thirtysomething'' and ``The Wonder Years,'' a segment of the CBS miniseries ``Common Ground'' and an ABC ``Afterschool Special'' each won a 1990 Humanitas Prize Wednesday. The animated CBS series ``Dink, the Little Dinosaur'' and a syndicated show on teaching morality to children also were honored for enriching television audiences during a luncheon in Century City. The awards were presented by the Human Family Educational and Cultural Institute. A total of $70,000 in prize money went to writers of network programs that ``most fully communicate those values which enrich the viewing public,'' according to the institute. Todd W. Langen, who wrote the ``Square Dance'' episode of ``The Wonder Years,'' in which the character Kevin snubs his assigned dance partner, won an award in the category for 30-minute prime-time programs. The episode was cited for ``its witty affirmation of each person's right to be uniquely different; for its poignant depiction of the ravages of peer pressure,'' the institute's statement said. Joseph Dougherty won in the 60-minute category for ``The Other Shoe'' episode of ``thirtysomething,'' which involved the character Nancy having ovarian cancer. The show was honored ``for its chilling dramatization of the specter of death, and of the moral stamina needed to face it down.'' The second part of the miniseries ``Common Ground'' earned Edward Hume a Humanitas Prize in the 90-minute-or-more category. The show, dealing with the mandated desegregation of Boston schools in the 1970s, celebrated the courage to abandon stereotypes and respond to hatred with non-violence, the institute said. An ABC ``Afterschool Special'' by Bruce Harmon, ``A Town's Revenge,'' dealt with ``the courage it takes to be ecologically sensitive,'' and to be faithful to one's values even at the risk of alienation from loved ones, the statement said. It won in the children's live action category. The prize in the children's animated category went to Cliff Ruby and Elana Lesser, whose ``Badge of Courage'' episode of ``Dink, the Little Dinosaur'' was commended for depicting the fulfillment of committing an unselfish act. In the episode, Dink overcomes fear to help others threatened by an erupting volcano. A documentary award went to Carol L. Fleisher for ``See Dick and Jane Lie, Cheat and Steal: Teaching Morality to Kids.'' The show was part of the syndicated series ``Raising Good Kids in Bad Times.''

Western leaders managed a breakthrough in a long-troublesome trade dispute but still left it to their aides to do the hard bargaining needed to craft a final plan for revamping global commerce. ``I'm not under any illusions that we'll be dealing with a new era by Christmas _ or even by next spring,'' Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said at Wednesday's close of a three-day economic summit. President Bush joined Mulroney and other leaders of the seven richest democracies in pledging to make sharp cuts in government support for farmers, a contentious issue in the current Uruguay Round of world trade talks. ``What we're trying to do is move the whole thing forward without saying that we have to have, tomorrow, totally unprotected trade,'' Bush told a news conference. The leaders of Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Canada, Italy and the United States took part in the summit. A representative of the 12-nation European Community also attended.

President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's government has opened talks with Sandinista leaders of a general strike that hurled the nation into a chaos of street skirmishes between armed partisans. Something of a truce emerged Wednesday night after six days of unrest that brought the capital to a virtual standstill and posed the most serious challenge yet to Mrs. Chamorro's 10-week-old administration. The president had called off negotiations over the weekend, but softened her position in response to an offer from the strikers on Wednesday. She also won a promise from army chief Gen. Humberto Ortega that troops would quiet Managua today.

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has scored another triumph at a watershed Communist Party Congress, persuading delegates to elect his protege as the party's second-in-command. This morning, on the final day of the 10-day congress, members considered nominations for a new Central Committee. Former Ukraine party chief Vladimir A. Ivashko defeated leading hard-liner Yegor K. Ligachev in an election Wednesday for the newly created post of deputy general secretary. The official Tass news agency said Ivashko was approved by a vote of 3,109-to-1,309. Ligachev was handed a stinging loss, with delegates voting 776-to-3,642 against him.

Corrupt executives who pillaged the savings and loan industry would face an expanded army of investigators and longer prison terms under major crime legislation approved by the Senate. ``We need to be cracking down on the orgy of fraud and lawbreaking that occurred in the savings and loan crisis,'' Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said Wednesday as the crime bill was approved 94-6 and sent to the House. The savings and loan provisions came as a last-minute addition to the crime package, which also would place curbs on nine kinds of semiautomatic assault weapons and make 34 federal offenses punishable by death. Senate approval of more money, new weapons and fresh troops to aid prosecutors put pressure on the Bush administration to clean up the scandal.

Undercover police guided by the stars staked out various points in the city in their quest for the Zodiac killer, whose 21-day pattern of shootings led investigators to suspect he would strike again today. Police consulted astrological charts, occult books, FBI psychological profiles and letters scrawled by the gunman in selecting their positions. The gunman has vowed in his letters to shoot 12 people, one for each sign of the zodiac. He has struck four times in four months. One victim died. Police, including a task force of 50, refused to divulge the locations staked out. To match Zodiac's pattern of preying on easy targets, they dressed as homeless or elderly people or others who are vulnerable.

DOC.HEAD: Was This Trip Necessary? `Great Journeys' on PBS Suggests It's Not
DOC.TEXT: Travel is hell. An airport traffic jam delivers you to an endless line with luggage to lug to your narrow airplane seat for a meal of cute, toy food, a pressurized atmosphere and a bouncy landing. Worse, to come back you reverse the procedure. International travel can be unshirted hell, exposing the unwary traveler to bad food, bad service and bad company in a foreign language AND an eccentric currency: Um, how many shinplasters for that there fried zobrovny, pardner? ``Great Journeys,'' an eight-part series bowing Saturday night on PBS, is another powerful incentive to stay home. It reminds you just how miserable travel can be. Or how much fun, if you're a masochist. ``I love to travel,'' you say. And then you tell the whole story of your 13-hour layover at Krazed Dictator International on the equator, where sullen customs men teased sunburned, sweaty Germans in counterfeit Chanel T-shirts and you saw babies get sucked dry by malarial mosquitoes the size of dinner plates. ``Great Journeys'' promises more of that kind of fun. Its first episode, ``The Silk Road'' takes you through Western China and some of the most desolate landscape ever seen outside a kitty box. The publicity for ``Great Journeys'' says it will travel the world's great trade routes with writers who ``make making personal `journeys of passion' along routes that hold personal significance for each of them.'' Hmm. The opening episode takes Colin Thubron, a well-regarded British novelist and travel writer, along the silk traders caravan route from the Great Wall of China to, well, China. He almost gets to Afghanistan. The lust for silk, he explains, nearly bankrupted the Roman Empire when travelers brought the fine fabric back from the Orient. The overland route flourished but has been in decline for, oh, 600 years or so. For Thubron, who chronicled a 10,000-mile road trip in his 1987 book ``Where Nights are Longest: Travels by Car through Western Russia,'' it must seem like a pleasant outing. It exhausts even an armchair traveler. Along the way, we see the waning influence of Chinese culture. It is gradually supplanted by the Moslem people known as the Turcomen _ farmers and traders whose culture is distinctly Middle Eastern and non-Chinese. They're a handsome, courteous people and they treat Thubron with great restraint, especially when he asks dumb questions: Q: Would you like to live in the city? A: Certainly! Why not? It turns out this journey has personal significance for Thubron because he always wanted to do it. Judging from the landscape and his fellow travelers, he is alone in that regard. Nobody but Thubron is out there for recreation. Remember, we're talking ``trade'' route, not ``scenic'' or ``fun'' route. The terrain is flat and monotonous or hummocked and monotonous or mountainous and ugly. A road runs through it. He travels mostly by bus. He loves it. The silk traders skirted the great deserts. Not Thubron. He hires a couple of spitting, toe-stomping camels and takes a daytrip onto the sand. He loves it. Heck, he even loves the camels, who care for nothing but other camels. He characterizes his journey as a solitary one. This was probably a comfort to the invisible cameraman and sound operator who filmed his departing bus or arriving truck or his camel caravan endlessly rolling across the horizon. Mostly, though, Thubron meditates on what it feels like to be in the last place God made. Other episodes of ``Great Journeys'' are much more promising than ``The Silk Road.'' The Burma Road, ``The Salt Road'' of the Sahara, The Pan American Highway and the Ho Chi Minh Trail will be featured in coming weeks. And you don't have to leave home to see them.

Elsewhere in television ... SHE SINGS, SHE DANCES, SHE'S ... EMMA WHO?: She's Emma Thompson, a funny, talented British actress known mostly for her work on ``Fortunes of War'' last season on ``Masterpiece Theater.'' She returns to the PBS on Sunday night with ``Thompson,'' a series of six comic half-hours she wrote for the BBC. The sketches are funny, wicked, fast-paced and wildly uneven, but the great ones are well worth waiting for. ``Self Defense in the Kitchen'' opens with various martial-arts techniques available to a woman with a cookstove, wok and saucepan lids; there's a monologue on a dinner party for guests who turn out to be vegetarians who only eat uncooked food. There's a howlingly funny scene about flatulence. Her mystery guest star in a song-and-dance number turns out to be her husband, Kenneth Branagh, the star and director of last year's ``Henry V,'' but the evening is all Thompson's and well worth your time.

DOC.HEAD: Why The Stock Market Isn't Doing What It `Should' Be Doing
DOC.TEXT: If the usual measurements indicate stocks are priced rather high, and the profit outlook is uninspiring, and the economy seems to be going nowhere fast, shouldn't the market averages fall? If you think so, you have lots of company among professional analysts, some of whom have been saying for a year that the market's price-to-equity and price-to-earnings and price-to-prospects ratios are too high. But the market never does what it ``should'' do. The very word has no meaning whatsoever in regard to stock prices except to offer alibis to those who have been wrong or who wish to parade their academic knowledge. That said, why should the market ride higher on a weaker substructure than it has in the past? Or, why shouldn't the popular blue-chip averages revert to their proper behavior? Here are a few possibilities, gleaned from analyst comments: _The institutionalization of the marketplace. Pension funds continue to grow. Their investment commitments are dictated not only by their analyses of stocks but by the need to put the money to use. In a sense, they must invest. Because of the large size of their transactions, they must buy stocks in companies that also are large and have enough shares outstanding to accommodate large-scale buying and selling. When the market was made up of small traders, there was more variability in their choices. But individual investors continue to leave the market. In the first quarter, they reduced equity holdings at an annual rate of $91 billion. _The popular averages reflect prices of the biggest stocks and the activities of the biggest investors. Not all stocks are doing as well as the blue chips. Smaller stocks have been laggards for several years. _More big buyers are indexing their portfolios. That is, they seek to at least match the popular indexes _ most of which are blue-chip indicators _ and they do so by buying the very stocks that make up the indexes. _The supply of equities is shrinking, but the number of equity seekers may not be shrinking. There are fewer stocks to buy today than there were last year or five years ago or seven years ago. Since 1983, according to Wright Investors' Service, which closely monitors the equities population, more than $500 billion of U.S. equities have been removed from the stock market. The shrinkage continued in the first quarter of 1990, according to Wright, which estimates that the value of equities retired exceeded the value of new issues by an annual rate of $63 billion. In the 1980s, most of the shrinkage resulted from corporate takeovers, many of which substituted debt for equity. More recently, the decline seems to be resulting more from corporations buying back their own shares. In late 1989 and early this year, for example, General Electric, IBM and Westinghouse announced major stock repurchase programs that will total about $16 billion over the next several years. What ``should'' the market be doing? Nothing but what it is doing.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates Debating Peace Dividend That May Be Just a Mirage
DOC.TEXT: Congressional candidate Rosa DeLauro wants to use a big chunk of the peace dividend to help defense workers and industries adapt to the end of the Cold War. It's a win-win proposal in her Connecticut district, which is dominated by three major military contractors already feeling the effects of friendlier relations around the world. There's only one catch: There might not be a peace dividend. The Cold War thaw is expected to produce military spending cuts adding up to tens of billions of dollars over the next few years. But even as candidates tout their big plans for that money, some politicians and analysts maintain the peace dividend is only a mirage. The savings and loan bailout will eat it up, Rep. Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois told the nation's mayors last month. Efforts to cut the federal deficit will swallow it, others say. ``Any politician in an election year is going to grab for any available resource and spend it on the trail because they don't have anything else to spend,'' said Democratic analyst Bob Beckel. ``But the pressure to take peace dividend money and use it for anything but deficit reduction is just too strong right now. And this is coming from a liberal,'' he added with a laugh. The same argument is coming from Republicans and fiscally conservative Democrats like Rostenkowski. Many of them contend that any peace dividend is too far down the road to mean much to voters anyway. ``People can't relate to the argument,'' said Linda DiVall, a GOP polling consultant. ``There is no $150 million surplus there on the table. If it existed, Republicans and Democrats would not be sitting down to talk about deficit reduction. The peace dividend was peace.'' Such talk aside, the peace dividend continues to crop up on campaign trails in places like Connecticut, Iowa, Colorado and Nebraska. Josie Heath, a Democratic Senate candidate in Colorado, visited with coal miners coming off the morning shift one day last week. ``I was telling them I'd like to cut the defense budget by 50 percent and they were shaking their heads and saying it's about time,'' Heath said. She and DeLauro, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for an open House seat, are suggesting similar peace dividend plans that would divide military savings between deficit reduction and domestic needs such as education, health care, housing subsidies, pollution cleanup, road and bridge repair, and aid to defense-dependent states and communities. Neither candidate believes peace dividend savings automatically must go to the S&L bailout. ``I don't think we need to accept Rostenkowski's dictum on that,'' said DeLauro. ``We have to decide what it is we want to do, what are the priorities we want to focus on.'' The DeLauro and Heath plans are similar to proposals being offered by more than a few Democrats eager to highlight their party's reputation for caring about domestic concerns. Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster, said it is a useful political exercise even if there's no pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. ``The peace dividend is just becoming a metaphor for talking about priorities in spending,'' she said. ``It's one of the few areas where Democrats still have an advantage.'' Several influential Democrats, including House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., believe the party can build on its strengths by becoming identified as the champion of displaced defense workers. This ``economic conversion'' theme, evolving in legislation and campaign pitches like those of Heath and DeLauro, involves a range of proposals to retool factories, redirect research and retrain workers while cushioning economic shocks. The policy holds obious appeal for defense-dependent regions of New England, Virginia, California, Texas, Colorado and New York. And Democrats believe their candidates stand to benefit most. ``People believe Democrats would cut the military more than Republicans, but they also know it's darn hard to change a 50-year-old tank welder into a toxic waste specialist,'' said Lake. ``They believe it takes resources. And if you're looking for resources, you're looking for Democrats.'' But Beckel cautions there are potential pitfalls to the strategy, as well. ``There's an advantage. You force the debate,'' he said. ``But I worry about raising expectations and then not being able to deliver on them.''

DOC.HEAD: Does Ingersoll Want or Have to Go to Europe?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ST1 of July 10
DOC.TEXT: With the U.S. newspaper empire he built on junk bonds and panache crumbling, it's not surprising that Ralph M. Ingersoll II has retreated to Europe to pick up the pieces. Ingersoll, whose network of newspaper holdings grew fast the past five years and shrank even faster earlier this month, always considered himself an odd duck among American newspaper publishers. He's been described as worldly, soft-spoken, debonair, continental and global. Some acquaintances just call the 44-year-old entrepreneur a European kind of guy. He speaks several languages, went to school in Switzerland, wears English suits, married a German, drives a German car and when he dashes off a note, he dates it the European way _ 2 July 1990. That date, July 2, was a turning point in the rise and fall of the media company started by Ingersoll's father, Ralph senior, a respected editor who got into publishing in the late 1950s. Ingersoll announced a trans-Atlantic swap with investment partner E.M. Warburg Pincus & Co. He gave up all his American newspapers and became sole owner of his European newspaper group. Ingersoll had controlled 10 American dailies and dozens of weeklies. The swap also left Ingersoll with a much smaller, less-indebted business that includes a morning, afternoon and Sunday newspaper in Dublin, Ireland, and three dailies and 39 weeklies in England. Ingersoll said he's happy with the deal. ``I think it was natural and basically inevitable,'' Ingersoll said in a telephone interview from the south of France where he was visiting friends. ``We had a philosophical difference. I saw great opportunity in Europe. They weren't really interested.'' He said the key to the deal for him is that he's severing his ties with Warburg Pincus, his investment partner since 1983. Under his original agreement with that firm, Ingersoll was obligated to share 50 percent of the profits of any acquisition or deal he made. After several years, he realized he had made a mistake, especially when he learned that Warburg Pincus wasn't particularly enthusiastic about European expansion. ``I was faced with an opportunity to get out from under that agreement and I took advantage of it,'' Ingersoll said. ``Now I'm free to negotiate with individual investor groups for each individual deal. That's the way my father and I did it for 25 years and that's the way I'm going to do it now.'' Nonetheless, a basic question still emerges: How much choice did he have in what's happened to him? ``What's happening, I think, was basically forced upon him,'' said John Morton, a media industry analyst for Lynch Jones & Ryan in New York. ``But I guess with his affinity for Europe, it might make it easier to swallow.'' Others say Ingersoll welcomes the chance to escape the recession that has hurt the American newspaper industry. Ingersoll said he talked with his partners about the trans-Atlantic swap last year and has been watching the European market for eight years. ``Ralph always said there were greater opportunities in Europe. He always expressed a strong interest over there. I think this move is consistent with his thinking,'' said Tom Tallarico, ex-publisher of Ingersoll's ex-newspaper, the St. Louis Sun. The Sun, launched last September, was supposed to be a revolutionary tabloid designed to show that growth was possible in a stagnant industry. After seven months, the newspaper folded with a loss of at least $25 million. Ingersoll, who used some of his own money to start the paper, said he stopped publishing because of inadequate street sales. Analysts said he was forced to pull the plug because of his weighty obligations in junk bonds, the high-yield, high-risk debt securities that became a primary financing tool for many companies in the 1980s. By some reckonings, Ingersoll's U.S. newspaper network amassed debts exceeding $700 million, much of it raised by Michael Milken, the junk-bond financier of the now-defunct Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. investment company. A month before the Sun's demise, Ingersoll offered to repurchase $240 million worth of junk bonds at deep discounts to avoid defaulting on upcoming interest payments. He got a poor response. ``Everyone in the industry said the St. Louis Sun was ill-fated from the start,'' said Kenneth Berents, a stock analyst with Alex Brown & Co. in Baltimore. ``And it's interesting that had he not gone out on a limb for the Sun, he might not be having the problems he's having today. The Sun may have cost him his whole empire.'' Ingersoll said the junk bond troubles had nothing to do with his decision to make the trans-Atlantic swap, and he's not sure where the startup of the Sun fits into the picture. ``It didn't figure in it directly, but I suppose it may have had some type of metaphysical impact on what Warburg Pincus was thinking, but it's hard to say,'' Ingersoll said. It's difficult to say much about the internal finances of Ingersoll's companies because they are privately owned. Even bondholders have a hard time obtaining information about them. But it's clear that things haven't been easy for Ingersoll since the Sun stopped publishing April 25. ``I think the failure of the Sun affected him more than anyone thought. It disenchanted him with American newspapers,'' said Kevin Horrigan, the Sun's lead columnist, who was lured away from the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. ``Ralph felt he had something to contribute and was basically told, `No thanks.' '' So, Horrigan said, he's not surprised to see Ingersoll going to Europe. Actually, many acquaintances say they're not surprised to see Ingersoll going to Europe because he's more attuned to that culture. When newspaper analysts and other experts said that starting a new metropolitan newspaper couldn't de done, Ingersoll rattled off the names of several recent successful startups _ in Europe and elsewhere. At one point, while his Sun was struggling with sagging circulation and an identity problem in St. Louis, Ingersoll was in England having dinner with Prince Charles. Ingersoll hinted he hasn't given up on U.S. newspapers completely. The financial problems in the industry probably will create opportunities for newspaper entrepreneurs with a global view to pick up some bargains, he said. ``Maybe in a perfect world, one would operate on every continent,'' Ingersoll said. For now, Ingersoll's world is less than perfect.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Escort: Best Seller of the '80s Is Growing
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: America's favorite car of the 1980s isn't resting on its laurels. For the 1991 model year, the Ford Escort is growing, adding more hiproom and shoulder room in the rear, more glass area up front and a new engine. It's also becoming more aerodynamic and improving its fuel efficiency. Nearly a decade ago Americans came to know and love the mild-mannered Escort, the vehicle that Ford called its ``world car'' because it would be sold in many countries. As the 1980s unfolded, the Escort subcompact was repeatedly at the top of the pack of favorite U.S. nameplates. By the end of the decade, more than 3.46 million Escorts had been sold in this country, far outdistancing the No. 2 nameplate, the Honda Accord. But Ford Motor Co. knew the old Escort needed upgrading. Annual sales peaked at around 524,500 in 1985, and the No. 2 U.S. automaker wanted to attract buyers of import cars to the Escort. ``The car was very good, but it was almost a decade old,'' said Mike Sullivan, Ford Division marketing plans manager for the Escort. ``It was not quite as modern as the (Honda) Civic and (Toyota) Corolla. The new Escort is virtually all new, very modern. It's not second fiddle to any car.'' Indeed, the 1991 Ford Escort LX 4-door hatchback test car was admirable in furnishing a back seat that can really be used for more than stowing briefcases and shopping bags. Though three good-sized adults might find it confining, two adults would be in decent shape. Sullivan noted that Ford added 2.5 inches of hiproom and more than 1 inch of shoulder room to the 2-door Escort. I had a couple inches of clearance above my head to the roofline while sitting on the nicely cushioned, cloth back seat, and my legs were even extended a bit with the front seat back a bit. With the front seats back all the way, I tucked my feet under the front seats and my knees still weren't crushed into the back of the front seatbacks. In the 4-door test car, the rear seatback is divided and either side can fold down to allow room for long items in the hatchback. The Escort LX rode solidly for a little car. I didn't feel particularly vulnerable to road bumps. The powertrain has its own subframe to help reduce vibration and noise, and new independent front and rear strut suspension kept the ride from being punishing. I could hear some road noise and the 1.9-liter, sequential, electronic fuel-injected four-cylinder engine _ teamed with the optional four-speed automatic transmission _ jerked a bit a few times. I also noticed when the air conditioner running at full blast tapped into the engine's power. Still, the engine can deliver up to 88 horsepower while propelling an Escort that's heavier than its predecessor _ all without losing fuel economy. A smoother exterior design helps, too, bringing the Escort's drag coefficient _ which indicates the ease with which the car moves through the air _ down from 0.39 to 0.35. Of course, I wasn't expecting a race car from the Escort LX. Overall, there was just no getting around the fact that the Escort LX was simple, decent transportation packaged in a body that was plainly pleasing, inside and out. I admired the way the car squeezed into awkward parking spots, how easy it was to read the large analog gauges, how comfortable it was to get used to this vehicle. The average price of a 1991 Escort is up about 2.5 percent from its comparably equipped predecessor. But base prices ranging from $7,565 for a 2-door hatchback to $11,063 for an Escort GT sport model remain within reach of many potential buyers. Ford expects Escort purchasers to have a median age of 34, with median household income of $30,000 a year. About 45 percent will be men and at least a third of buyers will be college graduates, Sullivan said. He added that many features _ such as better computerized engine control and tinted glass _ are now part of the standard Escort vehicle. Comparisons with competitors, such as the Civic, which starts at more than $6,600 for a 2-door hatchback with manual transmission, and Corolla, which starts at more than $8,700, are, therefore, difficult, Sullivan said. Consumer Reports magazine ranked 1987 and 1988 Escorts worse than average in owner reports of trouble. But Ford said the 1991 Escort ``will usher in a new era at Ford in terms of quality, manufacturing and design.'' The company looks to sell 400,000 Escorts a year.

DOC.HEAD: Global Population Growth, Improved Economies Could Help U.S. Farmers
DOC.TEXT: World population growth and the potential upgrading of Third World economies are cited by some economists when they predict a rosy future for American farmers. More people, particularly more people with money, means greater demands on world food production, goes the argument. And the United States, as the premier granary, stands to gain with rising exports. It's an iffy forecast. Global politics and the possibility of massive crop failures inhibit long-range predictions. Population growth is a certainty, but don't bet the old home place just yet that Third World countries will hoist themselves out of economic swamps and suddenly buy everything U.S. farmers produce. Nearly one-fourth of the world's people live in absolute poverty, says Alan B. Durning of the Worldwatch Institute. And poverty is much more than an economic condition. ``Poverty's horror extends to all aspects of a person's life: susceptibility to disease, limited access to most types of services and information, lack of control over resources, subordination to higher social and economic classes, and utter insecurity in the face of changing circumstances,'' Durning said. Poverty's psychological toll is the erosion of human dignity and self respect, he said. The figures describing the extent of world poverty are mind-warping. Durning, writing in Worldwatch's annual State of the World report for 1990, estimated that nearly 1.23 billion people _ more than 23 percent of the global population _ lived in poverty in 1989. According to Worldwatch estimates, the global network of absolute poverty included: Asia, 675 million people, 25 percent of the region's population; sub-Saharan Africa, 325 million, 62 percent; Latin America, 150 million, 35 percent; North Africa and Middle East, 75 million, 28 percent. The Agriculture Department recently issued a report on world population, including revisions since 1950 and projections to the year 2050. Authors Francis Urban and Michael Trueblood of the department's Economic Research Service noted that the world population passed 5 billion in 1987 and as of the writing in 1990 stood at 5.3 billion. It is likely to pass the 10 billion mark in 2041. But the report said there now appears to be a ``slowing down of the world population growth, even though the number of people added annually seems large.'' Global population growth peaked in the mid-1960s at an all-time high of 2.2 percent a year before declining gradually to the current rate of 1.7 percent. ``By the year 2050, the annual rate of population growth is estimated to drop to about 0.6 percent, indicating that the world population may stabilize at about 10.5 billion people toward the year 2100,'' the report said. However, while the growth rate has been declining in most countries and regions, ``it is just reaching its estimated peak in Africa and the Middle East of 3.2 percent and 3.4 percent, respectively,'' the report said. By the year 2050, the rate of population growth in these two regions probably will still be twice as high as the other regions of the world. Agricultural economists are more comfortable projecting a year or two ahead. But when hard-put they sometimes take a longer view. Right now, the year 2000 is a favorite target for speculation. Dennis Avery and Glenn H. Sullivan, of the Hudson Institute Center for Global Food Issues in Indianapolis, say world food demand will rise in the 1990s as higher incomes enable many countries to upgrade diets. But Avery and Sullivan said in a recent report that American farmers may be left out of this growing overseas market unless there is reform of international trading rules and U.S. farm policies. Negotiations aimed at reforming world trade are being conducted under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and Congress is trying to hammer out a new farm bill affecting domestic programs. At last week's economic summit in Houston, leaders of the seven richest nations issued a final communique that finessed the thorny issue of eliminating agricultural subsidies, as President Bush wants. The communique urges all nations to make ``substantial, progressive reductions'' in subsidies with an eventual goal of eliminating them. The Avery-Sullivan report said an 18 percent increase in world food production will be required in the 1990s to take care of the expected population growth. ``In addition, hundreds of millions of people in the world are getting higher incomes and want to upgrade their diets,'' the report said. ``There are probably more than 200 million `middle-class' food customers in India alone today, and India's economic growth has recently been about three times as rapid (5 percent to 6 percent) as her projected population growth (1.8 percent).'' Overall, the report said, low- and middle-income countries have been expanding their economies by 4 percent a year, more than double the rate of global population growth. ``We expect economic growth in the 1990s to be still more rapid than in the debt- and inflation-ridden 1980s,'' the report said. ``The GATT continues to offer developing countries good opportunities for export-led growth.'' Some examples of export-led growth are Algeria, Thailand and Mexico, which the report said are now trying to emulate the export success of such countries as Taiwan and South Korea. ``More and more of the world is rejecting the overdependence on governments which slowed economic growth in recent decades,'' the report said. ``It is happening now in the East Bloc and Nicaragua, but it has been evident in China for a decade, in much of Latin America the past several years, and even in large parts of Africa.''
