DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, July 15
DOC.HEAD: From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 17th graf pvs, ``We have ... environmental issues., to UPDATE with Energy Department acknowledging the Hanford plant in Washington leaked dangerous levels of radiation.
(APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The dangerous legacy of 45 years of building atomic bombs is contaminated nuclear graveyards that will cost billions of dollars to clean up, if indeed scientists can figure out a way to clean them up. One researcher even says that trying to get rid of the radioactive wastes would cost more lives than leaving them alone.

Miles of 8-foot-high electric fences stretch through Bethel Valley, the once-secret cradle of the atomic age. They stand watch over burial grounds of deadly wastes that are the legacy of four decades of nuclear bomb production. Yellow and magenta signs proclaim, ``Radiation Hazard, Keep Out.'' The fences encircling some of the hundreds of acres of contaminated land on the federal Oak Ridge nuclear weapons compound are reminders that while the Cold War may be over, it took a serious toll. It cost about $250 billion for the roughly 65,000 nuclear weapons that the United States has manufactured since 1945, when the first was assembled. That bill is paid. Yet to be settled is the toll this secretive manufacturing process has taken on weapons workers and the environment. At Oak Ridge alone, the Energy Department has spent $1 billion since 1983 trying to control the environmental damage. It is expected to take at least 10 more years just to determine what poisons have seeped into the soil and ground water here, and 20 more years to stop it from spreading. The total bill for cleaning up Oak Ridge may top $12 billion. Costs at some of the 16 other active nuclear arms laboratories, manufacturing plants and proving grounds in 11 other states will be much higher. The full cost of environmental repairs alone may top $100 billion. Estimates vary greatly because the government itself doesn't know how badly some sites are contaminated. Nor has all the necessary technology been developed. The Energy Department, which makes and tests all nuclear weapons for the Pentagon, said in a report on July 3 that the magnitude of the cleanup is expanding so rapidly that it cannot keep up. Its cost estimate for the next five years is $31.4 billion _ nearly 50 percent more than it expected just one year ago. And this is in the early days. The full cleanup effort will take at least 30 years. ``These amounts challenge and almost certainly exceed'' the cleanup resources available to the government and its hundreds of private contractors, the report said. In the meantime, Tennessee health authorities ban fishing and swimming in East Fork Poplar Creek, which winds through the 56,000-acre weapons plant as well as the adjacent city of Oak Ridge, and in a portion of the Clinch River, which borders the plant on three sides. The stream is poisoned by mercury, once used to separate lithium for nuclear weapons. Oak Ridge, originally called the Clinton Engineer Works, was the site of the first nuclear bomb production plants, code-named Y-12, X-10 and K-25. Today it remains a key link in the production chain, although some of its operations have been closed permanently. Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc., which runs Oak Ridge under a government contract, says 75 tons of toxic mercury and substantial amounts of the radioactive element cesium-137 have spread from the weapons plant and contaminated the sediment in Watts Bar Reservoir, which remains open to the public for swimming and boating. ``Not only did the atomic age start here, the problems did, too,'' says Bill Adams, the Energy Department's chief of waste and environmental management at Oak Ridge. Unfortunately, the problems don't end here. The radioactive and toxic contamination is so bad at several nuclear weapons plants _ in Colorado, Ohio, Tennessee, South Carolina, California, Missouri and Washington state _ that portions of these huge sites will become ``national sacrifice zones,'' scientists say, land deemed permanently unfit for human use. ``We have one hell of a legacy to clean up,'' says Leo Duffy, the top adviser to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins on long-term environmental issues. The legacy is not just environmental insults. It's damage to human health, damage long suspected by workers and plant neighbors but routinely denied by the government until Watkins two years ago began tearing down the walls of secrecy. On July 11, more than 40 years after the fact, the Energy Department acknowledged the Hanford plutonium production plant in south-central Washington state leaked radiation at levels that endangered the health of nearby residents. It was the government's first admission that the Hanford leaks were at levels sufficient to cause cancer and other illnesses in people living near the facility. The Energy Department is committed to cleaning up the environmental damage, even if it has made few promises about addressing the problem of health risks. The question is how to get the money needed to restore the soil and water. Congress and the Bush administration are under pressure to cut the budget deficit even as defense spending slows in response to moves toward democracy in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. In the emerging national debate over the size of a ``peace dividend'' from expected military savings _ and how to spend it _ little has been said about the ``mortgage'' the atomic bomb builders took out to compete in the arms race. During the World War II development of the first atomic bombs in the Army's secret Manhattan Project, any thoughts of environmental or excessive health risks were subsumed by a feeling that the very survival of democracy depended on getting the bomb as quickly as possible. Later, through the Cold War period, military authorities used the shield of strict secrecy _ justified on national security grounds _ to continue borrowing against the environment and workers' health to speed up bomb production, according to interviews with current and former arms plant workers, government officials, scientists and congressional investigators. Now payment is coming due. Officials who have surveyed the dozens of existing and former nuclear weapons sites around the country say hundreds of billions of dollars are needed not only to control environmental damage, but also to reduce the health risks of nuclear plant workers and to make safety improvements long put off. Until the mid-1980s the government would not acknowledge these failures. ``Nobody wants to look under the rug, and a lot has been swept under the rug in the nuclear weapons industry,'' says Elizabeth Paul of the Snake River Alliance, based in Ketchum, Idaho. The citizens group opposes the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, which recovers highly enriched uranium from naval reactors. Even an investment of $100 billion in environmental corrections won't completely reverse the damage. The chief problems are contamination of the soil and ground water _ on the federal sites and in surrounding areas _ with radioactive materials such as plutonium, tritium and strontium-90 and such toxics as mercury, arsenic and a variety of solvents.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, July 15
DOC.HEAD: OAK RIDGE, Tenn.: of solvents.
DOC.TEXT: Plutonium is so potent that lethal lung doses are measured in the billionths of a gram. The ``burial grounds'' and some other parts of Oak Ridge, as well as large sections of the Hanford weapons plant near Richland, Wash., the Savannah River plant near Aiken, S.C., and portions of other sites from coast to coast won't be fit for human use for hundreds, perhaps thousands, of years. ``There'll be hot spots that will never have any other use except for disposal of hazardous and radioactive waste,'' says Vic Rezendes, director of energy issues at the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress. The cost to human health is harder to assess. The government has never acknowledged any human health damage caused by emissions from its plants or by radiation releases from atomic bomb tests in the desert Southwest. But increasing numbers of Americans are going to court seeking compensation on grounds that chronic exposure to radiation caused illness and death, even at levels the government considers safe. Bruce H. DeBoskey, a Denver lawyer for some workers at the Rocky Flats plutonium processing plant, says relatives of workers who died of cancer feel cheated by the federal government. ``The widows of these workers who gave their lives to build these bombs are deeply embittered,'' DeBoskey says. ``There's a human tragedy here.'' Also at risk were thousands of uranium miners who dug out the bomb material in unventilated shafts in New Mexico, Arizona, Utah and Colorado from the late 1940s to the mid-1960s, when mining stopped because the government had stockpiled all it needed. Of the estimated 15,000 men who worked the mines, about 450 have died of lung cancer _ five times the number expected in a similar size group of American men, according to the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health. Congress is now trying to make some amends. In June the House passed a bill to establish a $100 million trust to compensate families of miners with radiation-induced illness, as well as certain cancer victims in Nevada, Utah and Arizona who were exposed to fallout from above-ground nuclear testing from 1951 to 1962. The Senate is expected to approve the bill. President Bush opposes it. Scientists have not yet determined conclusively whether accidental releases of radioactivity from nuclear weapons plants are a health threat. Nor are they yet sure of the risk posed by chronic exposure of workers to low levels of radiation. Until the mid-1980s these issues were secondary. Production was king, secrecy its serf. ``Things having to do with atomic weapons are born secret,'' says J. Carson Mark, who spent 27 years designing nuclear weapons at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico and is now retired. Clyde Hopkins remembers the mind-set in the early 1950s when he was a production control worker at the Oak Ridge Y-12 plant, which used tons of mercury to separate lithium for use as a fuel source in thermonuclear warheads. ``The pressure was intense to come up with weapons components on a short-term basis,'' he says. ``People back in those days didn't even think about the environment. They thought about getting the doggone work out to support the country's nuclear stockpile. ``I can remember days when people were walking around with lots of mercury on the floor. You kept operating because you wanted that product to come out. So the emphasis then was on production. The thought that we had mercury leaking on the floor, obviously working its way down through the concrete into the ground, it wasn't thought about back then.'' Hopkins thinks about it a lot now. He is president of Martin Marietta Energy Systems, which is locked in negotiations with the Energy Department over its financial and legal liability for failing to meet state and federal environmental laws. Oak Ridge was not alone in its approach to meeting bomb production schedules. Cleve Anderson recalls fighting against a ``production-first'' mentality while he headed a committee studying long-range waste management at Hanford in the late 1950s. Hanford was the main producer of plutonium _ the most lethal element known _ for use in nuclear bombs, although today its nine reactors are shut down. ``At Hanford we had been indoctrinated thoroughly that the nation's survival depended on what we were doing, that nothing was more important to national security than getting ever more plutonium. Anything else that might interfere was secondary,'' he said. In a classified report written in December 1958 for General Electric Co., which was running Hanford under a government contract, Anderson urged that more money be spent to develop safer disposal methods for radioactive wastes. He wrote: ``The probability of the superiority of alternate methods of waste disposal has long been recognized but the pressing problems of (weapons production) precluded any but the most cursory examinations of these alternatives.'' He said his report was shelved. Years later, he had to file a request under the Freedom of Information Act to obtain a copy. Today Hanford is considered the most extensively contaminated piece of land in the United States, perhaps in the world. The government's own advisers were sounding the alarm on nuclear waste as early as 1955. In that year the National Academy of Sciences formed a committee to advise the Atomic Energy Commission on waste disposal. The committee concluded in late 1955 that dumping radioactive wastes directly into the ground ``probably involves unacceptable long-term risks'' to the environment. Yet such practices continued for more three decades. Hopkins, the Martin Marietta manager at Oak Ridge, says, ``I'd be surprised'' if officials there were told prior to the 1980s that dumping wastes directly into the ground carried the risk of serious environmental damage. ``If they had, I don't think we'd have done it,'' he said. Regardless of the reasons, the hazards posed by huge accumulations of nuclear wastes now represents a technological challenge for America unlike any it has faced since the dawn of the atomic age. ``We've scratched the surface,'' says Duffy, the Energy Department waste czar. ``We know the problems, we don't know the solutions.'' One of the least understood problems is how much of the nuclear graveyards can be excavated or treated without putting workers at unacceptable risk. Frank L. Parker, who headed Oak Ridge National Laboratory's radioactive waste management research in the late 1950s and early 1960s and now teaches environmental engineering at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tenn., says the country will have to accept that some nuclear wastes are too dangerous to remove. ``The number of deaths you're going to incur to clean it up will dwarf the number who would be killed if you left it alone,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: Slim Political Pickings in New England
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It's a lean political year for New England governors, grappling with an economic slump, deficits and rebellious taxpayers _ woes that could worsen, according to a Vermont Republican who wants to reclaim the State House and try to manage them. ``I think I can create a sense of orderliness in hard times,'' said Richard A. Snelling, a four-term governor running for a reprise. While incumbent governors are facing the backlash of those hard times, Snelling is campaigning with the status and the name recognition of incumbency, but without the downside of blame for the slackening economy. That confronts Democrat Peter Welch with difficult odds, and he knows it. ``This is not going to be an uphill campaign,'' he said in launching his bid, ``it is an up-mountain campaign.'' Welch, 43, a lawyer and former president of the state Senate, got into the race after Democratic Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin got out in April. She had succeeded Snelling when he retired in 1984. Now Snelling is running against her record, after an administration that had to increase taxes, cut and scrape programs to produce the balanced budget that Gov. Kunin delivered this month. ``It creates an easy cruising agenda for the Republican,'' Welch said the other day at his cramped, cluttered campaign headquarters across the railroad tracks from the Lake Champlain docks. But Welch said he has the campaign time and the issues to overcome the Snelling advantage. He said he's talking with voters about tax fairness for the middle class, health care, housing, education. Snelling counters the new governor won't have much money to spend. ``It's going to be tough next year,'' he said. ``The next governor isn't going to get to solve problems with money.'' He advocates budgeting based on economic cycles, up or down. Snelling said governments should spend what is necessary, not what's available, cutting taxes when economic boom times swell revenues, accepting deficits when the economy slumps. ``He's the Babe Ruth of Vermont deficits,'' Welch said. ``He holds all the records.'' Snelling is a businessman. He's been managing investments, most of them his own, since he left the governor's office, with time out to lose, badly, in a 1986 Senate challenge. At his upstairs offices at a South Burlington shopping mall, he is addressed as governor. The photographs on the wall show him in that role with presidents and party leaders. Not long ago, one of his campaign aides called the State House to ask for some budget information for the governor, and was archly reminded that the governor's name is Kunin. In retirement, he was an ocean sailor. Now he is selling his 46-foot sailboat, saying he knows there will not be time to use it in the job he expects to win back. ``There's a great deal of difference between fun and satisfaction,'' Snelling said. So when supporters began saying he should come out of retirement at 63, he listened. ``If a lot of people say we need you, that's very powerful stuff,'' Snelling said. He'd expected to run against Gov. Kunin, but she became the third New England Democrat to decide against seeking re-election as governor this year. Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut opted out earlier in the spring. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts did so more than a year ago. The slump and its budget impact were factors in all three states. The region's other three governors are Republicans, all seeking re-election, all handicapped by financial problems. In New Hampshire, Gov. Judd Gregg has just told his administrators there will have to be more spending and personnel cuts to check a swelling deficit, blaming saying he can't forecast when the slump will end. Three Democrats seek the nomination to challenge Gregg. Tax and budget troubles also are plaguing Gov. Edward DiPrete of Rhode Island, a conservative who had to reverse his pledge against tax increases this spring, and he's facing a struggle to hold on for a fourth term. Snelling acknowledges he might have political problems of his own if he'd been in office when the economy faltered _ but he also said he managed the state government through two recessions without losing his support. ``I don't think the voters are just guaranteed to turn on you in hard times,'' he said. He said a politician who takes credit for an economic boom is going to suffer politically for a slowdown. ``If you tout the Massachusetts miracle and it ends, then you will be forced to take the blame,'' he said. That's what happened to Democrat Dukakis. A broader slump could confront President Bush with similar problems in 1992, after nearly a decade of campaign claims that Republicans policies are the path to uninterrupted economic growth. ``The slowdown in New England is contagious,'' warned New Hampshire's Gov. Gregg. ``I don't see how the rest of the nation can not be drawn in.''

DOC.HEAD: Fancy Foods Generally Not Lean Foods, But Some Change Is Afoot
DOC.TEXT: Low-fat cheeses, all-fruit jams and low-calorie crackers are making inroads in the fancy foods industry, and health-conscious eaters can find satisfaction in the gourmet section if they look carefully. ``All-natural'' was a common rallying cry as purveyers showed off 20,000 foods at the 36th Annual International Fancy Food and Confection Show last week. But even if all-natural, which generally has no legal meaning, most of the samples spread out for potential customers were more likely to be buttery or chocolatey than slimming. ``People are trying to eat healthy most of the time,'' said Ronald Tanner, spokesman for the National Association for the Specialty Food Trade Inc. ``And then when they're splurging, they're really splurging.'' Most of the time, people who buy fancier foods try to satisfy their urges with foods that carry rich flavors but at little cost to the waistline. ``Flavor is the real big selling point. People want to eat healthy, but they don't want to just eat lettuce,'' Tanner said. For the first time, this year's trade show included a seminar on healthy foods. So, there are mustards _ green chili mustard, sage mustard, wine and champagne mustards, sweet mustards. And wild rice. Organic baked beans. Oats added to pancake mixes. Organically grown teas. Goat's milk yogurt. Organic maple syrup. Eleven-calorie cookies. But just as in the supermarket, consumers should read labels at gourmet shops. Organic doesn't mean low-calorie, and cholesterol-free doesn't mean no fat. A sugar-free product may have as many calories as one with sugar. Le Slim Cow, a butter substitute made with buttermilk, was promoted as having half the fat of butter or margarine. And just 57 calories, compared with 103 calories per serving of butter. However, its makers, St. Hubert of Rolling Hills Estates, Calif., warn that the high moisture content of Le Slim Cow makes it unsuitable for frying. Elan Foods Inc. has introduced a chocolate-covered frozen yogurt bar that's available east of the Mississippi and should be available nationwide in a year or so, said Joanne Biltekoff, who runs the company with her husband. While a bar has 230 calories and 13 grams of fat, a premium ice cream bar has 350 calories and 22 fat grams. Salsas and chile sauces were plentiful at the show _ San Angel, La Preferida, Montezuma, Corn Mother red and green salsas, one made with eggplant, one with dried tomatoes, one from Canada. Generally, these have little fat, though eating them with tortilla chips cancels any advantage. Try them with bread or vegetables instead. The Baker brand of breads includes varieties made from stone-ground grains, but the company's booth also included rich brownies. And a Vermont company called Food 2000 offered vegetarian chili. There were organic vegetable pates from Threefold International Co. Ltd. in carrot, chestnut, mushroom and other flavors. But temptation lurked everywhere. Across the aisle from Golightly sugar-free candies was a big pan of tiramisu, the Italian dessert made with high-fat cheese. Walk down another aisle and go from butter cookies to spicy meat to potato pancakes. Pates seemed to be everywhere. And chocolate. Chocolate shaped like hair dryers, chocolate with every kind of nut imaginable, chocolate sauce, chocolate cookies, even chocolate-covered caramel corn.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Propose Crackdown on Cactus Raiders
DOC.TEXT: A federal plan to save a rare cactus that grows in Utah and Colorado includes a crackdown on professional and amateur growers who have been digging up the plants for private collections. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's draft recovery plan for the Uinta Basin hookless cactus, or Sclerocactus glaucus, notes the plant is prized by growers for its purplish-red flowers. The Colorado population has lost an estimated 200 to 300 plants to collectors since 1977, but there are no estimates for losses in Utah, the document said. Its total population is estimated at 20,000 plants. The plan calls for increased monitoring by the Fish and Wildlife Service, the Bureau of Land Management and local law enforcement officers. It also encourages the service to work with cactus horticulturists to try to provide a source of the plants to satisfy the horticultural demand. The cactus was designated a threatened species in 1979 and is protected under the federal Endangered Species Act. Other threats to the cactus include oil shale development, gold mining, oil and gas development, sand and gravel quarrying, building stone collection, off-road vehicles and water development. The recovery plan contains provisions to reduce the threat from those sources.
DOC.HEAD: Researcher Trying To Get Crustacean To Keep Soft Shell Longer
DOC.TEXT: A university researcher is trying to get softshell crayfish to keep that shell longer. ``People like to eat these creatures when they're soft because they can eat the whole animal, not just the tail and claws, and they don't have to work to take out the meat,'' said Michele Wheatly, a University of Florida zoologist. Most restaurants don't offer them regularly because they can't be assured of a steady supply. As crayfish and other crustaceans grow, they shed their hard shells to reveal a new soft one underneath. It takes a day or two for the soft shell to harden. Wheatly is studying whether this molting process can be manipulated to last longer, so that more softshell crustaceans can be caught. Learning how these creatures absorb calcium to harden their shells is a key, she said. In studies on crayfish in Florida, Wheatly found that calcium must be absorbed within a certain time after molting begins, usually three to four days, or a hard skeleton cannot form. ``We're trying to figure out what the mechanism is for getting the calcium into the skeleton and why it's so important that this happens right away,'' she said. ``If we can stop calcification from starting, we may be able to prolong the softshell state.'' That would allow the commercial fishing industry to serve a growing restaurant market and could encourage the development of new crustacean fisheries, Wheatly said. Wheatly, who received a $250,000 grant from the National Science Foundation, said the research may have application for people. ``By studying the mechanism that moves calcium in and out of the skeletons of crustaceans, we may be able to learn something about what happens in human bone,'' she said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, July 16

DOC.TEXT: The United States found last-minute common ground with its summit partners on a contentious farm subsidies dispute, hoping to give a push to long-running efforts to overhaul the world trading system. The compromise reached Wednesday allowed President Bush to claim success on his top summit priority: progress toward eliminating the subsidies he says skew world trade and cost taxpayers and consumers billions of dollars in government spending and higher food prices.

The United States and its partners at the economic summit sidestepped differences on global warming, but issued an environmental declaration that emphasized forestry protection. The seven leaders pledged Wednesday to negotiate an international agreement to curb deforestation as expeditiously as possible.

The government is recovering misspent funds from the officers and directors of failed savings institutions and banks at a rate better than $1 million a day, a top regulator said. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said Wednesday his agency was investigating whether to sue the officers of 1,300 failed thrifts and banks and has already filed lawsuits against officials of 500 institutions.

A former president of Sunbelt Savings Association was charged with bank fraud in a $700 million real estate deal. Edwin T. McBirney III also was charged Wednesday with misapplication of funds, false entries and making false statements. He resigned as chairman of Sunbelt Savings in 1986 under pressure from government regulators. The indictment came two years after a $2.5 billion government bailout of the thrift that a federal prosecutor said was the costliest S&L rescue so far.

Thirty-five million workers who drive on the job will have to wear seat belts under a new federal regulation that means even business people riding in taxis will have to buckle up. The rule announced Wednesday by Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole will take effect after a 120-day comment period and possibly a hearing. Employers who fail to make their workers use seat belts could face fines of up to $10,000.

Harvard University plans to purchase about $5 million in Ecuadoran debt at a steep discount to fund a scholarship program also aimed at easing the country's financial burdens, officials said. The elaborate ``debt-for-scholarship swap'' announced Wednesday essentially converts a portion of Ecuador's $11 billion foreign debt into cash to be used for financing education for Ecuadorans. In turn, the South American country's debt burden is reduced and its U.S. creditors get rid of bonds they fear never will be repaid.

Congress should overhaul regulation of the securities and banking industries, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission said while stopping short of recommending the best way to do it. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden also outlined several suggestions Wednesday for reversing U.S. financial firms' declining market share over the last decade, but cautioned against piecemeal change ``for the mere sake of change.''

The government likely will default on its debt for the first time next month unless Congress raises the limit before leaving Aug. 6 on its month-long recess, the Treasury Department warned. ``Treasury's current estimates show that the permanent ceiling of $3.12 trillion will be sufficient only until mid-August,'' Treasury Undersecretary Robert R. Glauber told the House Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday.

American Airlines Inc. is adding $1 to $4 to the cost of a ticket at five airports to help pay for what it calls ``exorbitant and intolerable'' fees at airports. Other airlines said Wednesday they would not follow the lead of the nation's largest carrier, and analysts don't expect the surcharges to establish a norm within the industry.

The stock market rallied with renewed force Wednesday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 41.83 points to 2,932.67, its highest close since it stood at a record 2,935.89 on June 15. Bond prices broke a four-day losing streak, posting tiny gains. The dollar rebounded modestly on foreign exchange markets. Copper futures prices leaped to their highest levels in two months; precious metals were mixed; grains and soybeans retreated; energy futures advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Plans To Launch Direct-Response TV Network
DOC.NOTE: Eds: W25AI in 15th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of Working Woman, Sassy and other magazines plans to launch a new television network this fall that will feature classic TV show reruns along with direct-response advertising programs. Dale Lang, chairman of the newly created Star Television Network Inc., said 23 independent UHF stations reaching more than 13.7 million of the nation's 92 million TV households have agreed to carry the service starting in September. Stations that sign affiliation agreements will be given eight hours of television programs a day, consisting of series such as ``Life of Riley,'' ``The Invaders'' and ``Richard Diamond,'' movies and game shows, Lang said. The programming concept will be marketed as ``TV Heaven'' and affiliate stations will be encouraged to use that term in their own promotions. In exchange for the programs, the stations must run at least four hours a day of direct-response programs, also called ``infomercials.'' These are program-length commercials in which a marketer typically demonstrates a product and invites viewers to call in to order. Lang said Star Television and the producers of the infomercials would share revenue from sales of the products or services with affiliate stations. In addition, stations would be given the option of using shorter direct-response advertising ranging from 30 seconds to two minutes to fill any gaps they may have in their commercial schedules. Informercials were once a staple of some cable networks, but have fallen into disfavor as those networks have grown and found more traditional revenue sources. Media critics have long faulted television stations for carrying such programming because viewers may not always recognize it as paid programming created expressly to sell a particular product or service. But Lang said this type of programming can help stations cut their operating losses and make it economically feasible for holders of FCC construction permits to proceed with new UHF stations. He said Star eventually will produce original programming for its network, and anticipates generating product sales of more than $100 million in its second year in operation. A spokeswoman for Lang could not say how much was being invested in the new network. The network will be transmitted to member stations via satellite from the MCA-Universal Studios in Orlando, Fla., Lang said. Lang also heads Lang Communications, a New York-based media company that publishes Working Woman, Working Mother, Sassy and Success magazines. It plans to resume publishing Ms. magazine later this month as an advertising-free publication. Ms. suspended publication last December shortly after Lang's company acquired it because of mounting losses. Lang said the stations that have signed up and their markets are: WOCD, Albany, N.Y.; KHFT, Albuquerque, N.M.; KDMD, Anchorage, Alaska; WNHT and WPHX, both in Boston; W25AI, Cincinnati; KJLF, El Paso, Texas; KKAK, Fresno, Calif.; and KBLR, Las Vegas. Also, KXLI, Minneapolis; WAYQ and WAYK, Orlando, Fla.; WWLA, Portland, Me.; KCFV, Portland, Ore.; WYED, Raleigh, N.C.; KXLT, Rochester, Minn.; KOOG and KZAR, both in Salt Lake City, and KLXV, San Francisco. Also, WBSV, Sarasota, Fla.; KBGE, Seattle; KSKN, Spokane, Wash.; and WTTA, Tampa, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Required To Write-Down Brazil, Argentine Loans
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators have ordered the nation's largest banks to write off as a loss large portions of about $14 billion in outstanding loans to economically troubled Brazil and Argentina. The order requires 36 affected banks to write off 20 percent of about $11 billion in loans to Brazil and to increase write-offs of $2.9 billion in loans to Argentina to 60 percent from 40 percent. The write-off of Brazilian loans is the first required by federal authorities and comes as the South American nation undertakes economic reform and is seeking new loans to bolster industry. Brazil and Argentina are far in arrears on debt repayments. Neither country has negotiated debt forgiveness with the United States, a step taken by Mexico last year and Venezuela earlier this year. Bank officials speaking on condition of anonymity Wednesday confirmed the receipt of letters ordering the write-downs in recent days from the Interagency Country Exposure Review Committee. The panel consists of representatives of the Federal Reserve Board, the Office of the Controller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. It normally does not announce its decisions. The action could force some of the banks to further boost reserves to protect against losses from nonperforming loans to developing nations, money that would be subtracted from profits. It a bank has enough money set aside in reserves to cover bad loans, then the new write-downs should not affect earnings. The 20 percent write-off of Argentine debt was the third ordered by federal authorities. Brazil's was considered surprising because the country has undertaken economic reform under new president Fernando Collor de Mello and is expected to resume negotiations this year on meeting some bank debt obligations. Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, declined to comment on the regulatory action. But it said the bank already had written down 60 percent of its Argentine exposure from a $1 billion reserve created last year. ``Any other such writedowns, voluntary or mandated, would likewise be charged to the reserve without earnings impact,'' the statement said. ``That's the reason for taking such provisions and reserves,'' Citicorp said. ``The earnings impact occurs when they are taken, not when a writedown subsequently occurs.'' Citicorp would be forced to write off $660 million of its $3.3 billion exposure to Brazilian loans under the new mandate, officials said. It would not have to take further write-downs against its current $400 million exposure to Argentine loans. Brazil has not paid interest on its long-term debt for more than a year and has a total foreign debt of about $113 billion. Argentina, which has debt of about $62 billion, last month began paying $40 million a month in interest, still far short of its interest obligations. The federal committee can order banks to write off loans if a country fall six months behind in payments unless it is attempting to make progress on paying its debt. Both Argentina and Brazil have implemented some economic reforms, but apparently not enough to persuade regulators not to take action.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Failed Hooker Corp. Declares Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: The former head of the collapsed retailing concern Hooker Corp. and his wife have declared bankruptcy, claiming debts of nearly $400 million. George and Sheila Herscu lodged debtors petitions in Federal Court at Melbourne on Monday, which the court accepted. Herscu was not in court Wednesday for a hearing involving FAI Insurance, which has been suing the couple for bankruptcy. The hearing was adjourned after the bankruptcy declaration was announced. Herscu is believed to be in New York for the birth of his daughter's child. The Hooker Corp. was placed in receivership a year ago with debts of about $1.6 billion. Sydney-based Hooker is being managed by a court-appointed provisional liquidator in a process similar to what its American subsidiary is experiencing in the U.S. bankruptcy court. The U.S. subsidiary, L.J. Hooker Corp., has disposed of the bulk of ts retail holdings acquired since 1986, including Bonwit Teller and other department store chains. According to documents filed with the Federal Court, Herscu claims assets of $150,000, including a Rolls Royce, a Cadillac, a 35 percent interest in a racehorse, paintings, jewelery, and furniture and effects at his mansion in suburban Melbourne. The house, modeled after Tara from the film ``Gone with the Wind,'' was the subject of an auction last month. Mrs. Herscu claims assets of $19,600, including a Daimler car, paintings and jewelry.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Chief to Congress: Banking, Securities Regulation Must Change
DOC.TEXT: Congress needs to overhaul regulation of the securities and banking industries, according to the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, but he isn't ready to recommend the best way to do it. In testimony before a House panel Wednesday, SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden also outlined several suggestions for reversing U.S. financial firms' declining market share over the last decade. But he cautioned against piecemeal change ``for the mere sake of change.'' ``The level of unnecessary costs created by the U.S. regulatory system could become a significant factor in the international competitiveness of U.S. firms,'' Breeden told a subcommittee considering proposals to update a nearly 60-year-old banking law. He noted that in 1970 seven of the world's 25 largest banks were based in the United States, while today just one is U.S.-based with most of the others are headquartered in Japan. Breeden was among several witnesses testifying before the finance subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Critics of existing regulation have called for repealing the Glass-Steagall Act, the Depression-era law that keeps most banks out of the securities business and vice versa. Such regulations, critics maintain, make the United States less able to compete for investment in the ever-shrinking global marketplace. But Breeden warned that deregulation must be a two-way street. He said if Congress repeals Glass-Steagall it simultaneously should amend the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 to permit bank ownership by non-banking companies. ``Banks should not be free to acquire securities firms, while many securities and other major U.S. firms remain, as a practical matter, unable to acquire banks,'' he said. Similar views were expressed by other witnesses, including Samuel J. Baptista, president of the Financial Services Council, a Washington-based trade group of 25 banks, securities firms and other financial service companies. ``The issue at hand is not deregulation, not re-regulation and not broader powers for banks,'' he said. ``The issue before Congress is comprehensive restructuring of our financial services industry that will benefit both financial services providers and consumers.'' Among his recommendations were opening all financial businesses to all companies _ financial and commercial _ that meet safety and soundness tests. Baptista also called for functional regulation, whereby the banking operations of a financial firm would be regulated by banking regulators and the securities part by securities regulators. Richard Stuart, former head of the Bank Capital Markets Association, a trade association of 100 banks, and David Silver, president of the Investment Company Institute, a trade group representing mutual funds, also supported functional regulation. ``Banks, securities firms and others should be allowed to offer all financial services,'' Silver said. In addition to repealing the 1933 Glass-Steagall Act, Silver called for amending the Bank Holding Company Act ``so that it no longer confines the banking business to a restricted group of players.'' In his testimony, Breeden critiqued ways of regulating financial firms after the barriers come down. One version, universal banking _ which allows banks to engage directly in a broad range of financial activities _ was ``fatally flawed,'' he said. Universal banking, which is used in West Germany and elsewhere in Europe, would expand federal deposit insurance guarantees to bank ventures in the securities and insurance industries. That would increase taxpayer risk in the event of a bank's losses, he said. Also no single federal regulator has the capability or expertise to examine all the different types of financial products that could be offered under universal banking, Breeden said.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Hear CFTC Blasted _ Again
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's move to transfer authority for stock-index futures from one regulatory agency to another now faces testimony from supporters of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The administration is pushing legislation that would strip the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of regulatory authority over stock-index futures and hand it to the rival SEC. The Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee is to conclude two days of hearings today with backers of the SEC. On Wednesday, Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Miss., suggested a compromise that would allow the CFTC to retain most regulation but allow the Federal Reserve Board to set margin levels for trading stock-index futures. Margins are the downpayments or collateral paid by investors who buy securities or futures contracts on credit. Bond said the administration does not have enough Senate votes to pass its measure. Stock-index futures, often used in program trading strategies by large institutional investors such as pension funds, allow investors to trade on the movement of a basket of stocks without having to buy the underlying stocks. The CFTC and the futures industry oppose any shift, saying it will cripple the agency's ability to regulate other futures products and overregulate a segment of an industry that's battling to stave off foreign competition. But the SEC and the Treasury Department argue the move is necessary to curb volatility in the stock markets arising out of price differences between the futures and securities markets. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady is scheduled to appear before the committee later today and witnesses representing the futures industry were slated to testify later this month. The administration bill also seeks to give the SEC authority to set margins for stock-index futures. Currently, futures margins are set by the exchanges, usually only a fraction of the amount required in securities transactions. On Wednesday, a former top official of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange blasted the CFTC as a ``pygmy of federal regulation.'' It was the second time Thomas F. Eagleton, who resigned from the Merc last year, had harsh words for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Last year his criticism came in a hearing before the Senate Agriculture Committee, which oversees the CFTC. In his testimony, Eagleton, a former Democratic senator from Missouri, criticized the CFTC's light regulatory touch and its limited resources to investigate illegal activities. ``The CFTC is about as sluggish a regulatory agency as one can find,'' he told the committee members. Recalling last year's FBI undercover investigation of fraud in the Chicago futures pits that led to more than 40 indictments, Eagleton said: ``After the sting, the CFTC, this pygmy of federal regulation, overwhelmed by its day-to-day operations, came plodding along with too-little, too-late to catch fast-moving crooks and fast-changing events.'' Also testifying before the Banking Committee in favor of the jurisdictional switch were representatives of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the American Stock Exchange and the Options Clearing Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.NOTE: EDS: will be updated with close.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar firmed against key currencies in European trading this morning. Gold was lower. Traders said the dollar was bouyed by a round of short-covering as the economic summit in Houston brought no signs of an imminent reduction in U.S. interest rates. Said one trader: ``The market isn't totally convinced about the dollar, but given the fact it doesn't move lower, we're seeing a prudent recovery. A lot of people had gone short before the summit, and now they're covering up.'' The dollar closed at 148.90 in Tokyo, up 0.80 yen from Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 149.30 yen. The British pound was quoted at $1.7810 in London, down from $1.7980 late Wednesday. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.6577 West German marks, up from 1.6507; 1.4080 Swiss francs, up from 1.4030; 5.5620 French francs, up from 5.5285; 1,214.00 Italian lire, up from 1,207.04, and 1.1615 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1586. The morning quotation for the Dutch guilder was unavailable. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $353.20 per ounce this morning, down from $354.45 an ounce late Wednesday. Gold was quoted in Zurich at $352.90 per ounce, down from $354.10 per ounce. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 64 cents an ounce, closing at $354.38. Silver bullion traded in London at a bid $4.84 an ounce, unchanged from late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Bounces Back, Stocks Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices closed higher on the Tokyo Stock Exchage while th U.S. dollar rebounded against the yen today. The dollar closed at 148.90 yen, up 0.80 yen from Wednesday's finish of 148.10 yen, the lowest closing since late February. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 281.14 points, or 0.87 percent, to 32,575.32. The index had gained 141.18 points Wednesday. Traders said stock prices got a boost fro the steep overnight rebound on the Wall Street. Currency dealers said the dollar firmed after the economic summit in Houston failed to meet market expections of a call for a stronger yen. They also said the dollar's rebound followed Bank of Japan officials' denial Wednesday that there would be an increase in Japan's official discount rate, which at 5.25 percent is one of the lowest among industrialized nations. Volume on the first section was estimated at 430 million shares, up from 400 million shares the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Crop Expected to Meet Demand for First Time Since Mid '80s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Farmers are harvesting a bumper wheat crop, large enough to bring U.S. production into line with demand for the first time since the mid-1980s, according to Agriculture Department analysts. But less than half of the U.S. output is used domestically, meaning that the financial well-being of wheat farmers depends heavily on the export market. Also, production is being stepped up in other countries, including some of the biggest U.S. export competitors. Production in the Soviet Union and China _ two huge markets for U.S. wheat _ also is increasing this year. Globally, says Sara Schwartz of USDA's Economic Research Service, wheat production is expected to exceed consumption for the first time since 1987-88, meaning ``a modest recovery'' in world inventories during 1990-91. That translates into lower wheat prices and an increase in world wheat trading, including more for livestock feeding. Schwartz and colleague Pete Riley said in the July issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine that many livestock feeders around the world will turn more heavily to wheat as tight supplies of corn and other coarse grains bolster prices of traditional feed supplies. Major U.S. competitors will have larger exportable supplies of wheat because of bigger crops this year, reflecting favorable weather across much of northern Europe, improved moisture conditions in the Canadian spring wheat areas and good planting conditions in Argentina and parts of Australia. Another reason will be the anticipated increase in the amount of wheat imported for livestock feeding. The bulk of U.S. exports is higher-quality wheat used for milling into flour and other food products. ``Competitors, especially the European Community (EC), have historically been the major suppliers of wheat for feeding and probably will be the beneficiaries of increased trade in the coming year,'' the report said. Schwartz, in a telephone interview Wednesday, said the general outlook described in the report continues to hold up without significant recent changes. ``The weather seems to be pretty good,'' she said. ``There still seems to be some questions about dryness in the EC, but that would affect spring crops more than their winter wheat.'' Looking at the four major wheat competitors, the report said wheat production in the 12-nation EC is expected to be the second largest on record, with yield increases most notable in France and the United Kingdom. Canada is forecast to boost wheat output sharply in 1990-91. The report said Canadian farmers have few production alternatives, and ``planting conditions are better than last year.'' Although prices are down from 1989-90, those still are expected to make wheat attractive to producers. In Australia, wheat production is expected to be down from last season because of lower yields, the report said. Sheep production competes with wheat for land, but wool prices recently dropped sharply and there are large stockpiles. ``Even though world wheat prices are likely to fall in 1990-91, the relative change in prices between wheat and wool is making wheat more attractive to some producers,'' the report said. ``Moreover, depreciation of the Australian dollar likely will cushion Australian producers from the slide in prices.'' Argentina, the fourth major U.S. wheat competitor, is expected to increase production, although there is uncertainty because of inflation and farm costs. But the Argentine government has reduced export taxes on grain, hoping to boost plantings, although it is unclear what effect this might have on acreages. ``Despite these uncertainties, many Argentine farmers, especially those who double-crop soybeans, probably need the income that wheat provides and likely will plant as much or more wheat than a year ago,'' the report said.

The Agriculture Department has expanded federal quarantine restrictions to control fire ants in all or parts of six Southern states. The quarantine is being expanded to keep up with the spread of the pests in Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, South Carolina, Tennessee and Texas. Other areas where federal quarantine restrictions continue unchanged include Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, North Carolina, Oklahoma and Puerto Rico. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said the restrictions are on the interstate movement of ``certain goods and equipment to prevent the artificial spread'' of the imported fire ant into uninfested areas. ``For example, nursery stock is treated before being shipped from infested areas to be sure it isn't harboring the ants,'' he said. The imported fire ant builds large mounds in fields and pastures, the agency said. Fire ants can damage certain crops, and the stings are painful to livestock, pets and people, not only on farms but also in the suburbs and cities of infested areas.

The Agriculture Department is seeing volunteers for a trade mission to Ireland this fall. Duane Acker, administrator of the department's Office of International Cooperation and Development, said about 20 mostly small to medium-size Irish companies have expressed interest in joint cooperation in marketing and specialized food processing technology. Areas of interest include wood, dairy and confectionary products, beef, pork and frozen food processing; smoked fish, specialty and convenience foods, and trading and wholesale food service distribution. Participants will have to pay their travel, lodging and meal expenses. Selection of U.S. companies, scheduling of appointments and side trips will be made by the agency. For further information on the trip, scheduled for Oct. 15-20, contact: Maria Nemeth-Ek, 202-653-7873.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Leaders Give Trade Talks a Nudge, But Hard Bargaining Remains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders managed a breakthrough in a long-troublesome trade dispute but still left it to their aides to do the hard bargaining needed to craft a final plan for revamping global commerce. ``I'm not under any illusions that we'll be dealing with a new era by Christmas _ or even by next spring,'' Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said at Wednesday's close of a three-day economic summit. President Bush joined Mulroney and other leaders of the seven richest democracies in pledging to make sharp cuts in government support for farmers, a contentious issue in the current Uruguay Round of world trade talks. ``What we're trying to do is move the whole thing forward without saying that we have to have, tomorrow, totally unprotected trade,'' Bush told a news conference. The leaders of Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Canada, Italy and the United States took part in the summit. A representative of the 12-nation European Community also attended. The Uruguay Round talks, involving some 100 countries, have been stymied by a nasty dispute between the United States and its European trading partners over slashing government payments to farmers. The United States wants the Europeans to cut more than they have been willing to do so far. The global trade bargaining, which opened in 1986, is due to end in early December in Brussels, Belgium. To try to restart the negotiations, aides to the summit leaders reached a last-minute compromise that promised ``substantial, progressive reductions'' in export subsidies, domestic price supports and barriers to imported goods. The United States had wanted to target those three areas. In a bow to the Europeans, the leaders acknowledged differences in ``the social and economic conditions of farming.'' European officials contend they need their extensive subsidy program to protect their many small-scale farms. The compromise also contained a European demand that they be allowed to work out a formula to measure, and then reduce, a variety of farm subsidies. Both sides claimed success. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said there were ``some quite tough discussions'' among the seven leaders over farm subsidies and, even now, progress on actual cuts would be slow. ``But there has been movement on all sides,'' she said. Jacques Delors, president of the European Community's executive body, agreed, ``This is clear progress on both sides.'' ``We have finally gotten the European Community engaged in a negotiation,'' said a senior American official, demanding anonymity. ``That, I do not believe, has occurred to date.'' The administration is counting on the talks to lower trade barriers and greatly expand opportunities for American farmers and businesses abroad. The aim is to help narrow America's $100 billion-plus trade deficits. The negotiations, which began in Uruguay in 1986, face a July 23 bargaining session in Geneva to draft basic agreements in 15 separate areas, including agriculture. Those outlines will then be used over the next five months to achieve a final deal by the December deadline. Looking ahead at the schedule, the senior American official predicted negotiators will ``take three or four steps forward, one back. There will be times when we are discouraged and times when we're elated.'' The Uruguay Round is being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and agreement for promoting freer trade.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Crime Bill With Tough S&L Provisions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Corrupt executives who pillaged the savings and loan industry would face an expanded army of investigators and longer prison terms under major crime legislation approved by the Senate. ``We need to be cracking down on the orgy of fraud and lawbreaking that occurred in the savings and loan crisis,'' Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said Wednesday as the crime bill was approved 94-6 and sent to the House. The savings and loan provisions came as a last-minute addition to the crime package, which also would place curbs on nine kinds of semiautomatic assault weapons and make 34 federal offenses punishable by death. Senate approval of more money, new weapons and fresh troops to aid prosecutors put pressure on the Bush administration to clean up the scandal. Lawmakers said the S&L scandal was heating up as an issue on the congressional campaign trail. The only lawmaker to oppose the provisions, Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., acknowledged that while calling the bill ``a knee-jerk response to the outrage that is spreading across the country over the savings and loan crisis.'' The plan provides for $162.5 million in each of the next three years to increase the number of agents and prosecutors pursuing S&L fraud and embezzlement cases. Sponsors said the funds would allow the FBI to add 224 agents and 146 support aides while permitting U.S. attorneys' offices to bring on 205 more prosecutors plus 205 support workers and 50 auditors. The Justice Department's tax, civil and criminal divisions would be fortified with 104 attorneys and 78 support workers in addition to those added after $50 million was appropriated in the current fiscal year. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee and floor manager of the bill, estimated the overall price tag as $2 billion a year starting in 1991 and acknowledged that the source of the funds was uncertain. The measure would also authorize $16 million for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 for the Internal Revenue Service to expand its corps of investigators pursuing savings and loan cases. A new financial institutions fraud unit would be established in the Justice Department. The measure also would establish strike forces composed of FBI agents, IRS investigators, bank examiners and prosecutors in cities hardest hit by the scandal. Maximum prison time for bank fraud and embezzlement would be increased from 20 years to 30 years under the plan and mandatory minimums would be set. The bill also provides life sentences as a maximum for a special category of S&L ``kingpins'' who act in concert with three others and derive more than $5 million from their crimes. The bill would expand the possible use of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act against S&L crime. Federal prosecutors would gain power to seize and freeze assets of savings and loan looters under the measure and whistle blowers could get rewards of up to $300,000 for helping put perpetrators behind bars. ``It is essential that those who broke the law be pursued aggressively and brought to justice,'' said Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo. ``Of we give the FBI and the U.S. attorneys more help, the Department of Justice will be able to make progress against the significant backlog of cases and pursue new cases,'' Wirth said. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas was critical of ``slick political operatives'' who are trying to capitalize on the S&L issue for fall congressional campaigns. He called it ``good news for the American people, who don't want to trivialize an American financial tragedy with ill-conceived efforts to achieve short-term political gain.'' Senators voting against the crime bill were Armstrong and Sens. David Durenberger, R-Minn.; Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass.; Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, and William Roth, R-Del.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Say Neil Bush Was Unqualified for S&L Director's Job
With PM-S&L Fraud, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's son Neil was unqualified to be a director of a Colorado thrift, but that doesn't excuse him from harm caused to the institution that failed at a cost of $1 billion, federal regulators say. Neil Bush described himself Wednesday as ``just a Denver guy trying to make a living and raise a family,'' and not as a freewheeling former director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. Bush, 34, continued to deny conflict of interest allegations raised against him by thrift regulators. Meanwhile, President Bush strongly defended his son on Wednesday, saying he has confidence in his ``honor and integrity.'' The president, who has pledged to vigorously prosecute fraud in the savings and loan industry, repeated his promise not to interfere with regulators' investigation of his son. ``If he's done something wrong, the system will digest that,'' he told a news conference in Houston. ``This is not easy for me as a father. It's easy for me as a president because the system is going to work. I am not going to intervene.'' In documents released by the Office of Thrift Supervision, regulators asserted that Neil Bush was ``unqualified and untrained'' for his position as an outside director of Denver-based Silverado. ``Certainly he had no experience in managing a large corporation, especially a financial institution with almost $2 billion in assets,'' said the documents released this week. ``Unfortunately, he was not cognizant of the conflict-of-interest situations he encountered as a director of Silverado.'' However, the regulators added, Bush's inexperience does not excuse him ``from the harm and potential harm he caused'' to the thrift. The younger Bush has been ordered by the thrift office to answer allegations of conflict of interest in his role as a director of Silverado, which lent millions of dollars to his business partner, who never repaid the money. At a news conference in Denver, Neil Bush said, ``I am standing on very solid ground when it comes to defending my role as an outside director.'' He said that his father ``had wanted me to keep a little lower profile.'' However, he told reporters for The Denver Post after the news conference that he is thinking about running for Congress because he thinks there should be more congressional accountability. ``I may (run),'' he said. ``Not anytime soon because it's something I have to build up to. But if I do it, it's probably going to be with the intent of being part of a shakeup.'' The federal government is considering filing lawsuits to recover misspent funds from the officers and directors of 1,300 failed banks and savings institutions, officials told a congressional hearing Wednesday. Neil Bush could be among the defendants. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., appearing at Wednesday's hearing, declined to comment on whether FDIC officials have recommended whether to sue Neil Bush. ``We are treating the Silverado case the way we treat every other case,'' Seidman told the House Judiciary subcommittee on criminal justice. ``Every failed institution, we go into and make a thorough investigation of whether or not there is the possibility of civil or criminal activity.'' In other savings and loan developments Wednesday: _The Senate approved a broad crime bill that stiffens prison terms for savings and loan fraud and offers rewards to whistleblowers for turning in S&L looters. _The former president of one of Texas' largest collapsed thrifts was indicted on fraud charges in connection with a $700 million real estate scheme. FBI officials in Dallas announced the indictment against Edwin T. McBirney III, former president of Sunbelt Savings Association. The regulators asserted that Bush was unqualified to sit on Silverado's board. They noted that he graduated from college in 1977, worked on his father's political campaign for a year and received a master's degree in business administration in 1979. The documents also noted that Bush worked as an oil lease negotiator for Amoco Production Co. in Denver from 1980 through late 1982, and later started his own oil company, JNB Exploration. He became a director of Silverado in the summer of 1985 and quit the job in August 1988, shortly after his father won the Republican presidential nomination. In earlier years, Bush held summer jobs with Republic National Bank in Dallas and a small oil equipment company there.

DOC.HEAD: After Fierce Argument, Summit Claims Vital Breakthroughs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders put their deadlocked trade talks back on course and christened a new era of economic cooperation with the Soviet Union in a summit President Bush says has strengthened ``free wills and free markets for all mankind.'' Bush, before returning to Washington early today, declared his meeting with the six other leaders of the world's richest nations had not only been a success, but ``it has been a celebration.'' ``In Houston, the presidents and prime ministers who lead the largest industrialized democracies met to build a world beyond the Cold War,'' the president told a farewell party in his adopted hometown. He declared the summit partners had managed ``to uphold the revolution of '89 _ to help liberated nations enter the 21st century as enduring democracies. To support free wills and free markets for all mankind.'' The three-day economic summit, along with a NATO gathering in London last week, saw Bush and his Western colleagues groping for ways to keep pace with the challenge of a world in transition. Bush said his summit partners ``all left feeling good'' at the end of the Houston meeting. The leaders agreed, despite what British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called some ``tough discussions,'' to broad cuts in farm subsidies, which are at the heart of long-festering charges of unfair trade practices among the allies. ``Coming after last week's very successful NATO summit, which took a major stride towards a more peaceful world, the results of the meeting in Houston are an important step towards a more prosperous world for everyone,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. Even Mrs. Thatcher, the most enthusiastic backer of the compromise deal on subsidies, acknowledged that the process of actually reducing them ``will be slow.'' West Germany's Helmut Kohl and France's Francois Mitterrand were reconciled to the summit's refusal, at U.S. insistence, to grant direct aid to the Soviet Union. To the end, however, Italy's Guilio Andreotti sought a united Western aid package to the Kremlin: ``When someone is ill, you don't want to wait for medicine.'' Instead, in a communique, the leaders of the United States, Canada, Japan and the four major West European nations urged the Soviet Union to reform its crumbling economy and commissioned a study of Soviet needs. They offered the prospect of ``meaningful and sustained'' aid if Moscow cut military spending and stopped supporting regional troublemakers, an apparent reference to Soviet aid to Cuba, North Korea, Syria, Libya and Vietnam. Bush did not rule out American cash for the Kremlin after the study supervised by the International Monetary Fund is completed at the end of the year. But he was cool about that prospect. ``We have some problems. I'm not particularly enthusiastic about the intercontinental ballistic missiles aimed at U.S. cities,'' Bush told reporter. He added, as he has on several occasions, that he found Soviet aid to Cuba ``a little contradictory.'' The first reaction from Moscow was favorable. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said his country welcomed new approaches that ``correspond to the spirit of the times.'' The summit, the first since the collapse of the Berlin Wall and the end of communist governments in half a dozen East European countries, appeared to mark the start of a new era of economic cooperation between the West and Mosow. Bush sent an immediate telegram to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev about the outcome, assuring him ``technical assistance would continue apace,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said. Bush told reporters on Air Force One that he messaged Gorbachev ``that I was going to call him in a couple of days, plus congratulated him on his victory'' in the Communist Party Congress. In addition, Secretary of State James A. Baker III was due to give a personal briefing to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze within days. On the environment, the leaders of the so-called G-7 group compromised too. The Europeans did not push Bush for specific ceilings on gas emissions, blamed for global warming of the environment. The communique said the seven nations would work to stop to stem global warming ``as expeditiously as possible.'' Overriding U.S. arguments that more study of the causes of global warming is needed, the joint statement said ``lack of full scientific certainty is no excuse to postpone actions which are justified in their own right.'' The final agreement on the agricultural front called for across-the-board cuts in all categories of farm subsidies. However, the last-minute compromise between the United States and the Europeans also allows the nations to measure subsidies in a way Washington has opposed. The United States has been pushing since 1987 for an end to agricultural subsidies, which cost taxpayers and consumers in developed nations an estimated $245 billion annually. The European Community is resisting, saying Bush's demands would put 3 million farmers out of business. There were fears before the summit that the international trade talks, known as the Uruguay round, would collapse. But most leaders said they were confident the political push from the Houston summit would help bring a deal by year's end. Said Mrs. Thatcher: ``The great achievement of the summit has been to make it easier for all of us to reject short-term soft options in favor of longer-term solutions.''

DOC.HEAD: Seat Belt Rule Might Be `Regulatory Overkill,' Business Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A new federal seat belt regulation for American workers that will cost employers about $220 million a year in training costs could be ``regulatory overkill,'' a spokesman for U.S. business says. ``It's perhaps a little more nitpicking than one would like to see,'' Fred Krebs of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce said Wednesday, reacting to a new rule that will require 35 million American workers to use seat belts on the job. In theory, a business could be fined if one of its workers was caught not wearing a seat belt. The regulation, announced by Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, is disturbing because it shows ``a mindset that Washington knows best,'' Krebs said. Under the new rule, workers who drive on the job _ anyone from delivery people to traveling salesmen to cab drivers _ will have to wear seat belts. Even business people riding in taxis would have to buckle up. The rule, a proposed addition to standards that fall under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, would exempt people who are self-employed or businesses with 10 or fewer workers. Employers would also have to provide training courses for workers who drive on a routine basis. The rule will not take effect until after a 120-day waiting period and possibly a hearing next January. Mrs. Dole estimated that the rule will cost the 5.4 million U.S. businesses that will be affected by it about $220 million a year, or about $6 for each driver. Krebs predicted the rule would end up costing businesses more than that. Businesses that violate OSHA regulations face fines of up to $10,000, but Mrs. Dole said only employers guilty of ``willful and egregious'' violations of the seat belt regulation would be subject to the maximum. Fine points of the regulation, such as whether it includes farm workers who ride in the back of trucks, still have to be worked out, she said. The regulation will be difficult to enforce, Mrs. Dole said, but federal inspectors will make checks of seat belt use among workers part of their routine. Mrs. Dole said the new rule could save an estimated 685 lives a year. But Krebs, manager of the Chamber of Commerce's business-government policy department, said ``it could be regulatory overkill'' and that ``there might be more significant safety and health issues that OSHA could be addressing. ``Seat belts are a good thing and people should wear them. But whether or not this is a good regulation for OSHA is debatable,'' he said. ``There are limits to what employers can do to regulate the conduct of their employees,'' Krebs added. The AFL-CIO, which represents 14.2 million unionized workers, praised the new regulation but said the standard also needs to require vehicle inspection and maintenance. The seat-belt rule ``is a first step in reducing the high toll of job-related motor vehicle fatalities and injuries,'' the labor federation said in a statement. Since 1984, when states began passing seat belt laws, belt use among the general public has risen from 14 percent to 46 percent, Mrs. Dole told a news conference. Thirty-six states with 88 percent of the U.S. population now have seat belt laws, she said. Under the training programs required by the new federal regulation, employers will have to familiarize workers with their vehicles and give instructions on seat belt use and on the effects of drinking and driving. ``I think people pay a lot of attention to what their bosses are telling them on the job,'' Mrs. Dole said. Automobile accidents are the single largest cause of occupational fatalities, causing about 2,100 job-related deaths a year, she said. Mrs. Dole chose Wednesday to announce the new rule because it marks the sixth anniversary of a regulation she pushed through, as transportation secretary in the Reagan administration, that requires all new cars to be equipped with seat belts.
