DOC.HEAD: Japan's Trade Surplus Widens for Second Time in 14 Months
DOC.TEXT: Japan's trade surplus expanded 28 percent in June to $6.72 billion, only the second time in 14 months it had climbed from a year earlier, the Ministry of Finance reported Thursday. The country's surplus with the United States, however, narrowed to $3.25 billion in June from $3.62 billion in June 1989. The 10 percent decline was good news in the wake of a recent agreement aimed at reducing trade frictions between the two countries. For the first six months of the year, Japan's overall merchandise trade surplus shrank 22.8 percent to $25.79 billion from $33.39 billion in the year-earlier period, the ministry said. Imports for the six months totaled $108.15 billion, up 5.6 percent from $102.43 billion the year before. Exports slipped 1.4 percent to $133.94 billion from $135.84 billion. Foreign Ministry officials attributed the June reversal to a drop in import values resulting from a decrease in world commodity prices and slowed domestic demand. At the same time, the export values of many big-ticket items sold by Japan grew, they said. Kazuko Mizuno, an economist at Baring Securities (Japan) Ltd., said export growth had accelerated since the yen began depreciating rapidly at the beginning of the year, and import growth slowed. ``When (the dollar) is between 150 and 160 yen, Japanese exports are quite competitive and it's quite easy for Japanese corporations to increase exports,'' Mizuno said. The dollar closed at 148.90 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Thursday, but it has been above 150 yen for much of the year. June exports to the United States fell 6.7 percent to $7.4 billion, in part because of sluggish car sales. But imports from the United States also slipped, down 3.7 percent to $4.15 billion, partly because of slowed purchases of lumber and aircraft. The overall rise from $5.27 billion in June 1989 to $6.72 billion last month marked only the second time since April 1989 that the nation's trade gap widened from the same month in the previous year. The last year-on-year increase was in March, when Japan's trade surplus broadened to $7.09 billion from $6.61 billion. Imports in June decreased by 2.2 percent to $17.04 billion from $17.42 billion in June 1989, while exports edged up 4.7 percent to $23.76 billion from $22.68 billion. Excluding March, when imports slipped because of extraordinary factors, the year-on-year decrease in imports was the first since February 1987, Finance Ministry officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Cray Research President Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Marcelo Gumucio, president and chief operating officer of Cray Research Inc., on Thursday resigned from both positions and from the supercomputer company's board of directors. Cray Chairman and Chief Executive Officer John A. Rollwagen announced the resignation in a letter to employees, saying he and Gumucio ``were unable to agree'' on implementing a long-range strategy for the company. ``We attempted to blend our distinct management styles effectively, but were not successful in that effort,'' Rollwagen said in his letter. ``The decision to part is mutual and in the best overall interests of the organization and the individuals involved.'' Rollwagen said for the ``foreseeable future'' he will assume Gumucio's responsibilities, in addition to retaining his other titles. Rollwagen was not specific in the letter about the nature of his disagreements with Gumucio. Neither Rollwagen nor Gumucio immediately returned phone calls seeking comment. Gumucio became president of Cray in November 1988. He joined the company in 1983 as executive vice president of marketing. At the company's annual meeting in May, Gumucio said Cray planned to continue expanding its line of supercomputers in the 1990s. He said the company's introduction of a new, smaller supercomputer was an example of how the company was developing outward from its original focus on the most powerful computers. Cray now is focused on a variety of products to fit the growing demand for computer networking, he said then. Cray suffered a slump in 1989, with sales up just 4 percent to $784.7 million and earnings declining 43 percent to $89 million. In April, however, Cray reported its first-quarter profit totaled $9.5 million, compared with $1.5 million for the same period in 1989. The company also said then that it expected its profit for the entire year to be higher.

DOC.HEAD: Fisher-Price Toys to Close Another New York Factory, Cut Headquarters Staff
DOC.TEXT: Fisher-Price Toys, the troubled Quaker Oats Co. unit, said Thursday that it is closing a nearby factory and slashing jobs at its headquarters here in a move that will cut more than 500 workers from its payroll. Some 245 jobs will be eliminated at the company's headquarters, and between 300 and 400 jobs will be lost when the shutdown of the plant in Holland, N.Y., is completed by November. Until recently, the plant made molded plastic parts that were shipped to the East Aurora plant for assembly. Company officials said the move, coupled with the closing of another plant in East Aurora earlier this year, would make Fisher-Price profitable again. Fisher-Price is expected to have lost about $44.5 million during the fiscal year that was just completed and the first three months of the current fiscal year. ``The closing of the Holland plant was necessary because of the excess capacity throughout our manufacturing system and the continued decline in sales volume,'' Ronald F. Jackson, chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. In February Fisher-Price terminated 450 employees when it closed its East Aurora plant. Following the reductions announced Thursday, the company will employ a total of 6,400 workers. Fisher-Price is scheduled to be spun off from its parent company, Chicago-based Quaker Oats, in early January and become an independent, free-standing company that will be publicly traded. Fisher-Price spokeswoman Carol Blackley said the company needs to take the drastic measures to recoup its losses and ``be as strong as we can possibly be when we go public.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Ties Food Handling by AIDS Patients to Scientific Findings
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 4 grafs conferee approval of changes; picks up 4th graf pvs, Health and Human Services ...also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators today approved major civil rights legislation for disabled Americans after agreeing on a provision that would help protect the jobs of AIDS-infected workers who handle food. Sponsors predicted quick final action in both chambers and said the legislation could reach President Bush's desk by the weekend. The legislation prohibits discrimination against disabled Americans _ 43 million, according to congressional estimates _ in employment, access to restaurants, stores and other commercial establishments, transportation and telecommunciations. The AIDS provision, approved by the Senate 99-1 Wednesday night, would allow owners of restaurants, packing companies and other food businesses to reassign AIDS-infected workers only if medical evidence shows a need. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan has said no evidence exists for removing AIDS-infected people from food-handling jobs. Most scientists believe AIDS is more difficult to spread: through intimate sexual contact, punctures with needles or other contaminated objects, and transfusions of contaminated blood products. ``It's a clear message that AIDS needs to be dealt with in a responsible way and we need to reject appeals to prejudice and bigotry,'' said Gregory King, a spokesman for the Human Rights Campaign Fund, a gay rights group. Male homosexuals and intravenous drug users have been the chief victims of the fatal disease. The vote Wednesday represents a reversal of a previous Senate vote and a defeat for Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., who said the fear of AIDS would drive any restaurant out of business if the public learned a chef or other employee were infected. He cast the lone negative vote. Supporters say the bill is the most comprehensive piece of civil rights legislation since the Civil Rights Act of 1964 outlawed discrimination against blacks. President Bush has asked Congress to speed up passage of the bill, which the Senate approved last September by a 76-8 vote. The House passed its version in May, 403-20, after including an amendment giving employers the right to reassign food-service workers with AIDS or other contagious diseases, regardless of how they are spread. The vote Wednesday was on a proposal by Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. Under it, the Health and Human Services Department would have to evaluate all contagious diseases each year. HHS would then determine which diseases could be spread through food handling. Food-service employers would be able to reassign workers whose diseases are determined to be passed along through such contact _ tuberculosis, for example. ``All it says is, `Let's use science, let's not use conjecture,''' Hatch said. Helms, however, said evidence that AIDS cannot be transmitted through such casual contact is short of conclusive. He referred to scientific findings as ``conventional wisdom.'' ``I don't want to go to that convention,'' he said. ``I don't want to take that chance.'' On June 6, the Senate voted 53-40 at Helms' urging to support the House AIDS provision. Later that month, however, House and Senate negotiators refused to include that amendment in their compromise version of the bill. On Wednesday, the Senate voted 61-39 to reject a similar Helms amendment.

DOC.HEAD: Voice of `Sleeping Beauty' Can Sue Disney in Florida
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The opera singer who was the voice of Sleeping Beauty can sue Walt Disney Co. in Florida because the company does business in the state, an appeals court ruled. The decision Wednesday could mean a speedier trial for Mary Costa, voice of the title character in Disney's 1959 animated film ``Sleeping Beauty.'' The Palm Beach soprano is seeking an unspecified cut of the $60 million the company made from the movie's videocassette release in 1986. Disney attorneys had hoped to move the lawsuit from Palm Beach County to California, where the suit could have languished for years in the state's overburdened judicial system. The company originally argued to have the Florida case thrown out because Disney is a Delaware corporation with its primary place of business in California. Circuit Judge Stephen Rapp refused to dismiss the case, and Disney attorneys appealed his decision to the 4th District Court of Appeals. Ms. Costa's suit claims Disney breached its contract with her by not paying her royalties from video sales of the movie.

DOC.HEAD: Nynex Parties Raise Phone Bill Questions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to add that Nynex is parent company. SUBS 7th graf, `Nynex refused...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with New York Telephone, NYNEX reaction; also moving general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Investigators are looking into allegations that New York Telephone suppliers helped pay for bawdy parties and prostitutes at annual conventions of company employees, The Wall Street Journal reported today. State regulators are questioning whether the meetings at Florida resorts resulted in higher costs being paid by customers, the newspaper said. The meetings, held for one week each year from 1984-88, allegedly involved improper contact between employees of Materiel Enterprises Co., the purchasing unit of New York Telephone corporate parent Nynex, and about 30 company suppliers, the Journal said. Annual awards were handed out to the wildest attendees of the events, the Journal reported. One Nynex worker won the ``Procurement Award'' three times in a row for his efforts in enticing women to attend the parties. Other honorees included the ``Most Valuable Pervert'' and the winner of the ``Moon Over Miami Award,'' for unspecified activities, the Journal said. The story comes on the same day that state Attorney Robert Abrams planned to announce his opposition to New York Telephone's request for a $965 million rate hike. Steve Marcus, a New York Telephone spokesman, denied today that the parties had resulted in higher costs to any of his company's customers. ``We want to emphasize there's been no general increase in rates since 1986, so no ratepayer funds are involved in any of the allegations about overcharges,'' Marcus said. Nynex is preparing a response to the charges, he said. Nynex refused to discuss the Florida meetings with the Journal. But the paper reported that at rate hearings held by the state Public Service Commission, Nynex officials said details of the parties and the names of those involved were ``trade secrets'' that need not be disclosed. Abrams disputes that argument, and is trying to get the testimony about the Florida parties unsealed.

DOC.HEAD: McBirney Indicted in Sunbelt Savings Collapse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf with 2 grafs on McBirney appearance in court; Picks up 12th graf pvs: McBirney was...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX-8
DOC.TEXT: After repeated criticism for failing to round up big names involved in the collapse of the nation's thrift industry, the government has indicted two major executives in recent weeks and is promising more. On Wednesday, officials announced the 17-count indictment of Edwin T. McBirney III, once a flamboyant young financier who presided over the tremendous growth and $2.5 billion failure of Sunbelt Savings Association of Texas. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said the indictment, returned by one of three grand juries in Dallas investigating bank and thrift fraud, ``marks another milestone in our crackdown on fraud in the thrift industry.'' Since Oct. 1, 1988, Justice Department prosecutors have obtained 307 indictments and 200 convictions involving S&L fraud, Thornburgh said. Thornburgh has been criticized in Congress for failing to bring indictments against many former executives suspected of stealing from thrifts. But he predicted it would take at least five years for the Justice Department to investigate and prosecute remaining cases of S&L fraud. Last month, former Vernon Savings and Loan Association owner Donald R. Dixon was indicted on 38 conspiracy and fraud counts in the billion-dollar collapse of his thrift in 1987. Dixon has pleaded innocent. Dixon and McBirney frequently were listed as being among the most sought-after officials of collapsed thrifts. Bob Gilliam, special agent in charge of the Dallas FBI office, said the increased pace of indictments was the result of manpower provided investigators by last year's thrift bailout legislation. ``You'll see the numbers continually increasing,'' Gilliam said. ``A year from now, we'll really see the impact.'' McBirney, 37, appeared before U.S. District Judge Barefoot Sanders today to be apprised of the charges against him. He was released on his own recognizance and faces a July 19 arraignment before U.S. District Judge Robert Maloney. His attorney, Paul Coggins, said he would plead innocent when arraigned later. McBirney had no immediate comment for reporters. McBirney was famed for the exuberant way he celebrated his wealth _ flying friends to Hawaii for fishing and Las Vegas for gambling, dressing as a king at a 1984 Halloween party where guests dined on pheasant, antelope and lion. The indictment accuses McBirney of hiding from regulators agreements with Western Savings Association over the partial financing of $700 million worth of property in Southern California. FBI agent Pat Dorsey said the deal contributed to the collapse of Sunbelt in 1988. The 17 counts involve one transaction. McBirney is accused of ensuring Western Savings a $6 million profit on the sale of a property of its choosing in return for Western providing $30 million in financing on California property being bought by Sun Cal, a Sunbelt subsidiary. The charges against McBirney include bank fraud, misapplication of funds, false entries and making false statements to regulators. He faces to up 85 years in prison and a $4.25 million fine if convicted. Coggins said the indictment ``is a typical case of government overkill.'' He said McBirney would show ``he acted in the best interests of Sunbelt.'' ``This case shows the great lengths to which people went to deceive regulators,'' U.S. Attorney Marvin Collins of Dallas told reporters in Washington. He said Sunbelt's was largest S&L bailout thus far. Thirteen other Sunbelt officials, borrowers and accountants have been convicted as a result of the 2{-year investigation of the failed thrift. Sunbelt and Western, both based in Dallas, were among eight insolvent thrifts taken over by the government in 1988 in one of the largest of the efforts to rescue failing institutions. McBirney, who bought Sunbelt in 1982, was forced out by regulators in 1986. Since then, he has been chairman of a company dealing in waste treatment technology. ``Under McBirney's guidance, the association engaged in high-risk loans that were either unsecured or inadequately secured by commercial real estate,'' the government said in 1988 when it finally closed the institution in a bailout estimated at least $2.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Video Resumes: Gimmick or Answer to Job Seekers' Prayers?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Morris Sultan knew the competition would be tough when he decided to look for a new job, so he tried something novel. Instead of writing a resume, he made a video. In a three-minute pitch sent out to a dozen prospective employers, Sultan detailed why he should be hired. One firm liked what they saw and brought Sultan in for an interview; he now oversees customs and merchandise orders for M&L Design, an accessory importing firm in New York. ``Communication is a big part of what I do, so I felt like I might have a better chance if they could get to know me. Usually, they just take your number and say, `We'll call you.' The tape helped me get noticed,'' Sultan said. The new-wave resumes are ``a nice calling card to start out with'' that can give candidates an edge on the competition, said Albert Dabah, who runs Video Portfolios where Sultan made his tape. But critics call video resumes a gimmick that fosters discrimination and gives stressed-out job seekers more to fret over. ``The rare person, maybe in advertising or something, can come across as a dynamo. Most people look like a jerk on videotape,'' said Kathryn Troutman, who owns The Resume Place in Washington, D.C., which still specializes in traditional paper resumes. Most people don't like the way they look in photographs, let alone on camera, she said. ``If someone tried to put me on a tape, I'd say, `Hey, I'm trying to look for a job here, not get myself depressed.' There's already enough trauma involved with looking for a job. This is just an extra aggravation,'' she said. Since the tapes give prospective employers a way to view job seekers' appearance, critics say they make age or race discrimination too easy and give employers a way to weed out people whose appearance they don't find appealing. But William Brown, who owns an Annapolis, Md., firm where job seekers pay $149 for a package that includes a video resume, said they don't give employers any more of a chance to discriminate than personal interviews. ``We can't control discrimination. If a person comes in, there's nothing to prevent me from saying, `Hey, she's a blonde. My ex-wife's a blonde and I'm not hiring a blonde,' '' Brown said. He conceded the tapes save employers' time by allowing them to ``laser through'' candidates. ``If someone can't take 10 minutes for a haircut or time to tuck their shirt in, why would you want to waste your time on them?'' said Brown, who founded Network Employment & Resume Inc. five years ago. Serouya Morey, the owner of M&L Design, said Sultan's video resume was the first he'd ever seen. ``It struck me as a little innovative, and this job takes some creativity,'' Morey said. The tape gave him a chance to judge Sultan's personality and make decisions ``you can't get from reading a resume,'' Morey said. ``The bottom line is he probably got the job because of it,'' Morey said. At Brown's office, clients, already prepped on what to wear, sit in front of a picture of the Manhattan skyline. Brown, with his back to the camera, asks them questions that might come up in any job interview. Clients talk about their current job and what they're looking for in their next post. Tapes containing several five-minute interviews with people looking for the same type of jobs are then sent to a network of corporate clients Brown is developing. Brown declined to provide the names of his clients. Steven Klein of Target Search, a Washington headhunting firm, called the tapes a ``gimmick people are using to make money.'' Job candidates lose out by trying to sell themselves on video rather than in person, he said. ``A lot of it is chemistry. It either clicks or it doesn't. With a video, you never get a chance to go eyeball to eyeball,'' Klein said. Peter Cushley, who handles video and advertising for Brown's firm, writes off the competition's criticism. ``If you're selling super widgets, is a guy selling widgets going to tell you super widgets are better?'' Cushley said.

DOC.HEAD: Armond Hammer Sued by Late Wife's Heir
DOC.TEXT: Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corp., has been sued for $700 million in damages by the estate of his late wife Frances, which claims at least a half interest in Hammer's art collection. The 18-count suit, filed Wednesday in a Los Angeles court, alleges fraud, legal malpractice and financial misconduct. It contends Hammer and a law firm representing the industrialist repeatedly deceived Frances Hammer about her ownership rights to Hammer's assets. The lawsuit was filed by Robert Weiss of Los Angeles, husband of Joan Weiss. Mrs. Weiss is a niece of Frances Hammer and sole heir to her estate. Mrs. Hammer died in December after 33 years of marriage to Armand Hammer and named Robert Weiss executor of her will. The 92-year-old Hammer maintains that his wife signed documents waiving her interest in his art collection, which has been estimated to be worth $450 million. Richard C. Cleary, a lawyer for the Weisses, said those signings were part of the pattern of fraud and deceit. The suit also says Mrs. Hammer was fraudulently deprived an interest in thousands of shares of Occidental stock and millions of dollars in cash paid to Armand Hammer in salary and fringe benefits. Howard Collins, a spokesman for Hammer and Occidental, declined comment on the lawsuit. Also named as defendants are Occidental; the Armand Hammer Foundation; Lewis, Overbeck and Furman, a Chicago law firm; and the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Cultural Center in Los Angeles, where Hammer's art collection is to be housed. The lawsuit was the fourth filed in connection with the museum, which is under construction beside Occidental's headquarters. The others were filed by Occidental shareholders seeking to halt the company's involvement with the museum. Occidental has committed about $100 million to building and endowing the facility _ money Hammer maintains is well-spent because it promotes the corporation and will provide a public service. Hammer began collecting art during the 1920s in the Soviet Union. His collection, including Impressionist and Old Master paintings and drawings by Leonardo da Vinci, had been promised to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. But he got into a dispute with that museum over how the art was to be displayed, and instead decided to build his own museum and donate the art to it.

DOC.HEAD: CPC International Earnings Rise 14 Percent
DOC.TEXT: CPC International Inc. said Thursday its second-quarter earnings rose 14 percent, helped by the acquisition of three products in its European food division. CPC, a U.S. food company that makes Hellman's mayonnaise and Skippy peanut butter, said sales in Europe were up 24 percent, largely due to the acquisitions, made after the first half of 1989. In the second quarter of 1990, profits totaled $94.98 million, or $1.23 a share, on revenue of $1.45 billion. That compared with earnings of $83.1 million, or $1.06 a share, on revenue of $1.26 billion in the same 1989 period. The Englewood Cliffs-based company's earnings for the first half of 1990 rose 15 percent to $173.9 million, or $2.24 a share, from $150.8 million, or $1.92 a share, from the first six months of 1989. During the second quarter, CPC completed three acquisitions: the leading producer of jams in Portugal, marketed under the brand names of Mateus and Casa de Mateus; the assets of the Bee Hive brand corn syrup business in Canada; and the Poti line of fruit compote desserts in France. CPC's worldwide consumer foods business accounts for about 80 percent of its total sales. Its U.S. brands include Mazola corn oil, Knorr products and Karo syrup, which showed strong volume gains in the second quarter. Mueller's pasta volumes were slightly higher, while volumes of the Best Foods Baking Group were somewhat lower and margarine volumes continued to decline, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Corn, Soybean Futures Slip Ahead Of Crop Report
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices fell Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade while wheat futures rose slightly ahead of a government report that was expected to contain a lower winter wheat crop estimate. Analysts attributed some of the activity to position-squaring ahead of the Agriculture Department crop report. Traders expected the USDA to reduce its winter wheat harvest projection to about 2.05 billion bushels from last month's estimate of 2.09 billion, according to one survey. In the report, which was released after the close, the USDA lowered the winter wheat production estimate to 2.04 billion bushels. The report did not contain production estimates for corn or soybeans. The corn and soybean markets were mainly influenced by forecasts for continued mild temperatures and adequate rainfall in the Midwest through the end of next week. The weather in the Corn Belt has been so fine for crop production that ``you could arguably state that yield potential has improved,'' said Richard Feltes, commodity research director with Refco Inc. in Chicago. At the close, wheat futures were } cent to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.07 a bushel; corn futures were 1{ cents to 3{ cents lower with July at $2.76\ a bushel; oats were 4 cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at $1.26{ a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at $6.07{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Abitibi-Price, Two Partners May Build Recycled Newsprint Mill in Scotland
DOC.TEXT: Canadian forest products giant Abitibi-Price Inc. and two British publishers have agreed to buy a venture that has been exploring building a newsprint plant in Scotland that would use only recycled fiber. Abitibi-Price said Thursday the partners would build the plant in Gartcosh, Scotland, under certain conditions that include updating engineering studies and cost estimates and securing approval from their respective boards. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. It comes amid growing global demand that newpaper companies increase their use of recycled newsprint to help preserve natural resources. Abitibi-Price's partners are London-based publishing companies, The Daily Telegraph PLC led by Conrad Black and Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd. led by Robert Maxwell. The publishing companies each would own 25 percent of the venture called North British Newsprint Ltd. while Abitibi-Price of Toronto would own 50 percent and operate the newsprint mill, according to an announcement by the companies. It said groundbreaking for the plant could take place in the first half of 1991 and construction time would take about two years. Bernd Koken, chairman and chief executive of Abitibi-Price, said the mill would give his company a newsprint manufacturing presence in the European community. The company now has nine newsprint plants, all in North America. The North British Newsprint project was conceived and developed by Stirling Fibre, a leading British waste paper merchant that has been working on it for several years. ``We are delighted that Abitibi-Price and its partners are taking over this outstanding project,'' Chairman Christopher Wilkins of Stirling said in a statement. Current estimates are that the plant will cost about 200 million pounds, or about $360 million at recent exchange rates. It is to produce 220,000 metric tons per year of newsprint, using about 270,000 metric tons of old newspapers and magazines. The newsprint is expected to be sold mainly in the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Kimberly-Clark Earnings Fall On Charge From Subsidiary's Sale
DOC.TEXT: Paper manufacturer Kimberly-Clark Corp. reported Thursday its second quarter pre-tax income rose 2.8 percent, although a charge against earnings due to the sale of a newsprint operation caused net income to fall 20.6 percent. In the three months ended June 30, the Dallas-based company said pre-tax income rose from $147.9 million to $152 million. Sales grew from $1.4 billion to $1.61 billion. But a $44 million after-tax charge connected to the pending sale of Spruce Falls Power and Paper Co. Ltd. reduced net income to $80.4 million, or $1.01 per share, compared with last year's $101.3 million, or $1.26 per share. The company said the charge amounted to 55 cents per share. The sale of the Canadian newsprint subsidiary, 50.5 percent owned by Kimberly-Clark, is expected to close in the third quarter. For the first half of the year, net income was $197.6 million, or $2.47 per share, compared with $204.4 million, or $2.54 per share, in the first half of 1989. Net sales grew from $2.82 billion to $3.19 billion. Chairman Darwin E. Smith said the operating improvements in the quarter came in the domestic consumer-related business and improved results in Mexico and Australia. Kimberly-Clark manufactures Kleenex brand tissues, Huggies disposable diapers, Kotex and New Freedom feminine pads, Hi-Dri household towels and Depend incontinence products. The company also manufactures newsprint and premium business and speciality papers.

DOC.HEAD: Beleaguered Developer Called as Witness in Union Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Cash-strapped Donald J. Trump tried to avoid more financial problems Thursday at a civil lawsuit that alleges he defrauded a union pension fund by using undocumented Polish workers to raze a building to make way for the Trump Tower. Trump tried to distance himself from the accusation by saying he did not directly supervise the 1980 project and did not know the contractor had used Polish workers until after the job was done. He also said repeatedly during his 90-minute appearance that he could not remember specific events and conversations. Trump's court appearance took place amid reports he is suffering from a severe cash crunch caused by the enormous debt on his casinos and real estate properties. Trump made a passing reference his financial problems when plaintiff attorney Wendy Sloan asked whether he generally read newspaper articles about his projects. ``Lately it's become almost impossible because of the volume,'' he said. If he loses this case, Trump could have yet another debt to pay. The lawsuit seeks more than $1 million in unpaid contributions and interest for the union pension fund. The multimillionaire developer and landlord was subpoenaed by the plaintiff, a retired demolition worker who was a member of the house wreckers union, to testify at the non-jury trial in Manhattan's federal court. The lawsuit charges that Trump conspired with union officials to defraud the pension fund by failing to make contributions on behalf of 200 illegal Polish aliens who worked on the job. The complaint also names the Equitable Life Assurance Society, Trump's partner in the demolition project. Trump said he probably visited the site on Fifth Avenue between 56th and 57th streets, but did not enter the old Bonwit Teller building that was being razed. ``You have to be very brave to walk into a building under demolition and I'm not sure I'm that brave,'' he said. Trump said he might have been aware that workers had lodged complaints about not being paid, but he placed the blame on the contractor, William Kaszycki, whom he described as ``a disaster, to put it mildly,'' who could not handle the job. ``In life you make mistakes and this was a mistake,'' he said. Trump said he did not learn until sometime after the demolition project was completed that Polish workers were used. He said he still does not know whether they were illegal aliens. His testimony was frequently interrupted by his attorney, Milton Gould, who objected that certain questions were irrelevant. On one occasion, Gould muttered, ``This case is nonsense.'' During one line of inquiry, Trump acknowledged that he ``on occasion'' had used the pen name ``John Barron,'' but U.S. District Judge Charles Stewart stopped Sloan from asking more questions on the subject.

Though analysts differed as to how much the Fed's views might have changed, the news was warmly received in the credit markets, sending interest rates lower. Brokers also said buyers appeared to have been encouraged by the market's steady showing of late in the face of a succession of disappointments in midyear corporate earnings reports.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Briefs Congress Leaders in `Upbeat' Session on Summits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-10, House Speaker, to CORRECT Foley quote on Soviet aid, add detail. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave congressional leaders his personal review Thursday of the NATO and economic summits, winning praise for going slowly on Soviet aid and quickly on fighting farm subsidies. However, one congressman said the history of farm supports in this country suggests they ``will live forever.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater indicated the president had not yet called Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to fill him in on the summit. Bush said Wednesday he had sent Gorbachev a cable indicating the results ``were positive as far as the Soviet desires went'' and planned to call him in a few days. Bush, back in the White House froma week of summitry on two continents, met first with his Cabinet, which greeted him with applause. Then, joined by his secretaries of state, defense and treasury, Bush gave more than a dozen top Democrat and Republican lawmakers a rundown on the London and Houston summits. ``It was basically upbeat,'' Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said of the briefing. Fascell said the United States had ``accomplished what it set out to do'' in London in revising the Western alliance's military strategy and showing ``that the Soviets need not fear NATO.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said the economic summit, which concluded Wednesday in Houston, ``made some progress. There are still obviously some unresolved issues with respect to trade. ... But in general, I think it was a successful outcome.'' On the question of Soviet aid, Foley said the president reiterated his belief ``that additional economic reforms are necessary. I can only say that I don't dispute the president's statement at this time.'' Bush kept a low profile Thursday, ignoring reporters' questions. On Wednesday night, however, flying home from Houston, he said, ``We're very satisfied with both events. We've got a lot of work to do now, but they went well.'' The United States won a commitment from its six economic summit partners and the European Community to revive the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade talks by trying to find ways to cut farm subsidies. Bush also withstood pressure from West Germany and France for coordinated Western aid in response to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's appeal for help. Rep. Bill Archer of Texas, the top Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, said Bush was ``eminently correct'' on the Soviet aid question. ``He was almost alone in that and ultimately, I think, negotiated a good arrangement,'' said Archer, who represents Bush's adopted home town of Houston. ``We're not ready ... to just jump in there with massive economic aid'' before the Soviets move closer to a market-oriented economy, Fascell said. Bush also said in Houston he will ask Congress to dismantle U.S. farm subsidies if other countries agree to lower their barriers. Asked if Congress would buy that, Fascell said, ``If you follow the history of farm price supports in this country, it's been very difficult to conclude anything except that farm subsidies will live forever.'' Fascell said there was no question the subsidies should be reduced, but added, ``we don't want to destroy our agriculture in the process.'' Foley said, ``There is great reluctance on the part of our trading partners to dismantle'' their subsidies. The European subsidies ``go far beyond anything the U.S. does with respect to agriculture,'' the speaker said. The Bush administration says such subsidies should be eliminated because they skew international trading and cost taxpayers and consumers billions of dollars in government payments and higher food costs.

DOC.HEAD: States Are Offering, But Some Firms Say `No, Thanks'
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Last week, H.J. Heinz Co. announced it was ``opting out'' of Pennsylvania's anti-takeover law, making the food manufacturer the latest company to voluntarily give up the protections offered by the new statute. States increasingly are offering corporations more protection from hostile threats. But faced with growing shareholder activism and other considerations, some companies would rather tough it out on their own. ``We don't need the protection ... We will live on our performance,'' said Bob Pugliese, Westinghouse Electric Corp.'s executive vice president for legal and corporate affairs. The Pennsylvania Legislature passed the anti-takeover law, considered the nation's toughest, last spring after to an unwanted foray against Armstrong World Industries Inc. by Canada's Belzberg family. Armstrong welcomed the bill. But other Pennsylvania-chartered companies, including Westinghouse and Heinz, began to take advantage of a 90-day period during which they could opt out of any or all of its provisions. David H. Gunning, a partner with the law firm Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Cleveland, said corporate managers have had to weigh the advantages and disadvantages of accepting the law's provisions. He described the dilemma: ``If I opt out of it, I haven't gotten the added protection, but I haven't gotten the more immediate problem of more active shareholders.'' Shareholders, particularly big pension funds, don't like anti-takeover laws that have been enacted in recent years because they perceive the statutes as barriers to higher stock prices. Shares of companies considered to be vulnerable to takeover frequently shoot higher on speculation or when an actual bid is made. Some of the big shareholders campaigned against the new law. The California Public Employees Retirement System, the nation's largest public pension fund, urged Pennsylvania corporations to opt out. Many companies complied with the request, realizing ``they're going to deter investors from acquiring shares in the company,'' said William Tyson. professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. Westinghouse's Pugliese said, ``We don't want them to have a disincentive to invest in Westinghouse.'' New takeover defenses continue being enacted, although the merger wave of the late 1980s continues to recede. The takeover business has slowed as financing has become more scarce, but this does not mean U.S. corporations are safe from hostile bids _ especially if financing becomes easier to obtain. ``There will come a time ... when money is going to become available again,'' Gunning said. ``These statutes will probably serve as inhibitions to some acquisitions in some place.'' Stat anti-takeover laws have flourished since 1987. That year, the Supreme Court upheld Indiana's anti-takeover statute in a ruling that recognized the states' rights to develop corporate defenses against hostile bidders. The Indiana law gave shareholders the right to decide whether an investor who buys a big stake in a company, even a majority interest, could vote those shares in corporate elections. The law, known as a control-share statute, has been copied in other states. Anti-takeover laws also have been evolving. More than half the states have adopted merger moratorium statutes, which generally prevent a hostile acquiror from taking control of a company's assets for several years without the approval of a specific percentage of shareholders. Such laws were aimed at raiders who sought to pay for debt-financed takeovers by breaking up a target company and selling it piece by piece. The Pennsylvania statute has both control-share and merger moratorium provisions and contains a provision that disarms corporate raiders. Under the law, a raider is forced to return any profits made after announcing a buyout bid that is intended solely to drive up the company's stock price or set off a bidding war. Westinghouse and Heinz opted out of all the provisions. Tyson said states continue passing takeover laws with new embellishments partly because many believe the Indiana-style control share laws aren't strong enough. Furthermore, he said, ``The trend seems to be getting stronger because the courts seem to be supporting these takeover statutes'' and upholding their constitutionality. Judges themselves continue to craft takeover defenses. In May, the Delaware Chancery Court continued its inclination toward giving boards of directors leeway in defending against unwanted bids. The court said the board of Apple Bancorp Inc., which is facing an unwanted bid, did not violate a duty to shareholders by delaying setting a date for its annual meeting, where suitor Stanley Stahl was threatening a proxy fight. Delaware court decisions are watched closely because many of the nation's biggest companies are incorporated in the state.

DOC.HEAD: Six Month Update: Still No Plan, But Creditors Don't Seem Worried
With BC-Federated-Allied-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Six months after the Federated-Allied department store empire plunged into the biggest retailing bankruptcy case in history, it still hasn't produced a plan to repay $7.7 billion in debts, reorganize and survive. But suppliers and creditors don't seem overly concerned, and some are optimistic about the future of the stores, which span some of the best-known names in retailing including Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and The Bon Marche. Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., the retailing divisions of the Campeau Corp. in Toronto, are still bleeding substantial amounts of money. Both lost nearly $100 million in the first full quarter under federal bankruptcy protection. Last week they reported a combined loss of $26.9 million in May alone. Nonetheless, they said the May loss was smaller than expected, and four of their nine chains recorded operating profits for the month. Seattle-based The Bon Marche reported the largest profit _ $3.9 million. ``From every indication we see, they are on the right track, and we are going to support them in every way we can,'' said Bernard Chaus, president of clothing supplier Bernard Chaus Inc. Chaus said he plans to ship the stores merchandise worth $30 million to $40 million this year. That's an indication of faith among many suppliers that the department stores will emerge successfully from their financial problems. A federal bankruptcy court has twice granted Federated and Allied extensions on their deadline to submit a plan to reorganize, giving them until Sept. 12. After that date, creditors can propose their own plans. The retailers say they plan to ask Judge J. Vincent Aug for at least one more extension at a hearing later this month. Federated and Allied sought protection from creditors Jan. 15 under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code, the biggest-ever bankruptcy case in the retail industry. The move gives them a respite while they devise a plan to pay the bills and emerge as healthy businesses. The retailers had been struggling to repay enormous debts that accrued from Campeau's takeover of Allied in 1986 and of Federated in 1988. Much of the debt was in risky high-yield ``junk bonds'' that developer Robert Campeau sold to finance his company's expansion in the United States. The stores themselves have remained largely healthy, despite pockets of weakness in the retailing industry. For that reason, some creditors have asked why the stores should remain in bankruptcy court refuge at all, since it is the parent company that was mostly responsible for the crippling debts. The court protection has delayed major decisions on expansion plans and financing arrangements. Lewis S. Rosenbloom, a lawyer for the retailers' major suppliers, said such protection could be costly for the stores. The next major step in the case will be for Federated and Allied to propose a plan to run the businesses in reorganization. Spokeswoman Carol Sanger said the plan is due by late summer or early autumn. ``I think until we see the companies' business plan later this summer, it is difficult even to begin negotiating over reorganization,'' said lawyer Joseph F. Kelly, who represents holders of $1.2 billion in Federated and Allied junk bonds. While creditors await a reorganization plan, the decision to appoint Federated veteran Allen I. Questrom chairman and chief executive officer has reassured some suppliers. Questrom, considered one of the nation's best retailers, was hired away from Dallas-based Neiman-Marcus in February. He had spent 23 years in Federated divisions before resigning in 1988. Questrom is implementing new marketing strategies and cutting out unprofitable segments of private label clothing brands, said Thomas Tashjian, a retail industry analyst for Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. ``As long as the losses remain reasonable within a wide range of expectations, I don't think the figures are really an issue. I really think the reassessment of strategy is more important,'' Tashjian said. ``And I expect them to emerge from Chapter 11 as a very strong, vibrant competitor in the department store business.''

DOC.HEAD: Up $3.10 Billion After Drop Last Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 512 money market mutual funds rose $3.10 billion in the latest week to $385.83 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $2.20 billion drop in fund assets the week earlier. That decline originally was reported as $2.24 billion but the Washington-based mutual fund trade group revised it. Fund assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 250 general purpose funds rose $763.5 million to $133.98 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds increased $2.12 billion to $160.04 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds rose $215.4 million to $91.82 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.65 percent from 7.68 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield remained unchanged at 7.67 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 43 days, down from 45 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.14 percent as of Wednesday from 6.16 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, remained unchanged at 5.04 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.90 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.91 percent the previous week. Yields were 8.09 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.10 percent; 8.10 percent on 2{-year CDs, unchanged; and 8.16 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.17 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Hint on Interest Rate Cut Sends Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar tumbled Thursday in a selloff sparked by Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's suggestion that the central bank might consider easing interest rates. The Fed chief's comments in Congressional testimony caught many foreign exchange dealers holding portfolios weighted heavily toward the dollar. Renewed technical buying in later afternoon New York trading carried the dollar above its session lows against other key currencies but it still ended below Wednesday's closing levels. In overseas and early U.S. trading, the dollar was driven higher amid buying inspired by the lack of any currency-related announcements when the seven major industrialized nations concluded the Houston summit on Wednesday. It had been expected that the leaders would indicate support for a stronger Japanese yen. But the dollar abruptly reversed course around midday in New York after reports of Greenspan's comments to the Senate Banking Committee reached the market. He said that slow growth in the money supply and an increase in average interest rates on commercial loans indicate credit conditions may be tightening independent of central bank action. ``If that is in fact the case, it could have undesirable effects on the economy that the Federal Reserve would have to consider offsetting using monetary policy,'' he said. Lower U.S. interest rates would tend to reduce returns on dollar-denominated investments and curb demand for dollars. Hugh Walsh, a currency dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank's office in New York, said as the session progressed traders began to view Greenspan's comments more skeptically, which may have aided the recovery in the dollar. Walsh said Greenspan only stated the possibility that the Fed might ease monetary policy and didn't declare that it would do so, or when. Late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late quotes, included: 1.6355 German marks, down from 1.6540; 1.3895 Swiss francs, down from 1.4020; 5.4910 French francs, down from 5.5515; 1,198.75 Italian lire, down from 1,211.25; and 1.15675 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15885. Selected late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Wednesday's levels were: 1.6525 German marks, up from 1.6507; 1.4020 Swiss francs, down from 1.4030; 5.5460 French francs, up from 5.5285; 1.8625 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8582; 1,211.00 Italian lire, up from 1,207.04; and 1.1580 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1586. The British pound closed higher despite a day of speculation about criticism of West Germany, France and the European Economic Community by Britain's Trade and Industry Secretary Nicholas Ridley. The pound fell in European trading when Ridley's remarks in a magazine interview were published but it rose afterwards and closed at $1.7995, more expensive for buyers than late Wednesday's $1.7980. A pound was quoted at $1.8130 late in New York, stronger than Wednesday's late level of $1.7995. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 148.90 Japanese yen from 148.10. In London late Thursday the dollar was quoted lower at 148.45 yen. The dollar traded late in New York at 147.40 yen, down from 148.40 yen late Wednesday. Gold prices ended mixed, rising in the United States after moving lower abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery added $4 a troy ounce to settle at $358.10. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $357.70 an ounce, up $4.30 from Wednesday. The late gold bid in London, the major metals market, was $351.75 a troy ounce, down from $354.45. The late Zurich bid was $351.60, down from $354.10. Gold in Hong Kong closed earlier at $353.45, down from $354.15. Silver prices also finished mixed. On the Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce rose of silver for current delivery settled at $4.890, up from $4.836 Wednesday. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid of $4.86 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Hits Record High On Interest Rate Speculation
DOC.TEXT: The stock market charged to record highs Thursday, with the Dow Jones industrial average hitting a new peak in trading sparked by visions of lower interest rates. The Dow average of 30 blue-chip industrial stocks jumped 37.13 to 2,969.80, giving it a gain of 78.96 points in the last two trading sessions. That carried the average past its previous closing peak of 2,935.89, reached June 15. Broader market indicators also showed strong gains, with nearly two stocks rising for every one that declined on the New York Stock Exchange. Much of the rally came after Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan indicated the central bank was ready to relax its monetary policy if necessary to counter a squeeze in the availability of bank credit. That could mean lower interest rates, which would help ease pressure on corporate profits. Greenspan's comments to the Senate Banking Committee were seen as a departure from his recent position that weakness in the economy did not warrant any immediate change in Fed policy. Brokers also said buyers apparently were encouraged by the market's steady recent showing despite a succession of disappointing midyear corporate earnings reports.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market rose sharply Thursday, carrying the Dow Jones industrial average to a record high in buying inspired by visions of easier credit and lower interest rates. Dow Jones's average of 30 blue chips jumped 37.13 to 2,969.80, extending its gain over the past two sessions to 78.96 points. That pushed the average decisively past its previous closing peak of 2,935.89, reached on June 15. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 987 up, 545 down and 479 unchanged. Much of the gain came after Chairman Alan Greenspan of the Federal Reserve Board indicated that the Fed was ready to relax its monetary policy if it proved necessary to counter a squeeze in availability of bank credit. Greenspan's comments to the Senate Banking Committee were seen as a departure from his recent position that weakness in the economy did not warrant any immediate change in Fed policy. Though analysts differed as to how much the Fed's views might have changed, the news was enthusiastically received in the credit markets, sending interest rates lower. Brokers also said buyers appeared to have been encouraged by the market's steady showing of late in the face of a succession of disappointments in midyear corporate earnings reports. Whatever the current profit picture, brokers say, traders seem convinced that the current slow pace of economic growth is helping to improve the outlook for earnings in future quarters. But some individual stocks still came under severe pressure in reaction to earnings news. Computer Associates International, the most active NYSE issue, tumbled 6\ to 10\. The company said it was likely to post lower sales and earnings results for the fiscal quarter ended June 30. Contel jumped 7[ to 35[ and GTE dropped 1\ to 29} after GTE agreed to acquire Contel through an exchange of stock. Energy stocks gained ground for the second straight day, powered in part by new efforts within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to foster higher oil prices. Atlantic Richfield rose 4\ to 121~; Unocal 2 to 29}; Chevron 2~ to 73~; Texaco 2[ to 60[, and Mobil 1~ to 63{. Other gainers among the blue chips included DuPont, up 1{ at 39~; McDonald's, up 1 at 37; International Business Machines, up ~ at 120, and Procter & Gamble, up 1| at 90~. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 211.51 million shares, against 162.22 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 249.23 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $34.89 billion, or 1.01 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 2.21 to 199.32. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 5.83 to 433.37, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 4.21 at 365.44. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 3.27 to 467.17. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 362.23, up 2.82.
