DOC.HEAD: Cray Research President Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Marcelo Gumucio, president and chief operating officer of Cray Research Inc., on Thursday resigned from both positions at the supercomputer maker. Cray Chairman and Chief Executive Officer John A. Rollwagen said for the ``foreseeable future'' he will assume Gumucio's responsibilities, in addition to retaining his titles of chairman and chief executive officer. Rollwagen said in a letter to employees that he and Gumucio ``were unable to agree'' on implementing a long-range strategy for the company. ``We attempted to blend our distinct management styles effectively, but were not successful in that effort,'' Rollwagen said. ``The decision to part is mutual and in the best overall interests of the organization and the individuals involved.'' Gumucio, who also resigned from the Cray board of directors, did not return a phone call Thursday. He joined the company in 1983 as executive vice president of marketing, becoming president in 1988. ``It boils down to a style difference, maybe not even a personality difference,'' Rollwagen said in an interview after the announcement. ``My style is somewhat more intuitive and informal, whereas Marcelo is more structured and more formal. That's one way to try to put a handle on it. Neither style is right nor wrong. Both styles have worked very effectively in a lot of companies, including ours. ``The problem is from trying to marry two styles at top of the company,'' Rollwagen said. Rollwagen emphasized there was no disagreement with Gumucio over long-range strategies the company has been developing. ``Absolutely not. We have full agreement on strategy,'' he said. At the company's annual meeting in May, Gumucio said Cray planned to continue expanding its line of supercomputers in the 1990s. He said the company's introduction of a new, smaller supercomputer was an example of how the company was developing outward from its original focus on the most powerful computers. Cray now is refocused on a variety of products to fit the growing world of computer networking, he said then. Cray suffered a slump in 1989, with sales up just 4 percent to $784.7 million and earnings declining 43 percent to $89 million. In April, however, Cray reported its first-quarter profit totaled $9.5 million, compared with $1.5 million for the same period in 1989. The company also said it expected an increase in profit for the year. Analyst Gary Smaby, president of the Minneapolis-based Smaby Group, said he met with Rollwagen and Gumucio after the announcement Thursday. ``My sense is the differences were stylistic differences,'' he said. ``There was no particular event or issue that caused them to reach this decision. It built up over a period of years.'' The change should be a positive one for Cray, Smaby said. ``Any time conflicts are resolved, it bodes well for the health of the enterprise. It helps people focus on the work at hand,'' he said. Smaby said Gumucio told him he had not yet decided on his future plans and did not have another job lined up.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Rises
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended July 2, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,276.1 billion from $3,271.2 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,058 billion from $4,054.5 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $818.2 billion from $809.4 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 5.7 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 2.2 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,268.3 billion, a 2.3 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,060.5 billion, up 0.4 percent, while M1 rose 3.5 percent to an average of $807.6 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $369 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $430 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $309.0 billion in the two-week period ended July 11, up from $307.2 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Prices Jump On Prospects For Lower Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices spurted higher Thursday, erasing a $3.40-an-ounce decline, after Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said the Fed was considering easing up on interest rates. On other commodity markets, silver futures also rose; energy futures soared; grains and soybeans were mixed; coffee fell; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $3.60 to $4 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in August at $359.50 a troy ounce; silver futures ended 4.9 cents to 5.4 cents higher with July at $4.89 an ounce. August gold traded as low as $352 in the first half of the session, following platinum's lead amid signs of significant platinum sales by the Japanese, analysts said. The mood in the gold market shifted early in the afternoon after Greenspan, testfying before the Senate banking committee, indicated that the Fed was ready to relax its monetary policy if it proved necessary to counter a squeeze in availability of bank credit. Lower interest rates could stimulate the economy and lead to higher inflation, which typically sparks investor demand for precious metals. Anne Orton, a vice president of the currency and precious metal dealer Deak International Inc., said gold's strength would be limited by fears of large-scale sales of bullion from the Middle East and the Soviet Union, which have recently tended to sell into rallies. ``The problem now is, where is the new selling going to come in,'' she said. Petroleum futures surged their permitted daily limits in late trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid reports that Saudi Arabia had expressed willingness to reduce its OPEC crude production quota. Crude oil prices have fallen sharply this year due to a worldwide crude glut that analysts have attributed to overproduction by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Traders have grown edgy over the prospects that OPEC members will take action to reduce their crude output at a meeting to be held later this month. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 78 cents to $1 higher with August at $18.46 a barrel; heating oil was 2 cents to 2.66 cents higher with August at 53.04 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.9 cents to 2.57 cents higher with August at 60.57 cents a gallon. Crude oil futures are limited by the exchange to daily moves of $1. The limit for refined products is 2 cents except for the nearest-term contracts, which are limitless. Corn and soybean futures prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade while wheat futures settled mixed ahead of a report in which the Agriculture Department, as expected, lowered its winter wheat crop estimate. In the report, which was released after the close, the USDA lowered the winter wheat production estimate to 2.04 billion bushels from last month's estimate of 2.09 billion. The total 1990 U.S. wheat harvest is estimated at 2.7 billion bushels, up 33 percent from last year's production, the USDA said. The USDA will not release official corn and soybean production estimates until Aug. 9. But analysts working backwards from the report's soybean and corn yield projections said the USDA projected a soybean crop of 1.86 billion bushels and a corn harvest of 7.85 billion bushels. Those numbers, along with a smaller-than-expected estimate of 1990-91 soybean ending stocks, were expected to give corn and soybean futures a boost Friday. Wheat futures settled \ cent lower to 1 cent higher with July at $3.06 a bushel; corn futures were 2\ cents to 3{ cents lower with July at $2.76{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 3 cents lower with July at $1.24} a bushel; soybeans were 5 cents lower to 3 cents higher with July at $6.07{ a bushel. Coffee futures fell in late trading on the New York Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange following a report that Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, remained opposed to coffee export quotas as a means of raising prices. Coffee settled 1.6 cents to 2.5 cents lower with July at 83.90 cents a pound. Firm cash markets supported cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures ended mixed. Live cattle were .30 cent to .75 cent higher with August at 74.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .35 cent to .85 cent higher with August at 86.27 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent lower to .42 cent higher with July at 60.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.4 cents lower to .07 cent higher with July at 50.25 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: IBM, Diebold To Combine Bank Machine Lines Under Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: IBM and Diebold Inc. said Thursday they will combine their automated teller machine operations and market the products worldwide under a joint venture. Based on last year's shipments, the combined operation would be the largest seller of ATMs in the United States and No. 2 worldwide after NCR Corp., said H. Spencer Nilson, the Los Angeles-based publisher of a newsletter on the banking and credit industry. The arrangement will benefit Diebold by giving it access to IBM's worldwide sales force. It also will allow Diebold to sell its ATMs as part of a package with IBM's banking computer systems, Nilson said. ``Diebold is the only major supplier of ATMs that wasn't tied into complete (banking) computer systems,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``NCR can practically give away the machines as long as they sell the whole system.'' IBM benefits because its ATMs are not as competitive as those of the market leaders, he said. IBM, the world's largest computer maker, ranked eighth in bank machine shipments worldwide last year and ATMs represent a tiny fraction of its overall sales, Nilson said. Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan was second in worldwide ATM shipments after NCR, but most of its sales were in Japan. Diebold was a close third, Nilson said. Diebold's stock rose on the news, gaining $1.37{ to close at $45.87{ in New York Stock Exchange trading. IBM shares closed at $120.12{, down $1. Under the agreement, the joint venture company and Diebold will market the combined ATM product lines of the two companies in the United States, with assistance from IBM. IBM will market the lines abroad, the companies said. No dollar value was placed on the deal. Diebold, based in Canton, Ohio, will own a majority of the joint venture. International Business Machines Corp., based in Armonk, N.Y., will hold the remainder, the companies said. Nilson said he believed Diebold's stake was 70 percent. Robert P. Barone, Diebold's president and chief operating officer, has been named chief executive officer of the venture. Diebold and IBM will continue to manufacture their existing ATM products under agreements with the joint venture, but the venture will own the manufacturing rights to the products, the companies said. The venture, which will be based in Canton, is expected to begin operations later this year. The company will have its own name but it has not yet been decided, Diebold spokeswoman Mary Ann Jackson said. Its products eventually will bear this name, the companies said. The company will have about 500 employees, coming from both Diebold and IBM, Ms. Jackson said. Robert W. Mahoney, Diebold's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview that his company views the venture as a way to increase its international business. Diebold currently conducts most of its international sales through outside distributors. In addition, Mahoney said, ``We wanted a partner that could bring very significant things to the table in terms of research and development.'' For IBM, the venture represents another move in its strategy of combining its resources with those of other companies to reduce development costs. IBM is involved in joint computer chip research with Siemens AG of West Germany and in cooperative software development with other companies. Diebold, which also makes corporate security systems, earned $36.2 million on revenue of $468.9 million last year. About 12 percent of its overall sales were abroad, Ms. Jackson said.

DOC.HEAD: European High Definition Television Consortium Launched
DOC.TEXT: European companies and television networks developing high definition television formed a consortium Wednesday in a bid to make their version of razor-sharp pictures and digital sound acceptable worldwide. The consortium is named Vision 1250 after the 1,250 horizontal lines of resolution planned for European HDTV screens, compared with the 625 on conventional sets. Its launch ``may turn out to be a milestone,'' said Antonio La Pergola, chairman of the European Parliament's energy, research and technology committee. The formation of Vision 1250 follows a 1989 decision by the 12 European Community nations to formulate a strategy to launch HDTV in Europe. The founding members of Vision 1250 are NV Philips of the Netherlands; RAI of Italy; the British Broadcasting Corp., British Satellite Broadcasting, Laser Creation and Thames Television of Britain; BHD TV, BTS, and Unitel of West Germany; Nokia of Finland; and France Telecom, OFRT, SFP and Thomson SA of France. One of Vision 1250's objectives is to promote its 1,250-line technology as a world standard. The system would allow HDTV signals to be received by conventional 625-line European television sets. Japan and the United States have proposed a worldwide HDTV standard based on 1,125 horizontal lines. Conventional TV sets in the United States and Japan use 525 horizontal lines. The EC has rejected the Japanese HDTV technology on grounds that it is incompatible with existing broadcast and reception equipment in Europe and would give Japanese companies a virtual monopoly over the television hardware market in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Surge Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices surged higher Thursday amid reports that Saudi Arabia, the biggest member of OPEC, was willing to accept a lower production quota to help rein in the cartel's output. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, soared 99 cents to $18.46 a 42-gallon barrel after rising $1 over the first three sessions of the week. Gasoline prices also rose sharply. The August contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline jumped 2.57 cents to 60.57 cents a gallon following a 3.03-cent climb over Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Meanwhile, home heating oil for August delivery shot up 2.66 cents to 53.04 cents a gallon after picking up 2.08 cents the first three days this week. Reports that the Saudis were willing to temporarily accept a production ceiling lower than their current 24.46 percent stake of OPEC's output sent prices soaring. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been unable to persuade its members to lower their output, and this has depressed oil prices. But the report about the Saudi agreement meant ``they would be willing to be a swing producer and this was viewed as very bullish for the market,'' said Andrew Lebow, a broker at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. Traders got a further impetus to buy from reports that the United Arab Emirates, another OPEC member, has agreed to a quota of 1.5 million barrels of crude a day. The United Arab Emirates have consistently violated their quota. OPEC officials have been meeting in hopes of reaching some agreements prior to a gathering of the full cartel on July 25. In natural gas trading Thursday, the August contract closed at $1.5002 per 1,000 cubic feet, up from $1.500 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Minister Visits U.S. Machine Tool Country, Wants Dialogue
DOC.TEXT: Japan's trade minister visited one of the major machine-tool manufacturing regions of the United States on Thursday and proposed a dialogue possibly leading up to joint ventures in the industry. Kabun Muto, touring Cincinnati after attending the Houston economic summit, said the proposal was part of his plan to send a mission to the United States in September to ease trade tensions and promote U.S. exports to Japan. Muto, head of the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry, spoke to an audience of about 250 at a luncheon sponsored by the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce. His appearance was considered symbolically important, since the Cincinnati area is a bastion of American manufacturing and its machine-tool industry has been hurt by foreign competition in recent years. The audience included Procter & Gamble Co. Vice President Durk I. Jager, who heads the company's international operations, and executives of Japanese businesses operating in Ohio. Muto said that his emissaries hope to start a dialogue ``consisting of American machine tool and parts makers, and Japanese users and makers to exchange opinions on procurements and establishing such long-term cooperative relationships as joint ventures.'' Muto gave no details. But the plan appeared to be part of a much broader agreement reached last month by Japan and the United States on ways to open Japan's markets, alleviate the huge U.S. trade deficit with the Japanese and make American products more competitive. ``Although it is true that the trade imbalance between the United States and Japan stands at nearly $50 billion, this is not because Japan is trying to hamper imports from the United States,'' Muto said. ``Japan is certainly not forcibly exporting. It is merely selling products that are demanded by the U.S. market.'' Earlier, Muto told a news conference at Procter & Gamble's headquarters that U.S.-Japanese relations should be based on cooperation in international economic development. His comments reflected the sentiment in a statement issued Wednesday at the end of the three-day summit of the world's leading industrialized democracies. They pledged liberalized trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcast Units Boost Westinghouse Income
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp. said Thursday its net income increased 11 percent in the second quarter as broadcasting revenue and operating profit grew. The diversified corporation said its earnings for the quarter ended June 30 totaled $252 million, or 86 cents per share, up from $228 million, or 78 cents per share in the same quarter a year earlier. Revenue for the period were $3.175 billion, compared with $3.178 billion for the same quarter last year. For the first half of 1990, Westinghouse said it earned $462 million, or $1.57 per share, up 11 percent from $417 million, or $1.43 per share, in the first half of 1989. Westinghouse said revenue for the first half of 1990 totaled $6.04 billion, compared with $6.07 billion for the first half of the previous year. Westinghouse's broadcasting unit saw substantial increases in revenue and operating profit in the second quarter, compared with the same quarter a year ago, the company said. Revenue and operating profit for the first six months also were higher than the first half of last year. Other income increased in the quarter mainly because of a gain from the sale of a minority interest in a cable television system, Westinghouse said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Auditors Helped Southmark Conceal Financial Condition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf pvs, `The report... and SUBS 3 grafs for grafs 12-13 pvs bgng, `Grant Thornton... to UPDATE with reactions from accounting firm; PICKS UP last graf pvs
DOC.TEXT: Southmark Corp.'s former top officers caused the collapse of the real estate concern and then concealed its failing financial condition with the help of outside auditors, a court-appointed examiner charged. Examiner Neal Batson said in a report filed last Friday that Dallas-based Southmark, which is operating under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code, should pursue claims against former Chairman Gene Phillips and former Vice Chairman William Friedman to recover a portion of an estimated $1.5 billion in losses the company allegedly suffered during their eight-year tenure. Batson also urged Southmark to investigate a severance agreement reached last year between the company and former officers. At the recommendation of the examiner, Southmark's creditors committee last month filed suit against Phillips and Friedman seeking to recover roughly $68 million in payments and rights surrendered to the officers. The report also advised the company to take legal action against Grant Thornton, Southmark's outside auditor from the early 1980s until 1988. Batson wrote that Grant's ``improper accounting'' was key to maintaining the illusion that Southmark was a growing and profitable company even as it slid toward insolvency. In a statement, Grant Thornton denied any wrongdoing. Concluding that Southmark was insolvent by December 1987, the examiner tried in the report to explain how the $9 billion company saw its net worth wiped out with one quarter's losses and wound up in bankruptcy court struggling to repay $1 billion in junk bonds with stock of doubtful value and $64.4 million in cash. ``The story of Southmark's rise and fall involved its ability to create the illusion of success and prosperity that deceived the investing public with a self-portrait of ever-increasing profits, assets and net worth,'' Batson wrote in the report, the last to arise from his investigation into the pre-bankruptcy affairs of the company. ``The Southmark story is one of unsound acquisitions, overvalued assets, illusory sales, phantom profits, hidden liabilities, insider deals and outsider cronyism resulting in a `sea of red ink,' '' he said. Attorneys for Phillips and Friedman, who said they hadn't yet seen the independent examiner's latest report, criticized its general findings. Henry Simon, one of the men's bankruptcy lawyers, said all highly leveraged real estate companies in Texas suffered the same fate as Southmark and that the state's real estate crash _ not mismanagement _ was responsible for Southmark's woes. ``So far, there's no one who has received a business achievement award for doing highly leveraged deals,'' Simon said. Grant Thornton said in a statement it ``emphatically disagrees'' with the report, charging the findings ``are supported neither by generally accepted accounting principles nor generally accepted auditing standards.'' The accounting firm defended its work, calling its audits ``extremely vigorous.'' It said its audit resulted in a $200 million loss for fiscal 1988, in place of the $6 million profit. ``Southmark's story is that of a failed business, not an audit failure,'' it said. ``Southmark did not fail because of its auditor. Grant will not allow itself to be made a scapegoat and will defend itself vigorously.'' Under the bankruptcy reorganization plan outlined Wednesday at the first day of the hearing, Southmark would contribute $100 million in new assets to its San Jacinto Savings unit, the centerpiece of the proposed reorganization, and repay creditors holding more than $1 billion in claims with cash, new debt and stock in the reorganized company.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Investor Fraud Going Global
DOC.TEXT: Con artists as well as capitalists see a potential jackpot in the globalization of investment opportunities, a House panel investigating telemarketing fraud was told Thursday. Kansas Securities Commissioner M. Douglas Mays said that the international investment fraud problem in this country ``parallels the growth in legitimate international investment activity.'' Mays, who is also president-elect of a state-level securities regulators organization, testified about a report that found small U.S. investors have lost more than $1 billion in the last two years to con men. Schemes described ranged from high interest bank accounts on Pacific Ocean islands to gold mines in South America. The 100-page report by the North American Securities Administrators Association found that crooks who have been selling phony oil well stocks and other get-rich-quick schemes over the phone have now turned to bogus overseas investment programs. Other witnesses included William McDonald, director of the enforcement division of the California Department of Corporations and Lawrence H. Fuchs, deputy comptroller of Florida's Department of Banking and Finance. Mays said the NASAA report identified two major centers of alleged fraud outside the United States: phony offshore banks on tiny islands in the Pacific and Caribbean, and high-pressure telephone marketing operations known as ``boiler rooms'' working out of Panama and Costa Rica. In one case cited, three boiler rooms based in San Jose, Costa Rica, took Hawaiian investors for more than $200,000 in phony investments in precious metals stocks. Officials in Iowa, Missouri and Alaska have issued cease and desist orders against a Georgia man who has been promising investors bank accounts that bear 9 percent to 21 percent interest at a financial institution on Saipan in the Northern Mariana Islands, the study said. Another case cited was a St. Louis man serving eight years in prison for bilking investors out of millions of dollars nationwide in phony contracts for five ounce bars of South African platinum. Missouri investigators found that the mine in question does not produce five ounce platinum bars and the self-styled business expert's previous experience was installing mirror tiles and table tops. ``International investment scams are now the fastest-growing fraud problem with which securities agencies are dealing,'' said Mays. The study is based on an analysis of 87 major enforcement actions and investigations by 40 state securities agencies in 1988 and 1989. It was prepared at the request of the consumer and monetary affairs subcommittee of the House Government Operations Committee. The study recommended that Congress: _Create a federal-state interagency working group on international financial fraud. _Direct the federal Securities and Exchange Commission to work with state regulators to create a database for tracking international investment swindlers. _Pass pending lesgislation that would give the SEC greater authority to crack down on various forms of securities fraud and exchange information with foreign regulatory agencies.

DOC.HEAD: French Lodging Company Agrees To Pay $1.3 Billion for Motel 6
DOC.TEXT: The French lodging company Accor SA said Thursday it has agreed to pay about $1.3 billion for Motel 6 LP in a deal it said will create the world's largest group of budget motels. Motel 6 is one of the best-known brand names in economy lodging in the United States, advertising its chain of 554 motels with a folksy charm that emphasizes its low cost and no-frills ambience. Its radio ads end with the signature, ``We'll leave the light on for you.'' Paris-based Accor already owns more than 850 hotels and 3,000 restaurants in 60 countries, including the growing Formula 1 budget hotel chain in Europe. The deal marks another hefty return for the buyout specialists Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., which led a group that bought the Motel 6 chain for about $880 million in 1985 and kept a controlling interest after the company went public a year later. Under the terms of the proposal, Accor said it had agreed to make a tender offer of $22.50 per share in cash for the more than 55 million outstanding Motel 6 partnership units. Payments for preferred stock make up the balance. An affiliate of Kohlberg Kravis owns more than 50 percent of Motel 6 and the companies said it has agreed to tender its holdings under the offer. The deal was announced after the stock market closed. Motel 6 units rose $2.62{ a share to $19.25 on volume of 1.5 million shares in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Accor said the transaction already has been fully financed and its offer is not conditioned on obtaining financing. Motel 6's outstanding debt of about $1 billion is expected to remain outstanding. The tender offer is expected to begin no later than July 18 and close in August. Paul Dubrule and Gerard Pelisson, co-chairmen of Accor, said the deal will help their company become the world's pre-eminent budget hotel company. They said it would give Accor more than 775 economy motels, well along toward its target of owning and operating 2,000 budget hotels. Motel 6 Chief Executive Joseph W. McCarthy and his management team were expected to stay on, the French company said, and its headquarters will remain in Dallas. The founding partners of Kohlberg Kravis, Henry R. Kravis and George R. Roberts, said the deal made sense for both sides. ``It is appropriate at this time, five years after we began the process of transforming Motel 6 into a dynamic, modernized and aggressive economy lodging company, that it become part of a global lodging company with even greater resources and potential,'' they said in a statement. Kohlberg Kravis and its partners acquired Motel 6 from City Investing Co. in 1985. The company was converted into a publicly traded limited master partnership in 1986 with units offered at $13.50 a share. A source close to the firm said investors who bought shares at that time will have received over $27 per unit for their investment by the time the Accor deal closes, a 21.5 percernt compounded annual rate of return counting both the amount of the tender and the $4.63 a share in cash dividends already paid. The source said those who invested in the original buyout did even better _ a 38 percent compounded annual rate of return on a $125 million equity investment. When Kohlberg bought it in 1985, Motel 6 had 378 motels with 42,279 rooms and 7,000 employees. The chain has since grown to 554 motels, 63,765 rooms and more than 11,500 employees. Motel 6's sales rose over the same period to an estimated $475 million this year from $226 million in 1985. Operating profit also has risen, reaching anm estimated $220 million this year from $122 million in 1985. Accor said the deal will give it more than 160,000 hotel rooms worldwide. Its properties include Sofitel, a luxury chain; Novotel and Mercure, aimed at business travelers; and Ibis-Urbis, moderately priced chains. Accor presently is expanding its Formula 1 budget chain at the rate of about one hotel a week in Europe. Accor estimated it will earn nearly $150 million this year on sales of more than $4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Union Sues U.S. Company for Unpaid Wages
DOC.TEXT: A South Korean union sued a U.S. company in federal court Thursday, alleging breach of contract for shutting down its South Korean factory and withholding $1 million in wages from workers. An attorney for the union, said the lawsuit was the first in federal court by foreign workers seeking to settle a labor disagreement. The lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court accuses Pico Products Inc. of suddenly closing its Pico Korea Ltd. factory in Buchun City in February 1989 to avoid compliance with a collective bargaining agreement. The union is seeking more than $1 million in back wages and severance it claims is owed to 294 workers employed by Pico Korea, a wholly owned subsidiary of Pico, a Liverpool, N.Y.-based maker of cable television components. ``In the United States, must a worker sue her boss to receive her paycheck?'' union president Jum Soon Yoo said through an interpreter. Yoo and a dozen other supporters ended a week-long hunger strike with the filing of the lawsuit. Yoo and two other union leaders came to the United States in April to get Pico Chairman Bernard Hitchcock to negotiate a settlement after failing to resolve the dispute in their homeland. Hitchcock has refused to negotiate with the union. At a news conference Thursday, Hitchcock repeated claims that union representatives are ``terrorists'' who kidnapped a company management team, ransacked the factory and seized its contents, and extorted unreasonable contract concessions. ``They ripped us off for $2 million and stole the company. I'm through with these people. We're now in court and I'm happy with that,'' Hitchcock said. During their three-month stay in the United States, the union leaders and a growing number of supporters have picketed Pico's headquarters regularly. Last weekend, they protested outside Hitchcock's home in Syracuse. Hitchcock responded by standing on his roof and dousing the demonstrators with water from a garden hose. Frank E. Deale, legal director of the Center for Constitutional Rights in New York City, which is representing the South Korean union, said the lawsuit was filed on the basis of two federal laws. They are the Labor Management Relations Act, which gives federal courts jurisdiction to enforce collective bargaining agreements and the 1988 Worker Adjustment, Retraining and Notification Act, which entitles all workers employed by American corporations to 60-day notice of plant closings. Deale said the lawsuit would test whether that law can apply to employees of a U.S. corporation who work abroad. The union charged that Pico Korea took full advantage of its status as a foreign firm and enjoyed tax breaks and other benefits offered by the South Korean government. The company grew rapidly after it opened in March 1983. The workers mobilized in June 1988 to form a union in response to what they called unsafe working conditions and subminimum wages. The union and company reached a labor accord in November 1988 that excluded the issue of wages, which was to be settled through future talks, according to the lawsuit. But before those talks could begin, Hitchcock fired Pico Korea's top officers and ordered the plant shut down, the lawsuit alleged. Union members admitted seizing the plant on Feb. 28, 1989, and refusing to allow shipment of finished products, but said they did so to force negotiations. Yoo said the union brought the lawsuit because the South Korean and American governments were ``ignoring the crimes of multinational firms against Third World workers.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pathe Communications Corp. filed a countersuit in the bitter dispute over its collapsed attempts to negotiate a loan from Time Warner Inc. for Pathe's buyout of MGM-UA Communications Co. A Pathe spokesman said it is now unlikely that Time Warner will participate in the planned purchase of MGM-UA. A story, AM-Pathe-Time Warner, is being expedited. The AP

DOC.HEAD: Toymaker Slashes Work Force Again
DOC.TEXT: Fisher-Price Toys announced Thursday it was cutting 720 jobs as it struggles amid weak sales, mounting losses and an expected spinoff from its parent company. The maker of brightly colored preschool toys said it was laying off 245 employees at its upstate New York headquarters and closing a nearby plant later this year. Fisher-Price in February closed its plant in East Aurora, where the company was founded 60 years ago. Fisher-Price, which employs 6,500 employees in plants in New York, Kentucky, England and on the U.S.-Mexico border, has lost $44.5 million in the last 15 months. Company president Ronald J. Jackson said Fisher-Price sales dipped to $700 million in fiscal 1990 from $849 million the previous year. He said the latest layoffs weren't necessarily related to the scheduled spinoff in early 1991 of Fisher-Price from its current owner, Quaker Oats Co. of Chicago. ``Whether you're a part of Quaker Oats or a public company, you just can't go forward losing money,'' he said. ``I think these cuts would be made whether it was part of Quaker or whether it was independent.'' Fisher-Price said it was closing its plant in Holland, which was built in 1962 and employs about 475 workers, between September and November because it is the company's oldest facility. The cutbacks at its headquarters, where the company will retain a work force of about 950 employees, involve all phases of the operation, including marketing, research and development, operations and engineering. David Leibowitz, a toy industry analyst with American Securities Corp., said the layoffs are designed to get Fisher-Price ``into fighting trim'' before the spinoff from Quaker Oats. ``These are very hard things to do, but the reality is if this company goes independent early next year and does not have a strong parent to fall back on during hard times, they have to be able to stand on their own two feet,'' he said. Jackson, who just joined the company seven weeks ago, said company executives had been enthusiastic about the reception Fisher-Price's products received at the annual Toy Fair. The company had promised no further layoffs in upstate New York. ``By the time they got to April, and saw the business trends ... our products just weren't doing as well as we'd hoped,'' he said. He said most of Fisher-Price's losses can be attributed to the company's decision within the past 10 years to branch out from its traditionally strong infant and preschool product lines. The promotion line of toys was aimed at and marketed to children between the ages of 5 and 12 had only initial success and the company has withdrawn from that line, Jackson said. He said Fisher-Price would refocus on infant and preschool products.

DOC.HEAD: SEC: Blinder Robinson Cheated Investors Out of $20 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 10th graf pvs, `A receptionist... to UPDATE with comment from Blinder lawyer; PICKS UP 11th graf pvs, `The Philadelphia...
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday charged the troubled Colorado penny stock brokerage Blinder, Robinson & Co. of overcharging investors by more than $20 million in 21 months. According to a lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court, Blinder Robinson marked up prices as high as 140 percent on penny stocks when selling them to investors. SEC attorney Stephen J. Crimmins said companies are permitted to mark up prices as much as 10 percent as commission for conducting transactions, but they must notify buyers if they charge more than that. He said Blinder did not. The SEC complaint said the alleged illegal activity took place from June 1985 through February 1987, with some occurring in Pennsylvania. In April the SEC suspended Blinder Robinson from trading in penny stocks for 45 days and from underwriting such offerings for two years. The SEC also barred the firm's founder and chairman, Meyer Blinder, from associating with and registered broker-dealer for at least two years. Blinder, 69, of Denver, Colo., and four associates were indicted in February on racketeering and securities fraud charges by a federal grand jury in Las Vegas. The indictment followed a 1988 Internal Revenue Service raid on Blinder Robinson's Denver office. Blinder Robinson once was the nation's largest penny stock brokerage. Penny stocks are low cost, high risk securities, usually trading for less than $3 per share. They are not listed on stock exchanges and typically are used to raise capital for new or small companies. The lack or reliable information about penny stocks has made them prone to fraud. The complaint charged that of more than 1 billion shares of penny stocks in 12 companies Blinder Robinson sold to customers, 99.7 percent were marked up by over 10 percent of the prevailing market price. Blinder Robinson general counsel Kalmon Glovin said the lawsuit appeared to be a ``rehashing of old allegations by the SEC, which Blinder Robinson ... and Meyer Blinder have been and are being vigorously defended against in other litigation.'' Glovin said the SEC was ``relentless'' in trying to justify ``systematic destruction of Blinder Robinson ... and the professional career of its founder, Meyer Blinder, under the guise of protecting the public interest.'' The Philadelphia lawsuit also charges that Blinder Robinson bid for and purchased stocks at the same time it was distributing them to customers. Crimmins said the practice is considered legal if a firm informs buyers but Blinder Robinson did not. The SEC also charges that the firm dominated the market in the 12 stocks _ accounting for over 86 percent of all inter-dealer and retail trading activity _ a practice which resulted in essentially giving the company complete control of the price of the stocks. The SEC seeks permanent injunctions against the alleged illegal practices. Crimmins declined to say whether other federal agencies would pursue criminal charges against the company or its officers. Intercontinental Enterprises, Inc., the Englewood, Colo., corporation that owns Blinder Robinson, also is named in the suit along with Blinder Robinson and Meyer Blinder.

DOC.HEAD: Up 5.3 Percent in Fourth Quarter, Down For Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `Federal Express... to CORRECT attribution to spokesman sted chairman; SUBS grafs 5, 7 to conform; PICKS UP last graf, `Federal Express...
DOC.TEXT: Federal Express Corp. said Thursday that profits rose 5.3 percent in its fourth quarter but slumped for the full year in large part because of the acquisition of Tiger International. Earnings for the quarter were $43.1 million, or 81 cents a share, up from $40.97 million, or 78 cents a share, in the same 1989 period. Revenue rose 14.7 percent to $1.9 billion from $1.7 billion. For the fiscal year ending May 31, profits fell 30.5 percent to $116 million, or $2.18 a share, from $185 million, or $3.18 a share in fiscal 1989. Revenue rose to $7 billion from $5.2 billion. Federal Express spokesman Dan Copp said the annual decline in earnings was due largely to increased debt resulting from the acquisition in February of Tiger International, a Los Angeles-based air cargo carrier. Copp said the company's net interest expense more than doubled in fiscal 1989 to $188 million due to the purchase of Tiger International and was the primary reason for the earnings decline. Federal Express' long-term debt increased to more than $2 billion from about $75 million a year because of the acquisition of Tiger International. Federal Express chief executive Frederick W. Smith also cited international expansion, disappointing air freight volumes and expansions at major hub facilities in Anchorage and Indianapolis also contributed to the earnings result. Federal Express is the world's largest air delivery service.
